V(x)=m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2, & |x|>b \\
V(x)=V_{0}, & |x|<b
\end{array}
$$

where $V_{0} \gg \hbar^{2} / m b^{2} \gg \hbar \omega$, i.e. a harmonic oscillator potential with a high, thin, nearly impenetrable barrier at $x=0$ (see Fig 1.16).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-058.jpg?height=304&width=339&top_left_y=947&top_left_x=489)

Fig. $1.16$

(a) What is the low-lying energy spectrum under the approximation that the barrier is completely impenetrable?

(b) Describe qualitatively the effect on the spectrum of the finite penetrability of the barrier.

$(M I T)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) For the low-lying energy spectrum, as the barrier is completely impenetrable, the potential is equivalent to two separate halves of a harmonic oscillator potential and the low-lying eigenfunctions must satisfy the condition $\psi(x)=0$ at $x=0$. The low-lying energy spectrum thus corresponds to that of a normal harmonic oscillator with odd quantum numbers $2 n+1$, for which $\psi_{n}(x)=0$, at $x=0$ and $E_{n}=(2 n+3 / 2) \hbar \omega, n=0,1,2, \ldots$ with a degeneracy of 2 . Thus only the odd-parity wave functions are allowed for the low-lying levels.

(b) There will be a weak penetration of the barrier. Obviously the probability for the particle to be in $|x|<b$, where the barrier exists, becomes less than that for the case of no potential barrier, while the probability outside the barrier becomes relatively larger. A small portion of the even-parity solutions is mixed into the particle states, while near the origin the probability distribution of even-parity states is greater than that of odd-parity states. Correspondingly, a small portion of the energy $E_{n}^{\prime}=(2 n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega$ is mixed into the energy for the case (a). Since $\langle\psi|$ barrier potential $|\psi\rangle>0$, the energy levels will shift upwards. The level shifts for the even-parity states are greater than for odd-parity states. Furthermore, the energy shift is smaller for greater energies for states of the same parity.

\section{4}

The Hamiltonian for a harmonic oscillator can be written in dimensionless units $(m=\hbar=\omega=1)$ as

$$
\hat{H}=\hat{a}^{+} \hat{a}+1 / 2,
$$

where

$$
\hat{a}=(\hat{x}+i \hat{p}) / \sqrt{2}, \quad \hat{a}^{+}=(\hat{x}-i \hat{p}) / \sqrt{2} .
$$

One unnormalized energy eigenfunction is

$$
\psi_{a}=\left(2 x^{3}-3 x\right) \exp \left(-x^{2} / 2\right) .
$$

Find two other (unnormalized) eigenfunctions which are closest in energy to $\psi_{a}$.

\section{Solution:}

In the Fock representation of harmonic oscillation, $\hat{a}$ and $\hat{a}^{+}$are the annihilation and creation operators such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{a} \psi_{n} &=\sqrt{n} \psi_{n-1}, \quad \hat{a}^{+} \psi_{n}=\sqrt{n+1} \psi_{n+1}, \quad \hat{a} \hat{a}^{+} \psi_{n}=(n+1) \psi_{n}, \\
E_{n} &=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{a} \hat{a}^{+} \psi_{a} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(x+\frac{d}{d x}\right)\left(x-\frac{d}{d x}\right)\left(2 x^{3}-3 x\right) e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2}} \\
&=\frac{1}{2}\left(x+\frac{d}{d x}\right)\left(4 x^{4}-12 x^{2}+3\right) e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2}} \\
&=4\left(2 x^{3}-3 x\right) e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}=(3+1) \psi_{a}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $n=3$. Hence the eigenfunctions closest in energy to $\psi_{a}$ have $n=2,4$, the unnormalized wave functions being

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{2}=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \hat{a} \psi_{a}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}\left(x+\frac{d}{d x}\right)\left(2 x^{3}-3 x\right) e^{-x^{2} / 2} \\
& \sim\left(2 x^{2}-1\right) e^{-x^{2} / 2} \\
\psi_{4}=& \frac{1}{2} \hat{a}^{+} \psi_{a}=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}\left(x-\frac{d}{d x}\right)\left(2 x^{3}-3 x\right) e^{-x^{2} / 2} \\
& \sim\left(4 x^{4}-12 x^{2}+3\right) e^{-x^{2} / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the unimportant constants have been omitted.

\section{5}

At time $t=0$ a particle in the potential $V(x)=m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2$ is described by the wave function

$$
\psi(x, 0)=A \sum_{n}(1 / \sqrt{2})^{n} \psi_{n}(x)
$$

where $\psi_{n}(x)$ are eigenstates of the energy with eigenvalues $E_{n}=(n+$ 1/2) $\hbar \omega$. You are given that $\left(\psi_{n}, \psi_{n^{\prime}}\right)=\delta_{n n^{\prime}}$.

(a) Find the normalization constant $A$.

(b) Write an expression for $\psi(x, t)$ for $t>0$.

(c) Show that $|\psi(x, t)|^{2}$ is a periodic function of time and indicate the longest period $\tau$.

(d) Find the expectation value of the energy at $t=0$. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The normalization condition

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\psi(x, 0), \psi(x, 0)) &=|A|^{2} \sum_{m, n}(1 / 2)^{(m+n) / 2}\left(\psi_{n}, \psi_{m}\right) \\
&=|A|^{2} \sum_{m}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{m}=2|A|^{2}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

gives $A=1 / \sqrt{2}$, taking $A$ as positive real.

(b) The time-dependent wave function is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t) &=e^{-i \hat{H} t / \hbar} \psi(x, 0) \\
&=\sum_{n}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{n+1} e^{-i \omega t\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right)} \psi_{n}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) The probability density is

$$
|\psi(x, t)|^{2}=\sum_{m n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1} e^{-i \omega t(n-m)} \psi_{n}(x) \psi_{m}^{*}(x)
$$

Note that the time factor $\exp [-i \omega(n-m) t]$ is a function with period $\frac{2 \pi}{(n-m) \omega}$, the maximum period being $2 \pi / \omega$.

(d) The expectation value of energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H} &=(\psi(x, 0), \hat{H} \psi(x, 0))=\sum_{m, n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1}\left(\psi_{n}, \hat{H} \psi_{m}\right) \\
&=\sum_{m, n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1}\left(m+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega \delta_{n m} \\
&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{n+1}}\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega
\end{aligned}
$$

Noting

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^{n}}=\frac{x}{x-1}
$$

or, by differentiation,

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{-n}{x^{n+1}}=\frac{-1}{(x-1)^{2}}
$$

we have

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{n}{2^{n+1}}=1
$$

and hence $\bar{H}=3 \hbar \omega / 2$.

\section{6}

Consider the one-dimensional motion of a particle of mass $\mu$ in the potential

$$
V(x)=V_{0}(x / a)^{2 n},
$$

where $n$ is a positive integer and $V_{0}>0$. Discuss qualitatively the distribution of energy eigenvalues and the parities, if any, of the corresponding eigenfunctions. Use the uncertainty principle to get an order-of-magnitude estimate for the lowest energy eigenvalue. Specialize this estimate to the cases $n=1$ and $n \rightarrow \infty$. State what $V(x)$ becomes in these cases and compare the estimates with your previous experience.

(Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

Since the potential $V(x) \rightarrow \infty$ as $x \rightarrow \infty$, there is an infinite number of bound states in the potential and the energy eigenvalues are discrete. Also, the $m$ th excited state should have $m$ nodes in the region of $E>V(x)$ given by $k \Delta x \simeq(m+1) \pi . \Delta x$ increases slowly as $m$ increases. From the virial theorem $2 \bar{T} \propto 2 n \bar{V}$, we have

$$
k^{2} \propto(\Delta x)^{2 n} \propto[(m+1) \pi / k]^{2 n},
$$

and so

$$
E \propto k^{2} \propto(m+1)^{2 n /(n+1)} .
$$

Generally, as $n$ increases, the difference between adjacent energy levels increases too. Since $V(-x)=V(x)$, the eigenstates have definite parities. The ground state and the second, fourth,... excited states have even parity while the other states have odd parity. The energy of the particle can be estimated using the uncertainity principle

$$
p_{x} \sim \hbar / 2 b
$$

where

$$
b=\sqrt{\overline{(\Delta x)^{2}}} .
$$

Thus

$$
E \sim \frac{1}{2 \mu}(\hbar / 2 b)^{2}+V_{0}(b / a)^{2 n} .
$$

For the lowest energy let $d E / d b=0$ and obtain

$$
b=\left(\hbar^{2} a^{2 n} / 8 \mu n V_{0}\right)^{1 / 2(n+1)} .
$$

Hence the lowest energy is

$$
E \sim\left[(n+1) V_{0} / a^{2 n}\right]\left(\hbar^{2} a^{2 n} / 8 \mu n V_{0}\right)^{n /(n+1)} .
$$

For $n=1, V(x)$ is the potential of a harmonic oscillator,

$$
V(x)=V_{0} x^{2} / a^{2}=\mu \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2 .
$$

In this case $E$ equals $\hbar \omega / 2$, consistent with the result of a precise calculation. For $n=\infty, V(x)$ is an infinite square-well potential, and

$$
E=\hbar^{2} / 8 \mu a^{2},
$$

to be compared with the accurate result $\hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 \mu a^{2}$.

\section{7}

Consider a particle in one dimension with Hamiltonian

$$
H=p^{2} / 2 m+V(x),
$$

where $V(x) \leq 0$ for all $x, V(\pm \infty)=0$, and $V$ is not everywhere zero. Show that there is at least one bound state. (One method is to use the Rayleigh-Ritz variational principle with a trial wave function

$$
\psi(x)=(b / \pi)^{1 / 4} \exp \left(-b x^{2} / 2\right)
$$

However, you may use any method you wish.)

(Columbia) 

\section{Solution:}

\section{Method 1:}

Assume a potential $V(x)=f(x)$ as shown in Fig 1.17. We take a square-well potential $V^{\prime}(x)$ in the potential $V(x)$ such that

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V^{\prime}(x)=-V_{0}, & |x|<a \\
V^{\prime}(x)=0, & |x|>a \\
V^{\prime}(x) \geq f(x) & \text { for all } x
\end{array}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-064.jpg?height=421&width=637&top_left_y=611&top_left_x=346)

Fig. $1.17$

We know there is at least a bound state $\varphi(x)$ in the well potential $V^{\prime}(x)$ for which

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\varphi(x)\left|H^{\prime}\right| \varphi(x)\right\rangle &=\left\langle\varphi\left|p^{2} / 2 m+V^{\prime}(x)\right| \varphi\right\rangle \\
&=E_{0}<0
\end{aligned}
$$

We then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\varphi|H| \varphi\rangle=&\left\langle\varphi\left|p^{2} / 2 m+f(x)\right| \varphi\right\rangle \\
& \leq\left\langle\varphi\left|p^{2} / 2 m+V^{\prime}(x)\right| \varphi\right\rangle \\
=& E_{0}<0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\cdots \psi_{n-1}(x), \psi_{n}(x), \cdots$ denote the eigenfunctions of $H$, and expand

$$
\varphi(x)=\sum_{n} C_{n} \psi_{n}(x) .
$$

As

$$
\langle\varphi|H| \varphi\rangle=\sum_{n}^{\infty}\left|C_{n}\right|^{2}\left\langle\psi_{n}|H| \psi_{n}\right\rangle<0
$$

there is at least an eigenfunction $\psi_{i}(x)$ satisfying the inequality

$$
\left\langle\psi_{i}|H| \psi_{i}\right\rangle<0 .
$$

Hence there exists at least one bound state in $V(x)$.

Method 2: Let the wave function be

$$
\psi(x)=(b / \pi)^{1 / 4} \exp \left(-b x^{2} / 2\right)
$$

where $b$ is an undetermined parameter. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle H\rangle &=\sqrt{b / \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-b x^{2} / 2}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}\right) e^{-b x^{2} / 2} d x+\langle V\rangle \\
&=\hbar^{2} b / 4 m+\langle V\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\langle V\rangle=(b / \pi)^{1 / 2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} V(x) \exp \left(-b x^{2}\right) d x
$$

and thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial\langle H\rangle}{\partial b} &=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}+\frac{1}{2 b}\langle V\rangle-\left(\frac{b}{\pi}\right)^{1 / 2} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} x^{2} V(x) e^{-b x^{2}} d x \\
&=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}+\frac{1}{2 b}\langle V\rangle-\left\langle x^{2} V\right\rangle=0
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
b=\frac{\langle V\rangle}{2\left[\left\langle x^{2} V\right\rangle-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}\right]} .
$$

Substitution in the expression for $\langle H\rangle$ yields

$$
\bar{E}=\langle H\rangle=\frac{\left[2\left\langle x^{2} V\right\rangle-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}\right]\langle V\rangle}{2\left[\left\langle x^{2} V\right\rangle-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}\right]} .
$$

As $V(x) \leq 0$ for all $x, V(\pm \infty)=0$, and $V$ is not everywhere zero, we have $\langle V\rangle<0,\left\langle x^{2} V\right\rangle<0$ and hence $\bar{E}<0, b>0$.

In fact, under the condition that the total energy has a certain negative value (which must be greater than $\langle V\rangle$ to make $\langle T\rangle$ positive), whatever the form of $V$ a particle in it cannot move to infinity and must stay in a bound state.

\section{8}

The wave function for a particle of mass $M$ in a one-dimensional potential $V(x)$ is given by the expression

$$
\begin{array}{rll}
\psi(x, t) & =\alpha x \exp (-\beta x) \exp (i \gamma t / \hbar), & x>0 \\
& =0, & x<0
\end{array}
$$

where $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are all positive constants.

(a) Is the particle bound? Explain.

(b) What is the probability density $\rho(E)$ for a measurement of the total energy $E$ of the particle?

(c) Find the lowest energy eigenvalue of $V(x)$ in terms of the given quantities.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The particle is in a bound state because the wave function $\psi(x, t)$ satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\lim _{x \rightarrow-\infty} \psi(x, t)=0, \\
&\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} \psi(x, t)=\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} \alpha x e^{-\beta x} e^{i \gamma t / \hbar}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b), (c) Substituting the wave function for $x>0$ in the Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(x, t)=\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+V(x)\right] \psi(x, t)
$$

gives

$$
-\gamma x=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\beta^{2} x-2 \beta\right)+V(x) x,
$$

whence the potential for $x>0$ :

$$
V(x)=-\gamma+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\beta^{2}-2 \beta / x\right) .
$$

As the stationary wave function of the particle in $V(x)$ satisfies

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-\beta^{2}+2 \beta / x\right) \psi_{E}(x)=(E+\gamma) \psi_{E}(x), \quad(x>0)
$$

or

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi_{E}(x)+\frac{2 M}{\hbar^{2}}\left(E^{\prime}+e^{2} / x\right) \psi_{E}(x)=0
$$

by setting

$$
E^{\prime}=E+\gamma-\beta^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 M, \quad e^{2}=\beta \hbar^{2} / M,
$$

and $\psi_{E}(x) \stackrel{x \rightarrow 0}{\longrightarrow 0}$, we see that the above equation is the same as that satisfied by the radial wave function of a hydrogen atom with $l=0$. The corresponding Bohr radius is $a=\hbar^{2} / M e^{2}=1 / \beta$, while the energy levels are

$$
E_{n}^{\prime}=-M e^{4} / 2 \hbar^{2} n^{2}=-\beta^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 M n^{2}, \quad n=1,2, \ldots
$$

Hence

$$
E_{n}=-\gamma+\left(\beta^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 M\right)\left(1-1 / n^{2}\right), \quad n=1,2, \ldots,
$$

and consequently the lowest energy eigenvalue is $E_{1}=-\gamma$ with the wave function

$$
\psi(x, t)=\alpha x \exp (-\beta x) \exp (i \gamma t / \hbar) \propto \psi_{E 1}(x) \exp \left(-i E_{1} t / \hbar\right)
$$

The probability density $\rho(E)=\psi^{*} \psi=\psi_{E 1}^{*} \psi_{E 1}$ is therefore

$$
\rho(E)= \begin{cases}1 & \text { for } E=-\gamma \\ 0 & \text { for } E \neq-\gamma\end{cases}
$$

\section{9}

A particle of mass $m$ is released at $t=0$ in the one-dimensional double square well shown in Fig. $1.14$ in such a way that its wave function at $t=0$ is just one sinusoidal loop ("half a sine wave") with nodes just at the edges of the left half of the potential as shown.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-068.jpg?height=369&width=662&top_left_y=302&top_left_x=347)

Fig. $1.18$

(a) Find the average value of the energy at $t=0$ (in terms of symbols defined above).

(b) Will the average value of the energy be constant for times subsequent to the release of the particle? Why?

(c) Is this a state of definite energy? (That is, will a measurement of the energy in this state always give the same value?) Why?

(d) Will the wave function change with time from its value at $t=0$ ? If "yes", explain how you would attempt to calculate the change in the wave function. If "no", explain why not.

(e) Is it possible that the particle could escape from the potential well (from the whole potential well, from both halves)? Explain.

$(W i s c o n s i n)$

\section{Solution:}

Thus

(a) The normalized wave function at $t=0$ is $\psi(x, 0)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \frac{\pi x}{a}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\hat{H}\rangle_{t=0} &=-V_{0}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{2}{a} \int_{0}^{a} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right) \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right) d x \\
&=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{2 m a}-V_{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) $\langle\hat{H}\rangle$ is a constant for $t>0$ since $\partial\langle\hat{H}\rangle / \partial t=0$.

(c) It is not a state of definite energy, because the wave function of the initial state is the eigenfunction of an infinitely deep square well potential with width $a$, and not of the given potential. It is a superposition state of the different energy eigenstates of the given potential. Therefore different measurements of the energy in this state will not give the same value, but a group of energies according to their probabilities.

(d) The shape of the wave function is time dependent since the solution satisfying the given conditions is a superposition state:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi(x, 0)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right)=\sum_{n} c_{n} \psi_{n}(x) \\
&\psi(x, t)=\sum_{n} c_{n} \psi_{n}(x) e^{-i E_{n} t / \hbar}
\end{aligned}
$$

The shape of $\psi(x, t)$ will change with time because $E_{n}$ changes with $n$.

(e) The particle can escape from the whole potential well if the following condition is satisfied: $\hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m a>V_{0}$. That is to say, if the width of the potential well is small enough (i.e., the kinetic energy of the particle is large enough), the depth is not very large (i.e., the value of $V_{0}$ is not very large), and the energy of the particle is positive, the particle can escape from the whole potential well.

\section{0}

A free particle of mass $m$ moves in one dimension. At time $t=0$ the normalized wave function of the particle is

$$
\psi\left(x, 0, \sigma_{x}^{2}\right)=\left(2 \pi \sigma_{x}^{2}\right)^{-1 / 4} \exp \left(-x^{2} / 4 \sigma_{x}^{2}\right)
$$

where $\sigma_{x}^{2}=\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle$

(a) Compute the momentum spread $\sigma_{p}=\sqrt{\left\langle p^{2}\right\rangle-\langle p\rangle^{2}}$ associated with this wave function.

(b) Show that at time $t>0$ the probability density of the particle has the form

$$
|\psi(x, t)|^{2}=\left|\psi\left(x, 0, \sigma_{x}^{2}+\sigma_{p}^{2} t^{2} / m^{2}\right)\right|^{2} .
$$

(c) Interpret the results of parts (a) and (b) above in terms of the uncertainty principle. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle p\rangle=& \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}\left(-i \hbar \frac{d}{d x}\right) \psi d x \\
=-i \hbar \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\left(2 \pi \sigma_{x}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}\left(-\frac{x}{2 \sigma_{x}^{2}}\right) e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2 \sigma_{x}^{2}}} d x=0 \\
\left\langle p^{2}\right\rangle=& \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}\left(-\hbar^{2} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}\right) \psi d x \\
=&-\hbar^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\left(2 \pi \sigma_{x}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}\left\{-\frac{1}{2 \sigma_{x}^{2}}+\frac{x^{2}}{4 \sigma_{x}^{4}}\right\} \\
& \times e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2 \sigma_{x}^{2}}} d x=\hbar^{2} / 4 \sigma_{x}^{2} \\
\sigma_{p}=& \sqrt{\left\langle p^{2}\right\rangle}=\frac{\hbar}{2 \sigma_{x}}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) By Fourier transform,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(p, 0)=& \frac{1}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{1 / 2}} \int e^{-i p x / \hbar} \psi(x, 0) d x \\
=& \frac{1}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{1 / 2}} \int e^{-i p x / \hbar} \frac{1}{\left(2 \pi \sigma_{x}^{2}\right)^{1 / 4}} \\
& \times \exp \left(-x^{2} / 4 \sigma_{x}^{2}\right) d x \\
=& {\left[\left(2 \pi \sigma_{x}^{2}\right)^{1 / 4} / \sqrt{2} \pi \hbar\right] \exp \left[-\sigma_{x}^{2} p^{2} / \hbar^{2}\right] }
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\psi(p, t)=\psi(p, 0) e^{-i E t / \hbar}
$$

where

$$
E=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}
$$

for a free particle. By inverse Fourier transformation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t)=& \int e^{i p x / \hbar} \psi(p, t) d p=\frac{\left(2 \pi \sigma_{x}^{2}\right)^{1 / 4}}{\sqrt{2}(\pi \hbar)} \int e^{i p x / \hbar} \exp \left(-i \frac{p^{2}}{2 m \hbar} t\right) \\
& \times \exp \left(-\frac{\sigma_{x}^{2} p^{2}}{\hbar^{2}}\right) d p=\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}^{2}}{2 \pi}\right)^{1 / 4} \frac{1}{\left(\sigma_{x}^{2}+i \frac{\hbar t}{2 m}\right)^{1 / 2}} \\
& \times \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{4\left(\sigma_{x}^{2}+i \frac{\hbar t}{2 m}\right)}\right] \\
|\psi(x, t)|^{2}=&\left.\left.\frac{1}{2 \pi\left(\sigma_{x}^{2}+\frac{\sigma_{p}^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2}}\right)} \exp \right]-\frac{x^{2}}{2} \frac{1}{\sigma_{x}^{2}+\frac{\sigma_{p}^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2}}}\right] \\
=&\left|\psi\left(x, 0, \sigma_{x}^{2}+\sigma_{p}^{2} t^{2} m^{-2}\right)\right|^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Discussion:

〈i〉 The results indicate the width of the Gaussian wave packet at time $t$ (which was originally $\sigma_{x}$ at $t=0$ ) is

$$
\sqrt{\sigma_{x}^{2}+\sigma_{p}^{2} t^{2} / m^{2}}
$$

where $\sigma_{p}^{2}=\hbar^{2} / 4 \sigma_{x}^{2}$.

〈ii As $\sigma_{x} \sigma_{p}=\hbar / 2$, the uncertainty principle is satisfied.

A particle of mass $m$ moves in one dimension under the influence of a potential $V(x)$. Suppose it is in an energy eigenstate $\psi(x)=\left(\gamma^{2} / \pi\right)^{1 / 4}$ $\exp \left(-\gamma^{2} x^{2} / 2\right)$ with energy $E=\hbar^{2} \gamma^{2} / 2 m$.
(a) Find the mean position of the particle.
(b) Find the mean momentum of the particle.
(c) Find $V(x)$ (d) Find the probability $P(p) d p$ that the particle's momentum is between $p$ and $p+d p$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The mean position of the particle is

$$
\langle x\rangle=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x) x \psi(x) d x=\frac{\gamma}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x e^{-\gamma^{2} x^{2}} d x=0
$$

(b) The mean momentum is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle p\rangle &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x) \frac{\hbar}{i}\left(\frac{d}{d x} \psi(x)\right) d x \\
&=\frac{\gamma \hbar}{i \sqrt{\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\gamma^{2} x^{2} / 2} \frac{d}{d x}\left(e^{-\gamma^{2} x^{2} / 2}\right) d x=0
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) The Schrödinger equation

$$
\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+V(x)\right) \psi(x)=E \psi(x)
$$

can be written as

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi(x)=[E-V(x)] \psi(x)
$$

As

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} e^{-\gamma^{2} x^{2} / 2}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(-\gamma^{2}+\gamma^{4} x^{2}\right) e^{-\gamma^{2} x^{2} / 2}
$$

we have

$$
E-V(x)=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(-\gamma^{2}+\gamma^{4} x^{2}\right)
$$

or

$$
V(x)=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(\gamma^{4} x^{2}-\gamma^{2}\right)+\frac{\hbar^{2} \gamma^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \gamma^{4} x^{2}}{2 m} .
$$

(d) The Schrödinger equation in momentum representation is

$$
\left(\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}-\frac{\hbar^{4} \gamma^{4}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d p^{2}}\right) \psi(p)=E \psi(p) .
$$



\section{Letting}

$$
\psi(p)=N e^{-a p^{2}}
$$

and substituting it into the above equation, we get

$$
\frac{p^{2}}{2 m} e^{-a p^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{4} \gamma^{4}}{2 m}\left(-2 a+4 a^{2} p^{2}\right) e^{-a p^{2}}=E e^{-a p^{2}}
$$

or

$$
4 a^{2} p^{2}-2 a=\frac{1}{\hbar^{2} \gamma^{2}}\left(\frac{p^{2}}{\hbar^{2} \gamma^{2}}-1\right) .
$$

As the parameter $a$ is independent of $p$, the above relation can be satisfied by $a=1 / 2 \hbar^{2} \gamma^{2}$. Hence

$$
\psi(p)=N \exp \left(-p^{2} / 2 \hbar^{2} \gamma^{2}\right) .
$$

This is the eigenfunction of the state with energy $\hbar^{2} \gamma^{2} / 2 m$ in the momentum representation. Normalization gives $N=\left(1 / \hbar^{2} \gamma^{2} \pi\right)^{1 / 4}$. Thus the probability that the particle momentum is between $p$ and $p+d p$ is

$$
P(p) d p=|\psi(p)|^{2} d p=\left(\frac{1}{\hbar^{2} \gamma^{2} \pi}\right)^{1 / 2} \exp \left(-\frac{p^{2}}{\hbar^{2} \gamma^{2}}\right) d p
$$

Note that $\psi(p)$ can be obtained directly by the Fourier transform of $\psi(x)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(p) &=\int \frac{d x}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{1 / 2}} e^{-i p \cdot x / \hbar}\left(\frac{\gamma^{2}}{\pi}\right)^{1 / 4} e^{-\gamma^{2} x^{2} / 2} \\
&=\int \frac{d x}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{1 / 2}}\left(\frac{\gamma^{2}}{\pi}\right)^{1 / 4} \exp \left[\left(\frac{p}{\sqrt{2} \hbar \gamma}-\frac{i \gamma x}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}\right] \exp \left(-\frac{p^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2} \gamma^{2}}\right) \\
&=\left(\frac{1}{\hbar^{2} \gamma^{2} \pi}\right)^{1 / 4} e^{-p^{2}} / 2 \hbar^{2} \gamma^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

1042

In one dimension, a particle of mass $m$ is in the ground state of a potential which confines the particle to a small region of space. At time $t=0$, the potential suddenly disappears, so that the particle is free for time $t>0$. Give a formula for the probability per unit time that the particle arrives at time $t$ at an observer who is a distance $L$ away.

$($ Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let $\psi_{0}(x)$ be the wave function at $t=0$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t) &=\left\langle x\left|\exp \left(\frac{-i p^{2} t}{2 m \hbar}\right)\right| \psi_{0}(x)\right\rangle \\
&=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\left\langle x\left|e^{-i p^{2} t /(2 m \hbar)}\right| x^{\prime}\right\rangle d x^{\prime}\left\langle x^{\prime} \mid \psi_{0}\right\rangle \\
&=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\left\langle x\left|e^{-i p^{2} t /(2 m \hbar)}\right| x^{\prime}\right\rangle \psi_{0}\left(x^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle x\left|\exp \left(-i \frac{p^{2} t}{2 m \hbar}\right)\right| x^{\prime}\right\rangle \\
=& \iint_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\left\langle x \mid p^{\prime}\right\rangle d p^{\prime}\left\langle p^{\prime}\left|\exp \left(-i \frac{p^{2} t}{2 m \hbar}\right)\right| p\right\rangle d p\left\langle p \mid x^{\prime}\right\rangle \\
=& \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{1}{2 \pi \hbar} \exp \left[i \frac{p x}{\hbar}-i \frac{p x^{\prime}}{\hbar}-i \frac{p^{2} t}{2 m \hbar}\right] d p \\
=& \frac{1}{2 \pi \hbar} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \exp \left\{-i\left[p \sqrt{\frac{t}{2 m \hbar}}\right] d p \cdot \exp \left[i\left(x^{\prime}-x\right)^{2} \frac{m}{2 \hbar t}\right]\right.\\
&\left.\left.+\frac{\left(x^{\prime}-x\right) \sqrt{m}}{\sqrt{2 \hbar t}}\right]^{2}\right\} d p \cdot e^{-i q^{2}} d q \\
=& \frac{1}{2 \pi \hbar} \sqrt{\frac{2 m \hbar}{t}} \exp \left[i\left(x^{\prime}-x\right)^{2} \frac{m}{2 \hbar t}\right] \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \\
=& \frac{1-i}{2} \sqrt{\frac{m}{\pi \hbar t}} \exp \left[i\left(x^{\prime}-x\right)^{2} \frac{m}{2 \hbar t}\right] \cdot
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus

$$
\psi(x, t)=\frac{1-i}{2} \sqrt{\frac{m}{\pi \hbar t}} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \exp \left[i\left(x^{\prime}-x\right)^{2} \frac{m}{2 \hbar t}\right] \cdot \psi_{0}\left(x^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime}
$$

Represent the particle as a Gaussian wave packet of dimension $a$ :

$$
\psi_{0}(x)=\left(\pi a^{2}\right)^{-1 / 4} \exp \left(-x^{2} / 2 a^{2}\right)
$$

The last integral then gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t)=& \frac{(1-i)}{2} \sqrt{\frac{m}{\pi \hbar t}} \frac{1}{\pi^{1 / 4} a^{1 / 2}} \\
& \times \exp \left\{i \frac{m x^{2}}{2 \hbar t}\left[1-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t\left(\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}+\frac{i}{2 a^{2}}\right)}\right]\right\} \\
& \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}+\frac{i}{2 a^{2}}}} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} e^{i \xi^{2}} d \xi \\
=& \frac{1}{a^{1 / 2} \pi^{1 / 4}} \sqrt{\frac{m}{m+i \frac{\hbar t}{a^{2}}}} \exp \left[-\frac{m x^{2}}{2 a^{2}} \frac{1}{m+i \frac{\hbar t}{a^{2}}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

whence the current density

$$
\begin{aligned}
j=& R e\left(\psi^{*} \frac{p_{x}}{m} \psi\right)=\frac{\hbar^{2} x t}{\sqrt{\pi} a^{5} m^{2}} \frac{1}{\left(1+\frac{\hbar^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} a^{4}}\right)^{3 / 2}} \\
& \times \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}} \frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{\hbar t}{m a^{2}}\right)^{2}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

By putting $x=L$, we get the probability per unit time that the particle arrives at the observer a distance $L$ away.

\section{3}

A free particle of mass $m$ moves in one dimension. The initial wave function of the particle is $\psi(x, 0)$.

(a) Show that after a sufficiently long time $t$ the wave function of the particle spreads to reach a unique limiting form given by

$$
\psi(x, t)=\sqrt{m / \hbar t} \exp (-i \pi / 4) \exp \left(i m x^{2} / 2 \hbar t\right) \varphi(m x / \hbar t)
$$

where $\varphi$ is the Fourier transform of the initial wave function:

$$
\varphi(k)=(2 \pi)^{-1 / 2} \int \psi(x, 0) \exp (-i k x) d x .
$$

(b) Give a plausible physical interpretation of the limiting value of $|\psi(x, t)|^{2}$

Hint: Note that when $\alpha \rightarrow \infty$,

$$
\exp \left(-i \alpha u^{2}\right) \rightarrow \sqrt{\pi / \alpha} \exp (-i \pi / 4) \delta(u)
$$

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Schrödinger equation is

$$
\left[i \hbar \partial / \partial t+\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 m\right) d^{2} / d x^{2}\right] \psi(x, t)=0
$$

By Fourier transform, we can write

$$
\psi(k, t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d x e^{-i k x} \psi(x, t)
$$

and the equation becames

$$
\left(i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}\right) \psi(k, t)=0
$$

\section{Integration gives}

$$
\psi(k, t)=\psi(k, 0) \exp \left(-i \frac{k^{2} \hbar t}{2 m}\right)
$$

where

$$
\psi(k, 0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d x e^{-i k x} \psi(x, 0) \equiv \varphi(k)
$$

Hence

$$
\psi(k, t)=\varphi(k) \exp \left(-i \frac{k^{2} \hbar t}{2 m}\right)
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t)=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d k e^{i k x} \psi(k, t) \\
=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d k \varphi(k) \exp \left(i k x-i \frac{k^{2} \hbar t}{2 m}\right) \\
=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp \left(i \frac{m x^{2}}{2 \hbar t}\right) \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d k \\
& \times \exp \left[-i \frac{\hbar t}{2 m}\left(k-\frac{m x}{\hbar t}\right)^{2}\right] \varphi(k)
\end{aligned}
$$

With $\xi=k-m x / \hbar t$, this becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t)=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp \left(i \frac{m x^{2}}{2 \hbar t}\right) \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d \xi \\
& \times \exp \left(-i \frac{\hbar t}{2 m} \xi^{2}\right) \varphi\left(\xi+\frac{m x}{\hbar t}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\alpha \rightarrow \infty$

$$
e^{-i \alpha u^{2}} \rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{\alpha}} \exp \left(-i \frac{\pi}{4}\right) \delta(u),
$$

and so after a long time $t(t \rightarrow \infty)$,

$$
\exp \left(-i \frac{\hbar t}{2 m} \xi^{2}\right) \rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{2 \pi m}{\hbar t}} \delta(\xi) \exp \left(-i \frac{\pi}{4}\right)
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t)=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp \left(i \frac{m x^{2}}{2 \hbar t}\right) \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d \xi \sqrt{\frac{2 \pi m}{\hbar t}} \\
& \times \delta(\xi) \varphi\left(\xi+\frac{m x}{\hbar t}\right) \exp \left(-i \frac{\pi}{4}\right) \\
=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp \left(i \frac{m x^{2}}{2 \hbar t}\right) \sqrt{\frac{2 \pi m}{\hbar t}} \exp \left(-i \frac{\pi}{4}\right) \varphi\left(\frac{m x}{\hbar t}\right) \\
=& \sqrt{\frac{m}{\hbar t}} \exp \left(-i \frac{\pi}{4}\right) \exp \left(i \frac{m x^{2}}{2 \hbar t}\right) \varphi\left(\frac{m x}{\hbar t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

(b)

$$
|\psi(x, t)|^{2}=\frac{m}{\hbar t}\left|\varphi\left(\frac{m x}{\hbar t}\right)\right|^{2} .
$$

Because $\varphi(k)$ is the Fourier transform of $\psi(x, 0)$, we have

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}|\varphi(k)|^{2} d k=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}|\psi(x, 0)|^{2} d x
$$

On the other hand, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}|\psi(x, t)|^{2} d x &=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{m}{\hbar t}\left|\varphi\left(\frac{m x}{\hbar t}\right)\right|^{2} d x \\
&=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}|\varphi(k)|^{2} d k=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}|\psi(x, 0)|^{2} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

which shows the conservation of total probability. For the limiting case of $t \rightarrow \infty$, we have

$$
|\psi(x, t)|^{2} \rightarrow 0 \cdot|\varphi(0)|^{2}=0,
$$

which indicates that the wave function of the particle will diffuse infinitely.

\section{4}

The one-dimensional quantum mechanical potential energy of a particle of mass $m$ is given by

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
V(x)=V_{0} \delta(x), & -a<x<\infty \\
V(x)=\infty, & x<-a
\end{array}
$$

as shown in Fig. 1.19. At time $t=0$, the wave function of the particle is completely confined to the region $-a<x<0$. [Define the quantities $k=\sqrt{2 m E} / \hbar$ and $\left.\alpha=2 m V_{0} / \hbar^{2}\right]$

(a) Write down the normalized lowest-energy wave function of the particle at time $t=0$.

(b) Give the boundary conditions which the energy eigenfunctions

$$
\psi_{k}(x)=\psi_{k}^{\mathrm{I}}(x) \quad \text { and } \quad \psi_{k}(x)=\psi_{k}^{\mathrm{II}}(x)
$$

must satisfy, where the region I is $-a<x<0$ and the region II $x \geq 0$. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-079.jpg?height=293&width=448&top_left_y=160&top_left_x=454)

Fig. $1.19$

(c) Find the (real) solutions for the energy eigenfunctions in the two regions (up to an overall constant) which satisfy the boundary conditions.

(d) The $t=0$ wave function can be expressed as an integral over energy eigenfunctions:

$$
\psi(x)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(k) \psi_{k}(x) d k .
$$

Show how $f(k)$ can be determined from the solutions $\psi_{k}(x)$.

(e) Give an expression for the time development of the wave function in terms of $f(k)$. What values of $k$ are expected to govern the time behavior at large times?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The required wave function $\psi(x)$ must satisfy the boundary conditions $\psi(-a)=\psi(0)=0$. A complete orthonormal set of wave functions defined in $-a<x<0$ and satisfying the Schrödinger equation consists of

$$
\phi_{n}(x)= \begin{cases}\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{a}\right), & -a<x<0 \\ 0, & \text { outside }[-a, 0],\end{cases}
$$

where $n=1,2, \ldots$, with

$$
\left\langle\phi_{n}|H| \phi_{m}\right\rangle=E_{n} \delta_{m n}, \quad E_{n}=\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 m\right)(n \pi / a)^{2} .
$$

The normalized lowest-energy wave function is given by $n=1$ as

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right), & -a<x<0, \\ 0, & \text { outside }[-a, 0] .\end{cases}
$$

(b) The Schrödinger equation for $x>-a$ is

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi+V_{0} \delta(x) \psi=E \psi
$$

or

$$
\psi^{\prime \prime}(x)+k^{2} \psi(x)=\alpha \delta(x) \psi(x)
$$

with

$$
k^{2}=\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}, \quad \alpha=\frac{2 m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2}} .
$$

The boundary conditions and the discontinuity condition to be satisfied are

$$
\begin{gathered}
\psi^{\mathbf{I}}(-a)=0, \quad \psi^{\mathbf{I}}(0)=\psi^{\mathbf{I I}}(0), \quad \psi^{\mathbf{I I}}(+\infty)=\text { finite } \\
\psi^{\mathbf{I I}^{\prime}}(0)-\psi^{\mathbf{I}^{\prime}}(0)=\alpha \psi^{\mathbf{I}}(0)
\end{gathered}
$$

The last equation is obtained by integrating the Schrödinger equation over a small interval $[-\varepsilon, \varepsilon]$ and letting $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$ (see Problem 1020).

(c) In both the regions I and II, the wave equation is

$$
\psi^{\prime \prime}(x)+k^{2} \psi(x)=0,
$$

whose real solutions are sinusoidal functions. The solutions that satisfy the boundary conditions are

$$
\psi_{k}(x)= \begin{cases}\psi_{k}^{\mathrm{I}}(x)=c_{k} \sin k(x+a), & -a<x<0, \\ \psi_{k}^{\mathrm{II}}(x)=c_{k} \sin k(x+a)+A_{k} \sin k x, & x \geq 0 \\ 0, & x<-a\end{cases}
$$

The discontinuity and normalization conditions then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{k} &=\frac{c_{k} \alpha}{k} \sin k a, \\
c_{k} &=\left\{\frac{\pi}{2}\left[1+\frac{\alpha \sin 2 k a}{k}+\left(\frac{\alpha \sin k a}{k}\right)^{2}\right]\right\}^{-\frac{1}{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(d) Expand the wave function $\psi(x)$ in terms of $\psi_{k}(x)$,

$$
\psi(x)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(k) \psi_{k}(x) d k
$$

and obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-a}^{\infty} \psi_{k^{\prime}}^{*}(x) \psi(x) d x &=\iint f(k) \psi_{k}(x) \psi_{k^{\prime}}^{*}(x) d k d x \\
&=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(k) \delta\left(k-k^{\prime}\right) d k=f\left(k^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
f(k)=\int_{-a}^{\infty} \psi_{k}^{*}(x) \psi(x) d x
$$

(e) As

$$
\psi(x, 0)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(k) \psi_{k}(x) d k
$$

we have

$$
\psi(x, t)=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} f(k) \psi_{k}(x) e^{-i E_{k} t / \hbar} d k
$$

At time $t=0$, the particle is in the ground state of an infinitely deep square well potential of width $a$, it is a wave packet. When $t>0$, since the $\delta(x)$ potential barrier is penetrable, the wave packet will spread over to the region $x>0$. Quantitatively, we compute first

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(k)=& \int_{-a}^{0} c_{k} \sin k(x+a) \cdot \sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \frac{\pi x}{a} d x \\
=& \sqrt{\frac{1}{2 a}} \int_{-a}^{0} c_{k}\left\{\cos \left[\left(k-\frac{\pi}{a}\right) x+k a\right]\right.\\
&\left.-\cos \left[\left(k+\frac{\pi}{a}\right) x+k a\right]\right\} d x \\
=& \frac{\pi}{a} \sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \frac{\sin k a}{k^{2}-\left(\frac{\pi}{a}\right)^{2}} c_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

and then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t)=& \frac{\pi}{a} \sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \int_{-\infty}^{-\infty} c_{k} \frac{\sin k a}{k^{2}-\left(\frac{\pi}{a}\right)^{2}} \\
& \times\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\sin k(x+a) \\
\sin k(x+a)+\frac{\alpha}{k} \sin k a \sin k x
\end{array}\right\} e^{-i E_{k} t / \hbar} d k,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $E_{k}=\hbar^{2} k^{2} / 2 m$. In the last expression the upper and lower rows are for regions I and II respectively.

When $t \rightarrow \infty$, the oscillatory factor $\exp \left(-i E_{k} t / \hbar\right)$ changes even more rapidly, while the other functions of the integrand behave quite normally $(k=\pi / a$ is not a pole $)$. Thus $\psi(x, t)$ tend to zero for any given $x$. When $t$ is very large, component waves of small wave number $k$ play the principal role. At that time the particle has practically escaped from the region $[-a, 0]$

\section{5}

The radioactive isotope ${ }_{83} \mathrm{Bi}^{212}$ decays to ${ }_{81} \mathrm{Tl}^{208}$ by emitting an alpha particle with the energy $E=6.0 \mathrm{MeV}$.

(a) In an attempt to calculate the lifetime, first consider the finite potential barrier shown in Fig. 1.20. Calculate the transition probability $T$ for a particle of mass $m$ incident from the left with energy $E$ in the limit $T \ll 1$

(b) Using the above result, obtain a rough numerical estimate for the lifetime of the nucleus $\mathrm{Bi}^{212}$. Choose sensible barrier parameters to approximate the true alpha particle potential.

$(C U S)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-082.jpg?height=274&width=455&top_left_y=1207&top_left_x=437)

Fig. $1.20$

\section{Solution:}

(a) If $T \ll 1$, the incident wave is reflected at $x=0$ as if the potential barrier were infinitely thick. We thus have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi(x)=e^{i k x}+\left(t_{1}-1\right) e^{-i k x}, & x<0 \\
\psi(x)=t_{1} e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & 0<x<b
\end{array}
$$

where $t_{1}$ is the amplitude transmission coefficient and

$$
k^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} .
$$

The continuity of $\psi^{\prime}(x)$ at $x=0$ gives

$$
i k\left(2-t_{1}\right)=-k^{\prime} t_{1}, \quad \text { or } \quad t_{1}=\frac{2 k}{k+i k^{\prime}}
$$

Consider the reflection at $b$. We have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi(x)=t_{1} e^{-k^{\prime} b}\left[e^{-k^{\prime}(x-b)}+\left(t_{2}-1\right) e^{k^{\prime}(x-b)}\right], & 0<x<b \\
\psi(x)=t_{1} t_{2} e^{-k^{\prime} b} e^{i k(x-b)}, & x>b
\end{array}
$$

and so

$$
-k^{\prime}\left(2-t_{2}\right)=i k t_{2}, \quad \text { or } \quad t_{2}=2 i k^{\prime} /\left(k+i k^{\prime}\right) .
$$

Hence the transition probability is given by

$$
T=t_{1} t_{2} e^{-k^{\prime} b}
$$

to be

$$
|T|^{2}=\frac{16 k^{2} k^{\prime 2}}{\left(k^{2}+k^{\prime 2}\right)^{2}} e^{-2 k^{\prime} b}=\frac{16 E\left(V_{0}-E\right)}{V_{0}^{2}} e^{-2 k^{\prime} b} .
$$

(b) To estimate the rate of $\alpha$-decay of ${ }_{83} \mathrm{Bi}^{212}$, we treat, in first approximation, the Coulomb potential experienced by the $\alpha$-particle in the ${ }_{81} \mathrm{Tl}$ nucleus as a rectangular potential barrier. As shown in Fig. 1.21, the width of the barrier $r_{0}$ can be taken to be

$$
\begin{aligned}
r_{0} &=\frac{2 Z e^{2}}{E}=\frac{2(83-2)}{6} \frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c} \frac{\hbar c}{\mathrm{MeV}} \\
&=\frac{162}{6} \times \frac{1}{137} \times 6.58 \times 10^{-22} \times 3 \times 10^{10} \\
&=3.9 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~cm} .
\end{aligned}
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-084.jpg?height=446&width=490&top_left_y=158&top_left_x=412)

Fig. $1.21$

The radius of the nucleus of $\mathrm{Tl}$ is

$$
R=1 \times 10^{-13} \times 208^{\frac{1}{3}}=6 \times 10^{-13} \mathrm{~cm},
$$

corresponding to a Coulomb potential height of

$$
V=\frac{2 Z e^{2}}{r_{0}} \cdot \frac{r_{0}}{R}=39 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$

An $\alpha$-particle, moving with speed $v$ in the nucleus of $\mathrm{T}$, makes $\frac{v}{2 R}$ collisions per second with the walls. Hence the lifetime $\tau$ of ${ }_{83} \mathrm{Bi}^{212}$ is given by

$$
\tau|T|^{2} \frac{v}{2 R} \approx 1,
$$

or

$$
\tau \simeq \frac{2 R}{v|T|^{2}} .
$$

Taking for the rectangular potential barrier a height $V_{0} \approx \frac{1}{2}(39-6)+6=$ $22.5 \mathrm{MeV}, b=r_{0}-R=33 \times 10^{-13} \mathrm{~cm}$ (see Fig. 1.21),$v=\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 6}{940}} c \approx$ $0.1 c$, we find

$$
\begin{gathered}
2 k^{\prime} b=\frac{2 \sqrt{2 m c^{2}\left(V_{0}-E\right)}}{\hbar c} \quad b=\frac{2 \sqrt{2 \times 940 \times 16.5} \times 33 \times 10^{-13}}{6.58 \times 10^{-22} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}=59, \\
\tau=\frac{2 \times 6 \times 10^{-13}}{3 \times 10^{9}} \times \frac{22.5^{2}}{16 \times 6 \times(22.5-6)} \times e^{59} \\
=5.4 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~s} .
\end{gathered}
$$



\section{6}

An electron with energy $E=1 \mathrm{eV}$ is incident upon a rectangular barrier of potential energy $V_{0}=2 \mathrm{eV}$ (see Fig. 1.22). About how wide must the barrier be so that the transmission probability is $10^{-3}$ ?

$(W i s c o n s i n)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-085.jpg?height=367&width=560&top_left_y=437&top_left_x=394)

Fig. $1.22$

\section{Solution:}

The transmission probability is (Problem 1045)

$$
\begin{aligned}
T & \simeq \frac{16 E\left(V_{0}-E\right)}{V_{0}^{2}} \cdot \exp \left[-\frac{2 d}{\hbar} \sqrt{2 m\left(V_{0}-E\right)}\right] \\
&=4 \exp \left[-\frac{2 d}{\hbar} \sqrt{2 m\left(V_{0}-E\right)}\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

whence

$$
\begin{aligned}
d &=-\frac{\ln \left(\frac{T}{4}\right)}{2} \frac{\hbar c}{\sqrt{2 m c^{2}\left(V_{0}-E\right)}} \\
&=-\frac{\ln \left(\frac{10^{-3}}{4}\right)}{2} \times \frac{6.58 \times 10^{-16} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}{\sqrt{2 \times 0.51 \times 10^{6}}}=8.1 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~cm} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{7}

Consider a one-dimensional square-well potential (see Fig 1.23)

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=0, & x<0 \\
V(x)=-V_{0}, & 0<x<a, \\
V(x)=0, & x>a,
\end{array}
$$

where $V_{0}$ is positive. If a particle with mass $m$ is incident from the left with nonrelativistic kinetic energy $E$, what is its probability for transmission through the potential? For what values of $E$ will this probability be unity?

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-086.jpg?height=383&width=557&top_left_y=391&top_left_x=407)

Fig. 1.23

\section{Solution:}

Let the wave function be

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi(x)=e^{i k x}+R e^{-i k x}, & x<0 \\
\psi(x)=S e^{i k x}, & x>a \\
\psi(x)=A e^{i k^{\prime} x}+B e^{-i k^{\prime} x}, & 0<x<a
\end{array}
$$

where

$$
k=\frac{\sqrt{2 m E}}{\hbar}, \quad k^{\prime}=\frac{\sqrt{2 m\left(E+V_{0}\right)}}{\hbar} .
$$

The constants $R, S, A, B$ are to be determined from the boundary conditions that $\psi(x)$ and $\psi^{\prime}(x)$ are both continuous at $x=0$ and $x=a$, which give

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
1+R=A+B \\
k(1-R)=k^{\prime}(A-B) \\
A e^{i k^{\prime} a}+B e^{-i k^{\prime} a}=S e^{i k a} \\
k^{\prime}\left(A e^{i k^{\prime} a}-B e^{-i k^{\prime} a}\right)=k S e^{i k a}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence

$$
S=\frac{4 k k^{\prime} e^{-i k a}}{\left(k+k^{\prime}\right)^{2} e^{-i k^{\prime} a}-\left(k-k^{\prime}\right)^{2} e^{i k^{\prime} a}}
$$

and the probability for transmission is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\frac{j_{t}}{j_{i}}=|S|^{2} \\
&=\frac{4 k^{2} k^{2}}{4\left(k k^{\prime} \cos k^{\prime} a\right)^{2}+\left(k^{2}-k^{\prime 2}\right)^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(k^{\prime} a\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Resonance transmission occurs when $k^{\prime} a=n \pi$, i.e., when the kinetic energy $E$ of the incident particle is

$$
E=n^{2} \pi^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 m a^{2}-V_{0} .
$$

The probability for transmission, $P$, then becomes unity.

\section{8}

Consider a one-dimensional square-well potential (see Fig. 1.24):

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-087.jpg?height=433&width=464&top_left_y=896&top_left_x=442)

Fig. 1.24

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=\infty, & x<0 \\
V(x)=-V_{0}, & 0<x<a \\
V(x)=0, & x>a .
\end{array}
$$

(a) For $E<0$, find the wave function of a particle bound in this potential. Write an equation which determines the allowed values of $E$.

(b) Suppose a particle with energy $E>0$ is incident upon this potential. Find the phase relation between the incident and the outgoing wave. 

\section{Solution:}

The Schrödinger equations for the different regions are

$$
\begin{gathered}
{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-V_{0}-E\right] \psi(x)=0, \quad 0<x<a,} \\
{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-E\right] \psi(x)=0, \quad x>a .}
\end{gathered}
$$

(a) $E<0$

〈i〉 Consider first the case of $V_{0}<-E$, for which the wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sinh (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & x>a\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(-V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m(-E)}{\hbar^{2}}} .
$$

The continuity conditions of the wave function give

$$
\begin{aligned}
A \sinh (k a) &=B e^{-k^{\prime} a} \\
A k \cosh (k a) &=-B k^{\prime} e^{-k^{\prime} a}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
k \operatorname{coth}(k a)=-k^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

As $\operatorname{coth} x>0$ for $x>0$, there is no solution for this case.

〈ii For $V_{0}>-E, i k \rightarrow k, k=\sqrt{2 m\left(V_{0}+E\right)} / \hbar$, and the equation determining the energy becomes $k \cot (k a)=-k^{\prime}$. The wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sin (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & x>a\end{cases}
$$

From the continuity and normalization of the wave function we get

$$
A=\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2}
$$



$$
B=\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2} e^{k^{\prime} a} \sin (k a) .
$$

(b) $E>0$. The wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sin (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B \sin \left(k^{\prime} x+\varphi\right), & x>a\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(E+V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 m E / \hbar^{2}} .
$$

As $\partial \ln \psi / \partial \ln x$ is continuous at $x=a$,

$$
(k a) \cot (k a)=\left(k^{\prime} a\right) \cot \left(k^{\prime} a+\varphi\right)
$$

whence

$$
\varphi=\operatorname{arccot}\left(\frac{k}{k^{\prime}} \cot (k a)\right)-k^{\prime} a .
$$

For $x>a$,

$$
\psi(x)=\frac{B}{2 i} e^{-i k^{\prime} x-i \varphi}-\frac{B}{2 i} e^{i k^{\prime} x+i \varphi}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\varphi_{\mathrm{inc}}(x) \propto e^{-i k^{\prime} x-i \varphi} \\
&\varphi_{\text {out }}(x) \propto e^{i k^{\prime} x+i \varphi}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the phase shift of the outgoing wave in relation to the incident wave is

$$
\delta=2 \varphi=2\left[\operatorname{arccot}\left(\frac{k}{k^{\prime}} \cot (k a)\right)-k^{\prime} a\right] .
$$

1049

Consider a one-dimensional system with potential energy (see Fig. 1.25)

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=V_{0}, & x>0, \\
V(x)=0, & x<0
\end{array}
$$

where $V_{0}$ is a positive constant. If a beam of particles with energy $E$ is incident from the left (i.e., from $x=-\infty$ ), what fraction of the beam is transmitted and what fraction reflected? Consider all possible values of $E$.

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-090.jpg?height=337&width=542&top_left_y=391&top_left_x=380)

Fig. $1.25$

\section{Solution:}

For $x<0$, the Schrödinger equation is

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi+\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}} \psi=0
$$

whose solution has the form

$$
\psi(x)=e^{i k x}+r e^{-i k x}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}
$$

For $x>0$, the equation is

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi+\frac{2 m\left(E-V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}} \psi=0
$$

$\langle$ i $\rangle$ If $E<V_{0}$, write the above as

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi-\frac{2 m\left(V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}} \psi=0 .
$$

As $\psi(x)$ must be finite for $x \rightarrow \infty$, the solution has the form

$$
\psi(x)=t e^{-k^{\prime} x}
$$

where

$$
k^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}
$$

The continuity conditions then give

$$
\begin{gathered}
1+r=t \\
i k-i k r=-t k^{\prime}
\end{gathered}
$$

whence $r=\left(k^{\prime}+i k\right) /\left(i k-k^{\prime}\right)=\left(1-i k^{\prime} / k\right) /\left(1+i k^{\prime} / k\right)$. Therefore the fraction reflected is $R=j_{\text {ref }} / j_{\text {inc }}=|r|^{2}=1$, the fraction transmitted is $T=1-R=0$.

〈ii $E>V_{0}$. For $x>0$, we have

$$
\left[\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+\frac{2 m\left(E-V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}}\right] \psi(x)=0
$$

where

$$
\psi(x)=t e^{i k^{\prime} x}, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(E-V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}
$$

Noting that there are only outgoing waves for $x \rightarrow \infty$, we have $1+r=t$, $i k-i k r=i k^{\prime} t$, and thus $r=\left(k^{\prime}-k\right) /\left(k^{\prime}+k\right)$. Hence the fraction reflected is $R=\left[\left(k^{\prime}-k\right) /\left(k^{\prime}+k\right)\right]^{2}$, the fraction transmitted is $T=1-R=$ $4 k k^{\prime} /\left(k+k^{\prime}\right)^{2}$

\section{0}

A particle of mass $m$ and momentum $p$ is incident from the left on the potential step shown in Fig. 1.26.

Calculate the probability that the particle is scattered backward by the potential if
(a) $p^{2} / 2 m<V_{0}$
(b) $p^{2} / 2 m>V_{0}$. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-092.jpg?height=293&width=463&top_left_y=160&top_left_x=412)

Fig. $1.26$

\section{Solution:}

The Schrödinger equations are

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}\right) \psi(x)=0 \text { for } x<x_{0}, \\
{\left[\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left(E-V_{0}\right)\right] \psi(x)=0 \text { for } x>x_{0} .}
\end{gathered}
$$

(a) If $E<V_{0}$, we have

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}e^{i k\left(x-x_{0}\right)}+r e^{-i k\left(x-x_{0}\right)}, & x<x_{0} \\ t e^{-k^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)}, & x>x_{0}\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
k &=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}, \\
k^{\prime} &=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}}},
\end{aligned}
$$

the condition that $\psi(x)$ is finite for $x \rightarrow \infty$ having been made use of. The continuity conditions give $1+r=t, i k-i k r=-k^{\prime} t$, whence $r=$ $\left(k^{\prime}+i k\right) /\left(i k-k^{\prime}\right)$. The probability of reflection is $R=j_{r} / j_{i}=|r|^{2}=1$.

(b) If $E>V_{0}$. We have

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}e^{i k\left(x-x_{0}\right)}+r e^{-i k\left(x-x_{0}\right)}, & x<x_{0} \\ t e^{i k^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)}, & x>x_{0}\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
k &=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}, \\
k^{\prime} &=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(E-V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

noting that there is only outgoing wave for $x>x_{0}$. The continuity conditions give $1+r=t$, ik -ikr $=i k^{\prime} t$, and hence $r=\left(k-k^{\prime}\right) /\left(k+k^{\prime}\right)$. The probability of reflection is then $R=|r|^{2}=\left[\left(k-k^{\prime}\right) /\left(k+k^{\prime}\right)\right]^{2}$.

\section{1}

Find the reflection and transmission coefficients for the one-dimensional potential step shown in Fig. $1.27$ if the particles are incident from the right.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-093.jpg?height=335&width=510&top_left_y=951&top_left_x=423)

Fig. $1.27$

\section{Solution:}

As the particles are incident from the right we must have $E>V_{0}$. And there are both incident and reflected waves in the region $x>0$. The Schrödinger equation for $x>0$,

$$
\psi^{\prime \prime}(x)+k_{1}^{2} \psi(x)=0
$$

where $k_{1}=\sqrt{2 m\left(E-V_{0}\right)} / \hbar$, has solutions of the form

$$
\psi=\exp \left(-i k_{1} x\right)+R \exp \left(i k_{1} x\right)
$$

There are only transmitted waves in the region $x<0$, where the Schrödinger equation is

$$
\psi^{\prime \prime}(x)+k_{2}^{2} \psi(x)=0
$$

with $k_{2}=\sqrt{2 m E} / \hbar$, and has the solution

$$
\psi(x)=S \exp \left(-i k_{2} x\right)
$$

Using the continuity conditions of the wave function at $x=0$, we get $1+R=S$. From the continuity of the first derivative of the wave function, we get $k_{1}(1-R)=k_{2} S$. Hence $R=\left(k_{1}-k_{2}\right) /\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right)$, giving the reflection coefficient

$$
|R|^{2}=\left|\frac{k_{1}-k_{2}}{k_{1}+k_{2}}\right|^{2}=\frac{V_{0}^{2}}{\left(\sqrt{E}+\sqrt{E-V_{0}}\right)^{4}},
$$

and the transmission coefficient

$$
|S|^{2}=1-|R|^{2}=1-\frac{V_{0}^{2}}{\left(\sqrt{E}+\sqrt{\left.E-V_{0}\right)^{4}}\right.} .
$$

\section{2}

Consider, quantum mechanically, a stream of particles of mass $m$, each moving in the positive $x$ direction with kinetic energy $E$ toward a potential jump located at $x=0$. The potential is zero for $x \leq 0$ and $3 E / 4$ for $x>0$. What fraction of the particles are reflected at $x=0$ ?

\section{Solution:}

The Schrödinger equations are

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi^{\prime \prime}+k^{2} \psi=0 & \text { for } \quad x \leq 0 \\
\psi^{\prime \prime}+(k / 2)^{2} \psi=0 & \text { for } \quad x>0
\end{array}
$$

where $k=\sqrt{2 m E} / \hbar$. As for $x<0$ there will also be reflected waves, the solutions are of the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi=\exp (i k x)+r \exp (-i k x), \quad x \leq 0, \\
& \psi=t \exp (i k x / 2), \quad x>0 \text {. } 
\end{aligned}
$$

From the continuity conditions of the wave function at $x=0$, we obtain $1+r=t, k(1-r)=k t / 2$, and hence $r=1 / 3$. Thus one-ninth of the particles are reflected at $x=0$.

\section{3}

Consider a particle beam approximated by a plane wave directed along the $x$-axis from the left and incident upon a potential $V(x)=\gamma \delta(x), \gamma>$ $0, \delta(x)$ is the Dirac delta function.

(a) Give the form of the wave function for $x<0$.

(b) Give the form of the wave function for $x>0$.

(c) Give the conditions on the wave function at the boundary between the regions.

(d) Calculate the probability of transmission.

\section{Solution:}

(a) For $x<0$, there are incident waves of the form $\exp (i k x)$ and reflected waves of the form $R \exp (-i k x)$. Thus

$$
\psi(x)=\exp (i k x)+R \exp (-i k x), \quad x<0 .
$$

(b) For $x>0$, there only exist transmitted waves of the form $S$ exp $(i k x)$. Thus

$$
\psi(x)=S \exp (i k x), \quad x>0 .
$$

(c) The Schrödinger equation is

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi(x)+\gamma \delta(x) \psi(x)=E \psi(x)
$$

and its solutions satisfy (Problem 1020)

$$
\psi^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)-\psi^{\prime}\left(0^{-}\right)=\frac{2 m \gamma}{\hbar^{2}} \psi(0) \text {. }
$$

As the wave function is continuous at $x=0, \psi\left(0^{+}\right)=\psi\left(0^{-}\right)$.

(d) From (a), (b) and (c) we have $1+R=S, i k S-i k(1-R)=2 m \gamma S / \hbar^{2}$, giving $S=1 /\left(1+i m \gamma / \hbar^{2} k\right)$. Hence the transmission coefficient is

where $E=\hbar^{2} k^{2} / 2 m$

$$
T=|S|^{2}=\left(1+\frac{m^{2} \gamma^{2}}{\hbar^{4} k^{2}}\right)^{-1}=\left(1+\frac{m \gamma^{2}}{2 E \hbar^{2}}\right)^{-1}
$$



\section{4}

Consider a one-dimensional problem of a particle of mass $m$ incident upon a potential of a shape shown in Fig. 1.28. Assume that the energy $E$ at $x \rightarrow-\infty$ is greater than $V_{0}$, where $V_{0}$ is the asymptotic value of the potential as $x \rightarrow \infty$

Show that the sum of reflected and transmitted intensities divided by the incident intensity is one.

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-096.jpg?height=290&width=624&top_left_y=581&top_left_x=345)

Fig. $1.28$

\section{Solution:}

As $E>V_{0}$ we may assume the asymptotic forms

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi \rightarrow e^{i k x}+r e^{-i k x} & \text { for } x \rightarrow-\infty \\
\psi \rightarrow t e^{i \beta x} & \text { for } x \rightarrow+\infty
\end{array}
$$

where $r, t, k, \beta$ are constants. The incident intensity is defined as the number of particles incident per unit time: $I=\hbar k / m$. Similarly, the reflected and transmitted intensities are respectively

$$
R=|r|^{2} \hbar k / m, \quad T=|t|^{2} \hbar \beta / m .
$$

\section{Multiplying the Schrödinger equation by $\psi^{*}$,}

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \psi^{*} \nabla^{2} \psi+\psi^{*} V \psi=E \psi^{*} \psi,
$$

and the conjugate Schrödinger equation by $\psi$,

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \psi \nabla^{2} \psi^{*}+\psi^{*} V \psi=E \psi^{*} \psi
$$

and taking the difference of the two equations, we have

$$
\psi^{*} \nabla^{2} \psi-\psi \nabla^{2} \psi^{*}=\nabla \cdot\left(\psi^{*} \nabla \psi-\psi \nabla \psi^{*}\right)=0
$$

This means that

$$
f(x)=\psi^{*} d \psi / d x-\psi d \psi^{*} / d x
$$

is a constant. Then equating $f(+\infty)$ and $f(-\infty)$, we find

$$
k\left(1-|r|^{2}\right)=\beta|t|^{2} .
$$

Multiplying both sides by $\frac{\hbar}{m}$ gives

$$
I=R+T .
$$

\section{5}

\section{A Schrödinger equation in one dimension reads}

$$
\left(-\partial^{2} / \partial x^{2}-2 \operatorname{sech}^{2} x\right) \psi=\varepsilon \psi
$$

$(\hbar=1, m=1 / 2)$

(a) Show that $\exp (i k x)(\tanh x+$ const) is a solution for a particular value of the constant. Calculate the S-matrix (transmission and reflection coefficients) for this problem.

(b) The wave function sech $x$ happens to satisfy the Schrödinger equation. Calculate the energy of the corresponding bound state and give a simple argument that it must be the ground state of the potential.

(c) Outline how you might have proceeded to estimate the ground-state energy if you did not know the wave function.

(Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Letting the constant in the given solution $\psi$ be $K$ and substituting $\psi$ in the Schrödinger equation, we obtain

$$
k^{2}(\tanh x+K)-2(i k+K) \operatorname{sech}^{2} x=\varepsilon(\tanh x+K)
$$

This equation is satisfied if we set $K=-i k$ and $\varepsilon=k^{2}$. Hence

$$
\psi(x)=e^{i k x}(\tanh x-i k)
$$

is a solution of the equation and the corresponding energy is $k^{2}$. Then as $\tanh x \rightarrow 1$ for $x \rightarrow \infty$ and $\tanh (-x)=-\tanh x$ we have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi=(1-i k) e^{i k x} \quad \text { as } \quad & x \rightarrow \infty \\
\psi=-(1+i k) e^{i k x} & \text { as } \quad x \rightarrow-\infty
\end{array}
$$

Since $V(x) \leq 0, \varepsilon>0$, the transmission coefficient is $T=1$ and the reflection coefficient is $R=0$ as the particle travels through $V(x)$. So the $S$-matrix is

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & -(1-i k) /(1+i k) \\
-(1-i k) /(1+i k) & 0
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

(b) Letting $\psi=$ sech $x$ in the Schrödinger equation we have $-\psi=\varepsilon \psi$. Hence $\varepsilon=-1$. Because sech $x$ is a non-node bound state in the whole coordinate space, it must be the ground state.

(c) We might proceed by assuming a non-node bound even function with a parameter and obtain an approximate value of the ground state energy by the variational method.

\section{6}

A monoenergetic parallel beam of nonrelativistic neutrons of energy $E$ is incident onto the plane surface of a plate of matter of thickness $t$. In the matter, the neutrons move in a uniform attractive potential $V$. The incident beam makes an angle $\theta$ with respect to the normal to the plane surface as shown in Fig. 1.29.

(a) What fraction of the incident beam is reflected if $t$ is infinite?

(b) What fraction of the incident beam is reflected if $V$ is repulsive and $V=E$ ? Consider $t$ finite. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-099.jpg?height=369&width=448&top_left_y=164&top_left_x=469)

Fig. $1.29$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $k_{0}$ be the wave number of an incident neutron, given by $k_{0}^{2}=$ $\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}$. For $x<0$, the wave function is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{1}(x, y)=& e^{i k_{0} x \cos \theta+i k_{0} y \sin \theta} \\
&+R e^{-i k_{0} x \cos \theta+i k_{0} y \sin \theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

With $t$ infinite and the potential negative, for $x>0$ the Schrödinger equation is

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2} \psi=(E+V) \psi
$$

\section{Assuming a solution}

$$
\psi_{2}(x, y)=T e^{i k_{x} x+i k_{y} y}
$$

and substituting it the equation, we obtain $k_{x}^{2}+k_{y}^{2}=2 m(E+V) / \hbar^{2}$.

The boundary conditions at $x=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi_{1}(0, y)=\psi_{2}(0, y) \\
&\left.\frac{\partial \psi_{1}}{\partial x}\right|_{x=0}=\left.\frac{\partial \psi_{2}}{\partial x}\right|_{x=0},
\end{aligned}
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&e^{i k_{0} y \sin \theta}+R e^{i k_{0} y \sin \theta}=T e^{i k_{y} y} \\
&i k_{0} \cos \theta e^{i k_{0} y \sin \theta}-R i k_{0} \cos \theta e^{i k_{0} y \sin \theta}=T i k_{x} e^{i k_{y} y}
\end{aligned}
$$

As the potential does not vary with $y, k_{y}=k_{0} \sin \theta$ and the above become

$$
\begin{gathered}
1+R=T, \\
k_{0}(1-R) \cos \theta=k_{x} T,
\end{gathered}
$$

which give $R=\left(k_{0} \cos \theta-k_{x}\right) /\left(k_{0} \cos \theta+k_{x}\right)$. The probability of reflection is then $P=|R|^{2}=\left(k_{0} \cos \theta-k_{x}\right)^{2} /\left(k_{0} \cos \theta+k_{x}\right)^{2}$, with $k_{x}^{2}=2 m(E+$ $V) / \hbar^{2}-k_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta, k_{0}^{2}=2 m E / \hbar^{2}$

(b) For $x<0$ the wave function has the same form as that in (a). For $0<x<t, E-V=0$, and the Schrödinger equation is

$$
-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 m\right) \nabla^{2} \psi=0 .
$$

As the potential is uniform in $y$ we assume $\psi=\exp \left(i k^{\prime} y\right) \exp (k x)$, where $k^{\prime}=k_{0} \sin \theta$. Substitution gives $-k^{\prime 2}+k^{2}=0$, or $k=\pm k^{\prime}$. Hence the wave function for $0<x<t$ is

$$
\psi_{2}(x, y)=\left(a e^{k^{\prime} x}+b e^{-k^{\prime} x}\right) e^{i k^{\prime} y} .
$$

Writing $\psi(x, y)=\phi(x) e^{i k^{\prime} y}$, we have for the three regions

$$
\begin{gathered}
x<0, \quad \phi_{1}(x)=e^{i k_{x} x}+r e^{-i k_{x} x} \\
0<x<t, \quad \phi_{2}(x)=a e^{k^{\prime} x}+b e^{-k^{\prime} x} \\
x>t, \quad \phi_{3}(x)=c e^{i k_{x} x}
\end{gathered}
$$

with

$$
k_{x}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \cos \theta, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 m E / \hbar^{2}} \sin \theta .
$$

The boundary conditions

give

$$
\begin{gathered}
\phi_{1}(0)=\phi_{2}(0), \quad \phi_{2}(t)=\phi_{3}(t) \\
\left.\frac{d \phi_{1}}{d x}\right|_{x=0}=\left.\frac{d \phi_{2}}{d x}\right|_{x=0},\left.\quad \frac{d \phi_{2}}{d x}\right|_{x=t}=\left.\frac{d \phi_{3}}{d x}\right|_{x=t}
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+r &=a+b, \\
i k_{x}(1-r) &=k^{\prime}(a-b) \\
c \exp \left(i k_{x} t\right) &=a \exp \left(k^{\prime} t\right)+b \exp \left(-k^{\prime} t\right), \\
i k_{x} c \exp \left(i k_{x} t\right) &=k^{\prime} a \exp \left(k^{\prime} t\right)-k^{\prime} b \exp \left(-k^{\prime} t\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

whose solution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
r &=\left[\frac{i k_{x}}{k^{\prime}}\left(\frac{a / b+1}{a / b-1}\right)-1\right]\left[\frac{i k_{x}}{k^{\prime}}\left(\frac{a / b+1}{a / b-1}\right)-1\right]^{-1} \\
a / b &=\left[\left(k^{\prime}+i k_{x}\right) /\left(k^{\prime}-i k_{x}\right)\right] \cdot e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
r=\frac{e^{2 k^{\prime} t}-1}{1-\beta^{2} e^{2 k^{\prime} t}}
$$

with

$$
\beta=\frac{k^{\prime}-i k_{x}}{k^{\prime}+i k_{x}},
$$

and the fraction of neutrons reflected is

$$
|R|^{2}=|r|^{2}=\frac{e^{2 k^{\prime} t}+e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}-2}{e^{2 k^{\prime} t}+e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}-2 \cos 4 \theta} .
$$

\section{Alternative Solution:}

The solution can also be obtained by superposition of infinite amplitudes, similar to the case of a Fabry-Perot interferometer in optics (see Fig. 1.30).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-101.jpg?height=373&width=346&top_left_y=1177&top_left_x=501)

Fig. $1.30$

We need only consider the x-component of the waves. Let $T_{12}, R_{12}$ denote the coefficients of amplitude transmission and reflection as a wave goes from medium 1 to medium 2, respectively. Let $T_{21}, R_{21}$ denote coefficients of amplitude transmission and reflection from medium 2 to medium 1. Take the amplitude of incident wave as 1 . Then the amplitude of the wave that is transmitted to medium 2 is the sum

$$
\begin{aligned}
T=& T_{12} e^{-\delta} \cdot T_{21}+T_{12} e^{-\delta} \cdot R_{21} e^{-2 \delta} R_{21} \cdot T_{21} \\
&+T_{12} e^{-\delta} \cdot\left(R_{21} e^{-2 \delta} R_{21}\right)^{2} \cdot T_{21}+\cdots \\
=& T_{12} e^{-\delta} T_{21}\left[1+R_{21}^{2} e^{-2 \delta}+\left(R_{21}^{2} e^{-2 \delta}\right)^{2}+\cdots\right] \\
=& T_{12} T_{21} e^{-\delta} \frac{1}{1-R_{21}^{2} e^{-2 \delta}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the above $\exp (-\delta)$ is the attenuation coefficient of a wave in medium 2 , where

$$
\delta=k^{\prime} t \quad \text { with } \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 m E\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right)} / \hbar=\sqrt{2 m E} \sin \theta / \hbar .
$$

From (a) we have the coefficients of transmission and reflection

$$
\begin{gathered}
R_{12}=\left(k_{1 x}-k_{2 x}\right) /\left(k_{1 x}+k_{2 x}\right), \\
T_{12}=1+R_{12}=2 k_{1} /\left(k_{1 x}+k_{2 x}\right) .
\end{gathered}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&k_{1 x}=\sqrt{2 m E} \cos \theta / \hbar, \\
&k_{2 x}=i k^{\prime}=i \sqrt{2 m E} \sin \theta / \hbar,
\end{aligned}
$$

we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T_{12}=2 k_{1 x} /\left(k_{1 x}+k_{2 x}\right)=\frac{2 \cos \theta}{\cos \theta+i \sin \theta}=2 \cos \theta e^{-i \theta} \\
&T_{21}=2 k_{2 x} /\left(k_{1 x}+k_{2 x}\right)=\frac{2 i \sin \theta}{\cos \theta+i \sin \theta}=2 i \sin \theta e^{-i \theta} \\
&R_{21}=\left(k_{2 x}-k_{1 x}\right) /\left(k_{1 x}+k_{2 x}\right)=\frac{i \sin \theta-\cos \theta}{i \sin \theta+\cos \theta}=e^{-2 i \theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=T_{12} T_{21} e^{-\delta} \frac{1}{1-R_{21}^{2} e^{-2 \delta}} \\
&=\frac{4 i \cos \theta \sin \theta e^{-2 i \theta} \cdot e^{-k^{\prime} t}}{1-e^{-4 i \theta} e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}} \\
&=\frac{2 i \sin 2 \theta e^{-2 i \theta} e^{-k^{\prime} t}}{1-e^{-4 i \theta} e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The transmissivity is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
|T|^{2} &=\frac{4 \sin ^{2} 2 \theta e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}}{\left(1-e^{-2 k^{\prime} t} \cos ^{4} \theta\right)^{2}+\left(e^{-2 k^{\prime} t} \sin 4 \theta\right)^{2}} \\
&=\frac{4 \sin ^{2} 2 \theta e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}}{1+e^{-4 k^{\prime} t}-2 e^{-2 k^{\prime} t} \cos 4 \theta} \\
&=\frac{4 \sin ^{2} 2 \theta}{e^{2 k^{\prime} t}+e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}-2 \cos 4 \theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the reflectivity is

$$
\begin{aligned}
1-|T|^{2} &=1-\frac{4 \sin ^{2} 2 \theta}{e^{2 k^{\prime} t}+e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}-2 \cos 4 \theta} \\
&=\frac{e^{2 k^{\prime} t}+e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}-2}{e^{2 k^{\prime} t}+e^{-2 k^{\prime} t}-2 \cos 4 \theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $k^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 m E} \sin \theta / \hbar$.

\section{7}

Find the wave function for a particle moving in one dimension in a constant imaginary potential $-i V$ where $V \ll E$.

Calculate the probability current and show that an imaginary potential represents absorption of particles. Find an expression for the absorption coefficient in terms of $V$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The Schrödinger equation is

$$
i \hbar \partial \psi / \partial t=\left(\hat{p}^{2} / 2 m-i V\right) \psi
$$

Supposing $\psi=\exp (-i E t / \hbar) \exp (i k x)$, we have $k^{2}=\left(2 m E / \hbar^{2}\right)(1+$ $i V / E)$. As $V \ll E$

$$
k \approx \pm \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}\left(1+i \frac{V}{2 E}\right)
$$

and hence

$$
\psi_{\pm}(x, t)=\exp \left(\mp \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \frac{V}{2 E} x\right) \cdot \exp \left(\pm i \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} x\right) \exp \left(-\frac{i E t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

where $\psi_{+}$and $\psi_{-}$refer to the exponentially attenuated right- and lefttraveling waves respectively. The probability current is

$$
\begin{aligned}
j=& \operatorname{Re}\left(\psi^{*} \frac{\hat{p}}{m} \psi\right)=\operatorname{Re}\left(\psi^{*} \frac{\hbar k}{m} \psi\right)=\operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{\hbar k}{m} \exp \left(\mp \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \frac{V}{E} x\right)\right] \\
& \approx \pm \frac{\hbar}{m} \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \exp \left(\mp \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \frac{V}{E} x\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

These are the exponentially attenuated currents in the respective directions. The absorption coefficient is then

$$
\mu=\left|-\frac{1}{j} \frac{d j}{d x}\right|=\left|-\frac{d \ln j}{d x}\right|=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \frac{V}{E} .
$$

The imaginary potential $i V$ is responsible for the absorption of the particle, since the exponent in $j$ would be imaginary. Hence there would be no absorption if $V$ were real.

\section{8}

Let the solution to the one-dimensional free-particle time-dependent Schrödinger equation of definite wavelength $\lambda$ be $\psi(x, t)$ as described by some observer $O$ in a frame with coordinates $(x, t)$. Now consider the same particle as described by wave function $\psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ according to observer $O^{\prime}$ with coordinates $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ related to $(x, t)$ by the Galilean transformation

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{\prime} &=x-v t, \\
t^{\prime} &=t .
\end{aligned}
$$

(a) Do $\psi(x, t), \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ describe waves of the same wavelength?

(b) What is the relationship between $\psi(x, t)$ and $\psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ if both satisfy the Schrödinger equation in their respective coordinates? 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The one-dimensional time-dependent Schrödinger equation for a free particle

$$
i \hbar \partial_{t} \psi(x, t)=\left(-\hbar^{2} / 2 m\right) \partial_{x}^{2} \psi(x, t)
$$

has a solution corresponding to a definite wavelength $\lambda$

$$
\psi_{\lambda}(x, t)=\exp [i(k x-\omega t)]
$$

with

$$
\lambda=2 \pi / k=2 \pi \hbar / p, \quad \omega=\hbar k^{2} / 2 m .
$$

As the particle momentum $p$ is different in the two reference frames, the wavelength $\lambda$ is also different.

(b) Applying the Galilean transformation and making use of the Schrödinger equation in the $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ frame we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
i \hbar \partial_{t} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) &=i \hbar \partial_{t} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t) \\
&=i \hbar\left[\partial_{t}^{\prime} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)-v \partial_{x}^{\prime} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right] \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \partial_{x}^{\prime 2} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)-i \hbar v \partial_{x}^{\prime} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \partial_{x}^{2} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t)-i \hbar v \partial_{x} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t)
\end{aligned}
$$

Considering

$$
\begin{aligned}
&i \hbar \partial_{t}\left[e^{i(k x-\omega t)} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right] \\
&\quad=i \hbar e^{i(k x-\omega t)}\left(\partial_{t} \psi^{\prime}-i \omega \psi^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
&-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \partial_{x}^{2}\left[e^{i(k x-\omega t)} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right] \\
&\quad=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} e^{i(k x-\omega t)}\left(-k^{2} \psi^{\prime}+2 i k \partial_{x} \psi^{\prime}+\partial_{x}^{2} \psi^{\prime}\right) \\
&\quad=i \hbar e^{i(k x-\omega t)}\left(\partial_{t} \psi^{\prime}-i \omega \psi^{\prime}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

making use of Eq. (1) and the definitions of $k$ and $\omega$, we see that

$$
\begin{array}{r}
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \partial_{x}^{2}\left[e^{i m v x / \hbar} e^{-i m v^{2} t / 2 \hbar} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t)\right] \\
=i \hbar \partial_{t}\left[e^{i m v x / \hbar} e^{-i m v^{2} t / 2 \hbar} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t)\right]
\end{array}
$$

This is just the Schrödinger equation that $\psi(x, t)$ satisfies. Hence, accurate to a phase factor, we have the relation

$$
\psi(x, t)=\psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t) \exp \left\{\frac{i}{\hbar}\left[m v x-\frac{m v^{2}}{2} t\right]\right\}
$$

\section{9}

A particle of mass $m$ bound in a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential of frequency $\omega$ and in the ground state is subjected to an impulsive force $p \delta(t)$.

Find the probability it remains in its ground state.

$($ Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The particle receives an instantaneous momentum $p$ at $t=0$ and its velocity changes to $p / m$ instantaneously. The duration of the impulse is, however, too short for the wave function to change. Hence, in the view of a frame $K^{\prime}$ moving with the particle, the latter is still in the ground state of the harmonic oscillator $\psi_{0}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$. But in the view of a stationary frame $K$, it is in the state $\psi_{0}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \exp (-i p x / \hbar)$. We may reasonably treat the position of the particle as constant during the process, so that at the end of the impulse the coordinate of the particle is the same for both $K$ and $K^{\prime}$. Hence the initial wave function in $K$ is

$$
\psi_{0}^{\prime}=\psi_{0}(x) \exp (-i p x / \hbar)
$$

Thus, the probability that the particle remains in its ground state after the impulse is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{0} &=\left|\left\langle\psi_{0}\left|\exp \left(-i \frac{p x}{\hbar}\right)\right| \psi_{0}\right\rangle\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{\alpha^{2}}{\pi}\left|\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} e^{-\alpha^{2} x^{2}-i \frac{p x}{\hbar}} d x\right|^{2} \\
&=\exp \left(-\frac{p^{2}}{2 \alpha^{2} \hbar^{2}}\right)\left|\frac{\alpha}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\alpha^{2}\left(x+\frac{i p}{2 \alpha^{2} \hbar}\right)^{2}\right] d x\right|^{2} \\
&=\exp \left(\frac{-p^{2}}{2 m \omega \hbar}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\alpha=\sqrt{m \omega / \hbar}$.

\section{0}

An idealized ping pong ball of mass $m$ is bouncing in its ground state on a recoilless table in a one-dimensional world with only a vertical direction.

(a) Prove that the energy depends on $m, g, h$ according to: $\varepsilon=K m g$ $\left(m^{2} g / h^{2}\right)^{\alpha}$ and determine $\alpha$.

(b) By a variational calculation estimate the constant $K$ and evaluate $\varepsilon$ for $m=1$ gram in ergs.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) By the method of dimensional analysis, if we have

$$
[\varepsilon]=\frac{[m]^{1+2 \alpha}[g]^{1+\alpha}}{[h]^{2 \alpha}}
$$

or

$$
\frac{[m][L]^{2}}{[T]^{2}}=\frac{[m][L]^{1-3 \alpha}}{[T]^{2}}
$$

then $\alpha=-\frac{1}{3}$. Thus, provided $\alpha=-\frac{1}{3}$, the expression gives the energy of the ball.

(b) Take the $x$ coordinate in the vertical up direction with origin at the table. The Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}+m g x=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+m g x
$$

taking the table surface as the reference point of gravitational potential. Try a ground state wave function of the form $\psi=x \exp \left(-\lambda x^{2} / 2\right)$, where $\lambda$ is to be determined. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle H\rangle &=\frac{\int \psi^{*} H \psi d x}{\int \psi^{*} \psi d x} \\
&=\frac{\int_{0}^{\infty} x e^{-\lambda x^{2} / 2}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+m g x\right) x e^{-\lambda x^{2} / 2} d x}{\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{2} e^{-\lambda x^{2}} d x} \\
&=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{4 m} \lambda+\frac{2 m g}{\sqrt{\pi} \lambda^{1 / 2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

To minimize $\langle H\rangle$, take $\frac{d\langle H\rangle}{d \lambda}=0$ and obtain $\lambda=\left(\frac{4 m^{2} g}{3 \sqrt{\pi} \hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}$.

The ground state energy is then

$$
\langle H\rangle=3(3 / 4 \pi)^{1 / 3} m g\left(m^{2} g / \hbar^{2}\right)^{-1 / 3} .
$$

giving

$$
K=3(3 / 4 \pi)^{1 / 3} .
$$

Numerically

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varepsilon &=3 m g\left(\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{4 \pi m^{2} g}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} \\
&=3 \times 980 \times\left(\frac{3 \times 1.054^{2} \times 10^{-54}}{4 \pi \times 980}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} \\
&=1.9 \times 10^{-16} \mathrm{erg} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{1}

The following theorem concerns the energy eigenvalues $E_{n}\left(E_{1}<E_{2}<\right.$ $E_{3}<\ldots$ ) of the Schrödinger equation in one dimension:

Theorem: If the potential $V_{1}(x)$ gives the eigenvalues $E_{1 n}$ and the potential $V_{2}(x)$ gives the eigenvalues $E_{2 n}$ and $V_{1}(x) \leq V_{2}(x)$ for all $x$, then $E_{1 n} \leq E_{2 n}$.

(a) Prove this theorem. Hint: Consider a potential $V(\lambda, x)$, where $V(0, x)=V_{1}(x)$ and $V(1, x)$ $=V_{2}(x)$ and $\partial V / \partial \lambda \geq 0$ (for all $x$ ), and calculate $\partial E_{n} / \partial \lambda$.

(b) Now consider the potential (Fig. 1.31)

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
U(x)=k x^{2} / 2, & |x|<a, \\
U(x)=k a^{2} / 2, & |x| \geq a .
\end{array}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-109.jpg?height=300&width=540&top_left_y=551&top_left_x=408)

Fig. $1.31$

We want to determine the number of bound states that this potential can hold. Assume this number $N$ is $\gg 1$. It may be helpful to draw a qualitative picture of the wave function for the highest bound state.

Choose a solvable comparison potential and use the theorem above to determine either a rigorous upper bound to $N$ or a rigorous lower bound to $N$. (Both can be done but you are asked for only one.)

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Define $V(\lambda, x)=\lambda V_{2}(x)+(1-\lambda) V_{1}(x)$. Obviously $V(0, x)=$ $V_{1}(x), V(1, x)=V_{2}(x), \partial V / \partial \lambda=V_{2}(x)-V_{1}(x) \geq 0$. The Hamiltonian is then

$$
\hat{H}(\lambda)=\hat{p}^{2} / 2 m+V(\lambda, x),
$$

and the eigenequation is

$$
\hat{H}(\lambda)|n, \lambda\rangle=E_{n}(\lambda)|n, \lambda\rangle
$$

where $E_{n}(\lambda)=\langle n, \lambda|\hat{H}(\lambda)| n, \lambda\rangle$. As 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial E_{n}(\lambda) / \partial \lambda &=\frac{\partial}{\partial \lambda}[\langle n, \lambda|\hat{H}(\lambda)| n, \lambda\rangle] \\
&=\langle n \lambda|\partial V(\lambda) / \partial \lambda| n \lambda\rangle \\
&=\int \frac{\partial V}{\partial \lambda}\left|\psi_{n}(x, \lambda)\right|^{2} d x \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $E_{1 n}=E_{n}(0) \leq E_{n}(1)=E_{2 n}$, and the theorem is proved. Note that we have used $\langle n \lambda \mid n \lambda\rangle=1$.

(b) Let $V(x)=k x^{2} / 2$. Then $V(x) \geq U(x)$. If $E_{n}$ is an energy level for the potential $U(x)$, then $E_{n} \leq(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega$, where $\omega=\sqrt{k / m}$. For a bound state, $E_{n} \leq k a^{2} / 2$. Solving $(N+1 / 2) \hbar \omega \leq k a^{2} / 2$, we find

$$
N \leq \frac{m \omega a^{2}}{2 \hbar}-\frac{1}{2}=\left[\frac{m \omega a^{2}}{2 \hbar}\right]
$$

where $[A]$ indicates the maximum integer that is less than $A$.

We now choose for $V(x)$ a square well of finite depth,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=k a^{2} / 2, & |x|>a, \\
V(x)=0, & |x| \leq a .
\end{array}
$$

The number of bound states of $U(x)$ is less than that of $V(x)$, which for the latter is $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]+1$. We can take the upper bound to the number of bound states of $U(x)$ as $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]$ as for $N \gg 1$ the term 1 can be neglected. Taken together, we get that the number of bound states is between $\left[m \omega a^{2} / 2 \hbar\right]$ and $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]$.

\section{2}

For electronic states in a one-dimensional system, a simple model Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\sum_{n=1}^{N} E_{0}|n\rangle\langle n|+\sum_{n=1}^{N} W\{|n\rangle\langle n+1|+| n+1\rangle\langle n|\}
$$
