where $|n\rangle$ are an orthonormal basis, $\left\langle n \mid n^{\prime}\right\rangle=\delta_{n n^{\prime}} ; E_{0}$ and $W$ are parameters. Assume periodic boundary conditions so that $|N+j\rangle=|j\rangle$. Calculate the energy levels and wave functions. 

\section{Solution:}

From the fact that $|n\rangle$ form a complete set of orthonormal functions, where $n=1,2,3, \ldots, N$, and

$$
\hat{H}=\sum_{n=1}^{N} E_{0}|n\rangle\langle n|+\sum_{n=1}^{N} W\{|n\rangle\langle n+1|+| n+1\rangle\langle n|\}
$$

or

$$
\hat{H}=E_{0}+W\left(A+A^{+}\right),
$$

with

$$
A \equiv \sum_{n=1}^{N}|n\rangle\left\langle n+1\left|, A^{+} \equiv \sum_{n=1}^{N}\right| n+1\right\rangle\langle n|
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
&A|n\rangle=|n-1\rangle, A^{+}|n\rangle=|n+1\rangle, \\
&A A^{+}=A^{+} A=1, \quad \text { or } \quad A^{+}=A^{-1},
\end{aligned}
$$

we know that $\hat{H}, A$ and $A^{+}$have the same eigenvectors. Hence we only need to find the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of the operator $A^{+}$to solve the problem. As

$$
A_{k^{\prime} k}=\left\langle k^{\prime}|A| k\right\rangle=\delta_{k^{\prime}, k-1}
$$

We have

$$
A=\left(\begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & 1 & 0 & \cdot & \cdot & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & \cdot & \cdot & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & \cdot & \cdot \\
\cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot \\
\cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & 0 & 1 \\
1 & 0 & 0 & \cdot & \cdot & 0
\end{array}\right)_{N \times N}
$$

and so

$$
A-\lambda I=\left(\begin{array}{cccccc}
-\lambda & 1 & 0 & \cdot & \cdot & 0 \\
0 & -\lambda & 1 & . & \cdot & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -\lambda & 1 & \cdot & \cdot \\
\cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot \\
\cdot & . & \cdot & \cdot & -\lambda & 1 \\
1 & 0 & 0 & \cdot & \cdot & -\lambda
\end{array}\right)_{N \times N}
$$

i.e.,

$$
\operatorname{det}(A-\lambda I)=(-\lambda)^{N}+(-1)^{N+1}=(-1)^{N}\left(\lambda^{N}-1\right)=0
$$

giving

$$
\lambda_{j}=e^{i \theta_{j}}, \theta_{j}=\frac{2 \pi}{N} j, j=0,1,2, \ldots, N-1 .
$$

If $|E\rangle$ are the same eigenvectors of the operators $A$ and $A^{+}$, i.e.,

$$
A\left|E_{j}\right\rangle=\lambda_{j}\left|E_{j}\right\rangle, A^{+}\left|E_{j}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\lambda_{j}}\left|E_{j}\right\rangle
$$

then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H}\left|E_{j}\right\rangle &=\left[E_{0}+W\left(\lambda_{j}+\frac{1}{\lambda_{j}}\right)\right]\left|E_{j}\right\rangle \\
&=\left(E_{0}+2 W \cos \theta_{j}\right)\left|E_{j}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the eigenvalues of $\hat{H}$ are

$$
E_{j}=E_{0}+2 W \cos \theta_{j}, \quad \text { with } \quad \theta_{j}=\frac{2 \pi}{N} j, \quad(j=0,1,2, \ldots, N-1) .
$$

The corresponding eigenfunctions can be obtained from the matrix equations

$$
\left(A-\lambda_{j}\right)\left|E_{j}\right\rangle=0 .
$$

Thus

$$
\left|E_{i}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
e^{i \theta_{j}} \\
e^{i 2 \theta_{j}} \\
\vdots \\
e^{i(N-1) \theta_{j}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

or

$$
\left|E_{j}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{n=1}^{N} e^{i(n-1) \theta_{j}}|n\rangle
$$

\section{3}

Give a brief discussion of why there are energy bands in a crystalline solid. Use the ideas of quantum mechanics but do not attempt to carry out any complicated calculations. You should assume that anyone reading your discussion understands quantum mechanics but does not understand anything about the theory of solids.

$(W i s c o n s i n)$

\section{Solution:}

A crystal may be regarded as an infinite, periodic array of potential wells, such as the lattice structure given in Problem 1065. Bloch's theorem states that the solution to the Schrödinger equation then has the form $u(x) \exp (i K x)$, where $K$ is a constant and $u(x)$ is periodic with the periodicity of the lattice. The continuity conditions of $u(x)$ and $d u(x) / d x$ at the well boundaries limit the energy of the propagating particle to certain ranges of values, i.e., energy bands. An example is given in detail in Problem 1065.

\section{4}

A particle of mass $m$ moves in one dimension in a periodic potential of infinite extent. The potential is zero at most places, but in narrow regions of width $b$ separated by spaces of length a $(b \ll a)$ the potential is $V_{0}$, where $V_{0}$ is a large positive potential.

[One may think of the potential as a sum of Dirac delta functions:

$$
V(x)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} V_{0} b \delta(x-n a)
$$

Alternatively one can arrive at the same answer in a somewhat more messy way by treating the intervals as finite and then going to the limit.]

(a) What are the appropriate boundary conditions to apply to the wave function, and why? (b) Let the lowest energy of a wave that can propagate through this potential be $E_{0}=\hbar^{2} k_{0}^{2} / 2 m$ (this defines $k_{0}$ ). Write down a transcendental equation (not a differential equation) that can be solved to give $k_{0}$ and thus $E_{0}$.

(c) Write down the wave function at energy $E_{0}$ valid in the region $0 \leq$ $x \leq a$ (For uniformity, let us choose normalization and phase such that $\psi(x=0)=1$ ). What happens to the wave function between $x=a$ and $x=a+b ?$

(d) Show that there are ranges of values of $E$, greater than $E_{0}$, for which there is no eigenfunction. Find (exactly) the energy at which the first such gap begins.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Schrödinger equation is

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} V_{0} b \delta(x-n a)\right] \psi(x)=E \psi(x)
$$

Integrating it from $x=a-\varepsilon$ to $x=a+\varepsilon$ and letting $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$, we get

$$
\psi^{\prime}\left(a^{+}\right)-\psi^{\prime}\left(a^{-}\right)=2 \Omega \psi(a)
$$

where $\Omega=m V_{0} b / \hbar^{2}$. This and the other boundary condition

$$
\psi\left(a^{+}\right)-\psi\left(a^{-}\right)=0
$$

apply to the wave function at $x=n a$, where $n=-\infty, \ldots,-1,0,1, \ldots$, $+\infty$.

(b) For $x \neq n a$, there are two fundamental solutions to the Schrödinger equation:

$$
u_{1}(x)=e^{i k x}, \quad u_{2}(x)=e^{-i k x}
$$

the corresponding energy being

$$
E=\hbar^{2} k^{2} / 2 m
$$

Let

$$
\psi(x)=A e^{i k x}+B e^{-i k x}, \quad 0 \leq x \leq a
$$

According to Bloch's Theorem, in the region $a \leq x \leq 2 a$

$$
\psi(x)=e^{i K a}\left[A e^{i k(x-a)}+B e^{-i k(x-a)}\right]
$$

where $K$ is the Bloch wave number. The boundary conditions give

$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{i K a}(A+B)=& A e^{i k a}+B e^{-i k a} \\
i k e^{i K a}(A-B)=& i k\left(A e^{i k a}-B e^{-i k a}\right) \\
&+2 \Omega\left(A e^{i k a}+B e^{-i k a}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For nonzero solutions of $A$ and $B$ we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
e^{i K a}-e^{i k a} & e^{i K a}-e^{-i k a} \\
i k e^{i K a}-(i k+2 \Omega) e^{i k a} & -i k e^{i K a}+(i k-2 \Omega) e^{-i k a}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

or

$$
\cos k a+\frac{\Omega}{k} \sin k a=\cos K a,
$$

which determines the Bloch wave number $K$. Consequently, the allowed values of $k$ are limited to the range given by

$$
\left|\cos k a+\frac{\Omega}{k} \sin k a\right| \leq 1
$$

or

$$
\left(\cos k a+\frac{\Omega}{k} \sin k a\right)^{2} \leq 1 .
$$

$k_{0}$ is the minimum of $k$ that satisfy this inequality.

(c) For $E=E_{0}$

$$
\psi(x)=A e^{i k_{0} x}+B e^{-i k_{0} x}, \quad 0 \leq x \leq a
$$

where $k_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E_{0}}{\hbar}}$.

Normalization $\psi(x=0)=1$ gives

$$
\psi(x)=2 i A \sin k_{0} x+e^{-i k_{0} x}, \quad 0 \leq x \leq a .
$$

The boundary conditions at $x=a$ give

$$
e^{i K a}=2 i A \sin k_{0} a+e^{-i k_{0} a},
$$

or

$$
2 i A=\left(e^{i K a}-e^{-i k_{0} a}\right) / \sin k_{0} a
$$

So

$$
\psi(x)=\left(e^{i K a}-e^{-i k_{0} a}\right) \frac{\sin k_{0} x}{\sin k_{0} a}+e^{-i k_{0} x}, \quad 0 \leq x \leq a .
$$

For $x \in[a, a+b]$, the wave function has the form $\exp \left(\pm k_{1}, x\right)$, where

$$
k_{1}=\sqrt{2 m\left(V_{0}-E_{0}\right)} / \hbar .
$$

(d) For $k a=n \pi+\delta$, where $\delta$ is a small positive number, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left|\cos k a+\frac{\Omega}{k} \sin k a\right| \\
=&\left|\cos (n \pi+\delta)+\frac{\Omega}{k} \sin (n \pi+\delta)\right| \\
\approx &\left|1-\frac{\delta^{2}}{2}+\frac{\Omega}{k} \delta\right| \leq 1 .
\end{aligned}
$$

When $\delta$ is quite small, the left side $\approx 1+\Omega \delta / k>1$. Therefore in a certain region of $k>n \pi / a$, there is no eigenfunction. On the other hand, $k a=n \pi$ corresponds to eigenvalues. So the energy at which the first energy gap begins satisfies the relation $k a=\pi$, or $E=\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 m a^{2}$.

\section{5}

We wish to study particle-wave propagation in a one-dimensional periodic potential constructed by iterating a "single-potential" $V(x)$ at intervals of length $l$. $V(x)$ vanishes for $|x| \geq l / 2$ and is symmetric in $x$ (i.e., $V(x)=V(-x))$. The scattering properties of $V(x)$ can be summarized as follows:

If a wave is incident from the left, $\psi_{+}(x)=\exp (i k x)$ for $x<-l / 2$, it produces a transmitted wave $\psi_{+}(x)=\exp (i k x)$ for $x>l / 2$ and a reflected wave $\psi_{-}(x)=\exp (-i k x)$ for $x<-l / 2$. Transmitted and reflected coefficients are given by

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
T(x)=\frac{\psi_{+}(|x|)}{\psi_{+}(-|x|)}=\frac{1}{2} e^{2 i k|x|}\left[e^{2 i \delta_{e}}+e^{2 i \delta_{0}}\right], & |x| \geq \frac{l}{2}, \\
R(x)=\frac{\psi_{-}(-|x|)}{\psi_{+}(-|x|)} \approx \frac{1}{2} e^{2 i k|x|}\left[e^{2 i \delta_{e}}-e^{2 i \delta_{0}}\right], & |x| \geq \frac{l}{2},
\end{array}
$$

and $\delta_{e}$ and $\delta_{0}$ are the phase shifts due to the potential $V(x)$. Take these results as given. Do not derive them.

Now consider an infinite periodic potential $V_{\infty}(x)$ constructed by iterating the potential $V(x)$ with centers separated by a distance $l$ (Fig. 1.32). Call the points at which $V_{\infty}(x)=0$ "interpotential points". We shall attempt to construct waves propagating in the potential $V_{\infty}(x)$ as superpositions of left- and right-moving waves $\phi_{+}$and $\phi_{-}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-117.jpg?height=352&width=800&top_left_y=525&top_left_x=272)

Fig. 1.32

(a) Write recursion relations which relate the amplitudes of the rightand left-moving waves at the $n$th interpotential point, $\phi_{\pm}^{n}$, to the amplitudes at the $(n-1)$ th and $(n+1)$ th interpotential points, $\phi_{\pm}^{n-1}$ and $\phi_{\pm}^{n+1}$.

(b) Obtain a recursion relation for $\phi_{-}$or $\phi_{+}$alone by eliminating the other from part (a).

(c) Obtain an expression for the ratio of amplitudes of $\phi_{+}$to $\phi_{-}$at successive interpotential points.

(d) Find the condition on $k, \delta_{e}$ and $\delta_{0}$ such that traveling waves are allowed.

(e) Use this result to explain why it is "normal" for conduction by electrons in metals to be allowed only for bands of values of energy.

\section{Solution:}

For the wave incident from the left, the potential being $V(x)$, let

$$
\begin{gathered}
\psi_{t+}=t \phi_{+} e^{i k x}, \quad t=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i 2 \delta_{e}}+e^{i 2 \delta_{0}}\right) \\
\psi_{r-}=r \phi_{-} e^{-i k x}, \quad r=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i 2 \delta_{e}}-e^{i 2 \delta_{0}}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

For the wave incident from the right, let the transmission and reflection coefficients be $t^{\prime}$ and $r^{\prime}$ respectively. It can be shown that $t^{\prime}=t, r^{\prime}=$ $-r^{*} t / t^{*}$. In the periodic potential, the transmission and reflection coefficients at adjacent interpotential points have relations $t_{n}=t_{n-1}$ and $r_{n}=r_{n-1} \exp (i 2 k l)$. So the transmission coefficient can be denoted by a single notation $t$.

(a) The waves at adjacent interpotential points are as shown in Fig. 1.33. Obviously, only the reflection term of $\phi_{-}^{n}$ and the transmission term of $\phi_{+}^{n-1}$ contribute to $\phi_{+}^{n}$ :

$$
\phi_{+}^{n}=r_{n-1}^{\prime} \phi_{-}^{n}+t \phi_{+}^{n-1} .
$$

Similarly,

$$
\phi_{-}^{n}=r_{n} \phi_{+}^{n}+t^{\prime} \phi_{-}^{n+1}
$$

Thus we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi_{+}^{n} &=e^{i 2 k l} r_{n}^{\prime} \phi_{-}^{n}+t \phi_{+}^{n-1} \\
\phi_{-}^{n} &=r_{n} \phi_{+}^{n}+t \phi_{-}^{n+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
\phi_{+}^{n-1} & \phi_{+}^{n} & \phi_{+}^{n+1} \\
\rightarrow & \rightarrow & \rightarrow \\
\leftarrow & \leftarrow & \leftarrow \\
\phi_{-}^{n-1} & \phi_{-}^{n} & \phi_{-}^{n+1}
\end{array}
$$

Fig. 1.33

(b) With $n$ replaced by $n+1, \mathrm{Eq}$. (1) gives

$$
\phi_{+}^{n+1}=r_{n}^{\prime} \phi_{-}^{n+1}+t \phi_{+}^{n}
$$

Equations (3), (4), (5) then give

$$
\phi_{+}^{n}=\frac{t\left(\phi_{+}^{n-1}+e^{i 2 k l} \phi_{+}^{n+1}\right)}{1+t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r_{n} r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}} .
$$

Let $r_{0}=r$. Then $r_{n}=r \exp (i 2 n k l)$. Assume $r_{n}^{\prime}=-r_{n}^{*} t / t^{*}$. Then $r_{n}^{\prime}=r^{\prime} \exp (-i 2 n k l)$. Hence

$$
\phi_{+}^{n}=\frac{t\left(\phi_{+}^{n-1}+e^{i 2 k l} \phi_{+}^{n+1}\right)}{1+t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}}
$$

Similarly,

$$
\phi_{-}^{n}=\frac{t\left(\phi_{-}^{n+1}+e^{i 2 k l} \phi_{-}^{n-1}\right)}{1+t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}} .
$$

(c) As the period of the potential is $l$, if $\psi(x)$ is the wave function in the region $\left[x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right]$, then $\psi(x-l) \exp (i \delta)$ is the wave function in the region $\left[x_{n}, x_{n+1}\right]$. Thus

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\phi_{+}^{n+1}=e^{i(\delta-k l)} \phi_{+}^{n} \\
\phi_{-}^{n+1}=e^{i(\delta+k l)} \phi_{-}^{n} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Let $c_{n}=\phi_{+}^{n} / \phi_{-}^{n}$. From (4) and (5) we obtain respectively

$$
\begin{gathered}
1=r_{n} c_{n}+t \frac{\phi_{-}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}, \\
\frac{\phi_{+}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}=r_{n}^{\prime} \frac{\phi_{-}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}+t c_{n} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Using (7), (9) can be written as

$$
c_{n} e^{-i 2 k l} \frac{\phi_{-}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}=r_{n}^{\prime} \frac{\phi_{-}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}+t c_{n}
$$

or, using (8),

$$
c_{n} e^{-i 2 k l}\left(1-r_{n} c_{n}\right)=r_{n}^{\prime}\left(1-r_{n} c_{n}\right)+t^{2} c_{n}
$$

i.e.,

$$
r_{n} c_{n}^{2}+\left(t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r_{n} r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}-1\right) c_{n}+r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}=0
$$

Solving for $c_{n}$ we have

$$
c_{n}=\frac{\left(1+r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}-t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}\right) \pm \sqrt{\Delta}}{2 r_{n}}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta &=\left(t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r_{n} r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}-1\right)^{2}-4 r_{n} r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l} \\
&=\left(t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}-1\right)^{2}-4 r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}
\end{aligned}
$$

(d) The necessary condition for a stable wave to exist in the infinite periodic field is

$$
\phi_{+}^{n+1} / \phi_{+}^{n}=e^{i \delta_{1}} \text {, }
$$

where $\delta_{1}$ is real and independent of $n$. If this were not so, when $n \rightarrow \infty$ one of $\phi_{+}^{n}$ and $\phi_{+}^{(-n)}$ would be infinite. From (7), we see that $\delta_{1}=\delta-k l$. From (6), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l} &=t\left(\frac{\phi_{+}^{n-1}}{\phi_{+}^{n}}+e^{i 2 k l} \frac{\phi_{+}^{n+1}}{\phi_{+}^{n}}\right) \\
&=t\left[e^{i(k l-\delta)}+e^{i(k l+\delta)}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting $r^{\prime}=-r^{*} t / t^{*}$ in the above equation and using $r r^{*}+t t^{*}=1$, we obtain

$$
t e^{i k l}+t^{*} e^{-i k l}=2 t t^{*} \cos \delta,
$$

which means

$$
\left|\frac{t e^{i k l}+t^{*} e^{-i k l}}{2 t t^{*}}\right| \leq 1
$$

or, using the definition of $t$,

$$
\left|\frac{\cos \left(2 \delta_{e}+k l\right)+\cos \left(2 \delta_{0}+k l\right)}{1+\cos \left[2\left(\delta_{e}-\delta_{0}\right)\right]}\right| \leq 1
$$

i.e.,

$$
\left|\frac{\cos \left(\delta_{e}+\delta_{0}+k l\right)}{\cos \left(\delta_{e}-\delta_{0}\right)}\right| \leq 1
$$

In general, only some of the values of $k$ satisfy the above inequality, i.e., only energy values in certain regions are allowed while the others are forbidden. Thus we obtain the band structure of energy levels.

(e) In metals, the distribution of positive ions is regular and so the conduction electrons move in a periodic potential. (d) Shows that the electron waves can only have certain $k$ values, corresponding to bands of electron energies.

\section{6}

You are given a real operator $\hat{A}$ satisfying the quadratic equation

$$
\hat{A}^{2}-3 \hat{A}+2=0 .
$$

This is the lowest-order equation that $\hat{A}$ obeys.
(a) What are the eigenvalues of $\hat{A}$ ?
(b) What are the eigenstates of $\hat{A}$ ?
(c) Prove that $\hat{A}$ is an observable.

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $\hat{A}$ satisfies a quadratic equation it can be represented by a $2 \times 2$ matrix. Its eigenvalues are the roots of the quadratic equation $\lambda^{2}-3 \lambda+2=$ $0, \lambda_{1}=1, \lambda_{2}=2$.

(b) $\hat{A}$ is represented by the matrix

$$
\hat{A}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 2
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

The eigenvalue equation

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 2
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\lambda\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)
$$

then gives $a=1, b=0$ for $\lambda=1$ and $a=0, b=1$ for $\lambda=2$. Hence the eigenstates of $\hat{A}$ are $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$.

(c) Since $\hat{A}=\hat{A}^{+}, \hat{A}$ is Hermitian and hence an observable.

\section{7}

If $\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle$ is any eigenstate of the electric charge operator $Q$ corresponding to eigenvalue $q$, that is to say,

$$
Q\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=q\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle
$$

the "charge conjugation" operator $C$ applied to $\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle$ leads to an eigenstate $\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle$ of $Q$ corresponding to eigenvalue $-q$ :

$$
C\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle .
$$
(a) Find the eigenvalues of the operator $C Q+Q C$.
(b) Can a state simultaneously be an eigenstate of $C$ and of $Q$ ?

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let

$$
|\psi\rangle=\sum_{q} c_{q}\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle
$$

Then

$$
(C Q+Q C)\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=q C\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle+Q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle=q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle-q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle=0
$$

Thus the eigenvalue of the operator $C Q+Q C$ is zero.

(b) As $C$ is the charge conjugation transformation, $C Q C^{-1}=-Q$, or $C Q+Q C=0$, i.e., $C$ and $Q$ do not commute (they anticommute) they cannot have common eigenstates. (Unless $q=0$, in which case it is quite meaningless to introduce charge conjugation.)

\section{8}

A quantum-mechanical system is known to possess only two energy eigenstates denoted $|1\rangle$ and $|2\rangle$. The system also includes three other observables (besides the energy), known as $P, Q$ and $R$. The states $|1\rangle$ and |2) are normalized but they are not necessarily eigenstates of $P, Q$ or $R$. Determine as many of the eigenvalues of $P, Q$ and $R$ as possible on the basis of the following sets of "experimental data". [Warning: one data set is unphysical.]
(a) $\langle 1|P| 1\rangle=1 / 2, \quad\left\langle 1\left|P^{2}\right| 1\right\rangle=1 / 4$.
(b) $\langle 1|Q| 1\rangle=1 / 2, \quad\left\langle 1\left|Q^{2}\right| 1\right\rangle=1 / 6$.
(c) $\langle 1|R| 1\rangle=1, \quad\left\langle 1\left|R^{2}\right| 1\right\rangle=5 / 4,\left\langle 1\left|R^{3}\right| 1\right\rangle=7 / 4$. 

\section{Solution:}

We are given three observables $P, Q, R$, which satisfy the Hermiticity $\langle n|P| m\rangle=\langle m|P| n\rangle^{*}$, and that the mechanical system has a complete set of energy eigenstates $|1\rangle$ and $|2\rangle$. give

(a) The completeness of the two states and the "experimental data",

$$
P|1\rangle=\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle+\alpha|2\rangle,
$$

where $\alpha$ is a constant to be determined. The orthogonality of the eigenstates and the Hermiticity of $P$ give

$$
\langle 1|P| 2\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\langle 1 \mid 2\rangle+\alpha^{2}\langle 2 \mid 2\rangle=\alpha^{*} .
$$

So we have

$$
P|2\rangle=\alpha^{*}|1\rangle+\beta|2\rangle,
$$

where $\beta$ is to be determined. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
P^{2}|1\rangle &=P(P|1\rangle) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} P|1\rangle+\alpha P|2\rangle=\left(1 / 4+\alpha^{*} \alpha\right)|1\rangle+(\alpha / 2+\alpha \beta)|2\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $P^{2}|1\rangle=\frac{1}{4}$ according to experiment, $\alpha^{*} \alpha=0$ and hence $\alpha=0$. Therefore,

$$
P|1\rangle=\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle,
$$

i.e., at least one of the eigenvalues of $P$ is $1 / 2$.

(b) Let

$$
Q|1\rangle=\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle+\gamma|2\rangle,
$$

where $\gamma$ is to be determined. By a similar procedure, we get $\gamma^{*} \gamma=1 / 6-$ $1 / 4<0$. So this data set is unphysical and the eigenvalue of $Q$ could not be determined.

(c) As $\langle 1|R| 1\rangle=1$, we can write

$$
R|1\rangle=|1\rangle+\lambda|2\rangle,
$$

where $\lambda$ is to be determined. Then

$$
\langle 1|R| 2\rangle=\langle 1 \mid 2\rangle+\lambda^{*}\langle 2 \mid 2\rangle=\lambda^{*}
$$

showing that

$$
R|2\rangle=\lambda^{*}|1\rangle+\eta|2\rangle .
$$

where $\eta$ is to be determined. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
R^{2}|1\rangle &=R|1\rangle+\lambda R|2\rangle \\
&=|1\rangle+\lambda|2\rangle+\lambda \lambda^{*}|1\rangle+\lambda \eta|2\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then as

$$
\left\langle 1\left|R^{2}\right| 1\right\rangle=1+\lambda \lambda^{*}=\frac{5}{4},
$$

we have

$$
\lambda \lambda^{*}=\frac{1}{4},
$$

and so

$$
\lambda=\frac{1}{2} \exp (i \delta),
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
R|1\rangle &=|1\rangle+\frac{1}{2} e^{i \delta}|2\rangle \\
R|2\rangle &=\frac{1}{2} e^{-i \delta}|1\rangle+\eta|2\rangle \\
R^{2}|1\rangle &=\frac{5}{4}|1\rangle+\frac{1}{2}(1+\eta) e^{i \delta}|2\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows also

$$
\begin{aligned}
R^{3}|1\rangle=& \frac{5}{4} R|1\rangle+\frac{1}{2}(1+\eta) e^{i \delta} R|2\rangle \\
=& \frac{5}{4}|1\rangle+\frac{5}{8} e^{i \delta}|2\rangle+\frac{1}{4}(1+\eta)|1\rangle \\
&+\frac{1}{2}(1+\eta) \eta e^{i \delta}|2\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Experimentally $\left\langle 1\left|R^{3}\right| 1\right\rangle=\frac{7}{4}$. Thus $\frac{5}{4}+\frac{1}{4}(1+\eta)=\frac{7}{4}$, giving $\eta=1$. Hence on the bases $|1\rangle$ and $|2\rangle$ the matrix of $R$ is

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \frac{1}{2} e^{-i \delta} \\
\frac{1}{2} e^{i \delta} & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

To find the eigenvalues of $R$, solve

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
1-\lambda & \frac{1}{2} e^{-i \delta} \\
\frac{1}{2} e^{i \delta} & 1-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

i.e., $(1-\lambda)^{2}-\frac{1}{4}=\left(1-\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(1-\lambda+\frac{1}{2}\right)=0$, and obtain the eigenvalues of $R=\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{2}$.

\section{9}

For a charged particle in a magnetic field, find the commutation rules for the operators corresponding to the components of the velocity.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the magnetic field arises from a vector potential A. Then the velocity components of the particle are

$$
\hat{v}_{i}=\hat{P}_{i} / m-q A_{i} / m c .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\hat{v}_{i}, \hat{v}_{j}\right] } &=\frac{1}{m^{2}}\left[\hat{P}_{i}-\frac{q}{c} A_{i}, \hat{P}_{j}-\frac{q}{c} A_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{q}{m^{2} c}\left\{\left[\hat{p}_{j}, A_{i}\right]-\left[\hat{p}_{i}, A_{j}\right]\right\}=\frac{i \hbar q}{m c^{2}}\left(\frac{\partial A_{j}}{\partial x_{i}}-\frac{\partial A_{i}}{\partial x_{j}}\right) \\
&=\frac{i \hbar q}{m^{2} c} \sum_{k=1}^{3} \varepsilon_{i j k} B_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\varepsilon_{i j k}$ is the Levi-Civita density, use having been made of the correspondence rule $\hat{p}_{i} \rightarrow \frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i}}$. 

\section{0}

Using the coordinate-momentum commutation relation prove that

$$
\sum_{n}\left(E_{n}-E_{0}\right) \mid\langle n|x| 0\rangle^{2}=\mathrm{constant}
$$

where $E_{n}$ is the energy corresponding to the eigenstate $|n\rangle$. Obtain the value of the constant. The Hamiltonian has the form $H=p^{2} / 2 M+V(x)$.

\section{Solution:}

As

$$
H=p^{2} / 2 M+V(x),
$$

we have

$$
[H, x]=\frac{1}{2 M}\left[p^{2}, x\right]=-i \hbar p / M
$$

and so

$$
[[H, x], x]=-\frac{i \hbar}{M}[p, x]=-\hbar^{2} / M
$$

Hence

$$
\langle m|[[H, x], x]| m\rangle=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{M} .
$$

On the other hand,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle m|[[H, x], x]| m\rangle &=\left\langle m\left|H x^{2}-2 x H x+x^{2} H\right| m\right\rangle \\
&=2 E_{m}\left\langle m\left|x^{2}\right| m\right\rangle-2\langle m|x H x| m\rangle \\
&=2 E_{m} \sum_{n}|\langle m|x| n\rangle|^{2}-2 \sum_{n} E_{n}|\langle m|x| n\rangle|^{2} \\
&=2 \sum_{n}\left(E_{m}-E_{n}\right)|\langle m|x| n\rangle|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the above we have used 

$$
\begin{aligned}
H|m\rangle &=E_{m}|m\rangle \\
\left\langle m\left|x^{2}\right| m\right\rangle &=\sum_{n}\langle m|x| n\rangle\langle n|x| m\rangle \\
&=\sum_{n}|\langle m|x| n\rangle|^{2} \\
\langle m|x H x| m\rangle &=\sum_{n}\langle m|x H| n\rangle\langle n|x| m\rangle \\
&=\sum_{n} E_{n}\langle m|x| n\rangle\langle n|x| m\rangle \\
&=\sum_{n} E_{n}|\langle m|x| n\rangle|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Equating the two results and setting $m=0$, we obtain

$$
\sum_{n}\left(E_{n}-E_{0}\right)|\langle n|x| 0\rangle|^{2}=\hbar^{2} / 2 M .
$$

\section{1}

(a) Given a Hermitian operator $A$ with eigenvalues $a_{n}$ and eigenfunctions $u_{n}(x)[n=1,2, \ldots, N ; 0 \leq x \leq L]$, show that the operator $\exp (i A)$ is unitary.

(b) Conversely, given the matrix $U_{m n}$ of a unitary operator, construct the matrix of a Hermitian operator in terms of $U_{m n}$.

(c) Given a second Hermitian operator $B$ with eigenvalues $b_{m}$ and eigenfunctions $v_{m}(x)$, construct a representation of the unitary operator $V$ that transforms the eigenvectors of $B$ into those of $A$.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $A^{+}=A, A$ being Hermitian,

$$
\{\exp (i A)\}^{+}=\exp \left(-i A^{+}\right)=\exp (-i A)=\{\exp (i A)\}^{-1}
$$

Hence $\exp (i A)$ is unitary.

(b) Let

$$
C_{m n}=U_{m n}+U_{n m}^{*}=U_{m n}+\left(U^{+}\right)_{m n}
$$

i.e.,

$$
C=U+U^{+} .
$$

As $U^{++}=U, C^{+}=C$. Therefore $C_{m n}=U_{m n}+U_{n m}^{*}$ is the matrix representation of a Hermitian operator.

(c) The eigenkets of a Hermitian operator form a complete and orthonormal set. Thus any $\left|u_{m}\right\rangle$ can be expanded in the complete set $\left|v_{n}\right\rangle$ :

$$
\left|u_{m}\right\rangle=\sum_{k}\left|v_{k}\right\rangle\left\langle v_{k} \mid u_{m}\right\rangle \equiv \sum_{k}\left|v_{k}\right\rangle V_{k m}
$$

which defines $V_{k m}$,

$$
V_{k m}=\int_{0}^{L} v_{k}^{*}(x) u_{m}(x) d x .
$$

Similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|v_{n}\right\rangle &=\sum_{j}\left|u_{j}\right\rangle\left\langle u_{j} \mid v_{n}\right\rangle \\
&=\sum_{j}\left|u_{j}\right\rangle\left\langle v_{n} \mid u_{j}\right\rangle^{*} \\
&=\sum_{j}\left|u_{j}\right\rangle V_{n j}^{*} \\
&=\sum_{j}\left|u_{j}\right\rangle \tilde{V}_{j n}^{*} \\
&=\sum_{j}\left|u_{j}\right\rangle V_{j n}^{+} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\left|u_{m}\right\rangle=\sum_{j} \sum_{k}\left|u_{j}\right\rangle V_{j k}^{+} V_{k m}=\sum_{j}\left|u_{j}\right\rangle \delta_{j m}
$$

or

$$
V^{+} V=1
$$

i.e.,

$$
V^{+}=V^{-1},
$$

showing that $V$ is unitary. Thus $V$ is a unitary operator transforming the eigenvectors of $B$ into those of $A$

\section{2}

Consider a one-dimensional oscillator with the Hamiltonian

$$
H=p^{2} / 2 m+m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2 .
$$

(a) Find the time dependence of the expectation values of the "initial position" and "initial momentum" operators

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{0}=x \cos \omega t-(p / m \omega) \sin \omega t \\
&p_{0}=p \cos \omega t+m \omega x \sin \omega t
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Do these operators commute with the Hamiltonian?

(c) Do you find your results for (a) and (b) to be compatible? Discuss.

(d) What are the motion equations of the operators in the Heisenberg picture?

(e) Compute the commutator $\left[p_{0}, x_{0}\right]$. What is its significance for measurement theory?

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Making use of the relation

$$
\frac{d f}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}[f, H]+\frac{\partial f}{\partial t},
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\left\langle x_{0}\right\rangle}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t, H]-\omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&-\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[\frac{\langle p\rangle}{m \omega} \sin \omega t, H\right]-\frac{\langle p\rangle}{m} \cos \omega t \\
=& \frac{1}{i \hbar} \overline{[x, H]} \cos \omega t-\omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&-\frac{1}{m \omega} \frac{1}{i \hbar} \frac{1}{[p, H]} \sin \omega t-\frac{1}{m}\langle p\rangle \cos \omega t=0
\end{aligned}
$$



$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\left\langle p_{0}\right\rangle}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\langle p\rangle \cos \omega t, H]-\langle p\rangle \omega \sin \omega t \\
&+\frac{1}{i \hbar}[m \omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t, H]+m \omega^{2}\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t \\
=& \frac{1}{i \hbar} \overline{[p, H]} \cos \omega t-\omega\langle p\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&+\frac{m \omega}{i \hbar} \overline{[x, H]} \sin \omega t+m \omega^{2}\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the expectation values of these operators are independent of time.

(b) Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[x_{0}, H\right] } &=[x, H] \cos \omega t-\frac{[p, H]}{m \omega} \sin \omega t \\
&=\frac{i \hbar p}{m} \cos \omega t+i \hbar \omega x \sin \omega t \\
{\left[p_{0}, H\right] } &=[p, H] \cos \omega t+m \omega[x, H] \sin \omega t \\
&=-i \hbar m \omega^{2} x \cos \omega t+i \hbar \omega p \sin \omega t
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the operators $x_{0}, p_{0}$ do not commute with $H$.

(c) The results of (a) and (b) are still compatible. For while the expressions for $x_{0}$ and $p_{0}$ contain $t$ explicitly, their non-commutation with $H$ does not exclude their being conserved. In fact

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{d x_{0}}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[x_{0}, H\right]+\frac{\partial x_{0}}{\partial t}=0 \\
&\frac{d p_{0}}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[p_{0}, H\right]+\frac{\partial p_{0}}{\partial t}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

showing that they are actually conserved.

(d) In the Heisenberg picture, the motion equation of an operator is

$$
d A / d t=\frac{1}{i \hbar}[A, H]+\frac{\partial A}{\partial t} .
$$

Thus the motion equations of $x_{0}$ and $p_{0}$ are respectively

$$
d x_{0} / d t=0, \quad d p_{0} / d t=0
$$

(e) Using the expressions for $x_{0}$ and $p_{0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[p_{0}, x_{0}\right]=} & {\left[p \cos \omega t+m \omega x \sin \omega t, x_{0}\right] } \\
=& {\left[p, x_{0}\right] \cos \omega t+\left[x, x_{0}\right] m \omega \sin \omega t } \\
=& {\left[p, x \cos \omega t-\frac{p}{m \omega} \sin \omega t\right] \cos \omega t } \\
&+\left[x, x \cos \omega t-\frac{p}{m \omega} \sin \omega t\right] m \omega \sin \omega t \\
=& {[p, x] \cos ^{2} \omega t-[x, p] \sin ^{2} \omega t } \\
=&-[x, p]=-i \hbar
\end{aligned}
$$

as $[x, x]=[p, p]=0,[x, p]=i \hbar$.

In general, if two observables $A$ and $B$ satisfy the equation

$$
[A, B]=i \hbar
$$

then their root-mean-square deviations $\Delta A, \Delta B$, when they are measured simultaneously, must satisfy the uncertainty principle

$$
\Delta A \cdot \Delta B \geq \frac{\hbar}{2} .
$$

In the present case, the simultaneous measurements of position and momentum in the same direction must result in

$$
\Delta x \cdot \Delta p \geq \frac{\hbar}{2} .
$$

The relation shows

$$
\sqrt{\overline{\Delta x_{0}^{2}}} \sqrt{\overline{\Delta p_{0}^{2}}} \geq \hbar / 2 .
$$

It is a relation between possible upper limits to the precision of the two quantities when we measure them simultaneously. 

\section{CENTRAL POTENTIALS}

\section{1}

An electron is confined in a three-dimensional infinite potential well. The sides parallel to the $x-, y$-, and $z$-axes are of length $L$ each.

(a) Write the appropriate Schrödinger equation.

(b) Write the time-independent wave function corresponding to the state of the lowest possible energy.

(c) Give an expression for the number of states, $N$, having energy less than some given $E$. Assume $N \gg 1$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Schrödinger equation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
i \hbar \partial \psi(\mathbf{r}, t) / \partial t &=-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 m\right) \nabla^{2} \psi(\mathbf{r}, t), & & 0 \leq x, y, z \leq L \\
\psi &=0, & & \text { otherwise }
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) By separation of variables, we can take that the wave function to be the product of three wave functions each of a one-dimensional infinite well sotential. The wave function of the lowest energy level is

$$
\psi_{111}(x, y, z)=\psi_{1}(x) \psi_{1}(y) \psi_{1}(z)
$$

where

$$
\psi_{1}(x)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{L}} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{L} x\right), \text { etc. }
$$

Thus

$$
\psi_{111}(x, y, z)=\left(\frac{2}{L}\right)^{3 / 2} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{L}\right) \sin \left(\frac{\pi y}{L}\right) \sin \left(\frac{\pi z}{L}\right) \text {. }
$$

The corresponding energy is $E_{111}=3 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m L^{2}$.

(c) For a set of quantum numbers $n_{x}, n_{y}, n_{z}$ for the three dimensions, the energy is

$$
E=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{2 m L^{2}}\left(n_{x}^{2}+n_{y}^{2}+n_{z}^{2}\right) .
$$

Hence the number $N$ of states whose energy is less than or equal to $E$ is equal to the number of sets of three positive integers $n_{x}, n_{y}, n_{z}$ satisfying the inequality 

$$
n_{x}^{2}+n_{y}^{2}+n_{z}^{2} \leq \frac{2 m L^{2}}{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}} E .
$$

Consider a Cartesian coordinate system of axes $n_{x}, n_{y}, n_{z}$. The number $N$ required is numerically equal to the volume in the first quadrant of a sphere of radius $\left(2 m L^{2} E / \hbar^{2} \pi^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}$, provided $N \geq 1$. Thus

$$
N=\frac{1}{8} \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{3}\left(\frac{2 m L^{2}}{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}} E\right)^{3 / 2}=\frac{4 \pi}{3}\left(\frac{m L^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2}} E\right)^{3 / 2}
$$

\section{2}

A 'quark' (mass $=m_{p} / 3$ ) is confined in a cubical box with sides of length 2 fermis $=2 \times 10^{-15} \mathrm{~m}$. Find the excitation energy from the ground state to the first excited state in $\mathrm{MeV}$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The energy levels in the cubical box are given by

$$
E_{n_{1} n_{2} n_{3}}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{2 m a^{2}}\left(n_{1}^{2}+n_{2}^{2}+n_{3}^{2}\right), \quad n_{i}=1,2, \ldots
$$

Thus the energy of the ground state is $E_{111}=3 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m a^{2}$, that of the first excited state is $E_{211}=6 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m a^{2}=3 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / m a^{2}$. Hence the excitation energy from the ground state to the first excited state is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=3 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m a^{2}=\frac{1.5 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2} c^{2}}{m c^{2} a^{2}} \\
&=\frac{1.5 \pi^{2}\left(6.58 \times 10^{-22}\right)^{2} \times\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}{\left(\frac{938}{3}\right) \times\left(2 \times 10^{-15}\right)^{2}}=461 \mathrm{MeV}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{3}

A $\mathrm{NaCl}$ crystal has some negative ion vacancies, each containing one electron. Treat these electrons as moving freely inside a volume whose dimensions are on the order of the lattice constant. The crystal is at room temperature. Give a numerical estimate for the longest wavelength of electromagnetic radiation absorbed strongly by these electrons.

\section{Solution:}

The energy levels of an electron in a cubical box of sides $a$ are given by

$$
E_{n m k}=\left(\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 m a^{2}\right)\left(n^{2}+m^{2}+k^{2}\right),
$$

where $n, m$ and $k$ are positive integers. Taking $a \sim 1 \AA$, the ground state energy is $E_{111}=3 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m a^{2} \approx 112 \mathrm{eV}$. For a crystal at room temperature, the electrons are almost all in the ground state. The longest wavelength corresponds to a transition from the ground state to the nearest excited state:

$$
\Delta E=E_{211}-E_{111}=\frac{3 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m a^{2}}=112 \mathrm{eV}
$$

for which

$$
\lambda=\frac{c}{\nu}=\frac{h c}{\Delta E}=110 \AA
$$

\section{4}

An electron is confined to the interior of a hollow spherical cavity of radius $R$ with impenetrable walls. Find an expression for the pressure exerted on the walls of the cavity by the electron in its ground state.

\section{Solution:}

For the ground state, $l=0$, and if we set the radial wave function as $R(r)=\chi(r) / r$, then $\chi(r)$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d^{2} \chi}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2 \mu E}{\hbar^{2}} \chi=0 & \text { for } r<R, \\
\chi=0 & \text { for } r \geq R,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mu$ is the electron rest mass. $R(r)$ is finite at $r=0$, so that $\chi(0)=0$. The solutions satisfying this condition are

$$
\chi_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{R}} \sin \frac{n \pi r}{R}, \quad(n=1,2,3, \ldots)
$$

for which

$$
E_{n}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 \mu R^{2}} n^{2} .
$$

The average force $F$ acting radially on the walls by the electron is given by

$$
F=\left\langle-\frac{\partial \hat{V}}{\partial R}\right\rangle=-\left\langle\frac{\partial \hat{H}}{\partial R}\right\rangle=-\frac{\partial}{\partial R}\langle\hat{H}\rangle=-\frac{\partial E}{\partial R} .
$$

As the electron is in the ground state, $n=1$ and

$$
F=-\partial E_{1} / \partial R=\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} / \mu R^{3} \text {. }
$$

The pressure exerted on the walls is

$$
p=F / 4 \pi R^{2}=\pi \hbar^{2} / 4 \mu R^{5} .
$$

\section{5}

A particle of mass $m$ is constrained to move between two concentric impermeable spheres of radii $r=a$ and $r=b$. There is no other potential. Find the ground state energy and normalized wave function.

(MIT)

\section{Solution:}

Let the radial wave function of the particle be $R(r)=\chi(r) / r$. Then $\chi(r)$ satisfies the equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{d^{2} \chi(r)}{d r^{2}}+\left\{\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}[E-V(r)]-\frac{l(l+1)}{r^{2}}\right\} \chi(r)=0 . \\
& (a \leq r \leq b)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the ground state, $l=0$, so that only the radial wave function is non-trivial. Since $V(r)=0$, letting $K^{2}=2 m E / \hbar^{2}$, we reduce the equation to

$$
\chi^{\prime \prime}+K^{2} \chi=0
$$

with

$$
\left.\chi\right|_{r=a}=\left.\chi\right|_{r=b}=0 .
$$

$\chi(a)=0$ requires the solution to have the form

$$
\chi(r)=A \sin [K(r-a)]
$$

Then from $\chi(b)=0$, we get the possible values of $K$ :

$$
K=n \pi /(b-a), \quad(n=1,2, \ldots)
$$

For the particle in the ground state, i.e., $n=1$, we obtain the energy

$$
E=\hbar^{2} K^{2} / 2 m=\hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m(b-a)^{2} .
$$

From the normalization condition

$$
\int_{a}^{b} R^{2}(r) r^{2} d r=\int_{a}^{b} \chi^{2}(r) d r=1
$$

we get $A=\sqrt{2 /(b-a)}$. Hence for the ground state, the normalized radial wave function is

$$
R(r)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{b-a}} \frac{1}{r} \sin \frac{\pi(r-a)}{b-a},
$$

and the normalized wave function is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi}} \sqrt{\frac{2}{b-a}} \frac{1}{r} \sin \frac{\pi(r-a)}{b-a} .
$$

\section{6}

(a) For a simple harmonic oscillator with $H=\left(p^{2} / m+k x^{2}\right) / 2$, show that the energy of the ground state has the lowest value compatible with the uncertainty principle.

(b) The wave function of the state where the uncertainty principle minimum is realized is a Gaussian function $\exp \left(-\alpha x^{2}\right)$. Making use of this fact, but without solving any differential equation, find the value of $\alpha$.

(c) Making use of raising or lowering operators, but without solving any differential equation, write down the (non-normalized) wave function of the first excited state of the harmonic oscillator. (d) For a three-dimensional oscillator, write down, in polar coordinates, the wave functions of the degenerate first excited state which is an eigenstate of $l_{z}$

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The ground state of the harmonic oscillator has even parity, so that

$$
\bar{x}=\langle 0|x| 0\rangle=0, \quad \bar{p}=\langle 0|p| 0\rangle=0 ;
$$

and so

$$
\overline{\Delta p^{2}}=\overline{p^{2}}, \quad \overline{\Delta x^{2}}=\overline{x^{2}} .
$$

The uncertainty principle requires

$$
\overline{\Delta p^{2}} \cdot \overline{\Delta x^{2}} \geq \frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} .
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{E} &=\frac{\overline{p^{2}}}{2 m}+\frac{k}{2} \overline{x^{2}} \\
& \geq \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} \sqrt{\overline{p^{2}} \cdot \overline{x^{2}}} \\
& \geq \frac{\hbar}{2} \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}=\hbar \omega / 2=E_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}=\omega$. Thus the energy of the ground state has the lowest value compatible with the uncertainty principle.

(b) Using the given wave function we calculate

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\overline{x^{2}}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-2 \alpha x^{2}} x^{2} d x / \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-2 \alpha x^{2}} d x=1 / 4 \alpha, \\
&\overline{p^{2}}=-\hbar^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\alpha x^{2}} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} e^{-\alpha x^{2}} d x / \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-2 \alpha x^{2}} d x=\hbar^{2} \alpha,
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
E=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \alpha+\frac{k}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{4 \alpha} .
$$

From $\frac{d E}{d \alpha}=0$ we see that when $\alpha=\sqrt{k m} / 2 \hbar=m \omega / 2 \hbar$ the energy is minimum. Therefore $\alpha=m \omega / 2 \hbar$.

(c) In the Fock representation of harmonic oscillation we define

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{a} &=i(\hat{p}-i m \omega \hat{x}) / \sqrt{2 m \hbar \omega} \\
\hat{a}^{+} &=-i(\hat{p}+i m \omega \hat{x}) / \sqrt{2 m \hbar \omega}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then $\left[\hat{a}, \hat{a}^{+}\right]=1$

$$
H=\left(\hat{a}^{+} \hat{a}+1 / 2\right) \hbar \omega .
$$

Denoting the ground state wave function by $|0\rangle$. As $H|0\rangle=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega|0\rangle$, the last equation gives $\hat{a}^{+} \hat{a}|0\rangle=0$. It also gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
H\left(\hat{a}^{+}|0\rangle\right) &=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega \hat{a}^{+}|0\rangle+\hbar \omega \hat{a}^{+} \hat{a} \hat{a}^{+}|0\rangle \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega \hat{a}^{+}|0\rangle+\hbar \omega \hat{a}^{+}\left(\hat{a}^{+} \hat{a}+1\right)|0\rangle \\
&=\frac{3}{2} \hbar \omega\left(\hat{a}^{+}|0\rangle\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
|1\rangle &=\hat{a}^{+}|0\rangle=\frac{-i}{\sqrt{2 m \hbar \omega}}\left(-i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial x}+i m \omega x\right) \exp \left(-\frac{m \omega}{2 \hbar} x^{2}\right) \\
&=\sqrt{\frac{2 m \omega}{\hbar}} x \exp \left(-\frac{m \omega}{2 \hbar} x^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

in the coordinate representation.

(d) For a 3-dimensional oscillator, the wave function is

$$
\psi_{n_{1} n_{2} n_{3}}(\mathbf{r})=\psi_{n_{1}}(x) \psi_{n_{2}}(y) \psi_{n_{3}}(z) .
$$

For the ground state, $\left(n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}\right)=(0,0,0)$. For the first excited states, $\left(n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}\right)=(1,0,0) ;(0,1,0) ;(0,0,1)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi_{100}(\mathbf{r})=N_{0}^{2} N_{1} 2 \alpha x \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \alpha^{2} r^{2}\right) \\
&\psi_{010}(\mathbf{r})=N_{0}^{2} N_{1} 2 \alpha y \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \alpha^{2} r^{2}\right) \\
&\psi_{001}(\mathbf{r})=N_{0}^{2} N_{1} 2 \alpha z \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \alpha^{2} r^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Expanding $x, y, z$ in spherical harmonics and recombining the wave functions, we get the eigenstates of $l_{z}$

$$
\psi_{m}(\mathbf{r})=N_{m} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \alpha^{2} r^{2}\right) r Y_{1 m}(\theta, \varphi)
$$

where

$$
N_{m}^{-1}=\sqrt{2} / \alpha^{2} .
$$

Note that here $\alpha=\sqrt{m \omega / \hbar}$, which is the usual definition, different from that given in (b).

\section{7}

The diagram (Fig. 2.1) shows the six lowest energy levels and the associated angular momenta for a spinless particle moving in a certain threedimensional central potential. There are no "accidental" degeneracies in this energy spectrum. Give the number of nodes (changes in sign) in the radial wave function associated with each level.

\section{Solution:}

The radial wave function of a particle in a three-dimensional central potential can be written as $R(r)=\chi(r) / r$. With a given angular quantum number $l$, the equation satisfied by $\chi(r)$ has the form of a one-dimensional Schrödinger equation. Hence, if an energy spectrum has no "accidental" degeneracies, the role of the nodes in the radial wave function of the particle is the same as that in the one-dimensional wave function. For bound states, Sturm's theorem remains applicable, i.e., $\chi(r)$ obeys Sturm's theorem: the radial wave function of the ground state has no node, while that of the $n$th excited state has $n$ nodes. Thus, for a bound state of energy $E_{n}$, which has quantum number $n=n_{r}+l+1$, the radial wave has $n_{r}$ nodes.

For angular quantum number $l=0$, the numbers of nodes for the three energy levels (ordered from low to high energy) are 0,1 and 2.

Similarly, for $l=1$, the numbers of nodes are 0 and 1 ; for $l=2$, the number of nodes is 0 .

Thus, the numbers of nodes in the energy levels shown in Fig. $2.1$ are $0,1,0,0,1,2$, from low to high energy. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-140.jpg?height=324&width=376&top_left_y=160&top_left_x=469)

Fig. $2.1$

\section{8}

A particle of mass $m$ and charge $q$ is bound to the origin by a spherically symmetric linear restoring force. The energy levels are equally spaced at intervals $\hbar \omega_{0}$ above the ground state energy $E_{0}=3 \hbar \omega_{0} / 2$. The states can be described alternatively in a Cartesian basis (three one-dimensional harmonic oscillators) or in a spherical basis (central field, separated into angular and radial motions).

(a) In the Cartesian basis, table the occupation numbers of the various states of the oscillators for the ground and first three excited levels. Determine the total degeneracy of each of these levels.

(b) In the spherical basis, write down (do not solve) the radial equation of motion.

(Note that in spherical coordinates $\nabla^{2}=\frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)-\frac{L^{2}}{r^{2}}$, where $L^{2}$ is the operator of total orbital angular momentum squared in units of $\hbar^{2}$.)

Identify the effective potential and sketch it. For a given angular momentum, sketch the "ground state" radial wave function (for a given $l$ value) and also the radial wave functions for the next two states of the same $l$.

(c) For the four levels of part (a), write down the angular momentum content and the parity of the states in each level. Compare the total degeneracies with the answers in (a).

(d) Does the second excited state $\left(E_{2}=7 \hbar \omega_{0} / 2\right)$ have a linear Stark effect? Why or why not? Compare similarities and differences between this oscillator level and the second excited level $(n=3)$ of the nonrelativistic hydrogen atom. 

\section{Solution:}

(a)

Table $2.1$

\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|}
\hline Energy level & Occupation Numbers & Degeneracy \\
\hline$E_{0}$ & $|0,0,0\rangle$ & 1 \\
$E_{1}$ & $|1,0,0\rangle,|0,1,0\rangle,|0,0,1\rangle$ & 3 \\
$E_{2}$ & $|2,0,0\rangle,|0,2,0\rangle,|0,0,2\rangle$ & 6 \\
& $|1,1,0\rangle,|1,0,1\rangle,|0,1,1\rangle$ & \\
$E_{3}$ & $|3,0,0\rangle,|0,3,0\rangle,|0,0,3\rangle$ & 10 \\
& $|2,1,0\rangle,|0,2,1\rangle,|1,0,2\rangle$ & \\
& $|1,2,0\rangle,|0,1,2\rangle,|2,0,1\rangle$ & \\
& $|1,1,1\rangle$ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

(b) Let

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r})=R(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi) .
$$

The radial wave function $R(r)$ satisfies the equation

$$
\frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d}{d r} R\right)+\left[\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left(E-\frac{m}{2} \omega^{2} r^{2}\right)-\frac{l(l+1)}{r^{2}}\right] R=0
$$

so that the effective potential is

$$
V_{\mathrm{eff}}=m \omega^{2} r^{2} / 2+\hbar^{2} l(l+1) / 2 m r^{2},
$$

which is sketched in Fig. 2.2, where $r_{0}=\left[\hbar^{2} l(l+1) / m^{2} \omega^{2}\right]^{1 / 4}$. The shapes of the radial wave functions of the three lowest states for a given $l$ are shown in Fig. 2.3.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-141.jpg?height=379&width=448&top_left_y=1394&top_left_x=454)

Fig. $2.2$ 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-142.jpg?height=368&width=540&top_left_y=159&top_left_x=381)

Fig. $2.3$

Note that the number of nodes of a wave function is equal to $n_{r}$. (c)

Table $2.2$

\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|c|c|}
\hline$E$ & $l$ & $m$ & $P$ & $D$ \\
\hline$E_{0}$ & 0 & 0 & $+$ & 1 \\
$E_{1}$ & 1 & $0, \pm 1$ & $-$ & 3 \\
$E_{2}$ & 2 & $0, \pm 1, \pm 2$ & $+$ & 6 \\
& 0 & 0 & & \\
$E_{3}$ & 3 & $0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \pm 3$ & $-$ & 10 \\
& 1 & $0, \pm 1$ & & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Note: $P=$ parity, $D=$ degeneracy.

(d) The second excited state does not have a linear Stark effect because $x$ is an operator of odd parity while all the degenerate states for $E_{2}$ have even parity, with the result that the matrix elements of $H^{\prime}$ in the subspace of the energy level $E_{2}$ are all zero.

On the other hand, for the second excited level of the hydrogen atom, $n=3$, its degenerate states have both even and odd parities, so that linear Stark effect exists.

\section{9}

(a) A nonrelativistic particle of mass $m$ moves in the potential

$$
V(x, y, z)=A\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+2 \lambda x y\right)+B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right)
$$

where $A>0, B>0,|\lambda|<1, \mu$ is arbitrary. Find the energy eigenvalues.

(b) Now consider the following modified problem with a new potential $V_{\text {new }}$ : for $z>-\mu$ and any $x$ and $y, V_{\text {new }}=V$, where $V$ is the same as in part (a) above; for $z<-\mu$ and any $x$ and $y, V_{\text {new }}=+\infty$. Find the ground state energy.

\section{Solution:}

(a) We choose two new variables $\mu, t$ defined by

or

$$
\mu=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x+y), \quad t=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x-y),
$$

and write the potential as

$$
x=(\mu+t) / \sqrt{2}, \quad y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\mu-t),
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
V(x, y, z)=& A\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}+t^{2}+2 \mu t\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}+t^{2}-2 \mu t\right)\right.\\
&\left.+2 \lambda \cdot \frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}-t^{2}\right)\right]+B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right) \\
=& A\left[(1+\lambda) \mu^{2}+(1-\lambda) t^{2}\right]+B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the differentials as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial x}=& \frac{\partial}{\partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}=&\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu \partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
&+\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t \partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial y}=& \frac{\partial}{\partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y^{2}}=&\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu \partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
&-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t \partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \\
\nabla^{2}=& \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then Schrödinger equation becomes

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}}\right) \phi(\mu, t, z)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}[E-V(\mu, t, z)] \phi(\mu, t, z)=0 \text {. }
$$

Let $\phi(\mu, t, z)=U(\mu) T(t) Z(z)$. The above equation can be separated into

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}} U(\mu)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E_{1}-A(1+\lambda) \mu^{2}\right] U(\mu)=0 \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} T(t)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E_{2}-A(1-\lambda) t^{2}\right] T(t)=0 \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}} Z(z)+\left(2 m / \hbar^{2}\right)\left[E_{3}-B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right)\right] Z(z)=0
\end{array}
$$

with

$$
E_{1}+E_{2}+E_{3}=E .
$$

By setting $z^{\prime}=z+\mu, E_{3}^{\prime}=E_{3}+B \mu^{2}$, all the above three equations can be reduced to that for a harmonic oscillator. Thus the energy eigenvalues are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E_{1}=\left(n_{1}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{1}, \quad \omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 A}{m}(1+\lambda)} \\
& E_{2}=\left(n_{2}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{2}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{2 A}{m}(1-\lambda)} \\
& E_{3}=\left(n_{3}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{3}-B \mu^{2}, \quad \omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{2 B}{m}} \text {. } \\
& \left(n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}=0,1,2,3, \ldots\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) With a new potential $V_{\text {new }}$ such that for $z<-\mu, V_{\text {new }}=\infty$ and for $z>-\mu, V_{\text {new }}$ is the same as that in (a), the wave function must vanish for $z \rightarrow-\mu$. The $Z$-equation has solution

$$
Z \sim H_{n_{3}}(\zeta) e^{-\zeta^{2} / 2},
$$

where $\zeta=\left(2 m B / \hbar^{2}\right)^{1 / 4}(z+\mu), H_{n_{3}}(\zeta)$ is the $n_{3}$ th Hermite polynomial and has the parity of $n_{3}$. Hence $n_{3}$ must be an odd integer. The ground state is the state for $n_{1}=n_{2}=0$ and $n_{3}=1$, with the corresponding energy

$$
E=\hbar\left(\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}\right) / 2+3 \hbar \omega_{3} / 2-B \mu^{2} .
$$



\section{0}

A particle of mass $m$ moves in the logarithmic potential

$$
V(r)=C \ln \left(r / r_{0}\right) .
$$

Show that:

(a) All eigenstates have the same mean squared velocity. Find this mean squared velocity.

(b) The spacing between any two levels is independent of the mass $m$.

$(C U S)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) We have

$$
\left\langle\mathbf{v}^{2}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathbf{P}^{2} / m^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{m^{2}}\left\langle\mathbf{P}^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{m^{2}} \int d^{3} \mathbf{r} \psi^{*} \mathbf{P}^{2} \psi
$$

and, for a stationary state, the virial law gives

$$
\langle\hat{T}\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\langle\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla V\rangle .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\mathbf{v}^{2}\right\rangle &=\left\langle\mathbf{P}^{2} / m^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{m} \cdot 2\langle T\rangle=\frac{1}{m}\langle\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla V\rangle \\
&=\frac{1}{m} \int d^{3} \mathbf{r} \cdot\left(r \frac{d}{d r} C \ln r / r_{0}\right) \psi^{*} \psi \\
&=\frac{C}{m} \int d^{3} \mathbf{r}|\psi|^{2}=\frac{C}{m},
\end{aligned}
$$

which is true for any eigenstate.

(b) Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial E_{n}}{\partial m} &=\left\langle\left|\frac{\partial \hat{H}}{\partial m}\right|\right\rangle=\left\langle\left|-\frac{\mathbf{P}^{2}}{2 m^{2}}\right|\right\rangle=-\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\mathbf{v}^{2}\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{C}{2 m},
\end{aligned}
$$

$\partial E_{n} / \partial m$ is independent of $n$. It follows that

$$
\frac{\partial\left(E_{n}-E_{n-1}\right)}{\partial m}=-\frac{C}{2 m}+\frac{C}{2 m}=0,
$$

i.e., $E_{n}-E_{n-1}$ is independent of the mass $m$. 

\section{1}

Assume that the eigenstates of a hydrogen atom isolated in space are all known and designated as usual by

$$
\psi_{n l m}(r, \theta, \phi)=R_{n l}(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \phi) .
$$

Suppose the nucleus of a hydrogen atom is located at a distance $d$ from an infinite potential wall which, of course, tends to distort the hydrogen atom.

(a) Find the explicit form of the ground state wave function of this hydrogen atom as $d$ approaches zero.

(b) Find all other eigenstates of this hydrogen atom in half-space, i.e. $d \rightarrow 0$, in terms of the $R_{n l}$ and $Y_{l m}$.

(Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Choose a coordinate system with origin at the center of the nucleus and $z$-axis perpendicular to the wall surface as shown in Fig. 2.4. As $d \rightarrow 0$, the solutions of the Schrödinger equation are still $R_{n l} Y_{l m}$ in the half-space $z>0$ i.e., $0<\theta<\pi / 2$, but must satisfy the condition $\psi=0$ at $\theta=\pi / 2$ where $V=\infty$. That is, only solutions satisfying $l+m=$ odd integer are acceptable. As $|m| \leq l$, the first suitable spherical harmonic is

$$
Y_{10}=\sqrt{3 / 4 \pi} \cos \theta \text {. }
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-146.jpg?height=550&width=526&top_left_y=1230&top_left_x=411)

Fig. $2.4$ Since $n \geq l+1$, the ground state wave function is $R_{21} Y_{10}$.

(b) All the other eigenstates have wave functions $R_{n l} Y_{l m}$ where $l+m=$ odd integer. For a given $l$, we have $m=l-1,1-3, \ldots,-1+1$ and hence a degeneracy $l$.

\section{2}

At the time $t=0$ the wave function for hydrogen atom is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, 0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}\left(2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right)
$$

where the subscripts are values of the quantum numbers $n, l, m$. Ignore spin and radiative transitions.

(a) What is the expectation value for the energy of this system?

(b) What is the probability of finding the system with $l=1, m=+1$ as a function of time?

(c) What is the probability of finding the electron within $10^{-10} \mathrm{~cm}$ of the proton (at time $t=0$ )? (A good approximate result is acceptable here.)

(d) How does this wave function evolve in time; i.e., what is $\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)$ ?

(e) Suppose a measurement is made which shows that $L=1$ and $L_{z}=$ $+1$. Describe the wave function immediately after such a measurement in terms of the $\psi_{n l m}$ used above.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Making use of the orthonormality of the wave functions, the expectation value for the energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle=& \frac{1}{10}\left\langle 2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right| 2 E_{1} \psi_{100} \\
&\left.+E_{2} \psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} E_{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} E_{2} \psi_{21-1}\right\rangle \\
=& \frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+E_{2}+2 E_{2}+3 E_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+6 E_{2}\right) \\
=& 0.55 E_{1}=-\frac{0.55}{2} m c^{2}\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c}\right)^{2} \\
=&-\frac{0.55}{2} \times 0.51 \times 10^{6} \times \frac{1}{137^{2}}=-7.47 \mathrm{eV},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $E_{1}=-m e^{4} / 2 \hbar^{2}, E_{2}=\frac{1}{4} E_{1}$ for the hydrogen atom.

(b) Since

$$
|\psi(t)\rangle=\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right)|\psi(0)\rangle
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle n 11 \mid \psi(t)\rangle &=\delta_{n 2}\left\langle 211\left|\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right)\right| \psi(0)\right\rangle \\
&=\delta_{n 2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} E_{2} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

using the given wave function for $t=0$. Hence the probability required is

$$
P=|\langle n 11 \mid \psi(t)\rangle|^{2}=\frac{1}{5} \delta_{n 2} .
$$

Thus if $n=2, P=1 / 5$; otherwise $P=0$.

(c) Let $\alpha=10^{-10} \mathrm{~cm}$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\int_{0}^{\alpha} \psi^{*} \psi r^{2} d r d \Omega \\
&=\int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{1}{10}\left(4\left|R_{10}\right|^{2}+6\left|R_{21}\right|^{2}\right) r^{2} d r
\end{aligned}
$$

making use of the given wave function as in (a). Here for the hydrogen atom

$$
\left|R_{10}\right|^{2}=\frac{4}{a^{3}} e^{-2 r / a}, \quad\left|R_{21}\right|^{2}=\frac{r^{2}}{24 a^{5}} e^{-r / 2 a}
$$

and $a=5.29 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~cm}$. As $r \leq \alpha \ll a$, we can make the approximation

$$
e^{-2 r / a} \approx 1-\frac{2 r}{a}, \quad e^{-r / 2 a}=1-\frac{r}{2 a} .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
P & \approx \frac{4}{10} \int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{4}{a^{3}}\left(1-\frac{2 r}{a}\right) r^{2} d r+\frac{6}{10} \int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{r^{2}}{24 a^{5}}\left(1-\frac{r}{2 a}\right) r^{2} d r \\
&=\left[\frac{4}{3}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{3}-2\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{4}\right] \frac{4}{10}+\frac{6}{10}\left[\frac{1}{120}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{5}-\frac{1}{288}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{6}\right] \\
& \approx \frac{8}{15}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{3} \approx 3.6 \times 10^{-6}
\end{aligned}
$$

(d) The wave function at time $t$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=& \exp \left[-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right] \psi(\mathbf{r}, 0) \\
=& \sqrt{\frac{1}{10}}\left[2 e^{-i \omega_{1} t} \psi_{100}+e^{-i \omega_{2} t} \psi_{210}\right.\\
&\left.+\sqrt{2} e^{-i \omega_{2} t} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} e^{-i \omega_{2} t} \psi_{21-1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega_{1}=E_{1} / \hbar, \omega_{2}=E_{2} / \hbar$.

(e) Since $n \geq L+1$, with $L=1$ we have $n=2$. Consequently the required state vector has the form

$$
|\rangle=C_{+}|211\rangle+C_{0}|210\rangle+C_{-}|21-1\rangle .
$$

Using $L_{z}=\left(L_{+}+L_{-}\right) / 2$, with $L_{-} Y_{l m}=\sqrt{(l-m+1)(l+m)} Y_{l m-1}$, $L_{+} Y_{l m}=\sqrt{(l+m+1)(l-m)} Y_{l m+1}$, we can write $L_{z}|\rangle=|\rangle$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{1}{2}\left\{\sqrt{2} C_{0}|211\rangle+\sqrt{2}\left(C_{+}+C_{-}\right)|210\rangle+\sqrt{2} C_{0}|21-1\rangle\right\} \\
&\quad=C_{+}|211\rangle+C_{0}|210\rangle+C_{-}|21-1\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

and obtain

$$
C_{+}=C_{-}=\frac{C_{0}}{\sqrt{2}} .
$$

Hence

$$
|\rangle=\frac{1}{2} C_{0}(\sqrt{2}|211\rangle+2|210\rangle+\sqrt{2}|21-1\rangle) .
$$

Normalization

$$
\langle 1\rangle=\frac{C_{0}^{2}}{4}(2+4+2)=1
$$

gives $C_{0}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$. Therefore

$$
|\rangle=\frac{1}{2}(|211\rangle+\sqrt{2}|210\rangle+|21-1\rangle) .
$$

\section{3}

The ground state energy and Bohr radius for the hydrogen atom are $E_{0}=-e^{2} / 2 a_{0}, a_{0}=\hbar^{2} / m e^{2}$, where $m$ is the reduced mass of the system. 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{\left[m_{e}=9.11 \times 10^{-28} \mathrm{~g}, m_{p}=1.67 \times 10^{-24} \mathrm{~g}, e=4.80 \times 10^{-10} \text { e.s.u., } \hbar=\right.} \\
&\left.1.05 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{erg} \text { sec. }\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

(a) Compute the ground state energy and Bohr radius of the positronium.

(b) What is the degeneracy of the positronium ground state due to electron spin? Write down the possible spin wave functions which have definite values of the total spin together with the corresponding eigenvalues.

(c) The ground state of positronium can decay by annihilation into photons. Calculate the energy and angular momentum released in this process and prove that there must be at least two photons in the final state.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The reduced mass $m$ of the positronium is given by $\frac{1}{m}=\frac{1}{m_{e}}+\frac{1}{m_{e}}$, i.e., $m=m_{e} / 2$. Its use in the formulas gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{0} &=\frac{-e^{2}}{2 a_{0}}=-\frac{m c^{2}}{2}\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c}\right)^{2}=\frac{-0.51 \times 10^{6}}{4 \times 137^{2}}=-6.8 \mathrm{eV} \\
a_{0} &=1.05 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~cm}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The degeneracy of the positronium ground state is 4. Denote the positron by 1 and the electron by 2 , and let the spin eigenstates in the $z$ direction of a single particle be $\alpha$ and $\beta$, corresponding to eigenvalues $\hbar / 2$ and $-\hbar / 2$ respectively. Then the ground eigenstates with definite total spin $S=s_{1}+s_{2}$ and $z$-component of the total spin $S_{z}=s_{1 z}+s_{2 z}$ are

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\alpha(1) \alpha(2), & S=\hbar, & S_{z}=\hbar . \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[\alpha(1) \beta(2)+\beta(1) \alpha(2)], & S=\hbar, & S_{z}=0 . \\
\beta(1) \beta(2), & S=\hbar, & S_{z}=-\hbar . \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[\alpha(1) \beta(2)-\beta(1) \alpha(2)], & S=0, & S_{z}=0 .
\end{array}
$$

(c) The energy released in the annihilation process mostly comes from the rest masses of the electron and positron, $\Delta E=2 m_{e} c^{2}=1.02 \mathrm{MeV}$. The released angular momentum depends on the state of the positronium before the annihilation. For the ground state $S=0$, no angular momentum is released. For the state $S=\hbar$, the angular momentum released is $\Delta J=\sqrt{l(l+1)} \hbar=\sqrt{2} \hbar$. There must be at least two photons in the final state of an annihilation, for if there were only one photon produced in the annihilation of a positronium, the energy and momentum of the system could not both be conserved. This can be shown by a simple argument. If the single photon has energy $E$, it must have a momentum $E / c$ at the same time. Thus the momentum of the photon cannot be zero in any reference frame. But in the positronium's rest frame the momentum is zero throughout the annihilation. Hence we have to conclude that there must be at least two photons in the final state of an annihilation whose momenta cancel out in the rest frame of the positronium.

\section{4}

Consider an electron moving in a spherically symmetric potential $V=$ $k r$, where $k>0$.

(a) Use the uncertainty principle to estimate the ground state energy.

(b) Use the Bohr-Sommerfeld quantization rule to calculate the ground state energy.

(c) Do the same using the variational principle and a trial wave function of your own choice.

(d) Solve for the energy eigenvalue and eigenfunction exactly for the ground state.

(Hint: Use Fourier transforms.)

(e) Write down the effective potential for nonzero angular momentum states.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The uncertainty principle states that

where

$$
\Delta p \Delta r \geq \frac{\hbar}{2},
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta p &=\left[\overline{(p-\bar{p})^{2}}\right]^{1 / 2}=\left[\left(\overline{p^{2}-2 p \bar{p}+\bar{p}^{2}}\right)\right]^{1 / 2} \\
&=\left(\overline{p^{2}}-\bar{p}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$



$$
\Delta r=\left(\overline{r^{2}}-\bar{r}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} .
$$

The potential is spherically symmetric, so we can take $\bar{p}=0$, i.e. $\Delta p \approx$ $\sqrt{\overline{p^{2}}}$. For an estimate of the energy

$$
E=\frac{\overline{p^{2}}}{2 m}+k \bar{r}
$$

we shall also take

$$
\Delta r \sim \bar{r} .
$$

Then

$$
E \approx \frac{(\Delta p)^{2}}{2 m}+k \Delta r \geq \frac{(\Delta p)^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{k \hbar}{2 \Delta p} .
$$

For the ground state energy $E$, we have

$$
\frac{\partial E}{\partial \Delta p}=\frac{\Delta p}{m}-\frac{k \hbar}{2(\Delta p)^{2}}=0
$$

giving

$$
\Delta p=\left(\frac{m k \hbar}{2}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

and

$$
E=\frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{k^{2} \hbar^{2}}{4 m}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

(b) The Bohr-Sommerfeld quantization rule gives

$$
\oint P_{r} d r=n_{r} h, \quad \oint P_{\phi} d \phi=n_{\phi} h
$$

Choose polar coordinates such that the particle is moving in the plane $\theta=\pi / 2$. The ground state is given by $n_{r}=0, n_{\phi}=1$, and the orbit is circular with radius $a$. The second integral gives

$$
P_{\phi}=I \omega=m a^{2} \omega=\hbar .
$$

The central force is

$$
F_{r}=-\frac{d V}{d r}=-k=-m \omega^{2} a .
$$

Combining we have $a=\left(\hbar^{2} / m k\right)^{1 / 3}$, and hence

$$
E_{0}=P_{\phi}^{2} / 2 m a^{2}+k a=\frac{3}{2}\left(k^{2} \hbar^{2} / m\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

(c) The notion in the ground state does not depend on $\theta$ and $\phi$. Take a trial wave function $\psi=\exp (-\lambda r)$ and evaluate

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{\langle\psi|\hat{H}| \psi\rangle}{\langle\psi \mid \psi\rangle}
$$

where

$$
\hat{H}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2}+k r .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\psi|\hat{H}| \psi\rangle & \propto-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\lambda r} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d}{d r} e^{-\lambda r}\right) r^{2} d r \\
&+k \int_{0}^{\infty} r^{3} e^{-2 \lambda r} d r \\
&=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \lambda \int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{2}{r}-\lambda\right) e^{-2 \lambda r} r^{2} d r+\frac{k 3 !}{(2 \lambda)^{4}} \\
&=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 m \lambda}+\frac{3 k}{8 \lambda^{4}}, \\
\langle\psi \mid \psi\rangle & \propto \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-2 \lambda r} r^{2} d r=\frac{2}{(2 \lambda)^{3}}=\frac{1}{4 \lambda^{3}},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \lambda^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{3 k}{2 \lambda} .
$$

For stable motion, $\bar{H}$ is a minimum. Then taking

$$
\frac{\partial \bar{H}}{\partial \lambda}=0,
$$

we find

$$
\lambda=\left(\frac{3 m k}{2 \hbar^{2}}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

and hence

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{9}{4} \frac{k}{\lambda}=\frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{9}{4} \frac{k^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

(d) The Schrödinger equation for the radial motion can be written as

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d r^{2}} \chi+(k r-E) \chi=0
$$

where $\chi=r R, R$ being the radial wave function. For the ground state, the angular wave function is constant. By the transformation

$$
y=\left(\frac{2 m k}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{1 / 3}\left(r-\frac{E}{k}\right)
$$

the Schrödinger equation becomes the Airy equation

$$
\frac{d^{2} \chi(y)}{d y^{2}}-y \chi(y)=0
$$

whose solutions are $A i(-x)$ and $A i(x)$, where $x=-|y|$, for $y<0$ and $y>0$ respectively. The boundary conditions that $R(r)$ and $R^{\prime}(r)$ be continuous at $r=\frac{E}{k}$, i.e. $y=0$, are satisfied automatically as $A i(x)=A i(-x)$, $A i^{\prime}(x)=A i^{\prime}(-x)$ for $x \rightarrow 0$. The condition that $R(r)$ is finite at $r \rightarrow 0$ requires that $A i(-x)=r R(r) \rightarrow 0$ as $r \rightarrow 0$. The first zero of $A i(-x)$ occurs at $x=x_{0} \approx 2.35$. Hence the ground state energy is

$$
E_{0}=\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m k}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} k x_{0}
$$

and the ground state eigenfunction is

$$
R(r)=\frac{1}{r} A i(-x) \quad \text { with } \quad x=\left(\frac{2 m k}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\left(\frac{E_{0}}{k}-r\right) \text {. }
$$

(e) The effective potential for nonzero angular momentum is

$$
V_{\mathrm{eff}}=k r+\hbar^{2} l(l+1) / 2 m r^{2} .
$$

\section{5}

The interactions of heavy quarks are often approximated by a spinindependent nonrelativistic potential which is a linear function of the radial variable $r$, where $r$ is the separation of the quarks: $V(r)=A+B r$. Thus the famous "charmonium" particles, the $\psi$ and $\psi^{\prime}$, with rest energies $3.1 \mathrm{GeV}$ and $3.7 \mathrm{GeV}\left(1 \mathrm{GeV}=10^{9} \mathrm{eV}\right)$, are believed to be the $n=0$ and $n=1$ bound states of zero orbital angular momentum of a "charm" quark of mass $m_{c}=1.5 \mathrm{GeV} / c^{2}$ (i.e. $E=1.5 \mathrm{GeV}$ ) and an anti-quark of the same mass in the above linear potential. Similarly, the recently discovered upsilon particles, the $\Upsilon$ and $\Upsilon^{\prime}$, are believed to be the $n=0$ and $n=1$ zero orbital angular momentum bound states of a "bottom" quark and anti-quark pair in the same potential. The rest mass of bottom quark is $m_{b}=4.5 \mathrm{GeV} / c^{2}$. The rest energy of $\Upsilon$ is $9.5 \mathrm{GeV}$.

(a) Using dimensional analysis, derive a relation between the energy splitting of the $\psi$ and $\psi^{\prime}$ and that of the $\Upsilon$ and $\Upsilon^{\prime}$, and thereby evaluate the rest energy of the $\Upsilon^{\prime}$. (Express all energies in units of $\mathrm{GeV}$ )

(b) Call the $n=2$, zero orbital angular momentum charmonium particle the $\psi^{\prime \prime}$. Use the WKB approximation to estimate the energy splitting of the $\psi^{\prime}$ and the $\psi^{\prime \prime}$ in terms of the energy splitting of the $\psi$ and the $\psi^{\prime}$, and thereby give a numerical estimate of the rest energy of the $\psi^{\prime \prime}$.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

In the center-of-mass system of a quark and its antiquark, the equation of relative motion is

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \nabla_{r}^{2}+V(r)\right] \psi(\mathbf{r})=E_{R} \psi(\mathbf{r}), \quad \mu=m_{q} / 2
$$

where $E_{R}$ is the relative motion energy, $m_{q}$ is the mass of the quark. When the angular momentum is zero, the above equation in spherical coordinates can be simplified to

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d}{d r}\right)+V(r)\right] R(r)=E_{R} R(r) .
$$

Let $R(r)=\chi_{0}(r) / r$. Then $\chi_{0}(r)$ satisfies

$$
\frac{d^{2} \chi_{0}}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2 \mu}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E_{R}-V(r)\right] \chi_{0}=0
$$

i.e.,

$$
\frac{d^{2} \chi_{0}}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2 \mu}{\hbar^{2}}\left(E_{R}-A-B r\right) \chi_{0}=0
$$

(a) Suppose the energy of a bound state depends on the principal quantum number $n$, which is a dimensionless quantity, the constant $B$ in $V(r)$, the quark reduced mass $\mu$, and $\hbar$, namely

$$
E=f(n) B^{x} \mu^{y} \hbar^{z} .
$$

As,

$$
\begin{aligned}
{[E] } &=[M][L]^{2}[T]^{-2}, \\
{[B] } &=[M][L][T]^{-2}, \quad[\mu]=[M] \\
{[\hbar] } &=[M][L]^{2}[T]^{-1},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
x=z=\frac{2}{3}, \quad y=-\frac{1}{3}
$$

and hence

$$
E=f(n)(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}(\mu)^{-1 / 3},
$$

where $f(n)$ is a function of the principal quantum number $n$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_{\psi} &=E_{\psi^{\prime}}-E_{\psi}=f(1) \frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\mu_{c}^{1 / 3}}-f(0) \frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\mu_{c}^{1 / 3}} \\
&=\frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\mu_{c}^{1 / 3}}[f(1)-f(0)]
\end{aligned}
$$

and similarly

$$
\Delta E_{\Upsilon}=\frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\mu_{b}^{1 / 3}}[f(1)-f(0)]
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{\Delta E_{\Upsilon}}{\Delta E_{\psi}}=\left(\frac{\mu_{c}}{\mu_{b}}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{1 / 3} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\Upsilon^{\prime}}-E_{\Upsilon} & \approx 0.42 \mathrm{GeV} \\
E_{\Upsilon^{\prime}} &=E_{\Upsilon}+0.42=9.5+0.42 \approx 9.9 \mathrm{GeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Applying the WKB approximation to the equation for $\chi_{0}$ we obtain the Bohr-Sommerfeld quantization rule

$$
2 \int_{0}^{\alpha} \sqrt{2 \mu\left(E_{R}-A-B r\right)} d r=(n+3 / 4) \hbar \quad \text { with } \quad a=\frac{E_{R}-A}{B},
$$

which gives, writing $E_{n}$ for $E_{R}$,

$$
E_{n}=A+\frac{\left[3\left(n+\frac{3}{4}\right) B \hbar / 4\right]^{2 / 3}}{(2 \mu)^{1 / 3}} .
$$

Application to the energy splitting gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\psi^{\prime}}-E_{\psi} &=\frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\left(2 \mu_{c}\right)^{1 / 3}}\left[\left(\frac{21}{16}\right)^{2 / 3}-\left(\frac{9}{16}\right)^{2 / 3}\right] \\
E_{\psi^{\prime \prime}}-E_{\psi^{\prime}} &=\frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\left(2 \mu_{c}\right)^{1 / 3}}\left[\left(\frac{33}{16}\right)^{2 / 3}-\left(\frac{21}{16}\right)^{2 / 3}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\frac{E_{\psi^{\prime \prime}}-E_{\psi^{\prime}}}{E_{\psi^{\prime}}-E_{\psi}}=\frac{(33)^{2 / 3}-(21)^{2 / 3}}{(21)^{2 / 3}-(9)^{2 / 3}} \approx 0.81
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\psi^{\prime \prime}}-E_{\psi^{\prime}} &=0.81 \times\left(E_{\psi^{\prime}}-E_{\psi}\right)=0.81 \times(3.7-3.1) \\
& \approx 0.49 \mathrm{GeV}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
E_{\psi^{\prime \prime}}=3.7+0.49 \approx 4.2 \mathrm{GeV}
$$

\section{6}

Two particles, each of mass $M$, are attracted to each other by a potential

$$
V(r)=-\left(g^{2} / d\right) \exp (-r / d)
$$

where $d=\hbar / m c$ with $m c^{2}=140$ million electron volts $(\mathrm{MeV}), M c^{2}=$ $940 \mathrm{MeV}$. (a) Show that for $l=0$ the radial Schrödinger equation for this system can be reduced to Bessel's differential equation

$$
\frac{d^{2} J_{\rho}(\mathbf{x})}{d x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x} \frac{d J_{\rho}(x)}{d x}+\left(1-\frac{\rho^{2}}{x^{2}}\right) J_{\rho}(x)=0
$$

by means of the change of variable $x=\alpha \exp (-\beta r)$ for a suitable choice of $\alpha$ and $\beta$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-158.jpg?height=1140&width=892&top_left_y=629&top_left_x=213)

Fig. $2.5$ (b) Suppose that this system is found to have only one bound state with a binding energy of $2.2 \mathrm{MeV}$; evaluate $g^{2} / \hbar c$ numerically and state its units.

[Note: a graph of values $J_{\rho}(x)$ in $x-\rho$ plane has been provided with the information at the beginning of the examination (Fig. 2.5)].

(c) What would the minimum value of $g^{2} / \hbar c$ have to be in order to have two $l=0$ bound states ( $d$ and $M$ remaining the same)?.

\section{Solution:}

(a) When $l=0$, the radial wave function $R(r)=\chi(r) / r$ satisfies the equation

$$
\frac{d^{2} \chi(r)}{d r^{2}}+\frac{M}{\hbar^{2}}\left(E+\frac{g^{2}}{d} e^{-r / d}\right) \chi(r)=0,
$$

the reduced mass being $\mu=M / 2$. By the change of variable

$$
r \rightarrow x=\alpha e^{-\beta r}, \quad x \in[0, \alpha],
$$

and writing $\chi(r)=J(x)$, we have

$$
\frac{d^{2} J(x)}{d x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x} \frac{d J(x)}{d x}+\left[\frac{M g^{2}}{\hbar^{2} d \beta^{2}}\left(\frac{x}{\alpha}\right)^{1 / d \beta} \frac{1}{x^{2}}+\frac{M E}{\hbar^{2} \beta^{2}} \frac{1}{x^{2}}\right] J(x)=0 .
$$

\section{Letting}

$$
\alpha=\frac{2 g}{\hbar} \sqrt{M d}, \quad \beta=\frac{1}{2 d},
$$

and

$$
\rho^{2}=\frac{4 d^{2} M|E|}{\hbar^{2}}=-\frac{4 d^{2} M E}{\hbar^{2}},
$$

we can reduce the Schrödinger equation to Bessel's differential equation of order $\rho$

$$
\frac{d^{2} J_{\rho}(x)}{d x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x} \frac{d J_{\rho}(x)}{d x}+\left(1-\frac{\rho^{2}}{x^{2}}\right) J_{\rho}(x)=0 .
$$

Thus the (unnormalized) radial wave function is

$$
R(r)=\frac{J_{\rho}\left(\alpha e^{-\beta r}\right)}{r} .
$$

(b) For bound states we require that for $r \rightarrow \infty, R(r) \rightarrow 0$, or $J_{\rho}$ remains finite. This demands that $\rho \geq 0$. $R(r)$ must also be finite at $r=0$, which means that $\chi(0)=J_{\rho}(\alpha)=0$.

This equation has an infinite number of real roots. For $E=2.2 \mathrm{MeV}$,

$$
\rho=\frac{2 d}{\hbar} \sqrt{M|E|}=\frac{2}{m c^{2}} \sqrt{M c^{2}|E|}=\frac{2}{140} \sqrt{940 \times 2.2} \approx 0.65 .
$$

Figure $2.5$ shows the contours of $J_{\rho}(x)$ for different values (indicated by right and top numbers) of the function in the $x-\rho$ plane. The lowest zero of $J_{\rho}(x)$ for $\rho=0.65$ is $3.3$, the next 6.6. Thus for $\alpha \approx 3.3$, the system has one $l=0$ bound state, for which

$$
g^{2} / \hbar c=\hbar \alpha^{2} / 4 M c d=m c^{2} \alpha^{2} / 4 M c^{2} \approx 0.41
$$

which is a dimensionless constant.

(c) For $\alpha \approx 6.6$, there is an additional $l=0$ bound state. Thus the minimum value of $\alpha$ for two $l=0$ bound states is $6.6$, for which

$$
\left(g^{2} / \hbar c\right)_{\min }=m c^{2} \alpha_{\min }^{2} / 4 M c^{2} \approx 1.62
$$

\section{7}

Prove that in any single-particle bound energy eigenstate the following relation is satisfied in nonrelativistic quantum mechanics for a central fieldof-force potential $V(r)$,

$$
|\psi(0)|^{2}=\frac{m}{2 \pi}\left\langle\frac{d V(r)}{d r}\right\rangle-\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left\langle\frac{L^{2}}{r^{3}}\right\rangle
$$

where $\psi(0)$ is the wave function at the origin, $m$ the particle mass, and $L^{2}$ the square of the orbital angular momentum operator (let $\hbar=1$ ). Give a classical interpretation of this equation for the case of a state with angular momentum $\neq 0$

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

(a) In the field of central force, the Schrödinger equation is

$$
-\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)-\frac{\hat{l}^{2}}{r^{2}}\right] \psi+V(r) \psi=E \psi
$$

Let

$$
\psi(r, \theta, \varphi)=R(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi) \equiv \frac{1}{r} u(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)
$$

where $u(r)=r R(r)$, and we have for the radial motion

$$
u^{\prime \prime}+\left\{2 m[E-V(r)]-\frac{l(l+1)}{r^{2}}\right\} u=0, \quad(r>0) .
$$

Multiplying the two sides of the above with $u^{\prime}(r)$ and integrating from $r=0$ to $r=\infty$, we get

$$
\int u^{\prime}(r) u^{\prime \prime}(r) d r+\int\left\{2 m[E-V(r)]-\frac{l(l+1)}{r^{2}}\right\}\left(\frac{1}{2} u^{2}(r)\right)^{\prime} d r=0
$$

For the eigenstates we may assume $u^{\prime}(\infty)=0, u(\infty)=u(0)=0$. With $u^{\prime}(0)=\left[R(r)+r R^{\prime}(r)\right]_{r=0}=R(0)$, partial integration gives

$$
-\frac{1}{2} R^{2}(0)+\frac{1}{2}\left[2 m \int R^{2} \frac{d V(r)}{d r} r^{2} d r-\int \frac{2 l(l+1)}{r^{3}} R^{2} r d r\right]=0 \text {. }
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\psi(0)|^{2}=& \frac{1}{4 \pi} R^{2}(0) \\
=& \frac{m}{2 \pi} \int\left[R(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)\right] \frac{d V(r)}{d r}\left[R(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)\right] r^{2} d r d \Omega \\
&-\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int\left[R(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)\right] \frac{\hat{L}^{2}}{r^{3}}\left[R(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)\right] r^{2} d r d \Omega
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
|\psi(0)|^{2}=\frac{m}{2 \pi}\left\langle\frac{d V(r)}{d r}\right\rangle-\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left\langle\frac{\hat{L}^{2}}{r^{3}}\right\rangle .
$$

(b) For $l \neq 0,|\psi(\dot{0})|^{2}=0$, and so

$$
\left\langle\frac{d V(r)}{d r}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{m}\left\langle\frac{\hat{L}^{2}}{r^{3}}\right\rangle .
$$
