We choose $\chi_{S M_{S}}$ as the common eigenstate of $\mathbf{S}^{2}=\left(\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right)^{2}$ and $S_{z}=s_{1 z}+s_{2 z}$. For $S=1, M_{S}=0, \pm 1$, it is a triplet and is symmetric when the two electrons are exchanged. For $S=0, M_{S}=0$, it is a singlet and is antisymmetric. For stationary states we use the time-independent Schrödinger equation

$$
H_{S M_{S}}=E \chi_{S M_{S}} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{S}^{2} \chi_{1 M_{S}} &=S(S+1) \hbar^{2} \chi_{1 M_{S}}=2 \hbar^{2} \chi_{1 M_{S}}, \mathbf{S}^{2} \chi_{00}=0 \\
\mathbf{S}^{2} &=\left(\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right)^{2}=\mathbf{s}_{1}^{2}+\mathbf{s}_{2}^{2}+2 \mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2} \\
&=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{4}+\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}+2 \mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
s_{1} \cdot s_{2} \chi_{1 M_{S}}=\left(\frac{S^{2}}{2}-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}\right) \chi_{1 M_{S}}=\left(\hbar^{2}-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}\right) \chi_{1 M_{S}}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} \chi_{1 M_{S}}
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2} \chi_{00}=\left(0-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}\right) \chi_{00}=-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2} \chi_{00}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
S_{z} \chi_{1 M_{S}} &=\left(s_{1 z}+s_{2 z}\right) \chi_{1 M_{S}}=M_{S} \hbar \chi_{1 M_{S}}, \\
s_{z} \chi_{00} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence for the triplet state, the energy levels are

$$
E=M_{S} \hbar A+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} B, \quad \text { with } \quad M_{S}=0, \pm 1,
$$

comprising three lines

$$
E_{1}=\hbar A+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} B, E_{2}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} B, E_{3}=-\hbar A+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} B
$$

For the singlet state, the energy level consists of only one line

$$
E_{0}=-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2} B .
$$

\section{2}

Suppose an atom is initially in an excited ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ state (Fig. 3.1) and subsequently decays into a lower, short-lived ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state with emission of a photon $\gamma_{1}$ (Fig. 3.2). Soon after, it decays into the ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ ground state by emitting a second photon $\gamma_{2}$ (Fig. 3.3). Let $\theta$ be the angle between the two emitted photons.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-210.jpg?height=199&width=192&top_left_y=1201&top_left_x=563)

Fig. $3.1$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-210.jpg?height=281&width=188&top_left_y=1499&top_left_x=565)

Fig. $3.2$ 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-211.jpg?height=278&width=209&top_left_y=160&top_left_x=562)

Fig. 3.3

(a) What is the relative probability of $\theta$ in this process?

(b) What is the ratio of finding both photons with the same circular polarization to that of finding the photons with opposite circular polarizations?

It may be of some help to know the rotation matrices $d_{m^{\prime} m}$, which relate one angular momentum representation in one coordinate system to another angular momentum representation in a rotated coordinate system, given below:

$$
\begin{array}{cccc}
m=1 & m=0 & m=-1 \\
m^{\prime}=1
\end{array}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{1+\cos \alpha}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \frac{1-\cos \alpha}{2} \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha \\
\frac{1-\cos \alpha}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \frac{1+\cos \alpha}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\alpha$ is the angle between the $z$-axis of one system and the $z^{\prime}$-axis of the other.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

The atom is initially in the excited state ${ }^{1} S_{0}$. Thus the projection of the atomic angular momentum on an arbitrary $z$ direction is $L_{z}=0$. We can take the direction of the first photon emission as the $z$ direction. After the emission of the photon and the atom goes into the ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state, if the angular momentum of that photon is $L_{z}=\pm \hbar$, correspondingly the angular momentum of the atomic state ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ is $L_{z}=\mp \hbar$, i.e., $m_{z}=\mp 1$. If we let the direction of emission of the second photon be the $z^{\prime}$-axis the projection of the eigenstate of the $z$-component of angular momentum on the $z^{\prime}$ direction is equivalent to multiplying the initial state with the $d_{m^{\prime} m}$ matrix. Only atoms that are in states $m_{z}^{\prime}=\pm 1$ can emit photon (as $L_{z}^{\prime}=\pm \hbar$ must be satisfied) in $z^{\prime}$ direction and make the atom decay into the ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ state $\left(m_{z}^{\prime}=0\right)$. Then the transitions are from $m=\pm 1$ to $m^{\prime}=\pm 1$, and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C_{1}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=-1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=+1\right\rangle \\
& =(0,0,1)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} \\\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \cos \theta & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta \\\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& =\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{2}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=+1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=+1\right\rangle \\
& =(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} \\\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \cos \theta & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta \\\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& =\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{3}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=+1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{4}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=-1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(a) The relative probability of $\theta$ is

$$
P(\theta) \propto\left|C_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{2}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{3}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{4}\right|^{2}=1+\cos ^{2} \theta .
$$

(b) The ratio of the probability of finding both photons with the same circular polarization to that of finding the photons with opposite circular polarizations is

$$
\left(\left|C_{2}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{4}\right|^{2}\right) /\left(\left|C_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{3}\right|^{2}\right)=(1+\cos \theta)^{2} /(1-\cos \theta)^{2} .
$$



\section{3}

Consider an electron in a uniform magnetic field in the positive $z \mathrm{di}$ rection. The result of a measurement has shown that the electron spin is along the positive $x$ direction at $t=0$. Use Ehrenfest's theorem to compute the probability for $t>0$ that the electron is in the state (a) $s_{x}=1 / 2$, (b) $s_{x}=-1 / 2$, (c) $s_{y}=1 / 2$, (d) $s_{y}=-1 / 2$, (e) $s_{z}=1 / 2$, (f) $s_{z}=-1 / 2$.

Ehrenfest's theorem states that the expectation values of a quantum mechanical operator obey the classical equation of motion.

[Hint: Recall the connection between expectation values and probability considerations].

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

In the classical picture, an electron spinning with angular momentum $\mathbf{s}$ in a magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ will, if the directions of $\mathbf{s}$ and $\mathbf{B}$ do not coincide, precess about the direction of $\mathbf{B}$ with an angular velocity $\mathbf{w}$ given by

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{s}}{d t}=\mathbf{s} \times \boldsymbol{\omega},
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\omega}=\frac{e}{m c} \mathbf{B}, m$ being the electron mass. Ehrenfest's theorem then states that in quantum mechanics we have

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\langle\mathbf{s}\rangle=\frac{e}{m c}\langle\mathbf{s}\rangle \times \mathbf{B} .
$$

This can be derived directly as follows.

An electron with spin angular momentum s has a magnetic moment $\boldsymbol{\mu}=\frac{e}{m c} \mathbf{s}$ and consequently a Hamiltonian

$$
H=-\mu \cdot \mathbf{B}=-\frac{e}{m c} B s_{z},
$$

taking the $z$ axis along the direction of $\mathbf{B}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\langle\mathbf{s}\rangle}{d t} &=\overline{\frac{1}{i \hbar}[\mathbf{s}, \hat{H}]}=-\frac{e B}{i \hbar m c} \overline{\left[s_{x} \hat{\mathbf{x}}+s_{y} \hat{\mathbf{y}}+s_{z} \hat{\mathbf{z}}, s_{z}\right]} \\
&=-\frac{e B}{i \hbar m c}\left\{\overline{\left[s_{x}, s_{z}\right] \hat{\mathbf{x}}}+\overline{\left[s_{y}, s_{z}\right]} \hat{\mathbf{y}}\right\} \\
&=-\frac{e}{m c} B\left(-\left\langle s_{y}\right\rangle \hat{\mathbf{x}}+\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle \hat{\mathbf{y}}\right) \\
&=\frac{e}{m c}\langle\mathbf{s}\rangle \times \mathbf{B},
\end{aligned}
$$

in agreement with the above. Note that use has been made of the commutation relations $\left[s_{x}, s_{y}\right]=i \hbar s_{z}$, etc.

Initially $\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle=1 / 2,\left\langle s_{y}\right\rangle=\left\langle s_{z}\right\rangle=0$, and so we can write for $t>0$, $\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle=(\cos \omega t) / 2,\left\langle s_{y}\right\rangle=(\sin \omega t) / 2,\left\langle s_{z}\right\rangle=0$.

Let the probability for $t>0$ of the electron being in the state $s_{x}=1 / 2$ be $P$ and being in the state $s_{x}=-1 / 2$ be $1-P$ since these are the only two states of $s_{x}$. Then

$$
P\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)+(1-P)\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \cos \omega t
$$

giving

$$
P=\cos ^{2}(\omega t / 2), \quad 1-P=\sin ^{2}(\omega t / 2) .
$$

Similarly, let the probabilities for the electron being in the states $s_{y}=$ $1 / 2, s_{y}=-1 / 2$ be $P$ and $1-P$ respectively. Then

$$
P\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)+(1-P)\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \sin \omega t=\frac{1}{2} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\omega t\right),
$$

or

$$
P=\frac{1}{2}\left[1+\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\omega t\right)\right]=\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\omega t}{2}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \text {, }
$$

and hence $1-P=\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\omega t}{2}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)$. Lastly for (e) and (f), we have

$$
P-\frac{1}{2}=0, \quad \text { giving } \quad P=\frac{1}{2}, \quad 1-P=\frac{1}{2} .
$$

\section{4}

A particle with magnetic moment $\mu=\mu_{0}$ s and spin s, with magnitude $1 / 2$, is placed in a constant magnetic field pointing along the $x$-axis. At $t=0$, the particle is found to have $s_{z}=+1 / 2$. Find the probabilities at any later time of finding the particle with $s_{y}=\pm 1 / 2$.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

The Hamiltonian (spin part) of the system is

$$
\hat{H}=-\mu_{0} \hat{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}=-\frac{1}{2} \hat{\sigma}_{x} B \mu_{0},
$$

as $\mathbf{s}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \sigma_{x}$, being in the $x$ direction. In the $\sigma_{x}$ representation, the Schrödinger equation that the spin wave function $\left(\begin{array}{l}a_{1} \\ a_{2}\end{array}\right)$ satisfies is

$$
i \hbar \frac{d}{d t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2}
\end{array}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \mu_{0} B\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2}
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

or

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
i \hbar \frac{d}{d t} a_{1}+\frac{1}{2} \mu_{0} B a_{2}=0 \\
i \hbar \frac{d}{d t} a_{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mu_{0} B a_{1}=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Elimination of $a_{1}$ or $a_{2}$ gives

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}} a_{1,2}+\frac{\mu_{0}^{2} B^{2}}{4 \hbar^{2}} a_{1,2}=0,
$$

which have solutions

$$
a_{1,2}=A_{1,2} e^{i \omega t}+B_{1,2} e^{-i \omega t}
$$

where

$$
\omega=\frac{\mu_{0} B}{2 \hbar}
$$

and $A_{1,2}, B_{1,2}$ are constants. As

$$
\hat{s}_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{z}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)
$$

and

$$
\hat{s}_{z}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right),
$$

the initial spin wave function is $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$, i.e. $a_{1}(0)=1, a_{2}(0)=0$. The Schrödinger equation then gives

$$
\frac{d a_{1}(0)}{d t}=0, \quad \frac{d a_{2}(0)}{d t}=i \frac{\mu_{0} B}{2 \hbar}=i \omega .
$$

These four initial conditions give

$$
\begin{cases}A_{1}+B_{1}=1, & A_{2}+B_{2}=0 \\ \omega\left(A_{1}-B_{1}\right)=0, & \omega\left(A_{2}-B_{2}\right)=\omega\end{cases}
$$

with the solution $A_{1}=A_{2}=B_{1}=-B_{2}=1 / 2$. Substitution in the expressions for $a_{1,2}$ results in

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
a_{1}(t) \\
a_{2}(t)
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega t \\
i \sin \omega t
\end{array}\right) .
$$

As the eigenstate of $s_{y}=+1 / 2$ is

$$
\left|s_{y}(+)\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
i
\end{array}\right)
$$

and that of $s_{y}=-1 / 2$ is

$$
\left|s_{y}(-)\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
-i
\end{array}\right)
$$

the probability of finding $s_{y}=+1 / 2$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(+) &=\left|\left\langle s_{y}(+) \mid \psi(t)\right\rangle\right|^{2} \\
&=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1-i)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega t \\
i \sin \omega t
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2}(1+\sin 2 \omega t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly the probability of finding $s_{y}=-1 / 2$ is

$$
P(-)=\left|\left\langle s_{y}(-) \mid \psi(t)\right\rangle\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2}(1-\sin 2 \omega t) .
$$

\section{5}

The Hamiltonian for a spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particle with charge $+e$ in an external magnetic field is

$$
H=-\frac{g e}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B} \text {. }
$$

Calculate the operator $d \mathbf{s} / d t$ if $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{y}$. What is $s_{z}(t)$ in matrix form?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

In the Heisenberg picture,

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{s}}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}[\mathbf{s}, H]=-\frac{g e}{i 2 m \hbar c}[\mathbf{s}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}] .
$$

As

$$
[\mathbf{s}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}]=\left[s_{x}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] \hat{\mathbf{x}}+\left[s_{y}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] \hat{\mathbf{y}}+\left[s_{z}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] \hat{\mathbf{z}}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[s_{x}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] } &=\left[s_{x}, s_{z}\right] B_{x}+\left[s_{x}, s_{y}\right] B_{y}+\left[s_{x}, s_{z}\right] B_{z} \\
&=i \hbar\left(s_{z} B_{y}-s_{y} B_{z}\right) \\
&=i \hbar(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{s})_{x}, \quad \text { etc }
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
[\mathbf{s}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}]=-i \hbar \mathbf{s} \times \mathbf{B},
$$

and hence

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{s}}{d t}=+\frac{g e}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \times \mathbf{B} .
$$

If $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{\mathbf{y}}$, the above gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d s_{x}(t)}{d t} &=-\frac{g e B}{2 m c} s_{z}(t), \\
\frac{d s_{z}(t)}{d t} &=\frac{g e B}{2 m c} s_{x}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

and so

$$
\frac{d^{2} s_{z}(t)}{d t^{2}}+\left(\frac{g e B}{2 m c}\right)^{2} s_{z}(t)=0
$$

with the solution

$$
s_{z}(t)=c_{1} \cos (g \omega t)+c_{2} \sin (g \omega t),
$$

where $\omega=e B / 2 m c$. At $t=0$ we have

$$
s_{z}(0)=c_{1}, \quad s_{z}^{\prime}(0)=c_{2} g \omega=g \omega s_{x}(0)
$$

and hence

$$
s_{z}(t)=s_{z}(0) \cos \left(\frac{g e B}{2 m c} t\right)+s_{x}(0) \sin \left(\frac{g e B}{2 m c} t\right) .
$$



\section{6}

Two electrons are tightly bound to different neighboring sites in a certain solid. They are, therefore, distinguishable particles which can be described in terms of their respective Pauli spin matrices $\sigma^{(1)}$ and $\sigma^{(2)}$. The Hamiltonian of these electrons takes the form

$$
H=-J\left(\sigma_{x}^{(1)} \sigma_{x}^{(2)}+\sigma_{y}^{(1)} \sigma_{y}^{(2)}\right)
$$

where $J$ is a constant.

(a) How many energy levels does the system have? What are their energies? What is the degeneracy of the different levels?

(b) Now add a magnetic field in the $z$ direction. What are the new energy levels? Draw an energy level diagram as a function of $B_{z}$.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=&-J\left[\sigma_{x}^{(1)} \sigma_{x}^{(2)}+\sigma_{y}^{(1)} \sigma_{y}^{(2)}\right] \\
=&-J\left[\frac{\left(\sigma^{(1)}+\sigma^{(2)}\right)^{2}-\sigma^{(1)^{2}}-\sigma^{(2)^{2}}}{2}\right.\\
&\left.-\frac{\left(\sigma_{z}^{(1)}+\sigma_{z}^{(2)}\right)^{2}-\sigma_{z}^{(1)^{2}}-\sigma_{z}^{(2)^{2}}}{2}\right] \\
=&-J\left[\frac{\left(\sigma^{(1)}+\sigma^{(2)}\right)^{2}-3-3}{2}\right.\\
&\left.-\frac{\left(\sigma_{z}^{(1)}+\sigma_{z}^{(2)}\right)^{2}-1-1}{2}\right] \\
=&-J\left[\frac{\left(\sigma^{(1)}+\sigma^{(2)}\right)^{2}-\left(\sigma_{z}^{(1)}+\sigma_{z}^{(2)}\right)^{2}}{2}-2\right] \\
=&-\frac{2 J}{\hbar^{2}}\left(\mathbf{s}^{2}-s_{z}^{2}-\hbar^{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\mathbf{s}=\mathbf{s}^{(1)}+\mathbf{s}^{(2)}=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\sigma^{(1)}+\sigma^{(2)}\right)
$$

is the total spin of the system and

$$
s_{z}=s_{z}^{(1)}+s_{z}^{(2)}=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\sigma_{z}^{(1)}+\sigma_{z}^{(2)}\right)
$$

is its total $z$-component. $s^{2}, s_{z}$ and $H$ are commutable. Using the above and the coupling theory of angular momentum, we have (noting the eigenvalue of $s^{2}$ is $\left.s(s+1) \hbar^{2}\right)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-219.jpg?height=222&width=619&top_left_y=588&top_left_x=349)

(a) As seen from the table, the system has three energy levels $-2 J, 0$, $2 J$, each with a degeneracy of 2 . Note that if the electrons are indistinguishable, the second and fourth rows of the table would be different from the above.

(b) In the presence of a magnetic field $|\mathbf{B}|=B_{z}$,

$$
H=-J\left[\sigma_{x}^{(1)} \sigma_{x}^{(2)}+\sigma_{y}^{(1)} \sigma_{y}^{(2)}\right]-\mu \cdot \mathbf{B}
$$

where

$$
\boldsymbol{\mu}=-\frac{e}{m c} \mathbf{s}
$$

$-e$ and $m$ being the electron charge and mass respectively. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=-J\left[\sigma_{x}^{(1)} \sigma_{x}^{(2)}+\sigma_{y}^{(1)} \sigma_{y}^{(2)}\right]+\frac{e}{m c} s_{z} B_{z} \\
&=-2 J\left[s(s+1)-\frac{s_{z}^{2}}{\hbar^{2}}-1\right]+\frac{e B_{z}}{m c} s_{z}
\end{aligned}
$$

$s^{2}, s_{z}$ and $H$ are still commutable, so the new energy levels are: $2 \mathrm{~J}$, $e B_{z} \hbar / m c,-e B_{z} \hbar / m c,-2 J$. The energy level diagram is shown in Fig. $3.4$ as a function of $B_{z}$ (lines $1,2,3$ and 4 for the above levels respectively). 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-220.jpg?height=611&width=660&top_left_y=162&top_left_x=321)

Fig. $3.4$

\section{7}

A free atom of carbon has four paired electrons in $s$-states and two electrons in $p$-states. Assume there is the fine structure coupling $\mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{S}$, i.e., $L^{2}, S^{2}$ and $J^{2}$ are "good" quantum numbers.

(a) Give the values of $S, L$ and $J$ of possible states by a table, indicating the corresponding multiplicities.

(b) Which state has the lowest energy? Give your reasoning.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

(a) A carbon atom has two 1s electrons and two 2s electrons, which form two closed shells. Thus the atomic states are determined by the combination of the two $2 p$ electrons. In $\mathbf{L}-\mathbf{S}$ coupling, as $l_{1}=l_{2}=1, s_{1}=s_{2}=1 / 2$, we have $L=\left|\mathbf{l}_{1}+\mathbf{l}_{2}\right|=0,1,2 ; S=\left|\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right|=0,1$. Taking into account Pauli's exclusion principle and the antisymmetry of the total wave function, we obtain the following table.

(b) According to Hund's rule, the ${ }^{3} P_{0}$ state has the lowest energy. 

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline$L$ & $S$ & $j$ & ${ }^{2 s+1} L_{j}$ & multiplicity \\
\hline 0 & 0 & 0 & ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ & 1 \\
1 & 1 & 2 & ${ }^{3} P_{2}$ & \\
1 & 1 & 1 & ${ }^{3} P_{1}$ & 3 \\
1 & 1 & 0 & ${ }^{3} P_{0}$ & \\
2 & 0 & 2 & ${ }^{1} D_{2}$ & 1 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

\section{8}

A negatively charged $\pi^{-}$meason (a pseudoscalar particle: zero spin, odd parity) is initially bound in the lowest-energy Coulomb wave function around a deuteron. It is captured by the deuteron (a proton and a neutron in a ${ }^{3} S_{1}$ state), which is converted into a pair of neutrons:

$$
\pi^{-}+d \rightarrow n+n .
$$

(a) What is the orbital angular momentum of the neutron pair?

(b) What is their total spin angular momentum?

(c) What is the probability for finding both neutron spins directed opposite to the spin of the deuteron?

(d) If the deuteron's spin is initially $100 \%$ polarized in the $\hat{\mathbf{R}}$ direction, what is the angular distribution of the neutron emission probability (per unit solid angle) for a neutron whose spin is opposite to that of the initial deuteron?

You may find some of the first few (not normalized) spherical harmonics useful:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
Y_{0}^{0}=1, & Y_{1}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sin \theta e^{\pm i \phi}, \\
Y_{1}^{0}=\cos \theta, & Y_{2}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sin 2 \theta e^{\pm i \phi} .
\end{array}
$$

\section{Solution:}

(a), (b) Because of the conservation of parity in strong interactions, we have

$$
p\left(\pi^{-}\right) p(d)(-1)^{L_{1}}=p(n) p(n)(-1)^{L_{2}},
$$

where $L_{1}, L_{2}$ are the orbital angular momenta of $\pi^{-}+d$ and $n+n$ respectively. As the $\pi^{-}$, being captured, is in the lowest energy state of the Coulomb potential before the reaction, $L_{1}=0$. Since $p\left(\pi^{-}\right)=-1, p(d)=$ $1, p(n) p(n)=1$, we have

$$
(-1)^{L_{2}}=-1 \text {, }
$$

and so

$$
L_{2}=2 m+1, m=0,1,2, \ldots .
$$

The deutron has $J=1$ and $\pi^{-}$has zero spin, so that $J=1$ before the reaction takes place. The conservation of angular momentum requires that after the reaction, $\mathbf{L}_{2}+\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{J}$. The identity of $n$ and $n$ demands that the total wave function be antisymmetric. Then since the spacial wave function is antisymmetric, the spin wave function must be symmetric, i.e. $S=1$ and so $L_{2}=2,1$ or 0 . As $L_{2}$ is odd, we must have $L_{2}=1, S=1$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-222.jpg?height=420&width=265&top_left_y=782&top_left_x=532)

Fig. $3.5$

The total orbital angular momentum and the total spin angular momentum are both $\sqrt{1(1+1)} \hbar=\sqrt{2} \hbar$.

(c) Assume that the deuteron spin is in the direction $J_{z}=1 \hbar$ before the reaction. If both neutrons had spins in the reversed direction, we would have $S_{z}=-1 \hbar, L_{z}=2 \hbar$, which is impossible since $L_{2}=1$. Hence the probability is zero.

(d) Take the $z$-axis along the $\hat{\mathbf{R}}$ direction. Then the initial state is $\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=|1,1\rangle$. In the noncoupling representation, the state is $\mid L, L_{z}$, $\left.S, S_{z}\right\rangle$, with $L=1, S=1$. Thus

$$
|1,1\rangle=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}|1,0,1,1\rangle-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}|1,1,1,0\rangle .
$$

The state

$$
|1,1,1,0\rangle=Y_{1}^{1}(\theta, \phi)|1,0\rangle=-\sqrt{3 / 8 \pi} \sin \theta e^{i \phi}|1,0\rangle
$$

has $S_{z}=0$ and so there must be one neutron with $s_{z}=-\hbar / 2$. Hence the probability distribution required is

$$
d P(\theta, \phi) / d \Omega=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta=\frac{3}{16 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta .
$$

\section{9}

An $\Omega^{-}$hyperon (spin $3 / 2$, mass $1672 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $+$ ) can decay via the weak interaction into a $\Lambda$ hyperon (spin $1 / 2$, mass $1116 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $+$ ) and a $K^{-}$meson (spin 0 , mass $494 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $-)$, i.e., $\Omega^{-} \rightarrow \Lambda+K^{-}$.

(a) What is the most general form of the angular distribution of the $K^{-}$mesons relative to the spin direction of the $\Omega^{-}$for the case when the $\Omega^{-}$has a maximum possible component of angular momentum along the $z$-axis, i.e., the initial state $\left|\Omega_{j}^{m}\right\rangle=\left|\Omega_{3 / 2}^{+3 / 2}\right\rangle$. (Assume that the $\Omega^{-}$is at rest).

(b) What restrictions, if any, would be imposed on the form of the angular distribution if parity were conserved in the decay process?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The initial state of the system is $|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle$, where the values are the orbital and spin momenta of the $\Omega^{-}$. The spin part of the final state is $\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle|0,0\rangle=\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle$, and the orbital part is $Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)=|l, m\rangle$. Thus the total final state of this system is

$$
|l, m\rangle\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle \text {. }
$$

By conservation of angular momentum $l=1,2 ; m=3 / 2-s_{z}$. Thus the final state is a $p$ wave if $l=1$, the state being $|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle$; a $d$ wave if $l=2$, the state being a combination of $|2,2\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle$ and $|2,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle$

Hence the wave functions are

$$
\psi_{p}=Y_{11}(\theta, \varphi)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$



$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{d} &=\left[\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}}|2,2\rangle\left|\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle-\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}}|2,1\rangle\left|\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right] \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} Y_{21}(\theta, \varphi) \\
\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}} Y_{22}(\theta, \varphi)
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi &=a_{d} \psi_{d}+a_{p} \psi_{p} \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
a_{p} Y_{11}(\theta, \varphi)-a_{d} \sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} Y_{21}(\theta, \varphi) \\
\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}} a_{d} Y_{22}(\theta, \varphi)
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
\psi^{*} \psi=\frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta\left[\left|a_{p}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{d}\right|^{2}-2 R e a_{p}^{*} a_{d} \cos \theta\right],
$$

i.e., the intensity of the emitted particles is

$$
I \propto \sin ^{2} \theta(1+\alpha \cos \theta),
$$

where

$$
\alpha=-2 \operatorname{Re} a_{p}^{*} a_{d} /\left(\left|a_{p}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{d}\right|^{2}\right) .
$$

This is the most general form of the angular distribution of the $\mathrm{K}^{-}$mesons.

(b) If parity were conserved in the decay process, the final state would have positive parity, i.e.

$$
(-1)^{l} P_{K} P_{\Lambda}=+1
$$

Since

$$
P_{K} P_{\Lambda}=(-1)(+1)=-1 \text {, }
$$

we get $l=1$. It would follow that

$$
\psi_{f}=Y_{11}(\theta, \varphi)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

and

$$
\psi_{f}^{*} \psi_{f}=\frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta=\frac{3}{8 \pi}\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right) .
$$

Hence parity conservation would impose an angular distribution of the form

$$
I \propto\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right) .
$$

\section{0}

Given two angular momenta $\mathbf{J}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{J}_{2}$ (for example, $\mathbf{L}$ and $\mathbf{S}$ ) and the corresponding wave functions, where $j_{1}=1$ and $j_{2}=1 / 2$. Compute the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for the states with $\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{J}_{1}+\mathbf{J}_{2}, m=m_{1}+m_{2}$, where:
(a) $j=3 / 2, m=3 / 2$,
(b) $j=3 / 2, m=1 / 2$.

Consider the reactions

$$
\begin{aligned}
K^{-} p & \rightarrow \Sigma^{-} \pi^{+} \\
& \rightarrow \Sigma^{+} \pi^{-} \\
& \rightarrow \Sigma^{0} \pi^{0} \\
K^{-} n & \rightarrow \Sigma^{-} \pi^{0} \\
& \rightarrow \Sigma^{0} \pi^{-} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Assume they proceed through a resonance and hence a pure $I$-spin state. Find the relative rates based on $I$-spin conservation:

(c) for an $I=1$ resonance state,

(d) for an $I=0$ resonance state.

Use the Clebsch-Gordan cofficients supplied. The $I$-spins for $K, n, \Sigma$, and $\pi$ are $1 / 2,1 / 2,1$, and 1 respectively.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $j_{1}=1, j_{2}=\frac{1}{2}$, we have

$$
|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle=|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle \text {. }
$$

(b) Defining the operator $J_{-}=J_{1-}+J_{2-}$, we have

$$
J_{-}|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle=\left(J_{1-}+J_{2-}\right)|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle,
$$

or, using the properties of $J_{-}$(Problem 3008),

$$
\hbar \sqrt{3}|3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\hbar \sqrt{2}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle+\hbar|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle,
$$

and hence

$$
|3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle+\sqrt{1 / 3}|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle .
$$

To calculate the relative reaction cross sections, we use the coupling representation to describe the initial and final $I$-spin states:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|K^{-} p\right\rangle &=|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{1 / 2}|1,0\rangle-\sqrt{1 / 2}|0,0\rangle \\
\left|\Sigma^{-} \pi^{+}\right\rangle &=|1,-1\rangle|1,1\rangle=\sqrt{1 / 6}|2,0\rangle-\sqrt{1 / 2}|1,0\rangle+\sqrt{1 / 3}|0,0\rangle \\
\left|\Sigma^{+} \pi^{-}\right\rangle &=|1,1\rangle|1,-1\rangle=\sqrt{1 / 6}|2,0\rangle+\sqrt{1 / 2}|1,0\rangle+\sqrt{1 / 3}|0,0\rangle, \\
\left|\Sigma^{0} \pi^{0}\right\rangle &=|1,0\rangle|1,0\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}|2,0\rangle-\sqrt{1 / 3}|0,0\rangle \\
\left|K^{-} n\right\rangle &=|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle=|1,-1\rangle \\
\left|\Sigma^{-} \pi^{0}\right\rangle &=|1,-1\rangle|1,0\rangle=\sqrt{1 / 2}|2,-1\rangle-\sqrt{1 / 2}|1,-1\rangle \\
\left|\Sigma^{0} \pi^{-}\right\rangle &=|1,0\rangle|1,-1\rangle=\sqrt{1 / 2}|2,-1\rangle+\sqrt{1 / 2}|1,-1\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

To $K^{-} p$ reactions going through the resonance state $I=1$, the final states $\left|\Sigma^{-} \pi^{+}\right\rangle$contributes $-\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}|1,0\rangle,\left|\Sigma^{+} \pi^{-}\right\rangle$contributes $\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}|1,0\rangle$, while $\left|\Sigma^{0} \pi^{0}\right\rangle$ does not contribute. Hence

$$
\sigma\left(\Sigma^{-} \pi^{+}\right): \sigma\left(\Sigma^{+} \pi^{-}\right): \sigma\left(\Sigma^{0} \pi^{0}\right)=1: 1: 0 .
$$

Similarly for $K^{-} n$ reactions we have

$$
\sigma\left(\Sigma^{-} \pi^{0}\right): \sigma\left(\Sigma^{0} \pi^{-}\right)=1: 1 .
$$

Only the $K^{-} p$ reactions go through the $I=0$ resonance state. A similar consideration gives the following reaction cross section ratios:

$$
\sigma\left(\Sigma^{-} \pi^{+}\right): \sigma\left(\Sigma^{+} \pi^{-}\right): \sigma\left(\Sigma^{0} \pi^{0}\right)=1: 1: 1 .
$$



\section{1}

(a) Compute the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for the states with $\mathbf{J}=$ $\mathbf{J}_{1}+\mathbf{J}_{2}, M=m_{1}+m_{2}$, where $j_{1}=1$ and $j_{2}=1 / 2$, and $j=3 / 2, M=1 / 2$ for the various possible $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ values.

(b) Consider the reactions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\pi^{+} p \rightarrow \pi^{+} p \\
&\pi^{-} p \rightarrow \pi^{-} p \\
&\pi^{-} p \rightarrow \pi^{0} n
\end{aligned}
$$

These reactions, which conserve isospin, can occur in the isospin $I=3 / 2$ state ( $\Delta$ resonance ) or the $I=1 / 2$ state $\left(N^{*}\right.$ resonance). Calculate the ratios of these cross-sections, $\sigma_{\mathrm{i}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{ii}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{iii}}$, for an energy corresponding to a $\Delta$ resonance and an $N^{*}$ resonance respectively. At a resonance energy you can neglect the effect due to the other isospin states. Note that the pion is an isospin $I=1$ state and the nucleon an isospin $I=1 / 2$ state.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $M=m_{1}+m_{2}=1 / 2,\left(m_{1}, m_{2}\right)$ can only be $(1,-1 / 2)$ or $(0,1 / 2)$. Consider

$$
|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle=|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle .
$$

As

$$
M_{-}|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{3}|3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle,
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
M_{-}|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle &=\left(M_{1-}+M_{2-}\right)|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle \\
&=\sqrt{2}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle+|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle,
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\langle 1,1,1 / 2,-1 / 2 \mid 3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=1 / \sqrt{3} \\
\langle 1,0,1 / 2,1 / 2 \mid 3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}
\end{gathered}
$$

(b) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi^{+} &=|1,1\rangle, \quad \pi^{0}=|1,0\rangle, \quad \pi^{-}=|1,-1\rangle, \\
p &=|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle, \quad n=|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle,
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\pi^{+} p\right\rangle &=|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle \\
\left|\pi^{-} p\right\rangle &=|1,-1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=a|3 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle+b|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle, \\
\left|\pi^{0} n\right\rangle &=|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle=c|3 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle+d|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

From a table of Clebsch-Gordan coefficients, we find $a=\sqrt{1 / 3}, b=$ $-\sqrt{2 / 3}, c=\sqrt{2 / 3}, d=\sqrt{1 / 3}$. For the $\Delta$ resonance state, $I=3 / 2$ and the ratios of the cross sections are

$$
\sigma_{\mathrm{i}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{ii}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{iii}}=1:|a|^{4}:|a c|^{2}=1: \frac{1}{9}: \frac{2}{9} .
$$

For the $N^{*}$ resonance state, $I=1 / 2$, and the ratios are

$$
\sigma_{\mathrm{i}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{ii}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{iii}}=0:|b|^{4}:|b d|^{2}=0: \frac{4}{9}: \frac{2}{9} .
$$

\section{2}

Consider an electron in a uniform magnetic field along the $z$ direction. Let the result of a measurement be that the electron spin is along the positive $y$ direction at $t=0$. Find the Schrödinger state vector for the spin, and the average polarization (expectation value of $s_{x}$ ) along the $x$ direction for $t>0$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

As we are only interested in the spin state and the magnetic field is uniform in space, we can leave out the space part of the wave function. Then the Hamiltonian can be taken to be

$$
H=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\mu_{e} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\hbar \omega \sigma_{z},
$$

where $\mu=-\mu_{e} \sigma, \omega=\mu_{e} B / \hbar=e B / 2 m c, \mu_{e}$ being the Bohr magneton $\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}$. As the electron is initially along the $y$ direction, the initial spin wave function is

$$
\psi(t=0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
i
\end{array}\right)
$$

Let the spin wave function at a later time $t$ be $\left(\begin{array}{c}\alpha \\ \beta\end{array}\right)$. The Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar d \psi / d t=H \psi
$$

then gives

$$
i \hbar\left(\begin{array}{l}
\dot{\alpha} \\
\dot{\beta}
\end{array}\right)=\hbar \omega\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\alpha \\
\beta
\end{array}\right)
$$

or

$$
\dot{\alpha}=-i \omega \alpha, \quad \dot{\beta}=i \omega \beta,
$$

with the solution

$$
\psi(t)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\alpha(t) \\
\beta(t)
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i \omega t} \alpha_{0} \\
e^{i \omega t} \beta_{0}
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i \omega t} \\
i e^{-i \omega t}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle &=\left\langle\psi(t)\left|\hat{s}_{x}\right| \psi(t)\right\rangle \\
&=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left\langle\psi\left|\sigma_{x}\right| \psi\right\rangle \\
&=\frac{\hbar}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i \omega t}-i e^{-i \omega t}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
e^{-i \omega t} \\
i e^{i \omega t}
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{i \hbar}{4}\left(e^{2 i \omega t}-e^{-2 i \omega t}\right) \\
&=-\frac{\hbar}{2} \sin (2 \omega t)
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{3}

Consider an electron in a uniform magnetic field pointing along the $z$ direction. The electron spin is measured (at time $t_{0}$ ) to be pointing along the positive $y$-axis. What is the polarization along the $x$ and $z$ directions (i.e. the expectation values of $2 s_{x}$ and $2 s_{z}$ ) for $t>t_{0}$ ?

$($ Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The Schrödinger equation for the spin state vector is

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)=-\mu \cdot \mathbf{B}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)=\mu_{e} \sigma \cdot \mathbf{B}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\mu_{e}=|e| \hbar / 2 m_{e} c$ is the magnitude of the magnetic moment of an electron. As $\mathbf{B}$ is along the $z$ direction, the above becomes

or

$$
i \hbar \partial_{t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)=\mu_{e} B\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right) \text {, }
$$

The solutions are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
i \hbar \partial_{t} a(t)=\mu_{e} B a(t), \\
i \hbar \partial_{t} b(t)=-\mu_{e} B b(t) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a(t)=a\left(t_{0}\right) e^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} \mu_{e} B\left(t-t_{0}\right)}, \\
&b(t)=b\left(t_{0}\right) e^{\frac{i}{\hbar} \mu_{e} B\left(t-t_{0}\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

At time $t_{0}$, the electron spin is in the positive $y$ direction. Thus

or

$$
s_{y}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a\left(t_{0}\right) \\
b\left(t_{0}\right)
\end{array}\right)=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a\left(t_{0}\right) \\
b\left(t_{0}\right)
\end{array}\right)=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{c}
a\left(t_{0}\right) \\
b\left(t_{0}\right)
\end{array}\right)
$$

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
-i b\left(t_{0}\right)=a\left(t_{0}\right), \\
i a\left(t_{0}\right)=b\left(t_{0}\right) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

The normalization condition

$$
\left|a\left(t_{0}\right)\right|^{2}+\left|b\left(t_{0}\right)\right|^{2}=1 \text {, }
$$

then gives

As $\frac{b\left(t_{0}\right)}{a\left(t_{0}\right)}=i$, we can take

$$
\left|a\left(t_{0}\right)\right|^{2}=\left|b\left(t_{0}\right)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2} .
$$

$$
a\left(t_{0}\right)=1 / \sqrt{2}, \quad b\left(t_{0}\right)=i / \sqrt{2} .
$$

Hence for time $t>t_{0}$, the polarizations along $x$ and $z$ directions are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle 2 s_{x}\right\rangle &=\hbar\left(a^{*}, b^{*}\right)\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\hbar\left(a^{*} b+b^{*} a\right)=-\hbar \sin \left[\frac{2 \mu_{e}}{\hbar} B\left(t-t_{0}\right)\right] \\
\left\langle 2 s_{z}\right\rangle &=\hbar\left(a^{*}, b^{*}\right)\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\hbar\left(a^{*} a-b^{*} b\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{4}

Two spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles form a composite system. Spin $A$ is in the eigenstate $S_{z}=+1 / 2$ and spin $B$ in the eigenstate $S_{x}=+1 / 2$. What is the probability that a measurement of the total spin will give the value zero?

$(C U S)$

\section{Solution:}

In the uncoupling representation, the state in which the total spin is zero can be written as

$$
|0\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|S_{A z}=\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\left|S_{B z}=-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle-\left|S_{A z}=-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\left|S_{B z}=\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right)
$$

where $S_{A z}$ and $S_{B z}$ denote the $z$-components of the spins of $A$ and $B$ respectively. As these two spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles are now in the state

$$
|Q\rangle=\left|S_{A z}=+1 / 2\right\rangle\left|S_{B x}=+1 / 2\right\rangle
$$

the probability of finding the total spin to be zero is

$$
P=|\langle 0 \mid Q\rangle|^{2} .
$$

In the representation of $\hat{\mathbf{S}}^{2}$ and $\hat{S}_{z}$, the spin angular momentum operator $\hat{S}_{x}$ is defined as

$$
\hat{S}_{x}=\frac{\hbar}{2} \sigma_{x}=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Solving the eigenequation of $\hat{S}_{x}$, we find that its eigenfunction $\mid S_{x}=$ $+1 / 2\rangle$ can be expressed in the representation of $\mathbf{S}^{2}$ and $S_{z}$ as

$$
\left|S_{x}=+1 / 2\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|S_{z}=1 / 2\right\rangle+\left|S_{z}=-1 / 2\right\rangle\right)
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\langle S_{z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{x}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left\langle S_{z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{z}=\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right. \\
\left.+\left\langle S_{z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{z}=-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
\end{gathered}
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle 0 \mid Q\rangle=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left\langle S_{A z}=\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{A z}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\left\langle S_{B z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{B x}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right.\\
&\left.-\left\langle S_{A z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{A z}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\left\langle S_{B z}=\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{B x}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right) \\
=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left\langle S_{B z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{B x}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
P=|\langle 0 \mid Q\rangle|^{2}=\frac{1}{4}=25 \% .
$$

\section{5}

(a) An electron has been observed to have its spin in the direction of the $z$-axis of a rectangular coordinate system. What is the probability that a second observation will show the spin to be directed in $x-z$ plane at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis?

(b) The total spin of the neutron and proton in a deuteron is a triplet state. The resultant spin has been observed to be parallel to the $z$-axis of a rectangular coordinate system. What is the probability that a second observation will show the proton spin to be parallel to the $z$-axis?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The initial spin state of the electron is

$$
\left|\psi_{0}\right\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

The state whose spin is directed in $x-z$ plane at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis is

$$
|\psi\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{r}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Thus the probability that a second observation will show the spin to be directed in $x-z$ plane at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(\theta)=\left|\left\langle\psi \mid \psi_{0}\right\rangle\right|^{2} &=\left|\left(\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, \sin \frac{\theta}{2}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2} \\
&=\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The initial spin state of the neutron-proton system is

$$
\left|\psi_{0}\right\rangle=|1,1\rangle=|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle_{n}|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle_{p}
$$

Suppose a second observation shows the proton spin to be parallel to the $z$-axis. Since the neutron spin is parallel to the proton spin in the deuteron, the final state remains, as before,

$$
\left|\psi_{f}\right\rangle=|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle_{n}|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle_{p} .
$$

Hence the probability that a second observation will show the proton spin to be parallel to the $z$-axis is 1 .

\section{6}

The deuteron is a bound state of a proton and a neutron of total angular momentum $J=1$. It is known to be principally an $S(L=0)$ state with a small admixture of a $D(L=2)$ state.

(a) Explain why a $P$ state cannot contribute.

(b) Explain why a $G$ state cannot contribute.

(c) Calculate the magnetic moment of the pure $D$ state $n-p$ system with $J=1$. Assume that the $n$ and $p$ spins are to be coupled to make the total spin $S$ which is then coupled to the orbital angular momentum $L$ to give the total angular momentum $J$. Express your result in nuclear magnetons. The proton and neutron magnetic moments are $2.79$ and $-1.91$ nuclear magnetons respectively.

$(C U S)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) The parities of the $S$ and $D$ states are positive, while the parity of the $P$ state is negative. Because of the conservation of parity in strong interaction, a quantum state that is initially an $S$ state cannot have a $P$ state component at any later moment.

(b) The possible spin values for a system composed of a proton and a neutron are 1 and 0 . We are given $\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{L}+\mathbf{S}$ and $J=1$. If $S=0, L=1$, the system would be in a $P$ state, which must be excluded as we have seen in (a). The allowed values are then $S=1, L=2,1,0$. Therefore a $G$ state $(L=4)$ cannot contribute.

(c) The total spin is $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{s}_{p}+\mathbf{s}_{n}$. For a pure $D$ state with $J=1$, the orbital angular momentum (relative to the center of mass of the $n$ and $p$ ) is $L=2$ and the total spin must be $S=1$. The total magnetic moment arises from the coupling of the magnetic moment of the total spin, $\mu$, with that of the orbital angular momentum, $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{L}$, where $\boldsymbol{\mu}=\boldsymbol{\mu}_{p}+\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}, \boldsymbol{\mu}_{p}, \boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}$ being the spin magnetic moments of $p$ and $n$ respectively.

The average value of the component of $\mu$ in the direction of the total spin $\mathbf{S}$ is

$$
\mu_{s}=\frac{\left(g_{p} \mu_{N} \mathbf{s}_{p}+g_{n} \mu_{N} \mathbf{s}_{n}\right) \cdot \mathbf{S}}{\mathbf{S}^{2}} \mathbf{S}=\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N} \mathbf{S}
$$

where

$$
\mu_{N}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m_{p} c}, \quad g_{p}=5.58, \quad g_{n}=-3.82,
$$

as $\mathbf{s}_{p}=\mathbf{s}_{n}=\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{S}$.

The motion of the proton relative to the center of mass gives rise to a magnetic moment, while the motion of the neutron does not as it is uncharged. Thus

$$
\mu_{L}=\mu_{N} \mathbf{L}_{p},
$$

where $\mathbf{L}_{p}$ is the angular momentum of the proton relative to the center of mass. As $\mathbf{L}_{p}+\mathbf{L}_{n}=\mathbf{L}$ and we may assume $\mathbf{L}_{p}=\mathbf{L}_{n}$, we have $\mathbf{L}_{p}=\mathbf{L} / 2$ (the center of mass is at the mid-point of the connecting line, taking $m_{p} \approx m_{n}$ ). Consequently, $\mu_{L}=\mu_{N} \mathbf{L} / 2$.

The total coupled magnetic moment along the direction of $\mathbf{J}$ is then

$$
\mu_{T}=\frac{\left[\frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{J}+\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N} \mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{J}\right] \mathbf{J}}{J(J+1)} .
$$

Since $\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{L}+\mathbf{S}, \mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{L}=\frac{1}{2}\left(J^{2}-L^{2}-S^{2}\right)$. With $J=1, L=2, S=1$ and so $J^{2}=2, L^{2}=6, S^{2}=2$, we have $\mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{L}=-3$ and thus $\mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{J}=3$, $\mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{J}=-1$. Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\mu}_{T} &=\left[\frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \cdot 3+\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N}(-1)\right] \mathbf{J} / 2 \\
&=\left[1.5-\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right)\right] \frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \mathbf{J}=0.31 \mu_{N} \mathbf{J} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the direction of $\mathbf{J}$ as the $z$-axis and letting $J_{z}$ take the maximum value $J_{z}=1$, we have $\mu_{T}=0.31 \mu_{N}$.

\section{7}

A preparatory Stern-Gerlach experiment has established that the $z$ component of the spin of an electron is $-\hbar / 2$. A uniform magnetic field in the $x$-direction of magnitude $B$ (use cgs units) is then switched on at time $t=0$.

(a) Predict the result of a single measurement of the $z$-component of the spin after elapse of time $T$.

(b) If, instead of measuring the $z$-component of the spin, the $x$-component is measured, predict the result of such a single measurement after elapse of time $T$

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Method 1

The spin wave function $\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\ b\end{array}\right)$ satisfies

$$
i \hbar \partial_{t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\frac{e \hbar B}{2 m c} \sigma_{x}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\hbar \omega\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\hbar \omega\left(\begin{array}{l}
b \\
a
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\omega=e B / 2 m c$, or

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
i \dot{a}=\omega b, \\
i \dot{b}=\omega a .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Thus

$$
\ddot{a}=-i \omega \dot{b}=-\omega^{2} a,
$$

the solution being

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a=A e^{i \omega t}+C e^{-i \omega t} \\
&b=\frac{i}{\omega} \dot{a}=-\left(A e^{i \omega t}-C e^{-i \omega t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $A$ and $C$ are arbitrary constants. From the initial condition $a(0)=0$ and $b(0)=1$ as the initial spin is in the $-z$ direction, we get $A=-1 / 2, C=$ 1/2. Hence

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{-i \omega t}-e^{i \omega t}\right)=-i \sin \omega t \\
b=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i \omega t}+e^{-i \omega t}\right)=\cos \omega t
\end{array}\right.
$$

and the wave function at time $t$ is

$$
\psi(t)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-i \sin \omega t \\
\cos \omega t
\end{array}\right)
$$

(a) At $t=T$

$$
\psi(T)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-i \sin \omega T \\
\cos \omega t
\end{array}\right)=-i \sin \omega T\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)+\cos \omega T\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

As $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ are the eigenvectors for $\sigma_{z}$ with eigenvalues $+1$ and $-1$ respectively the probability that the measured $z$-component of the spin is positive is $\sin ^{2} \omega T$; the probability that it is negative is $\cos ^{2} \omega T$.

(b) In the diagonal representation of $\sigma_{z}$, the eigenvectors of $\sigma_{x}$ are

$$
\psi\left(\sigma_{x}=1\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \quad \psi\left(\sigma_{x}=-1\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-1 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

As we can write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(T) &=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-i \sin \omega T \\
\cos \omega T
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} e^{-i \omega T} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} e^{i \omega T} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-1 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} e^{-i \omega T} \psi\left(\sigma_{x}=1\right)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} e^{i \omega T} \psi\left(\sigma_{x}=-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

the probabilities that the measured $x$-component of the spin is positive and is negative are equal, being

$$
\left|\frac{e^{-i \omega T}}{\sqrt{2}}\right|^{2}=\left|\frac{e^{i \omega T}}{\sqrt{2}}\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2} .
$$

\section{Method 2}

The Hamiltonian for spin energy is 

$$
H=-\mu \cdot \mathbf{B}=e B \hbar \sigma_{x} / 2 m c .
$$

The eigenstates of $\sigma_{x}$ are

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \quad \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

We can write the initial wave function as

$$
\psi(t=0)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right)-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right)\right]
$$

The Hamiltonian then gives

$$
\psi(t)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right) e^{-i \omega t}-\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right) e^{i \omega t}, \quad \omega=\frac{e B}{2 m c}
$$

(a) As

$$
\psi(t)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-i \sin \omega t \\
\cos \omega t
\end{array}\right)
$$

the probabilities at $t=T$ are

$$
P_{z \uparrow}=\sin ^{2} \omega T, \quad P_{z \downarrow}=\cos ^{2} \omega T .
$$

(b) As in method 1 above,

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
P_{x \uparrow}=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} e^{-i \omega t}\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2}, \\
P_{x \downarrow}=\frac{1}{2} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

\section{8}

An alkali atom in its ground state passes through a Stern-Gerlach apparatus adjusted so as to transmit atoms that have their spins in the $+z$ direction. The atom then spends time $\tau$ in a magnetic field $H$ in the $x$ direction. At the end of this time what is the probability that the atom would pass through a Stern-Gerlach selector for spins in the $-z$ direction? Can this probability be made equal to unity? if so, how? 

\section{Solution:}

The Hamiltonian

$$
\hat{H}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{H}=\frac{|e| \hbar H}{2 m c} \sigma_{x} \equiv \hbar \omega \sigma_{x}, \quad \omega=\frac{|e| H}{2 m c}
$$

gives the equation of motion

$$
-\frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{d}{d t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{1} \\
\psi_{2}
\end{array}\right)=\hbar \omega\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{1} \\
\psi_{2}
\end{array}\right)=\hbar \omega\left(\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{2} \\
\psi_{1}
\end{array}\right)
$$

or

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
i \dot{\psi}_{1}=\omega \psi_{2} \\
i \dot{\psi}_{2}=\omega \psi_{1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

and hence

$$
\ddot{\psi}_{1}+\omega^{2} \psi_{1}=0 .
$$

The solution is $\psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}\psi_{1} \\ \psi_{2}\end{array}\right)$, with

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{1}(t)=a e^{i \omega t}+b e^{-i \omega t} \\
\psi_{2}(t)=\frac{i}{\omega} \dot{\psi}_{1}=-a e^{i \omega t}+b e^{-i \omega t} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

The initial condition

$$
\psi(t=0)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

then gives $a=b=1 / 2$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi &=\left(\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{1} \\
\psi_{2}
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{i \omega t}+e^{-i \omega t} \\
-e^{i \omega t}+e^{-i \omega t}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega t \\
-i \sin \omega t
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\cos \omega t\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)-i \sin \omega t\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In the above $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ is the eigenvector $\sigma_{z}$ for eigenvalue $-1$. Hence the probability that the spins are in the $-z$ direction at time $\tau$ after the atom passes through the Stern-Gerlach selector is

$$
\left|\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega \tau \\
-i \sin \omega \tau
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2}=\sin ^{2} \omega \tau=\frac{1-\cos 2 \omega \tau}{2} .
$$

The probability equals 1 , if

$$
1-\cos 2 \omega \tau=2,
$$

or

$$
\cos 2 \omega \tau=-1,
$$

i.e. at time

$$
\tau=\frac{(2 n+1) \pi}{2 \omega}=(2 n+1) \frac{m c \pi}{|e| H} .
$$

Hence the probability will become unity at times $\tau=(2 n+1) m c \pi /$ $|e| H$

\section{9}

A beam of particles of spin $1 / 2$ is sent through a Stern-Gerlach apparatus, which divides the incident beam into two spatially separated components depending on the quantum number $m$ of the particles. One of the resulting beams is removed and the other beam is sent through another similar apparatus, the magnetic field of which has an inclination $\alpha$ with respect to that of the first apparatus (see Fig. 3.6). What are the relative numbers of particles that appear in the two beams leaving the second apparatus?

Derive the result using the Pauli spin formalism.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

For an arbitrary direction in space $\mathbf{n}=(\sin \theta \cos \varphi, \sin \theta \sin \varphi, \cos \theta)$ the spin operator is

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-239.jpg?height=231&width=619&top_left_y=1497&top_left_x=361)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-239.jpg?height=32&width=34&top_left_y=1747&top_left_x=776)

Fig. $3.6$ 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{n} &=\sigma_{x} \sin \theta \cos \varphi+\sigma_{y} \sin \theta \sin \varphi+\sigma_{z} \cos \theta \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\cos \theta & \sin \theta e^{-i \varphi} \\
\sin \theta e^{i \varphi} & -\cos \theta
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\sigma_{x}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)
$$

are Pauli's spin matrices. Let its eigenfunction and eigenvalue be $\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\ b\end{array}\right)$ and $\lambda$ respectively. Then

$$
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{n}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\lambda\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)
$$

or

$$
\begin{gathered}
a(\cos \theta-\lambda)+b e^{-i \varphi} \sin \theta=0 \\
a e^{i \varphi} \sin \theta-b(\lambda+\cos \theta)=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

For $a, b$ not to vanish identically,

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\cos \theta-\lambda & e^{-i \varphi} \sin \theta \\
e^{i \varphi} \sin \theta & -(\lambda+\cos \theta)
\end{array}\right|=\lambda^{2}-\cos ^{2} \theta-\sin ^{2} \theta=0
$$

or $\lambda^{2}=1$, i.e., $\lambda=\pm 1$, corresponding to spin angular momenta $\pm \frac{1}{2} \hbar$. Also, normalization requires

$$
\left(a^{*} b^{*}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=|a|^{2}+|b|^{2}=1 .
$$

For $\lambda=+1$, we have

$$
\frac{b}{a}=\frac{1-\cos \theta}{e^{-i \varphi} \sin \theta}=\frac{\sin \frac{\theta}{2}}{\cos \frac{\theta}{2}} e^{i \varphi}
$$

and, with normalization, the eigenvector

$$
|\uparrow n\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
e^{i \varphi} \sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

For $\lambda=-1$, we have

$$
\frac{b}{a}=-\frac{\cos \theta+1}{e^{-i \varphi} \sin \theta}=-\frac{\cos \frac{\theta}{2}}{e^{-i \varphi} \sin \frac{\theta}{2}}
$$

and, with normalization, the eigenvector

$$
|\downarrow n\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-e^{-i \varphi} \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\cos \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

For the first Stern-Gerlach apparatus take the direction of the magnetic field as the $z$ direction. Take $\mathbf{n}$ along the magnetic field in the second SternGerlach apparatus. Then $\varphi=0, \theta=\alpha$ in the above.

If the particles which are sent into the second $S-G$ apparatus have spin up, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\uparrow z\rangle &=c|\uparrow n\rangle+d|\downarrow n\rangle \\
c &=\langle\uparrow n \mid \uparrow z\rangle=(\cos (\alpha / 2), \sin (\alpha / 2))\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\cos (\alpha / 2) \\
d &=\langle\downarrow n \mid \uparrow z\rangle=(-\sin (\alpha / 2), \cos (\alpha / 2))\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=-\sin (\alpha / 2)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, after they leave the second $S-G$ apparatus, the ratio of the numbers of the two beams of particles is

$$
\frac{|c|^{2}}{|d|^{2}}=\frac{\cos ^{2}(\alpha / 2)}{\sin ^{2}(\alpha / 2)}=\cot ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2} .
$$

If the particles which are sent into the second $S-G$ apparatus have spin down, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\downarrow z\rangle &=c|\uparrow n\rangle+d|\downarrow n\rangle \\
c &=\langle\uparrow n \mid \downarrow z\rangle=(\cos (\alpha / 2), \sin (\alpha / 2))\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\sin (\alpha / 2) \\
d &=\langle\downarrow n \mid \downarrow z\rangle=(-\sin (\alpha / 2), \cos (\alpha / 2))\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\cos (\alpha / 2)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the ratio of the numbers of the two beams of the particles is

$$
\frac{\sin ^{2}(\alpha / 2)}{\cos ^{2}(\alpha / 2)}=\tan ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}
$$

\section{0}

The magnetic moment of a silver atom is essentially equal to the magnetic moment of its unpaired valence electron which is $\boldsymbol{\mu}=-\gamma \mathbf{s}$, where $\gamma=e / m c$ and $\mathbf{s}$ is the electron's spin.

Suppose that a beam of silver atoms having velocity $V$ is passed through a Stern-Gerlach apparatus having its field gradient in the $z$ direction, and that only the beam with $m_{s}=\hbar / 2$ is to be considered in what follows. This beam then enters a region of length $L$ having a constant magnetic field $B_{0}$ directly along the axis of the beam ( $y$-axis). It next enters another Stern-Gerlach apparatus identical to the first as shown in Fig. 3.7. Describe clearly what is seen when the beam exits from the second SternGerlach apparatus. Express the intensities of the resulting beams in terms of $V, L, B_{0}$ and the constants of the problem.

Use quantum mechanical equations of motion to derive your result.

(Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-242.jpg?height=263&width=772&top_left_y=1190&top_left_x=273)

Fig. $3.7$

\section{Solution:}

If we took a picture at the exit of the second $S-G$ apparatus, we would see two black lines arising from the deposition of the two kinds of silver atoms with $m_{s}=\hbar / 2$ and $m_{s}=-\hbar / 2$.

Denote the state of the system in the region $L$ by $|t\rangle$. If we consider only atoms of $m_{s}=\hbar / 2$ in the beam that enters the region $L$ at $t=0$, then 

$$
|t=0\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) .
$$

The Hamiltonian of the system in the region of length $L$ is

$$
H=-\mu \cdot \mathbf{B}=\frac{\gamma \hbar B_{0}}{2} \sigma_{y},
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
|t\rangle &=\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} H t\right)|t=0\rangle \\
&=\exp \left(-\frac{i \gamma B_{0} t}{2} \sigma_{y}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\left(\cos \frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}-i \sigma_{y} \sin \frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\cos \frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)+\sin \frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence at the exit of the region, the intensities of beams with $m_{s}=\frac{\hbar}{2}$ and $m_{s}=-\frac{\hbar}{2}$ are respectively

$$
I_{+}=I_{0} \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\right), \quad I_{-}=I_{0} \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\right)
$$

where $I_{0}$ is the intensity of the beam that enters the region.

When the beam leaves the region $L, t=L / V$. So the ratio of intensities is

$$
\cot ^{2}\left(\gamma B_{0} L / 2 V\right) \text {. }
$$

The splitting of the beam is seen when it exists from the second SternGerlach apparatus.

\section{1}

Two oppositely charged spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles (spins $\mathbf{s}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{s}_{2}$ ) are coupled in a system with a spin-spin interaction energy $\Delta E$.

The system is placed in a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{H}=H \hat{\mathbf{z}}$. The Hamiltonian for the spin interaction is

$$
\hat{H}=(\Delta E / 4)\left(\sigma_{1} \cdot \sigma_{2}\right)-\left(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}\right) \cdot \mathbf{H}
$$

where $\mu_{i}=g_{i} \mu_{0} \mathbf{s}_{i}$ is the magnetic moment of the $i$ th particle.

The spin wave functions for the 4 states of the system, in terms of the eigenstates of the $z$-component of the operators $\sigma_{i}=2 \mathbf{s}_{i}$, are

$$
\psi_{1}=\alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}, \quad \psi_{2}=s \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+c \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}, \quad \psi_{3}=c \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}-s \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}, \quad \psi_{4}=\beta_{1} \beta_{2}
$$

where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(\sigma_{z}\right)_{i} \alpha_{i}=\alpha_{i}, \quad\left(\sigma_{z}\right)_{i} \beta_{i}=-\beta_{i}, \quad s=(1 / \sqrt{2}) \cdot\left(1-x / \sqrt{1+x^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
c=(1 / \sqrt{2})\left(1+x / \sqrt{1+x^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
x=\mu_{0} H\left(g_{2}-g_{1}\right) / \Delta E
\end{gathered}
$$

(a) Find the energy eigenvalues associated with each state $\psi_{i}$. Discuss the limiting cases $\mu_{0} H / \Delta E \gg 1$ and $\mu_{0} H / \Delta E \ll 1$.

(b) Assume that an initial state $\psi(0)$ is prepared in which particle 1 is polarized along the field direction $z$, but particle 2 is unpolarized. Find the time dependence of the polarization of particle 1 :

$$
P_{1 z}(t)=\left\langle\psi(t)\left|\sigma_{1 z}\right| \psi(t)\right\rangle
$$

Again discuss the limiting cases $\mu_{0} H / \Delta E \ll 1$ and $\mu_{0} H / \Delta E \gg 1$. (Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

(a) $\sigma, \alpha, \beta$ may be represented by matrices

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sigma_{x}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right) \\
\alpha=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right), \quad \beta=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

for which the following relations hold:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\sigma_{i x} \alpha_{i}=\beta_{i}, & \sigma_{i x} \beta_{i}=\alpha_{i} \\
\sigma_{i y} \alpha_{i}=i \beta_{i}, & \sigma_{i y} \beta_{i}=-i \alpha_{i} \\
\sigma_{i z} \alpha_{i}=\alpha_{i}, & \sigma_{i z} \beta_{i}=-\beta_{i}
\end{array}
$$



\section{Then as}

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H}=&(\Delta E / 4)\left(\sigma_{1} \cdot \sigma_{2}\right)-\left(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}\right) \cdot \mathbf{H} \\
=&(\Delta E / 4)\left(\sigma_{1 x} \sigma_{2 x}+\sigma_{1 y} \sigma_{2 y}+\sigma_{1 z} \sigma_{2 z}\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{2} \mu_{0} H\left(g_{1} \sigma_{1 z}+g_{2} \sigma_{2 z}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used $\mu=g \mu_{0} \mathbf{s}=\frac{1}{2} g \mu_{0} \sigma$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H} \psi_{1} &=\hat{H} \alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}=(\Delta E / 4)\left(\beta_{1} \beta_{2}-\beta_{1} \beta_{2}+\alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \mu_{0} H\left(g_{1}+g_{2}\right) \alpha_{1} \alpha_{2} \\
&=\left(\Delta E / 4-\frac{g_{1}+g_{2}}{2} \mu_{0} H\right) \alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}=\left(\Delta E / 4-\frac{g_{1}+g_{2}}{2} \cdot \mu_{0} H\right) \psi_{1},
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
E_{1}=\Delta E / 4-\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{1}+g_{2}\right) \mu_{0} H
$$

Similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H} \psi_{2}=& \frac{\Delta E}{4}\left[s\left(\alpha_{1} \beta_{2}+\alpha_{1} \beta_{2}-\beta_{1} \alpha_{2}\right)+c\left(\beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+\beta_{1} \alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right)\right] \\
&+\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{1}-g_{2}\right) \mu_{0} H\left(s \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}-c \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right) \\
=& {[(\Delta E / 4)(2 c-s)-(\Delta E / 2) x s] \beta_{1} \alpha_{2} } \\
&+[(\Delta E / 4)(2 s-c)+(\Delta E / 2) x c] \alpha_{1} \beta_{2} \\
=&(\Delta E / 4)(2 c / s-2 x-1) s \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+(\Delta E / 4)(2 s / c+2 x-1) c \alpha_{1} \beta_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 c / s-2 x &=2 \frac{\left(1+x / \sqrt{1+x^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2}}{\left(1-x / \sqrt{1+x^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2}}-2 x=2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}} \\
&=2\left(\sqrt{1+x^{2}}-x\right)+2 x=2 s / c+2 x
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\hat{H} \psi_{2}=(\Delta E / 4)\left(2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}-1\right) \psi_{2}
$$

or

$$
E_{2}=(\Delta E / 4)\left(2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}-1\right) .
$$

By the same procedure we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{3}=(-\Delta E / 4)\left(2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}+1\right) \\
&E_{4}=(\Delta E / 4)+\frac{g_{1}+g_{2}}{2} \mu_{0} H
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) As particle 2 is unpolarized and can be considered as in a mixed state, its state $\xi_{2}$ can be expanded in terms of $\alpha_{2}$ and $\beta_{2}$ :

$$
\xi_{2}=a \alpha_{2}+b \beta_{2},
$$

where $|a|^{2}=|b|^{2}=1 / 2$. Then the initial total wave function is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(0) &=\alpha_{1} \xi_{2}=\alpha_{1}\left(a \alpha_{2}+b \beta_{2}\right) \\
&=a \psi_{1}+b \frac{c}{c^{2}+s^{2}} \psi_{2}-b \frac{s}{c^{2}+s^{2}} \psi_{3} \\
&=a \psi_{1}+b c \psi_{2}-b s \psi_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

as

$$
c^{2}+s^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{x}{\sqrt{1+x^{2}}}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{x}{\sqrt{1+x^{2}}}\right)=1
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(t)=& a \psi_{1} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{1}}{\hbar} t\right)+b c \psi_{2} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{2}}{\hbar} t\right) \\
&-b s \psi_{3} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{3}}{\hbar} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then using the relations

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\sigma_{1 z} \psi_{1}=\sigma_{1 z} \alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}=\alpha_{1} \alpha_{2} \\
&\sigma_{1 z} \psi_{2}=\sigma_{1 z}\left(s \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+c \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right)=-s \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+c \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}, \\
&\sigma_{1 z} \psi_{3}=\sigma_{1 z}\left(c \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}-s \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right)=-\left(c \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+s \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{1 z}(t)=&\left\langle\psi(t)\left|\sigma_{1 z}\right| \psi(t)\right\rangle \\
=&|a|^{2}+|b|^{2}\left\langle\exp \left(-i E_{2} t / \hbar\right) c\left(s \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+c \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right)\right.\\
&-\exp \left(-i E_{3} t / \hbar\right) s\left(c \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}-s \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right)|| \exp \left(-i E_{2} t / \hbar\right) \\
&\left.\times c\left(-s \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+c \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right)+\exp \left(-i E_{3} / \hbar\right) s\left(c \beta_{1} \alpha_{2}+s \alpha_{1} \beta_{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
=& \frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(s^{2}-c^{2}\right)^{2}+4 s^{2} c^{2} \cos \left(E_{2}-E_{3}\right) t / \hbar\right] \\
=& \frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2\left(1+x^{2}\right)}\left[x^{2}+\cos \left(\sqrt{1+x^{2}} \Delta E t / \hbar\right)\right] \\
=& 1-\frac{1}{1+x^{2}} \sin ^{2}\left(\sqrt{1+x^{2}} \Delta E t / 2 \hbar\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) In the limit $\mu_{0} H / \Delta E \gg 1$, i.e., $x \gg 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1} &=\frac{\Delta E}{4}-\frac{g_{1}+g_{2}}{2} \mu_{0} H \approx-\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{1}+g_{2}\right) \mu_{0} H, \\
E_{2} &=\frac{\Delta E}{4}\left(2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}-1\right) \approx(\Delta E / 4) \times 2 x=\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{2}-g_{1}\right) \mu_{0} H, \\
E_{3} &=-\frac{\Delta E}{4}\left(1+2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}\right) \approx-\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{2}-g_{1}\right) \mu_{0} H, \\
E_{4} &=\frac{\Delta E}{4}+\frac{g_{1}+g_{2}}{2} \mu_{0} H \approx \frac{1}{2}\left(g_{1}+g_{2}\right) \mu_{0} H, \\
P_{1 z}(t) & \approx 1 .
\end{aligned}
$$

When $\mu_{0} H / \Delta E \ll 1$, i.e., $x \ll 1$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{1} \approx E_{4} \approx \Delta E / 4 \\
E_{2}=\frac{\Delta E}{4}\left(2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}-1\right) \approx \frac{\Delta E}{4} \\
E_{3} \approx-\frac{3 \Delta E}{4} \\
P_{1 z}(t) \approx 1-\sin ^{2}(\Delta E t / 2 \hbar)
\end{gathered}
$$



\section{2}

A hydrogen atom is in a ${ }^{2} P_{1 / 2}$ state with total angular momentum up along the $z$-axis. In all parts of this problem show your computations and reasoning carefully.

(a) With what probability will the electron be found with spin down?

(b) Compute the probability per unit solid angle $P(\theta, \varphi)$ that the electron will be found at spherical angles $\theta, \varphi$ (independent of radial distance and spin).

(c) An experimenter applies a weak magnetic field along the positive $z$-axis. What is the effective magnetic moment of the atom in this field?

(d) Starting from the original state, the experimenter slowly raises the magnetic field until it overpowers the fine structure. What are the orbital and spin quantum numbers of the final state?

[Assume the Hamiltonian is linear in the magnetic field.]

(e) What is the effective magnetic moment of this final state?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) For the state ${ }^{2} P_{1 / 2}, l=1, s=1 / 2, J=1 / 2, J_{z}=1 / 2$. Transforming the coupling representation into the uncoupling representation, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=&|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle \\
&-\sqrt{1 / 3}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $P_{\downarrow}=2 / 3$.

(b) As

$$
\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\sqrt{2} Y_{11} \\
Y_{10}
\end{array}\right) \text {, }
$$

we have

$$
P(\theta, \varphi) d \Omega=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 Y_{11}^{*} Y_{11}+Y_{10}^{*} Y_{10}\right) d \Omega .
$$

Hence the probability per unit solid angle is

$$
P(\theta, \varphi)=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 \times \frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta+\frac{3}{4 \pi} \cos ^{2} \theta\right)=\frac{1}{4 \pi} .
$$

(c) In the weak magnetic field, $J$ and $J_{z}$ are "good" quantum numbers and the state remains unchanged. The effective magnetic moment is

$$
\mu=\left\langle\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\left|\mu_{z}\right| \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=g \frac{e}{2 m c}\left\langle\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\left|J_{z}\right| \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=g \cdot \frac{e \hbar}{4 m c}
$$

where $m$ is the electron mass and

$$
g=1+\frac{J(J+1)-l(l+1)+s(s+.1)}{2 J(J+1)}=\frac{2}{3} .
$$

Hence $\mu=e \hbar / 6 m c$.

(d) In a strong magnetic field, the interaction of the magnetic moment with the field is much stronger than the coupling interaction of spin and orbit, so that the latter can be neglected. Here $l$ and $s$ are good quantum numbers. The Hamiltonian related to the magnetic field is

$$
W=-\boldsymbol{\mu}_{l} \cdot \mathbf{B}-\boldsymbol{\mu}_{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}=e B \hat{l}_{z} / 2 m c+e B \hat{s}_{z} / m c
$$

When the magnetic field is increased slowly from zero, the state remains at the lowest energy. From the expression of $W$, we see that when the magnetic field becomes strong, only if $l_{z}=-\hbar, s_{z}=-\hbar / 2$ can the state remain at the lowest energy. Thus the quantum numbers of the final state are $l=1, l_{z}=-1, s=1 / 2, s_{z}=-1 / 2$.

(e) the effective magnetic moment of the final state is

$$
\mu=\bar{\mu}_{l z}+\bar{\mu}_{s z}=-e \hbar / 2 m c-e \hbar / 2 m c=-e \hbar / m c
$$

\section{3}

Consider a neutral particle with intrinsic angular momentum $\sqrt{s(s+1)}$, where $s=\hbar / 2$, i.e., a spin-1/2 particle.

Assume the particle has a magnetic moment $\mathbf{M}=\gamma \mathbf{s}$, where $\gamma$ is a constant. The quantum-mechanical state of the particle can be described in a spin space spanned by the eigenvectors $|+\rangle$ and $|-\rangle$ representing alignments parallel and antiparallel to the $z$-axis:

$$
\hat{s}_{z}|+\rangle=\frac{\hbar}{2}|+\rangle, \quad \hat{s}_{z}|-\rangle=-\frac{\hbar}{2}|-\rangle .
$$

At time $t=0$ the state of the system is $|\psi(t=0)\rangle=|+\rangle$. The particle moves along the $y$-axis through a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{\mathbf{y}}$ oriented along the $y$-axis.

(a) As expressed in the $|+\rangle,|-\rangle$ basis, what is $|\psi(t)\rangle$ ?

(b) What would be the expectation values for measurements of the observables $s_{x}, s_{y}, s_{z}$ as functions of time?

$(C U S)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Hamiltonian of the particle is

$$
\hat{H}=-\mathbf{M} \cdot \mathbf{B}=-\gamma \hat{s}_{y} B .
$$

In the representation of $\hat{\mathbf{s}}^{2}, \hat{s}_{z}$

$$
\hat{s}_{y}=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right) \text {, }
$$

and so the two eigenstates of $\hat{s}_{y}$ are

$$
\left|s_{y}=\hbar / 2\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-i \\
1
\end{array}\right), \quad\left|s_{y}=-\hbar / 2\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\hat{H}\left|s_{y}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=-\gamma B \frac{1}{2} \hbar\left|s_{y}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle \\
&\hat{H}\left|s_{y}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=\gamma B \frac{1}{2} \hbar\left|s_{y}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

any state of the particle can be expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\psi(t)\rangle=& c_{1}\left|s_{y}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle \exp \left(+i \frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
&+c_{2}\left|s_{y}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle \exp \left(-i \frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then the initial condition

$$
|\psi(t=0)\rangle=\left|s_{z}=\hbar / 2\right\rangle
$$

gives

$$
\left|s_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=c_{1}\left|s_{y}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle+c_{2}\left|s_{y}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{1} &=\left\langle\frac{1}{2} \hbar=s_{y} \mid s_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-i \\
1
\end{array}\right)^{+}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(i 1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} i \\
c_{2} &=\left\langle-\frac{1}{2} \hbar=s_{y} \mid s_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right)^{+}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(-i 1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} i .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\psi(t)\rangle=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} i \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-i \\
1
\end{array}\right) \exp \left(i \frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} i \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right) \exp \left(-i \frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
=& \cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)\left|s_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)\left|s_{z}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle s_{z}\right\rangle=&\left(\cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)\right) \frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right) \\
& \times\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)\right) \\
& \times\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \cos (\gamma B t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

$\left\langle s_{y}\right\rangle=0$, because $\left\langle s_{y}\right\rangle=0$ at $t=0$ and $s_{y}$ is conserved.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle=&\left(\cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)\right) \frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right) \\
& \times\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)
\end{array}\right)=\left(-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)\right) \\
& \times \frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)
\end{array}\right)=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar \sin (\gamma B t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{4}

A particle of spin $1 / 2$ and magnetic moment $\mu$ is placed in a magnetic field

$$
\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \hat{\mathbf{z}}+B_{1} \cos \omega t \hat{\mathbf{x}}-B_{1} \sin \omega t \hat{\mathbf{y}},
$$

which is often employed in magnetic resonance experiments.

Assume that the particle has spin up along the $+z$-axis at $t=0$ $\left(m_{s}=+1 / 2\right)$. Derive the probability to find the particle with spin down $\left(m_{s}=-1 / 2\right)$ at time $t>0$.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

The Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
H=-\mu \sigma \cdot \mathrm{B} .
$$

Letting

$$
\omega_{0}=\mu B_{0} / \hbar, \quad \omega_{1}=\mu B_{1} / \hbar,
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=-\mu\left(B_{0} \sigma_{z}+B_{1} \sigma_{x} \cos \omega t-B_{1} \sigma_{y} \sin \omega t\right) \\
&=-\hbar \omega_{0} \sigma_{z}-\hbar \omega_{1}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & e^{i \omega t} \\
e^{-i \omega t} & 0
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\sigma_{x}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right), \sigma_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right), \sigma_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Let the wave function of the system be

$$
|t\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

The Schrödinger equation $i \hbar \partial_{t}|t\rangle=H|t\rangle$, or

$$
i\left(\begin{array}{l}
\dot{a} \\
\dot{b}
\end{array}\right)=-\omega_{0}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)-\omega_{1}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & e^{i \omega t} \\
e^{-i \omega t} & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right),
$$

gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{a}=i \omega_{0} a+i \omega_{1} e^{i \omega t} b, \\
\dot{b}=-i \omega_{0} b+i \omega_{1} e^{-i \omega t} a .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Try a solution of the type

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a=\alpha \exp \left(i \omega_{0} t\right), \\
b=\beta \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Substitution in the above equations gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{\alpha}=i \omega_{1} \exp \left[i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right] \beta, \\
\dot{\beta}=i \omega_{1} \exp \left[-i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right] \alpha .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Assume that $\alpha$ and $\beta$ have the forms

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\alpha=A_{1} \exp \left[i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega+\Omega\right) t\right], \\
\beta=A_{2} e^{i \Omega t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $A_{1}, A_{2}$, and $\Omega$ are constants. Substitution gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega+\Omega\right) A_{1}-\omega_{1} A_{2}=0, \\
-\omega_{1} A_{1}+\Omega A_{2}=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

For this set of equations to have nontrivial solutions the determinant of the coefficients of $A_{1}, A_{2}$ must be zero, i.e.,

$$
\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega+\Omega\right) \Omega-\omega_{1}^{2}=0,
$$

giving

$$
\Omega_{\pm}=-\left(-\omega_{0}+\frac{\omega}{2}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(-\omega_{0}+\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} .
$$

Therefore the general form of $\beta$ is

$$
\beta=A_{2+} \exp \left(i \Omega_{+} t\right)+A_{2-} \exp \left(i \Omega_{-} t\right),
$$

and that of $\alpha$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha=& \frac{\dot{\beta} \exp \left[i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]}{i \omega_{1}} \\
