=& \frac{1}{\omega_{1}} \exp \left[i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]\left[\Omega_{+} A_{2+} \exp \left(i \Omega_{+} t\right)\right.\\
&\left.+\Omega_{-} A_{2-} \exp \left(i \Omega_{-} t\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Initially the spin is up along the $z$-axis, so

giving

$$
|t=0\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
a(0) \\
b(0)
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\alpha(0) \\
\beta(0)
\end{array}\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\omega_{1}}\left(\Omega_{+} A_{2+}+\Omega_{-} A_{2-}\right) &=1, \\
A_{2+}+A_{2-} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The solution is

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{2+} &=-A_{2-}=\omega_{1} /\left(\Omega_{+}-\Omega_{-}\right) \\
&=\frac{\omega_{1}}{2 \sqrt{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
b(t)=& \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) \beta(t) \\
=& \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) A_{2+} \\
& \times\left[\exp \left(i \Omega_{+} t\right)-\exp \left(i \Omega_{-} t\right)\right] \\
=& \exp (-i \omega t / 2) 2 i A_{2+} \\
& \times \sin \left(\sqrt{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} t\right) \\
=& \frac{i \omega_{1} \exp [-i(\omega / 2) t]}{\sqrt{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}}} \\
& \times \sin \left(\sqrt{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The probability that the particle has spin down along the $z$-axis at time $t$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=|\langle z \downarrow \mid t\rangle|^{2} \\
&=|b(t)|^{2}=\frac{\omega_{1}^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(\sqrt{\left.\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} t\right)}{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{5}

A spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ system with magnetic moment $\boldsymbol{\mu}=\mu_{0} \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is located in a uniform time-independent magnetic field $B_{0}$ in the positive $z$ direction. For the time interval $0<t<T$ an additional uniform time-independent field $B_{1}$ is applied in the positive $x$ direction. During this interval, the system is again in a uniform constant magnetic field, but of different magnitude and direction $z^{\prime}$ from the initial one. At and before $t=0$, the system is in the $m=1 / 2$ state with respect to the $z$-axis .

(a) At $t=0+$, what are the amplitudes for finding the system with spin projections $m^{\prime}=\pm 1 / 2$ with respect to the $z^{\prime}$ direction?

(b) What is the time development of the energy eigenstates with respect to the $z^{\prime}$ direction, during the time interval $0<t<T$ ?

(c) What is the probability amplitude at $t=T$ of observing the system in the spin state $m=-1 / 2$ along the original $z$-axis?

[Express your answers in terms of the angle $\theta$ between the $z$ and $z^{\prime}$ axes and the frequency $\left.\omega_{0}=\mu_{0} B_{0} / \hbar.\right]$

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) In the representation of $s_{z}$, the eigenvectors of $s_{z^{\prime}}$ are

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right),\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\sin \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\cos \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right),
$$

corresponding to the eigenvalues $s_{z^{\prime}}=1 / 2$ and $-1 / 2$ respectively. Then the probability amplitudes for $m^{\prime}=\pm 1 / 2$ are respectively 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&C_{+}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} & \sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, \\
&C_{-}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
-\sin \frac{\theta}{2} & \cos \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=-\sin \frac{\theta}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The Hamiltonian in the interval $0<t<T$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=-\mu \cdot \mathbf{B}=-\mu_{0}\left(B_{0} \sigma_{z}+B_{1} \sigma_{x}\right) \\
&=-\mu_{0}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
B_{0} & B_{1} \\
B_{1} & -B_{0}
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The initial eigenfunctions are

$$
\chi_{+}(0)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right), \quad \chi_{-}(0)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\sin \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\cos \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

where

$$
\theta=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{B_{1}}{B_{0}}\right) .
$$

Substitution in the Schrödinger equation $H \chi_{\pm}(0)=\pm E \chi_{\pm}(0)$ gives

$$
E=-\mu_{0} B_{0} / \cos \theta=-\mu_{0} B,
$$

where

$$
B=\sqrt{B_{0}^{2}+B_{1}^{2}} .
$$

At a later time $t$ in $0<t<T$, the eigenstates are

$$
\chi_{\pm}(t)=\exp (\mp i E t / \hbar) \chi_{\pm}(0)=\exp \left(\pm i \mu_{0} B t / \hbar\right) \chi_{\pm}(0)
$$

(c) The probability amplitude at $t=T$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
C_{-}(T) &=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1
\end{array}\right) \exp (-i H T / \hbar)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\left(i B_{1} / \sqrt{B_{0}^{2}+B_{1}^{2}}\right) \sin \left(\mu_{0} T \sqrt{B_{0}^{2}+B_{1}^{2}} / \hbar\right) \\
&=i \sin \theta \sin \left(\mu_{0} B T / \hbar\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

An alternative way is to make use of

$$
\psi(0)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\cos \frac{\theta}{2} \chi_{+}(0)-\sin \frac{\theta}{2} \chi_{-}(0)
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(t)=& \chi_{+}(0) \cos \frac{\theta}{2} \exp \left(i \mu_{0} B t / \hbar\right) \\
&-\chi_{-}(0) \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \exp \left(-i \mu_{0} B t / \hbar\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

to get

$$
\begin{aligned}
C_{-}(T)=& \beta^{+} \psi(T)=\cos \frac{\theta}{2} \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \\
& \times\left\{\exp \left(i \mu_{0} B T / \hbar\right)-\exp \left(-i \mu_{0} B T / \hbar\right)\right\} \\
=& i \sin \theta \sin \frac{\mu_{0} B T}{\hbar}, \quad \text { where } \beta=\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{6}

A spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ system of magnetic moment $\mu$ is placed in a dc magnetic field $H_{0} \mathbf{e}_{z}$ in which the energy of the spin state $|+1 / 2\rangle$ is $\hbar \omega_{0}$, that of $|-1 / 2\rangle$ being taken as 0 . The system is in the state $|-1 / 2\rangle$ when at $t=0$, a magnetic field $H\left(\mathbf{e}_{x} \cos \omega_{0} t+\mathbf{e}_{y} \sin \omega_{0} t\right)$ is suddenly turned on. Ignoring relaxation find the energy of the spin system as a function of $\omega_{0}, H, c$ and $t$, where

$$
c=\left\langle+1 / 2\left|\mu_{x}+i \mu_{y}\right|-1 / 2\right\rangle .
$$

Why is the energy of the spin system not conserved?

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

The Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H} &=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot\left(\mathbf{H}+\mathbf{H}_{0}\right)=-\mu \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot\left(\mathbf{H}+\mathbf{H}_{0}\right) \\
&=-\mu\left(H \sigma_{x} \cos \omega_{0} t+H \sigma_{y} \sin \omega_{0} t+H_{0} \sigma_{z}\right) \\
&=-\mu\left(\begin{array}{cc}
H_{0} & H \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) \\
H \exp \left(i \omega_{0} t\right) & -H_{0}
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar \partial \psi / \partial t=\hat{H} \psi
$$

setting

$$
\psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)
$$

we get

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d a}{d t}=\frac{\mu i}{\hbar}\left[H_{0} a+H \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) b\right] \\
\frac{d b}{d t}=\frac{\mu i}{\hbar}\left[H \exp \left(i \omega_{0} t\right) a-H_{0} b\right]
\end{array}\right.
$$

Try a solution of the type

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a=A \exp \left[-i\left(\Omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right) t\right] \\
&b=B \exp \left[-i\left(\Omega-\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right) t\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $A, B$ and $\Omega$ are constants. Substitution gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(\Omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right) A+\omega^{\prime} B=0 \\
\left(\Omega-\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}-\omega\right) B+\omega^{\prime} A=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega &=\frac{\mu H_{0}}{\hbar}, \\
\omega^{\prime} &=\frac{\mu H}{\hbar}
\end{aligned}
$$

For nontrivial solutions we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\Omega+\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right) & \omega^{\prime} \\
\omega^{\prime} & \Omega-\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right)
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

giving

$$
\Omega=\pm \sqrt{\omega^{\prime 2}+\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right)^{2}}=\pm Q
$$

where $Q=\left|\sqrt{\omega^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right)^{2}}\right|$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(t)=&\left(A_{1} e^{-i Q t}+A_{2} e^{i Q t}\right) \exp \left(-i \frac{\omega_{0}}{2} t\right) \alpha \\
&+\left(B_{1} e^{-i Q t}+B_{2} e^{i Q t}\right) \exp \left(i \frac{\omega_{0}}{2} t\right) \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
B_{1,2}=-A_{1,2} \frac{\Omega_{1,2}+\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)}{\omega^{\prime}}
$$

the subscripts 1,2 corresponding to the values of $\Omega$ with $+,-$ signs respectively, and

$$
\alpha=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right), \quad \beta=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

At $t=0$ the system is in the $\left|-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle$ state and $\psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$. Thus $B_{1}+$ $B_{2}=1, A_{1}+A_{2}=0$. Then as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(Q+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right) A_{1}+\omega^{\prime} B_{1}=0 \\
\left(-Q+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right) A_{2}+\omega^{\prime} B_{2}=0
\end{gathered}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q\left(A_{1}-A_{2}\right)+\omega^{\prime} &=0 \\
\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right)\left(A_{1}-A_{2}\right)+\omega^{\prime}\left(B_{1}-B_{2}\right) &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{1} &=-\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{2 Q}, \quad A_{2}=\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{2 Q} \\
B_{1} &=\frac{Q+\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)}{2 Q} \\
B_{2} &=\frac{Q-\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)}{2 Q}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore the wave function of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(t)=& \frac{\omega^{\prime}}{Q} i \sin (Q t) \exp \left(-i \frac{\omega_{0}}{2} t\right) \alpha \\
&+\left[\cos Q t-i \frac{\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)}{Q} \sin Q t\right] \exp \left(i \frac{\omega_{0}}{2} t\right) \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

and the energy of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=&\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle=-\mu\left[-H_{0} \cos ^{2} Q t\right.\\
&\left.+\frac{\omega^{2} H_{0}-\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)^{2} H_{0}-2 \omega^{\prime} H\left(\omega+\frac{\omega_{0}}{2}\right)}{Q^{2}} \sin ^{2} Q t\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Note that as}

$$
\begin{aligned}
c &=\left\langle+\frac{1}{2}\left|\mu_{x}+i \mu_{y}\right|-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle \\
&=\mu\left\langle+\frac{1}{2}\left|\sigma_{x}+i \sigma_{y}\right|-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle \\
&=\mu\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 2 \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=2 \mu, \\
\mu &=\frac{c}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As the energy of the system changes with time $t$, it is not conserved. This is because with regard to spin it is not an isolated system.

\section{7}

A beam of neutrons of velocity $v$ passes from a region (I) (where the magnetic field is $\mathbf{B}=B_{1} \mathbf{e}_{z}$ ) to a region (II) (where the field is $\mathbf{B}=B_{2} \mathbf{e}_{x}$ ). In region (I) the beam is completely polarized in the $+z$ direction.

(a) Assuming that a given particle passes from (I) to (II) at time $t=0$, what is the spin wave function of that particle for $t>0$ ?

(b) As a function of time, what fraction of the particles would be observed to have spins in the $+x$ direction; the $+y$ direction; the $+z$ direction?

(c) As a practical matter, how abrupt must the transition between (I) and (II) be to have the above description valid?

$(W i s c o n s i n)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Considering only the spin wave function, the Schrödinger equation is

$$
i \hbar \partial|\chi\rangle / \partial t=\hat{H}|\chi\rangle
$$

where

$$
\hat{H}=-\mu \cdot \mathrm{B}=-\mu_{n} B_{2} \sigma_{x},
$$

with $\mu_{n}=-1.9103 \mu_{N}$ being the anomalous magnetic moment of the neutron, $\mu_{N}=e \hbar / 2 m_{p} c$ the nuclear magneton, $m_{p}$ the mass of a proton. Thus

$$
\frac{d}{d t}|\chi\rangle=\frac{i}{\hbar} \mu_{n} B_{2} \sigma_{x}|\chi\rangle \equiv-i \omega_{2} \sigma_{x}|\chi\rangle
$$

where $\omega_{2}=\frac{\left|\mu_{n}\right| B_{2}}{\hbar}$. Let $|\chi\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\ b\end{array}\right)$. The above gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{a}=-i \omega_{2} b, \\
\dot{b}=-i \omega_{2} a .
\end{array}\right.
$$

The initial condition is $a(0)=1, b(0)=0$ as the beam is initially polarized in the $+z$ direction. Solving for $a$ and $b$ and using the initial condition we obtain for $t>0$ 

$$
|\chi\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega_{2} t \\
-i \sin \omega_{2} t
\end{array}\right)
$$

(b) The mean value of the spin in the state $|\chi\rangle$, i.e., the polarized vector for neutron, is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{p} &=\langle\chi|\boldsymbol{\sigma}| \chi\rangle=\left\langle\chi\left|\sigma_{x} \mathbf{e}_{x}+\sigma_{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}+\sigma_{z} \mathbf{e}_{z}\right| \chi\right\rangle \\
&=\left(0,-\sin 2 \omega_{2} t, \cos 2 \omega_{2} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus in the region (II), the neutron spin is in the $y z$ plane and precesses about the $x$ direction with angular velocity $2 \omega_{2}$.

(c) For the descriptions in (a) and (b) to be valid, the time of the transition between (I) and (II) must satisfy

$$
t \ll \frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{2}}=\frac{h}{\left|\mu_{n}\right| B_{2}} .
$$

For example if $B_{2} \sim 10^{3} \mathrm{Gs}$, then $t \ll 0.7 \mu \mathrm{s}$.

If the kinetic energy of the incident neutrons is given, we can calculate the upper limit of the width of the transition region.

\section{8}

The Hamiltonian for a $\left(\mu^{+} e^{-}\right)$atom in the $n=1, l=0$ state in an external magnetic field $B$ is

$$
H=a \mathbf{s}_{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{e}+\frac{|e|}{m_{e} c} \mathbf{s}_{e} \cdot \mathbf{B}-\frac{|e|}{m_{\mu} c} \mathbf{s}_{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B} .
$$

(a) What is the physical significance of each term? Which term dominates in the interaction with the external field?

(b) Choosing the $z$-axis along $\mathbf{B}$ and using the notation (F, M), where $\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{s}_{\mu}+\mathbf{s}_{e}$, show that $(1,+1)$ is an eigenstate of $H$ and give its eigenvalue.

(c) An $r f$ field can be applied to cause transitions to the state $(0,0)$. Describe qualitatively how an observation of the decay $\mu^{+} \rightarrow e^{+} \nu_{e} \nu_{\mu}$ could be used to detect the occurrence of this transition.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The first term in $\hat{H}$ is due to the magnetic interaction between $\mu$ and $e$, the second and third terms respectively account for the magnetic interactions of $\mu$ and $e$ with the external field $\mathbf{B}$. Of the latter, the term $|e| \mathbf{s}_{e} \cdot \mathbf{B} / m_{e} c$ is dominant as $m_{e} \approx m_{\mu} / 200$.

(b) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=\mathbf{s}_{\mu}+\mathbf{s}_{e} \\
\hat{H} &=\frac{1}{2} a\left[\mathbf{F}^{2}-\mathbf{s}_{\mu}^{2}-\mathbf{s}_{e}^{2}\right]+\frac{e B}{m_{e} c} s_{e z}-\frac{e B}{m_{\mu} c} s_{\mu z}
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider the state

$$
(1,+1)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)_{\mu}
$$

As the eigenvalues of $F^{2}, s_{\mu}^{2}, s_{e}^{2}, s_{\mu z}, s_{e z}$ are $1(1+1) \hbar^{2}, \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{2}+1\right) \hbar^{2}$, $\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{2}+1\right) \hbar^{2}, \frac{1}{2} \hbar, \frac{1}{2} \hbar$ respectively, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H}(1,+1) &=\left\{\frac{1}{2} a \hbar^{2}\left[2-2 \cdot \frac{3}{4}\right]+\frac{e \hbar}{2 m_{e} c} B-\frac{e \hbar}{2 m_{\mu} c} B\right\}(1,+1) \\
&=\left(\frac{1}{4} a \hbar^{2}+\frac{e \hbar}{2 m_{e} c} B-\frac{e \hbar}{2 m_{\mu} c} B\right)(1,+1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $(1,+1)$ is an eigenstate of $\hat{H}$, with the eigenvalue

$$
a \hbar^{2} / 4+e \hbar B / 2 m_{e} c-e \hbar B / 2 m_{\mu} c .
$$

(c) The decay $\mu^{+} \rightarrow e^{+} \nu_{e} \nu_{\mu}$ can be detected through the observation of the annihilation of the positronium $e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow 2 \gamma$. For the state $(1,+1)$, the total angular momentum of the $e^{+} e^{-}$system is 1 , and so $e^{+} e^{-}$cannot decay into $2 \gamma$ whose total angular momentum is 0 . For the state $(0,0)$, the total angular momentum of the $e^{+} e^{-}$system is 0 and so it can decay into $2 \gamma$. Hence, detection of $e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow 2 \gamma$ implies the decay $\mu^{+} \rightarrow e^{+} \nu_{e} \nu_{\mu}$ of the $\left(\mu^{+} e^{-}\right)$system in the state $(0,0)$, as well as the transition $(1,+1) \rightarrow(0,0)$. 

\section{MOTION IN ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELD}

\section{1}

We may generalize the semi-classical Bohr-Sommerfeld relation

$$
\oint \mathbf{P} \cdot d \mathbf{r}=(n+1 / 2) h,
$$

(where the integral is along a closed orbit) to apply to the case where electromagnetic field is present by replacing $\mathbf{P}$ with $\mathbf{p}-e \mathbf{A} / c$, where $e$ is the charge of the particle. Use this and the equation of motion for the linear momentum $\mathbf{p}$ to derive a quantization condition on the magnetic flux of a semi-classical electron which is in a magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ in an arbitrary orbit. For electrons in solids this condition can be restated in terms of the size $S$ of the orbit in k-space. Obtain the quantization condition on $S$ in terms of $B$ (Ignore spin effects).

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

In the presence of an electromagnetic field, the mechanical momentum $\mathbf{P}$ is

$$
\mathbf{P}=\mathbf{p}-e \mathbf{A} / c,
$$

where $\mathbf{p}$ is the canonical momentum, $e$ is the charge of particle. The generalized Bohr-Sommerfeld relation becomes

$$
\oint \mathbf{P} \cdot d \mathbf{r}=\oint\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right) \cdot d \mathbf{r}=(n+1 / 2) h,
$$

or

$$
\oint \mathbf{p} \cdot d \mathbf{r}-\frac{e}{c} \phi=(n+1 / 2) h
$$

where

$$
\phi=\int_{S} \mathbf{B} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\int_{S}(\nabla \times \mathbf{A}) \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\oint \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{r},
$$

using Stokes theorem. The classical equation of the motion of an electron in a constant magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$,

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=-\frac{e}{c} \frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t} \times \mathbf{B},
$$

gives $\mathbf{p}=-e \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{B} / c$ and

$$
\oint \mathbf{p} \cdot d \mathbf{r}=-\oint \frac{e}{c}(\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{B}) \cdot d \mathbf{r}=\int_{S} \frac{e}{c} \nabla \times(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{r}) \cdot d \mathbf{s}
$$



$$
=\frac{e}{c} \int_{S} 2 \mathbf{B} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=2 e \phi / c .
$$

Hence

$$
\phi=(n+1 / 2) \phi_{0},
$$

where $\phi_{0}=h c / e$.

Defining $\mathbf{k}$ by $\mathbf{p}=\hbar \mathbf{k}=-e \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{B} / c$, we have, assuming $\mathbf{r}$ is perpendicular to $\mathbf{B}$

$$
\hbar \Delta k=-B e \Delta r / c,
$$

or

$$
\Delta r=-\hbar c \Delta k / B e .
$$

Therefore, if the orbit occupies an area $S_{n}$ in k-space and an area $A_{n}$ in $\mathbf{r}$-space, we have the relation

$$
A_{n}=(\hbar c / B e)^{2} S_{n} .
$$

As

$$
\phi=\int B d A_{n}=\left(\frac{\hbar c}{B e}\right)^{2} \int B d S_{n}=\left(\frac{\hbar c}{B e}\right)^{2} B S_{n}=(n+1 / 2) h c / e
$$

we have

$$
S_{n}=2 \pi B e(n+1 / 2) / \hbar c .
$$

\section{2}

A particle of charge $q$ and mass $m$ is subject to a uniform electrostatic field E.

(a) Write down the time-dependent Schrödinger equation for this system.

(b) Show that the expectation value of the position operator obeys Newton's second law of motion when the particle is in an arbitrary state $\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)$.

(c) It can be shown that this result is valid if there is also a uniform magnetostatic field present. Do these results have any practical application to the design of instruments such as mass spectrometers, particle accelerators, etc.? Explain. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Schrödinger equation for the particle is

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2} \psi-q \mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{r} \psi
$$

(b) The Hamiltonian of the particle is

$$
H=\frac{\mathbf{p}^{2}}{2 m}-q \mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{r} .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d x}{d t} &=\frac{1}{i \hbar}[x, H]=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[x, \frac{p_{x}^{2}}{2 m}\right]=\frac{p_{x}}{m} \frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[x, p_{x}\right]=\frac{p_{x}}{m} \\
\frac{d p_{x}}{d t} &=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[p_{x}, H\right]=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[p_{x},-E_{x} x\right]=-\frac{q E_{x}}{i \hbar}\left[p_{x}, x\right]=q E_{x}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\langle\mathbf{r}\rangle}{d t} &=\frac{\langle\mathbf{p}\rangle}{m} \\
\frac{d\langle\mathbf{p}\rangle}{d t} &=q \mathbf{E}
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}\langle\mathbf{r}\rangle=\frac{1}{m} \frac{d\langle\mathbf{p}\rangle}{d t}
$$

$$
m \frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}\langle\mathbf{r}\rangle=q \mathbf{E},
$$

which is just Newton's second law of motion.

(c) These results show that we could use classical mechanics directly when we are computing the trajectory of a charged particle in instruments such as mass spectrometers, particle accelerators, etc.

\section{3}

The Hamiltonian for a spinless charged particle in a magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A}$ is

$$
H=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r})\right)^{2},
$$

where $e$ is the charge of particle, $\mathbf{p}=\left(p_{x} p_{y}, p_{z}\right)$ is the momentum conjugate to the particle's position $\mathbf{r}$. Let $A=-B_{0} y \mathbf{e}_{x}$, corresponding to a constant magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{z}$. (a) Prove that $p_{x}$ and $p_{z}$ are constants of motion.

(b) Find the (quantum) energy levels of this system.

\section{Solution:}

The Hamiltonian for the particle can be written as

$$
H=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(p_{x}+\frac{e B_{0}}{c} y\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{y}^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{z}^{2} .
$$

(a) As $H$ does not depend on $x$ and $z$ explicitly, the basic commutation relations in quantum mechanics

$$
\left[x_{i}, p_{j}\right]=i \hbar \delta_{i j},\left[p_{i}, p_{j}\right]=0,
$$

require

$$
\left[p_{x}, H\right]=0,\left[p_{z}, H\right]=0,
$$

which show that $p_{x}, p_{z}$ are constants of the motion.

(b) In view of (a) we can choose $\left\{H, p_{x}, p_{z}\right\}$ as a complete set of mechanical variables. The corresponding eigenfunction is

$$
\psi(x, y, z)=e^{i\left(x p_{x}+z p_{z}\right) / \hbar} \phi(y)
$$

where $p_{x}, p_{z}$ are no longer operators but are now constants. The Schrödinger equation

$$
H \psi(x, y, z)=E \psi(x, y, z)
$$

then gives

or

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\left(p_{x}+\frac{e B_{0}}{c} y\right)^{2}-\hbar^{2} \frac{d^{2}}{d y^{2}}+p_{z}^{2}\right] \phi(y)=E \phi(y)
$$

Setting

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \phi}{d y^{2}}+\frac{m}{2}\left(\frac{e B_{0}}{m c}\right)^{2}\left(y+\frac{c p_{x}}{e B_{0}}\right)^{2} \phi=\left(E-\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m}\right) \phi
$$

$$
\omega=\frac{|e| B_{0}}{m c}, y^{\prime}=y+\frac{c p_{x}}{e B_{0}}, E^{\prime}=E-\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m},
$$

we can write the equation as

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \phi}{d y^{\prime 2}}+\frac{m}{2} \omega^{2} y^{\prime 2} \phi=E^{\prime} \phi,
$$

which is the energy eigenequation for a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator. The energy eigenvalues are therefore

$$
E^{\prime}=E-p_{z}^{2} / 2 m=(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega, n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

Hence the energy levels for the system are

$$
E_{n}=p_{z}^{2} / 2 m+(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega, n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

\section{4}

An electron of mass $m$ and charge $-e$ moves in a region where a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A}$ exists in $z$ direction.
(a) Set up the Schrödinger equation in rectangular coordinates.
(b) Solve the equation for all energy levels.
(c) Discuss the motion of the electron.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Hamiltonian is

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{\mathbf{P}}+\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\partial A_{z}}{\partial y}-\frac{\partial A_{y}}{\partial z}=0, \\
\frac{\partial A_{x}}{\partial z}-\frac{\partial A_{z}}{\partial x}=0, \\
\frac{\partial A_{y}}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial A_{x}}{\partial y}=B,
\end{gathered}
$$

we can take $A_{x}=A_{z}=0, A_{y}=B x$, i.e. $\quad \mathbf{A}=B x \hat{\mathbf{y}}$, and write the Schrödinger equation as

$$
\hat{H} \psi=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\hat{P}_{x}^{2}+\left(\hat{P}_{y}+\frac{e B x}{c}\right)^{2}+\hat{P}_{z}^{2}\right] \psi=E \psi
$$

(b) As $\left[\hat{P}_{y}, \hat{H}\right]=\left[\hat{P}_{z}, \hat{H}\right]=0, P_{y}$ and $P_{z}$ are conserved. Choose $H, P_{y}, P_{z}$ as a complete set of mechanical variables and write the Schrödinger equation as

$$
\left[\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{P}_{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{P}_{y}+\frac{e B x}{c}\right)^{2}\right] \psi=\left(E-\frac{P_{z}^{2}}{2 m}\right) \psi
$$

Let $\xi=x+c P_{y} / e B, \hat{P}_{\xi}=\hat{P}_{x}$. Then $\left[\xi, \hat{P}_{\xi}\right]=i \hbar$ and 

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{P}_{\xi}^{2}+\frac{m}{2}\left(\frac{e B}{m c}\right)^{2} \xi^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{P}_{z}^{2} .
$$

The above shows that $\hat{H}-\frac{\hat{P}_{z}^{2}}{2 m}$ is the Hamiltonian of a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator of angular frequency $\omega=\frac{e B}{m c}$. Hence the energy levels of the system are

$$
E=(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega+P_{z}^{2} / 2 m, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

Because the expression of $E$ does not contain $P_{y}$ explicitly, the degeneracies of the energy levels are infinite.

(c) In the coordinate frame chosen, the energy eigenstates correspond to free motion in the $z$ direction and circular motion in the $x-y$ plane, i.e. a helical motion. In the $z$ direction, the mechanical momentum $m v_{z}=P_{z}$ is conserved, describing a uniform linear motion. In the $x$ direction there is a simple harmonic oscillation round the equilibrium point $x=-c P_{y} / e B$. In the $y$ direction, the mechanical momentum is $m v_{y}=P_{y}+e B x / c=e B \xi /$ $c=m \omega \xi$ and so there is a simple harmonic oscillation with the same amplitude and frequency.

\section{5}

Write down the Hamiltonian for a spinless charged particle in a magnetic field. Show that the gauge transformation $\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r}) \rightarrow \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r})+\nabla f(\mathbf{r})$ is equivalent to multiplying the wave function by the factor $\exp [i e f(r) / \hbar c]$. What is the significance of this result? Consider the case of a uniform field $B$ directed along the $z$-axis. Show that the energy levels can be written as

$$
E=(n+1 / 2) \frac{|e| \hbar}{m c} B+\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{z}^{2}}{2 m} .
$$

Discuss the qualitative features of the wave functions.

Hint: use the gauge where $A_{x}=-B y, A_{y}=A_{z}=0$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The Hamiltonian for the particle is

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}
$$

where $\mathbf{A}$ is related to the magnetic field by 

$$
\mathbf{B}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A} .
$$

The Schrödinger equation is then

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} \psi(\mathbf{r})=E \psi(\mathbf{r})
$$

Suppose we make the transformation

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r}) \rightarrow \mathbf{A}^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})=\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r})+\nabla f(\mathbf{r}), \\
& \psi(\mathbf{r}) \rightarrow \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})=\psi(\mathbf{r}) \exp \left\{\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right\},
\end{aligned}
$$

and consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}^{\prime}\right) \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r}) &=\hat{\mathbf{p}} \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})-\left[\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}+\frac{e}{c} \nabla f(\mathbf{r})\right] \exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right] \psi(\mathbf{r}) \\
&=\exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right]\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right) \psi(\mathbf{r}) \\
\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r}) &=\exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right]\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} \psi(\mathbf{r})
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used

$$
\hat{\mathbf{p}} \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{\hbar}{i} \nabla\left\{\exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right] \psi(\mathbf{r})\right\}=\exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right]\left[\frac{e}{c} \nabla f(\mathbf{r})+\hat{\mathbf{p}}\right] \psi(\mathbf{r}) .
$$

Substitution in Schrödinger's equation gives

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})=E \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r}) .
$$

This shows that under the gauge transformation $\mathbf{A}^{\prime}=\mathbf{A}+\nabla f$, the Schrödinger equation remains the same and that there is only a phase difference between the original and the new wave functions. Thus the system has gauge invariance.

Now consider the case of a uniform field $\mathbf{B}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=B \mathbf{e}_{z}$, for which we have

$$
A_{x}=-B y, \quad A_{y}=A_{z}=0 .
$$

The Hamiltonian can be written as

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\left(\hat{p}_{x}+\frac{e B}{c} y\right)^{2}+\hat{p}_{y}^{2}+\hat{p}_{z}^{2}\right] .
$$

Since $\left[\hat{p}_{x}, \hat{H}\right]=\left[\hat{p}_{z}, \hat{H}\right]=0$ as $H$ does not depend on $x, z$ explicitly, we may choose the complete set of mechanical variables $\left(\hat{p}_{x}, \hat{p}_{z}, \hat{H}\right)$. The corresponding eigenstate is

$$
\psi(x, y, z)=e^{i\left(p_{x} x+p_{z} z\right) / \hbar} \chi(y) .
$$

Substituting it into the Schrödinger equation, we have

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\left(p_{x}+\frac{e B}{c} y\right)^{2}-\hbar^{2} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y^{2}}+p_{z}^{2}\right] \chi(y)=E \chi(y)
$$

Let $c p_{x} / e B=-y_{0}$. Then the above equation becomes

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \chi^{\prime \prime}+\frac{m}{2}\left(\frac{e B}{m c}\right)^{2}\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2} \chi=\left(E-p_{z}^{2} / 2 m\right) \chi
$$

which is the equation of motion of a harmonic oscillator. Hence the energy levels are

$$
E=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} k_{z}^{2}+\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \frac{|e| B}{m c}, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots,
$$

where $k_{z}=p_{z} / \hbar$, and the wave functions are

$$
\psi_{p_{x} p_{z} n}(x, y, z)=e^{i\left(p_{x} x+p_{z} z\right) / \hbar} \chi_{n}\left(y-y_{0}\right),
$$

where

$$
\chi_{n}\left(y-y_{0}\right) \sim \exp \left[-\frac{|e| B}{2 \hbar c}\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}\right] H_{n}\left(\sqrt{\frac{|e| B}{\hbar c}}\left(y-y_{0}\right)\right)
$$

$H_{n}$ being Hermite polynomials. As the expressions for energy does not depend on $p_{x}$ and $p_{z}$ explicitly, there are infinite degeneracies with respect to $p_{x}$ and $p_{z}$

\section{6}

A point particle of mass $m$ and charge $q$ moves in spatially constant crossed magnetic and electric fields $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \hat{\mathbf{z}}, \mathbf{E}=E_{0} \hat{\mathbf{x}}$.

(a) Solve for the complete energy spectrum.

(b) Evaluate the expectation value of the velocity $\mathbf{v}$ in a state of zero momentum. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Choose a gauge $\mathbf{A}=B_{0} x \hat{\mathbf{y}}, \varphi=-E_{0} x$ so that $\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=B_{0} \hat{\mathbf{z}}$, $-\nabla \cdot \varphi=E_{0}$. Then

$$
H=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}+q \varphi=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{x}^{2}+\left(p_{y}-\frac{q}{c} B_{0} x\right)^{2}+p_{z}^{2}\right]-q E_{0} x .
$$

As $H$ does not depend on $y$ and $z$ explicitly, $p_{y}$ and $p_{z}$ each commutes with $H$, so that $p_{y}$ and $p_{z}$ are conserved. Thus they can be replaced by their eigenvalues directly. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=& \frac{1}{2 m} p_{x}^{2}+\frac{q^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{2 m c^{2}}\left(x-\frac{c p_{y}}{q B_{0}}-\frac{c^{2} m E_{0}}{q B_{0}^{2}}\right)^{2} \\
&+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{z}^{2}-\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}^{2}}{2 B_{0}^{2}}-\frac{c p_{y} E_{0}}{B_{0}}=\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\xi}^{2} \\
&+\frac{m}{2} \omega^{2} \xi^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{z}^{2}-\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}^{2}}{2 B_{0}^{2}}-\frac{c p_{y} E_{0}}{B_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
p_{\xi}=p_{x}, \quad \xi=x-\frac{c p_{y}}{q B_{0}}-\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}}{q B_{0}^{2}}
$$

are a new pair of conjugate variables. Let $\omega=|q| B_{0} / m c$. By comparing the expression of $H$ with that for a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator, we get the eigenvalues of $H$ :

$$
E_{n}=(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega+p_{z}^{2} / 2 m-m c^{2} E_{0}^{2} / 2 B_{0}^{2}-c p_{y} E_{0} / B_{0}, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

The fact that only $p_{y}$ and $p_{z}$, but not $y$ and $z$, appear in the expression for energy indicates an infinite degeneracy exists with respect to $p_{y}$ and to $p_{z}$

(b) A state of zero momentum signifies one in which the eigenvalues of $p_{y}$ and $p_{z}$ as well as the expectation value of $p_{x}$ are all zero. As velocity is defined as

$$
\mathbf{v}=\frac{1}{m} \mathbf{p}_{\mathrm{mec}}=\frac{1}{m}\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)
$$

its expectation value is

$$
\langle\mathbf{v}\rangle=\frac{1}{m}\left\langle\mathbf{p}-\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{A}\right\rangle=-\frac{q}{m c}\langle\mathbf{A}\rangle=-\frac{q B_{0}}{m c}\langle x\rangle \hat{\mathbf{y}} .
$$

Then as

$$
\langle x\rangle=\langle\xi\rangle+\frac{c p_{y}}{q B_{0}}+\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}}{q B_{0}^{2}}=\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}}{q B_{0}^{2}},
$$

since $\langle\xi\rangle=0$ for a harmonic oscillator and $p_{y}=0$, we have

$$
\langle\mathbf{v}\rangle=-\frac{c E_{0}}{B_{0}} \hat{\mathbf{y}} .
$$

\section{7}

Determine the energy levels, their degeneracy and the corresponding eigenfunctions of an electron contained in a cube of essentially infinite volume $L^{3}$. The electron is in an electromagnetic field characterized by the vẹctor potential

$$
\mathbf{A}=H_{0} x \hat{\mathbf{e}}_{y} \quad\left(\left|\hat{\mathbf{e}}_{y}\right|=1\right) .
$$

\section{Solution:}

As $\mathbf{A}=H_{0} x \hat{\mathbf{e}}_{y}$, we have the Schrödinger equation

$$
\hat{H} \psi=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\hat{p}_{x}^{2}+\hat{p}_{z}^{2}+\left(\hat{p}_{y}-H_{0} x e / c\right)^{2}\right] \psi=E \psi,
$$

where $e$ is the electron charge $(e<0)$.

As $\left[\hat{H}, \hat{p}_{y}\right]=\left[\hat{H}, \hat{p}_{z}\right]=0,\left[\hat{p}_{y}, \hat{p}_{z}\right]=0$, we can choose $\hat{H}, \hat{p}_{y}, \hat{p}_{z}$ as a complete set of mechanical variables, the corresponding eigenfunction being

$$
\psi=e^{i\left(p_{y} y+p_{z} z\right) / \hbar} \psi_{0}(x),
$$

where $p_{y}, p_{z}$ are arbitrary real numbers. Substitution of $\psi$ in the Schrödinger equation gives

where $E_{0}=E-p_{z}^{2} / 2 m$, or

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\hat{p}_{x}^{2}+\left(e H_{0} / c\right)^{2}\left(x-c p_{y} / e H_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \psi_{0}=E_{0} \psi_{0}
$$

where $x_{0}=c p_{y} / e H_{0}$.

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} d^{2} \psi_{0} / d x^{2}+\frac{m}{2}\left(H_{0} e / c m\right)^{2}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2} \psi_{0}=E_{0} \psi_{0}
$$

The last equation is the energy eigenequation of a one-dimensional oscillator of natural frequency $\omega_{0}=-H_{0} e / m c$ and equilibrium position $x=x_{0}$, the energy eigenvalues being

$$
E_{0}=(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega_{0}, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots,
$$

or

$$
E=p_{z}^{2} / 2 m-(n+1 / 2) H_{0} e \hbar / m c, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

The corresponding eigenfunctions are

$$
\psi_{0 n} \sim \exp \left[\frac{e H_{0}}{2 \hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}\right] H_{n}\left(-\frac{e H_{0}}{\hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)\right)
$$

where $H_{n}$ are Hermite polynomials.

As no $p_{y}$ terms occur in the expression for energy levels and $p_{y}$ can be any arbitrary real number, the degeneracies of energy levels are infinite.

The eigenfunctions for the original system are therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\mathbf{x})=& C_{n} \exp \left[\frac{i\left(p_{y} y+p_{z} z\right)}{\hbar}+\frac{e H_{0}}{2 \hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \times H_{n}\left(-\frac{e H_{0}}{\hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{n}$ is the normalization constant.

\section{8}

Consider a loop of thin wire in the shape of a circle of radius $R$ (Fig. 4.1). A constant magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the loop produces a magnetic flux passing through the loop. Imagine that the wire contains only one electron which is free to move. This electron has a wave function $\psi(\theta)$ which depends only upon the angular $\operatorname{coordinate} \theta$. Neglect all interactions between the electron spin and the magnetic field as well as all magnetic fields produced by the electron itself.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-274.jpg?height=335&width=433&top_left_y=1265&top_left_x=442)

Fig. 4.1

(a) How does the ground state energy of the electron depend upon the value of the applied magnetic field in the approximation we have described? Derive a formula and give a rough picture of the result. (b) Imagine that we start with the wire in its ground state in the presence of a magnetic flux $\phi$. Next the magnetic field is turned off. Calculate the current in the loop.

(c) Calculate the current in amps assuming $R=2 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $\phi=0.6$ gauss $\mathrm{cm}^{2}$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) In cylindrical coordinates $r, \theta$, $z$, as $\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=B \hat{\mathbf{e}}_{z}$ where $B$ is a constant, we can take $A_{r}=A_{z}=0, A_{\theta}=\frac{r B}{2}$, i.e., $\mathbf{A}=\frac{r B}{2} \hat{\mathbf{e}}_{\theta}$, and consider the Schrödinger equation for the electron,

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} \psi=E \psi
$$

where $e$ is the electron charge $(e<0)$. Let

$$
\psi=\psi^{\prime} \exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{x} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right)
$$

Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right) \psi &=\exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{x} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right)\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}+\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right) \psi^{\prime} \\
&=\exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{x} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) \hat{\mathbf{p}} \psi^{\prime} \\
\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} \psi &=\exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{x} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) \hat{\mathbf{p}}^{2} \psi^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

the Schrödinger equation becomes

$$
\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{\mathbf{p}}^{2} \psi^{\prime}=E \psi^{\prime} .
$$

Since the electron is confined to a loop of radius $R$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi=\psi(\theta) &=\psi^{\prime} \exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int_{r=R} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right)=\psi^{\prime} \exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{\theta} A R d \theta\right) \\
& \propto \psi^{\prime} \exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} A R \theta\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\psi^{\prime}=\psi^{\prime}(\theta)$ and $\hat{p}=-\frac{i \hbar}{R} \frac{d}{d \theta}$. Thus we have

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}} \frac{d^{2} \psi^{\prime}(\theta)}{d \theta^{2}}=E \psi^{\prime}(\theta),
$$

with solution

$$
\psi^{\prime}(\theta) \sim e^{i c_{1} \theta},
$$

where $c_{1}$ is a constant given by $E=\frac{\hbar^{2} c_{1}^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}$. Thus

$$
\psi(\theta) \sim \exp \left[i\left(c_{1}+e A R / c \hbar\right) \theta\right] .
$$

For single-valuedness, $\psi(\theta)=\psi(\theta+2 \pi)$, i.e.,

$$
2 \pi\left(c_{1}+e A R / c \hbar\right)=2 n \pi,
$$

where $n$ is zero or an integer $(0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots)$. Solving for $c_{1}$ we have

$$
c_{1}=n-e A R / c \hbar=n-e R^{2} B / 2 c \hbar,
$$

and hence

$$
E_{n}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}\left(n-e R^{2} B / 2 c \hbar\right)^{2}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}\left(n+\phi / \phi_{0}\right)^{2},
$$

where $\phi=\pi R^{2} B, \phi_{0}=-c h / e$. It is seen that the dependence of $E_{n}$ on the external magnetic field $B$ or the flux $\phi$ is parabolic, as shown in Fig. 4.2.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-276.jpg?height=342&width=343&top_left_y=1227&top_left_x=487)

Fig. $4.2$

As $n$ is an integer, the ground state (lowest energy level) energy $E_{g}$ is given by

$$
E_{g}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}\left[n^{*}-e R^{2} B / 2 c \hbar\right]^{2}
$$

where $n^{*}$ is the integer nearest to $e R^{2} B / 2 c \hbar$ (or $e \phi / c h$ ), which is negative as $e$ is negative for an electron.

(b) Suppose we start with a state $E_{n}$ which is the ground state, $n$ will remain the same when $B$ is turned off. Thus the wave function will be $\psi=C \exp (i n \theta)$ and the electric current density is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{j} &=\left.e \frac{\hbar}{2 m i}\left(\psi^{*} \nabla \psi-\psi \nabla \psi^{*}\right)\right|_{r=R}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m i}(i n) \frac{2}{R} \psi^{*} \psi \hat{e}_{\theta} \\
&=\frac{e \hbar n}{m R} \psi^{*} \psi \hat{e}_{\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C$ is the normalization constant. Let $S$ denote the cross section of the thin wire. We have from the normalization condition

$$
\int \psi^{*} \psi d l d S=2 \pi R|C|^{2} S=1
$$

that

$$
|C|^{2}=\frac{1}{2 \pi R S} .
$$

Hence

$$
I=\int \mathbf{j} \cdot d \mathbf{S}=\frac{e \hbar n}{m R}|C|^{2} S=\frac{e \hbar n}{2 \pi m R^{2}} .
$$

Note that $\mathbf{j}$ has been considered to be uniform in any cross section as the wire is thin.

Because the electron is initially in the ground state, for which $E_{n}$ is the minimum energy, we have

$$
n=\left[\frac{e \phi}{c h}\right] \quad \text { or } \quad\left[\frac{e \phi}{c h}\right]-1,
$$

where $[A]$ denotes the greatest integer which is not greater than $A$.

For the case of macroscopic magnetudes as in part (c), the quantum number is numerically large and we can simply use $n \approx e \phi / c h$, in which case

$$
I \approx e^{2} \phi / 4 \pi^{2} R^{2} m c .
$$

(c) For $R=2 \mathrm{~cm}, \phi=0.6$ gauss $\mathrm{cm}^{2}$, we have in SI units

$$
\begin{aligned}
I=& e^{2} \phi / 4 \pi^{2} R^{2} m=\left(1.6 \times 10^{-19}\right)^{2} \times 0.6 \times 10^{-4} \times 10^{-4} /\left[4 \pi^{2}\right.\\
&\left.\times\left(2 \times 10^{-2}\right)^{2} \times 0.9 \times 10^{-30}\right]=1.1 \times 10^{-14} A .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{9}

(a) Assuming that nonrelativistic quantum mechanics is invariant under time reversal, derive the time reversed form of the Schrödinger wave function.

(b) What is the quantum mechanical Hamiltonian for a free electron with magnetic moment $\mu$ in the external constant magnetic field $H_{z}$ in the $z$-direction, in the reference frame of the electron?

(c) Suppose that an extra constant magnetic field $H_{y}$ is imposed in the $y$-direction. Determine the form of the quantum mechanical operator for the time rate of change of $\mu$ in this case.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider the Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(t)=\hat{H} \psi(t)
$$

Making the time reversal transformation $t \rightarrow-t$, we obtain

$$
-i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(-t)=\hat{H}(-t) \psi(-t)
$$

or

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi^{*}(-t)=\hat{H}^{*}(-t) \psi^{*}(-t) .
$$

If $\hat{H}^{*}(-t)=\hat{H}(t)$, then the Schrödinger equation is covariant under time reversal and the time reversed form of the wave function is $\psi^{*}(-t)$.

(b) Let $-e$ be the charge of the electron. Then $\boldsymbol{\mu}=-\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c} \sigma$ and in the reference frame of the electron,

$$
\hat{H}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{H}=-\mu_{z} H_{z}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c} \sigma_{z} H_{z} .
$$

(c) The magnetic field is now $H_{y} \hat{\mathbf{y}}+H_{z} \hat{\mathbf{z}}$, and so

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}\left(\sigma_{z} H_{z}+\sigma_{y} H_{y}\right),
$$

SO

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \mu}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\mu, \hat{H}]=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left(\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}\right)^{2}\left[-\sigma_{x} \hat{\mathbf{x}}-\sigma_{y} \hat{\mathbf{y}}-\sigma_{z} \hat{\mathbf{z}},\right.\\
\left.\sigma_{z} H_{z}+\sigma_{y} H_{y}\right]=& \frac{2}{\hbar}\left(\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}\right)^{2}\left[\left(\sigma_{y} H_{z}-\sigma_{z} H_{y}\right) \hat{x}-\sigma_{x} H_{z} \hat{y}\right.\\
&\left.+i \sigma_{x} H_{y} \hat{z}\right]=\frac{2}{\hbar}\left(\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}\right)^{2} \sigma \times \mathbf{H} \\
=& \frac{e}{m c} \mathbf{H} \times \mu
\end{aligned}
$$

where use has been made of the relations $\sigma_{x} \sigma_{y}=i \sigma_{z}, \sigma_{y} \sigma_{z}=i \sigma_{x}$, $\sigma_{z} \sigma_{x}=i \sigma_{y}$

\section{0}

A particle has mass $m$, charge $q$, intrinsic angular momentum $\mathbf{s}(s$ is not necessarily equal to $\hbar / 2)$ and a magnetic dipole moment $\boldsymbol{\mu}=g q \mathbf{s} / 2 m c$. The particle moves in a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ with a velocity small compared with $c$.

(a) Write down the Hamiltonian for this system. (The vector potential for the uniform magnetic field may be written as $\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{r} / 2$ )

(b) Derive the quantum mechanical (Heisenberg) equations of motion from this Hamiltonian, for the linear momentum $\mathbf{P}$ and for the angular momentum s. The $A^{2}$ term may be neglected in this nonrelativistic approximation.

(Note that the results look exactly like the classical equations of motion.)

(c) Without solving these equations, identify the value of the constant $g$ for which the helicity will remain constant. (Helicity is defined here as the cosine of the angle between the vectors $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{s})$

(d) What is the actual value of the constant $g$ for any one of the following particles: $e, p, n, \pi$ ?

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Hamiltonian for the system is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=& \frac{1}{2 m}\left(\mathbf{P}-\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\frac{1}{2 m} \mathbf{P}^{2}-\frac{q}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{P} \\
&+\frac{q^{2}}{2 m c^{2}} \mathbf{A}^{2}-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Neglecting terms $A^{2}$ and higher in $H$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d P_{i}}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[P_{i}, H\right]=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[P_{i},-\frac{q}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{P}\right.\\
&\left.-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right]=\frac{i q}{\hbar m c}\left[P_{i}, A_{j} P_{j}\right] \\
=& \frac{i q}{\hbar m c}\left(P_{i} A_{j} P_{j}-A_{j} P_{j} P_{i}\right) \\
=& \frac{i q}{\hbar m c}\left[\left(P_{i} A_{j}\right) P_{j}+A_{j} P_{i} P_{j}-A_{j} P_{j} P_{i}\right] \\
=& \frac{i q}{\hbar m c}\left(P_{i} A_{j}\right) P_{j}=\frac{q}{m c}\left(\partial_{i} A_{j}\right) P_{j} . \\
\frac{d s_{i}}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[s_{i}, H\right]=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[s_{i},-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] \\
&=\frac{i g q}{2 \hbar m c}\left[s_{i}, s_{j} B_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{-g q}{2 m c}\left(B_{j} s_{k}-B_{k} s_{j}\right) \\
&=-\frac{g q}{2 m c}(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{s})_{i},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\left[s_{i}, s_{j}\right]=i \hbar s_{k}$. Note that we have used the convention that repetition of a subscript implies summation over that subscript.

(c) As $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{s}$ commute we can consider the problem in the common eigenstates of $\mathbf{P}, \mathbf{s}^{2}$ and $s_{z}$.

The helicity $h$ is defined as

$$
h=\mathbf{P} \cdot \mathbf{s} /|\mathbf{P}||\mathbf{s}|=\frac{P_{i} s_{i}}{|\mathbf{P}||\mathbf{s}|},
$$

and as

$$
\mathbf{A}_{i}=\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{r})_{i}=\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon_{i j k} B_{j} x_{k},
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[h,-\frac{q}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{P}\right] } &=\frac{-q}{m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left[s_{i} P_{i}, A_{j} P_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{-q s_{i}}{m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left[P_{i}, A_{j} P_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{q s_{i} P_{j}}{m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left(\frac{i \hbar}{2}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i}}\left(\varepsilon_{j k l} B_{k} x_{l}\right) \\
&=\frac{i \hbar q}{2 m c} \varepsilon_{j k l} \frac{s_{i}}{|\mathbf{s}|} \frac{P_{j}}{|\mathbf{P}|} B_{k} \delta_{i l} \\
&=\frac{i \hbar q}{2 m c} \varepsilon_{i j k} \frac{s_{i}}{|\mathbf{s}|} \frac{P_{j}}{|\mathbf{P}|} B_{k} \\
{\left[h,-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] } &=\frac{-g q}{2 m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left[s_{i} P_{i}, s_{j} B_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{-g q P_{i}}{2 m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left[s_{i}, s_{j} B_{j}\right] \\
&=-\frac{i \hbar g q}{2 m c} \varepsilon_{i j k} \frac{s_{i}}{|\mathbf{s}|} \frac{P_{j}}{|\mathbf{P}|} B_{k} .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the helicity is a constant of the motion, then

$$
[h, H]=\left[h,-\frac{q}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{P}\right]+\left[h,-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right]=0
$$

which requires $g=1$.

(d) The values of $g$ for the various particles are

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline Particle & $e$ & $p$ & $n$ & $\pi$ \\
\hline$g$ & $-2.0$ & $5.6$ & $-3.8$ & 0 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

\section{1}

In a recent classic table-top experiment, a monochromatic neutron beam $(\lambda=1.445 \AA)$ was split by Bragg reflection at point $A$ of an interferometer into two beams which were recombined (after another reflection) at point $D$ (see Fig. 4.3). One beam passes through a region of transverse magnetic field of strength $B$ for a distance $l$. Assume that the two paths from $A$ to $D$ are identical except for the region of the field.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-282.jpg?height=343&width=582&top_left_y=298&top_left_x=368)

Fig. $4.3$

Find the explicit expressions for the dependence of the intensity at point $D$ on $\mathbf{B}, l$ and the neutron wavelength, with the neutron polarized either parallel or anti-parallel to the magnetic field.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

This is a problem on spinor interference. Consider a neutron in the beam. There is a magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ in the region where the Schrödinger equation for the (uncharged) neutron is

$$
\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2}-\mu \sigma \cdot \mathbf{B}\right) \psi=E \psi
$$

Supposing B to be constant and uniform, we have

$$
\psi\left(t_{1}\right)=\exp \left[-i \hat{H}\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right) / \hbar\right] \psi\left(t_{0}\right)
$$

where $t_{0}, t_{1}$ are respectively the instants when the neutron enters and leaves the magnetic field.

Write $\psi(t)=\psi(\mathbf{r}, t) \psi(\mathbf{s}, t)$, where $\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)$ and $\psi(\mathbf{s}, t)$ are respectively the space and spin parts of $\psi$. Then

$$
\psi\left(\mathbf{r}, t_{1}\right)=\exp \left[-\frac{i}{\hbar}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2}\right)\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right)\right] \psi\left(\mathbf{r}, t_{0}\right)
$$

which is the same as the wave function of a free particle, and 

$$
\psi\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{1}\right)=\exp \left[\frac{i}{\hbar} \mu \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right)\right] \psi\left(s, t_{0}\right) .
$$

The interference arises from the action of $\mathbf{B}$ on the spin wave function. As $\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)$ is the wave function of a free particle, we have $t_{1}-t_{0}=l / v=$ $m l / \hbar k$ and

$$
\psi\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{1}\right)=\exp \left[i 2 \pi \mu m l \lambda \sigma \cdot \mathbf{B} / h^{2}\right] \psi\left(s, t_{0}\right)
$$

where $k=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}=\frac{m v}{\hbar}$ is the wave number of the neutron. The intensity of the interference of the two beams at $D$ is then proportional to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left|\psi_{D}^{(1)}(\mathbf{r}, t) \psi_{D}^{(1)}(\mathbf{s}, t)+\psi_{D}^{(2)}(\mathbf{r}, t) \psi_{D}^{(2)}(\mathbf{s}, t)\right|^{2} \\
&\quad \propto\left|\psi_{D}^{(1)}(\mathbf{s}, t)+\psi_{D}^{(2)}(\mathbf{s}, t)\right|^{2}=\left|\psi^{(2)}\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{0}\right)+\psi^{(2)}\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{1}\right)\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\exp \left(i \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda}{h^{2}} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right)=& \cos \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}+i \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \frac{\mathbf{B}}{B} \\
& \times \sin \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\pm \sigma B$ depending on whether $\sigma$ is parallel or anti-parallel to $\mathbf{B}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\psi^{(2)}\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{0}\right)+\psi^{(2)}\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{1}\right)\right|^{2}=&\left|1+\exp \left(i \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda}{h^{2}} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right)\right|^{2}\left|\psi\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{0}\right)\right|^{2} \\
=&\left|1+\cos \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}} \pm i \sigma \sin \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}\right|^{2} \\
=&\left(1+\cos \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}\right)^{2} \\
&+\sin ^{2} \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}=4 \cos ^{2} \frac{\pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the interference intensity at $D \propto \cos ^{2}\left(\pi \mu m l \lambda B / h^{2}\right)$, where $\mu$ is the intrinsic magnetic moment of the neutron $(\mu<0)$. 

\section{2}

A neutron interferometer beam splitter plus mirrors as shown in Fig. $4.4$ has been built out of a single crystal.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-284.jpg?height=440&width=511&top_left_y=347&top_left_x=407)

Fig. $4.4$

(a) By varying the thickness of a thin plastic sheet placed in the beam in one arm of the interferometer one can vary the relative phase and hence shift the fringes. Give a brief qualitative explanation of the origin of the phase shift.

(b) By inserting in one arm a magnetic field which is normal to the beam, time independent and very nearly uniform so that the force on the neutrons can be neglected, and by choosing the field so each neutron spin vector precesses through just one rotation, one finds the relative phase of the two beams is shifted by $\pi$ radians, or one-half cycle. Explain, with appropriate equations, why this is so.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) When a neutron passes through the thin plastic sheet, it is under the action of an additional potential, and so its momentum changes together with its de Broglie wavelength. The phase change of the neutron when it passes through the plastic sheet is different from that when it passes through a vacuum of the same thickness. If the thickness of the plastic sheet is varied, the relative phase of the two beams (originating from the same beam) also changes, causing a shift in the fringes.

(b) The neutron possesses an anomalous magnetic moment $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}=-\mu_{n} \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ and its Schrödinger equation is 

$$
\left(\mathbf{p}^{2} / 2 m_{n}+\mu_{n} \sigma \cdot \mathbf{B}\right) \psi=E \psi .
$$

We may neglect the reflection that occurs when a neutron wave is incident on the "surface" of the sheet-like magnetic field as the action of the field on the neutron is rather weak. Under such an approximation we may show (by solving the above two-spin-component Schrödinger equation for a one-dimensional square well): The wave function $\psi_{\text {inc }}$ for a neutron incident normally on the sheet-like magnetic field is related to the transmitted wave function $\psi_{\text {out }}$ out of the field by a unitary transformation

$$
\psi_{\text {out }}=\exp (-i \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \boldsymbol{\rho} / 2) \psi_{\text {inc }}
$$

where $\rho=\omega_{L} \tau \mathbf{e}_{B}$, with $\omega_{L}=2 \mu_{n} B / \hbar$ being the Larmor frequency, $\tau=$ $L m_{n} / \hbar k$ the time taken for the neutron to pass through the magnetic field of thickness $L, \mathbf{e}_{B}$ the unit vector in the direction of $\mathbf{B}, k$ the wave number of the incident neutron.

If a neutron is polarized in the $(\theta, \varphi)$ direction before entering the field, i.e., its polarized vector is

$$
\left\langle\psi_{\text {inc }}|\boldsymbol{\sigma}| \psi_{\text {inc }}\right\rangle=\{\sin \theta \cos \varphi, \sin \theta \sin \varphi, \cos \theta\} \text {, }
$$

then we can take

$$
\psi_{\mathrm{inc}}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i \varphi / 2} \cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\\
e^{i \varphi / 2} \sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right) e^{i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{x}},
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle the polarized vector makes with the direction of the magnetic field. Taking the latter as the $z$ direction, we have $\boldsymbol{\rho} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma}=\rho \sigma_{z}$. Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\exp \left(-i \frac{\rho}{2} \sigma_{z}\right)=& \cos \frac{\rho}{2}-i \sigma_{z} \sin \frac{\rho}{2}=\cos \frac{\rho}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right) \\
&-i \sin \frac{\rho}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
e^{-i \rho / 2} & 0 \\
0 & e^{i \rho / 2}
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\psi_{\text {out }}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
e^{-i \rho / 2} & 0 \\
0 & e^{i \rho / 2}
\end{array}\right) \psi_{\mathrm{inc}}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i(\varphi+\rho) / 2} \cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
e^{i(\varphi+\rho) / 2} \sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right) e^{i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{x}}
$$

By adjusting $\mathbf{B}$ (or $L$ ) so that $\rho=2 \pi$, we make the polarized vector of a neutron precess through one rotation as it traverses the region of the magnetic field. Then

$$
\psi_{\text {out }}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i \varphi / 2} \cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
e^{i \varphi / 2} \sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right) e^{i(\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{x}+\pi)}
$$

i.e., the phase of the transmitted wave increases by $\pi$. Hence, compared with the wave traversing the other arm (without magnetic field), the relative phase of the beam changes by a half-cycle.

\section{3}

(a) A hydrogen atom is in its $2 P$ state, in a state of $L_{x}=+\hbar$. At time $t=0$ a strong magnetic field of strength $|\mathbf{B}|$ pointing in the $z$ direction is switched on. Assuming that the effects of electron spin can be neglected, calculate the time dependence of the expectation value of $L_{x}$.

(b) How strong must the magnetic field in part (a) be so that the effects of electron spin can actually be neglected? The answer should be expressed in standard macroscopic units.

(c) Suppose that, instead, the magnetic field is very weak. Suppose, further, that at $t=0$ the atom has $L_{x}=+\hbar$ and $s_{x}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar$, and the magnetic field is still oriented in the $z$ direction. Sketch how you would calculate the time dependence of the expectation value of $L_{x}$ in this case. You need not do the full calculation, but explain clearly what the main steps would be.

Note: All effects of nuclear spin are to be ignored in this problem.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The initial wave function of the atom is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t=0)=R_{21}(r) \Theta(\theta, \varphi),
$$

where

$$
\Theta(\theta, \varphi)=\frac{1}{2}\left(Y_{11}+Y_{1-1}+\sqrt{2} Y_{10}\right)
$$

is the eigenstate of $L_{x}=\hbar$.

At $t=0$ a strong magnetic field $B \mathbf{e}_{z}$ is switched on. Then for $t \geq 0$ the Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{\mathbf{p}^{2}}{2 m_{e}}+\frac{e B l_{z}}{2 m_{e} c}+\frac{e^{2} B^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)}{8 m_{e} c^{2}}-\frac{e^{2}}{r} .
$$

For a not too strong magnetic field $B \sim 10^{5} \mathrm{Gs}$, we can neglect the $B^{2}$ term and take as the Hamiltonian

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{\mathbf{p}^{2}}{2 m_{e}}+\frac{e B l_{z}}{2 m_{e} c}-\frac{e^{2}}{r} .
$$

The Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar \partial \psi / \partial t=\hat{H} \psi
$$

then gives the eigenstate solutions

$$
\psi_{n}(\mathbf{r}, t)=R_{n l}(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi) e^{-i E_{n l m} t / \hbar}
$$

where

$$
E_{n l m}=E_{n l}+\frac{e B}{2 m_{e} c} m \hbar .
$$

Thus the general solution is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=\sum_{n, l, m} a_{n} \psi_{n l m}(\mathbf{r}) \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{n l m}}{\hbar} t\right)
$$

For $t=0$, we then have

$$
\sum_{n, l, m} a_{n} \psi_{n l m}(\mathbf{r})=R_{21}(r)\left(\frac{1}{2} Y_{11}+\frac{1}{2} Y_{1-1}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} Y_{10}\right)
$$

or

$$
a_{2} \psi_{211}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{1}{2} R_{21}(r) Y_{11}, \quad \text { etc. }
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=& R_{21}(r)\left[\frac{1}{2} Y_{11} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{211}}{\hbar} t\right)\right.\\
&+\frac{1}{2} Y_{1-1} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{21-1}}{\hbar} t\right) \\
&\left.+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} Y_{10} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{210}}{\hbar} t\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The expectation value of $L_{x}$ is given by $\left\langle\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)\left|L_{x}\right| \psi(\mathbf{r}, t)\right\rangle$. As $L_{x}=$ $\left(L_{+}+L_{-}\right) / 2$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L_{+} Y_{l m}=\hbar \sqrt{(l+m+1)(l-m)} Y_{l, m+1}, \\
&L_{-} Y_{l m}=\hbar \sqrt{(l-m+1)(l+m)} Y_{l, m-1},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L_{x} Y_{11}=\frac{\hbar}{\sqrt{2}} Y_{10}, \quad L_{x} Y_{1-1}=\frac{\hbar}{\sqrt{2}} Y_{10} \\
&L_{x} Y_{10}=\frac{\hbar}{\sqrt{2}}\left(Y_{11}+Y_{1-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\overline{L_{x}(t)}=\left\langle\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)\left|L_{x}\right| \psi(\mathbf{r}, t)\right\rangle=\hbar \cos \frac{e B t}{2 m_{e} c} .
$$

(b) The effects of electron spin can be neglected if the additional energy due to the strong magnetic field is much greater than the coupling energy for spin-orbit interaction, i.e.,

$$
\frac{e \hbar B}{2 m_{e} c} \gg \Delta E_{\text {spin-orbit }} \approx 10^{-3} \mathrm{eV}
$$

or

$$
B \geq 10^{6} \mathrm{Gs} \text {. }
$$

Thus when the magnetic field $B$ is greater than $10^{6} \mathrm{Gs}$, the effects of electron spin can be neglected.

(c) If the magnetic field is very weak, the effects of electron spin must be taken into consideration. To calculate the time dependence of the expectation value of $L_{x}$, follow the steps outlined below.

(i) The Hamiltonian is now

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{\mathbf{p}^{2}}{2 m_{e}}-\frac{e^{2}}{r}+\frac{e^{2}}{2 m_{e}^{2} c^{2} r^{3}}(\hat{\mathbf{s}} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{L}})+\frac{e B}{2 m_{e} c} \hat{J}_{z}+\frac{e B}{2 m_{e} c} \hat{s}_{z},
$$

which is the Hamiltonian for anomalous Zeeman effect and we can use the coupling representation. When calculating the additional energy due to the $\hat{s}_{x}$ term, we can regard $\hat{s}_{x}$ as approximately diagonal in this representation. (ii) Write down the time-dependent wave function which satisfies the initial condition $L_{x}=+\hbar$ and $s_{x}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar$. At time $t=0$ the wave function is

$$
\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}, s_{x}\right)=R_{21}(r) \Theta(\theta, \varphi) \phi_{s},
$$

where $\Theta$ and $\phi_{s}$ are the eigenfunctions of $L_{x}=\hbar$ and $s_{x}=\hbar / 2$ in the representations $\left(l^{2}, l_{z}\right),\left(s^{2}, s_{z}\right)$ respectively. Explicitly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}, s_{x}\right)=& R_{21}(r) \frac{1}{2}\left[Y_{11}+Y_{1-1}+\sqrt{2} Y_{10}\right] \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\alpha+\beta) \\
=& \frac{R_{12}(r)}{2 \sqrt{2}}\left(Y_{11} \alpha+Y_{11} \beta+Y_{1-1} \alpha+Y_{1-1} \beta\right.\\
&\left.+\sqrt{2} Y_{10} \alpha+\sqrt{2} Y_{10} \beta\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi_{j}=\frac{3}{2}, m_{j} &=\frac{3}{2}=Y_{11} \alpha, \quad \phi_{\frac{3}{2} \frac{1}{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}} Y_{11} \beta+\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} Y_{10} \alpha, \\
\phi_{\frac{3}{2}-\frac{1}{2}} &=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}} Y_{1-1} \alpha+\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} Y_{10} \beta, \quad \phi_{\frac{3}{2}-\frac{3}{2}}=Y_{1-1} \beta,
\end{aligned}
$$

$\psi_{0}$ can be written in the coupling representation as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}, s_{x}\right)=& \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}} R_{21}(r)\left(\phi_{\frac{3}{2} \frac{3}{2}}+\sqrt{3} \phi_{\frac{3}{2} \frac{1}{2}}\right.\\
&\left.+\sqrt{3} \phi_{\frac{3}{2}-\frac{1}{2}}+\phi_{\frac{3}{2}-\frac{3}{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\phi_{j m_{j}}$ is the eigenfunction of $\left(j^{2}, j_{z}\right)$ for the energy level $E_{n l j m_{j}}$.

Therefore, the time-dependent wave function for the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi(\mathbf{r}, s, t)=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}} R_{21}(r) \cdot\left[\phi_{\frac{3}{2} \frac{3}{2}} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{21 \frac{3}{2} \frac{3}{2}}}{\hbar} t\right)\right. \\
& +\sqrt{3} \phi_{\frac{3}{2} \frac{1}{2}} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{21 \frac{3}{2} \frac{1}{2}}}{\hbar} t\right) \\
& +\sqrt{3} \phi_{\frac{3}{2}-\frac{1}{2}} \exp \left(-i \frac{E_{21 \frac{3}{2}-\frac{1}{2}}^{\hbar}}{\hbar}\right) \\
& +\phi_{\frac{3}{2}-\frac{3}{2}} \exp \left(-i \frac{\left.\left.E_{21 \frac{3}{2}-\frac{3}{2}}^{\hbar} t\right)\right] .}{}\right. \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

(iii) Calculate the expectation value of $L_{x}$ in the usual manner:

$$
\left\langle\psi(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{s}, t)\left|L_{x}\right| \psi(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{s}, t)\right\rangle .
$$



\section{4}

Consider the one-dimensional motion of an uncharged particle of spin $1 / 2$ and magnetic moment $\mu=-2 \mu_{0} \mathrm{~s} / \hbar$. The particle is confined in an infinite square well extending from $x=-L$ to $x=L$. In region I $(x<0)$ there is a uniform magnetic field in the $z$ direction $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{z}$; in region II $(x>0)$ there is a uniform field of the same magnitude but pointing in the $x$ direction $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{x}$. Here $\mathbf{e}_{x}$ and $\mathbf{e}_{z}$ are unit vectors in the $x$ and $z$ directions.

(a) Use perturbation theory to find the ground state energy and ground state wave function (both space and spin parts) in the weak field limit $B_{0} \ll(\hbar / L)^{2} / 2 m \mu_{0}$

(b) Now consider fields with $B_{0}$ of arbitrary strength. Find the general form of the energy eigenfunction $\psi_{I}$ (both space and spin parts) in region I which satisfies the left-hand boundary condition. Find also the form $\psi_{\mathrm{II}}$ that the eigenfunction has in region II which satisfies the right-hand boundary condition (Fig. 4.5).

(c) Obtain an explicit determinantal equation whose solutions would give the energy eigenvalues $E$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-290.jpg?height=403&width=557&top_left_y=1093&top_left_x=380)

Fig. $4.5$

\section{Solution:}

(a) In the absence of magnetic field, $H=H_{0}$ and the energy eigenfunctions (space part) and eigenvalues are respectively

$$
\psi_{n}=\sqrt{1 / L} \sin \frac{n \pi(x+L)}{2 L},
$$



$$
E_{n}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} n^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}, \quad n=1,2,3, \ldots
$$

As for the spin part, we know that each energy level has a degeneracy of 2 . When a magnetic field is present, $H=H_{0}+H^{\prime}$, where

$$
H^{\prime}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\frac{2 \mu_{0} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}}{\hbar}=\mu_{0} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}= \begin{cases}\mu_{0} B_{0} \sigma_{z}, & -L \leq x \leq 0 \\ \mu_{0} B_{0} \sigma_{x}, & 0 \leq x \leq L \\ 0 & \text { elsewhere }\end{cases}
$$

If the field is weak, let $u_{1}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right), u_{2}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ be the base vectors. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
H_{11}^{\prime}=&\left\langle u_{1}\left|H^{\prime}\right| u_{1}\right\rangle=\mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
& \times \int_{-L}^{0} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}, \\
H_{21}^{\prime}=& H_{12}^{\prime}=\left\langle u_{1}\left|H^{\prime}\right| u_{2}\right\rangle \\
=& \mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \int_{0}^{L} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}, \\
H_{22}^{\prime}=&\left\langle\mu_{2}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \mu_{2}\right\rangle \\
=&-\mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \int_{-L}^{0} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=-\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

and from det $\left(H^{\prime}-E^{(1)} I\right)=0$ we get

$$
\left(\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}-E^{(1)}\right)\left(-\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}-E^{(1)}\right)-\frac{\mu_{0}^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{4}=0,
$$

or

$$
E^{(1)}=\pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mu_{0} B_{0} .
$$

The ground state energy level is therefore

$$
E_{0}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mu_{0} B_{0} .
$$

From

$$
\left(H^{\prime}-E^{(1)} I\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

we get the ground state wave function

$$
\varphi_{0}=a u_{1}+b u_{2}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{c}
1-\sqrt{2} \\
1
\end{array}\right) . \quad \text { (unnormalized) }
$$

(b) The space part of the wave function in region $I$ is

$$
\psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1}}= \begin{cases}A \sin k_{1}(x+L)+B \cos k_{1}(x+L), & -L \leq x \leq 0, \\ 0, & x<-L\end{cases}
$$

The continuity condition of the wave function gives $B=0$. In region I, the spin is aligned to the $z$ direction, the eigenvectors being $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ for $z \downarrow$ and $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ for $z \uparrow$. Hence

$$
\begin{cases}\psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1} z \downarrow}=\sin k_{1}(x+L)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right), & E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{1}^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0} \\
\psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1} z \uparrow}=\sin k_{1}(x+L)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right), & E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{1}^{2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}\end{cases}
$$

In a similar way we obtain the eigenfunctions for region II $(0 \leq x \leq L)$

$$
\begin{cases}\psi_{\mathrm{II} k_{2} x \downarrow}=\sin k_{2}(x-L)\left(\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right), \quad E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{2}^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0} \\
\psi_{\mathrm{II} k_{2} x \uparrow}=\sin k_{2}(x-L)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \quad E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{2}^{2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}\end{cases}
$$

(c) Considering the whole space the energy eigenfunction is

$$
\psi_{E}=\left\{\begin{array}{lc}
A \psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1} z \downarrow}+B \psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1}^{\prime} z \uparrow}, & -L \leq x \leq 0, \\
C \psi_{\mathrm{II} k_{2} x \downarrow}+D \psi_{\mathrm{II} k_{2}^{\prime} x \uparrow}, & 0 \leq x \leq L \\
0, & \text { elsewhere. }
\end{array}\right.
$$

Thus $H \psi_{E}=$

$$
\begin{cases}\left(\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{1}^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0}\right) A \psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1} z \downarrow}+\left(\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}\right) B \psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1}^{\prime} z \uparrow}, & -L \leq x \leq 0 \\ \left(\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{2}^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0}\right) C \psi_{\mathrm{II} k_{2} x \downarrow}+\left(\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{2}^{\prime 2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}\right) D \psi_{\mathrm{II} k_{2}^{\prime} x \uparrow}, & 0 \leq x \leq L \\ 0 . & \text { elsewhere. }\end{cases}
$$

From $H \psi_{E}=E \psi_{E}$ for each region we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{1}^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{2}^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0} \\
&=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{2}^{\prime 2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

and so $k_{1}=k_{2}=k, k_{1}^{\prime}=k_{2}^{\prime}=k^{\prime}$.

Then the continuity of the wave function at $x=0$ gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
B \sin k^{\prime} L=-C \sin k L-D \sin k^{\prime} L \\
A \sin k L=C \sin k L-D \sin k^{\prime} L
\end{gathered}
$$

and the continuity of the derivative of the wave function at $x=0$ gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
B k^{\prime} \cos k^{\prime} L &=C k \cos k L+D k^{\prime} \cos k^{\prime} L, \\
A k \cos k L &=-C k \cos k L+D k^{\prime} \cos k^{\prime} L .
\end{aligned}
$$

To solve for $A, B, C, D$, for nonzero solutions we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cccc}
0 & \sin k^{\prime} L & \sin k L & \sin k^{\prime} L \\
\sin k L & 0 & -\sin k L & \sin k^{\prime} L \\
0 & k^{\prime} \cos k^{\prime} L & -k \cos k L & -k^{\prime} \cos k^{\prime} L \\
k \cos k L & 0 & k \cos k L & -k^{\prime} \cos k^{\prime} L
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

i.e.,

$$
k \sin k L \cos k^{\prime} L-k^{\prime} \sin k^{\prime} L \cos k L=0 .
$$

This and

$$
E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}
$$

determine the eigenvalues $E$. 

\section{5}

Consider an infinitely long solenoid which carries a current $I$ so that there is a constant magnetic field inside the solenoid. Suppose in the region outside the solenoid the motion of a particle with charge $e$ and mass $m$ is described by the Schrödinger equation. Assume that for $I=0$, the solution of the equation is given by

$$
\psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t)=e^{i E_{0} t} \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}) . \quad(\hbar=1)
$$

(a) Write down and solve the Schrödinger equation in the region outside the solenoid for the case $I \neq 0$.

(b) Consider a two-slit diffraction experiment for the particles described above (see Fig. 4.6). Assume that the distance $d$ between the two splits is large compared to the diameter of the solenoid. Compute the shift $\Delta S$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-294.jpg?height=322&width=617&top_left_y=789&top_left_x=350)

Fig. 4.6

of the diffraction pattern on the screen due to the presence of the solenoid with $I \neq 0$. Assume $l \gg \Delta S$.

Hint: Let

$$
\psi(\mathbf{x}, t)=\psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t) \psi_{A}(\mathbf{x})
$$

where

$$
\left(\nabla-i \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{x})\right) \psi_{A}(\mathbf{x})=0 . \quad(\hbar=1) .
$$

\section{Solution:}

(a) In the presence of a vector potential $\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{p} \rightarrow \mathbf{p}-e \mathbf{A} / c$. In the absence of electromagnetic field the Schrödinger equation is

$$
i \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t)=\left[\frac{1}{2 m} \mathbf{p}^{2}+V(\mathbf{x})\right] \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t),
$$

where, as below, we shall use units such that $\hbar=1$. The Schrödinger equation in the presence of an electromagnetic field can thus be obtained (using the minimum electromagnetic coupling theory) as

$$
i \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(\mathbf{x}, t)=\left[\frac{1}{2 m}\left(-i \nabla-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}+V(\mathbf{x})\right] \psi(\mathbf{x}, t)
$$

where $A$ is given by $\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=\mathbf{B}$. Let

$$
\psi(\mathbf{x}, t)=\psi_{1}(\mathbf{x}, t) \exp \left(i \int^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) .
$$

Then the above becomes

$$
i \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi_{1}(\mathbf{x}, t)=\left[\frac{1}{2 m} \mathbf{p}^{2}+V(\mathbf{x})\right] \psi_{1}(\mathbf{x}, t),
$$

which is the Schrödinger equation for zero magnetic field. Hence

$$
\psi_{1}(\mathbf{x}, t)=\psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t)=e^{i E_{0} t} \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}),
$$

and so

$$
\psi(\mathbf{x}, t)=e^{i E_{0} t} \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}) \exp \left(i \int^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) .
$$

(b) This is a problem on the Aharonov-Bohm effect. When $I=0$, for any point on the screen the probability amplitude $f$ is $f=f_{+}+f_{-}$, where $f_{+}$and $f_{-}$represent the contributions of the upper and lower slits respectively. When the current is on, i.e., $I \neq 0$, we have the probability amplitude $f^{\prime}=f_{+}^{\prime}+f_{-}^{\prime}$ with

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{+}^{\prime} &=\exp \left(i \int_{c_{+}}^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{+}, \\
f_{-}^{\prime} &=\exp \left(i \int_{c_{-}}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{-},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $c_{+}$and $c_{-}$denote integral paths above and below the solenoid respectively. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}=& f_{+}^{\prime}+f_{-}^{\prime}=\exp \left(i \int_{c_{+}}^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{+}+\exp \left(i \int_{c_{-}}^{\mathbf{x}} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{-} \\
& \sim \exp \left(i \oint \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{-}+f_{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

on dividing the two contributions by a common phase factor $\exp \left(i \int_{c_{+}}^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right.$. $d \mathbf{x})$, which does not affect the interference pattern. The closed line integral, to be taken counterclockwise along an arbitrary closed path around the solenoid, gives

$$
\oint \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}=\frac{e}{c} \int \nabla \times \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\frac{e}{c} \int \mathbf{B} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\frac{e \phi}{c},
$$

where $\phi$ is the magnetic flux through the solenoid.

Thus the introduction of the solenoid gives a phase factor $e \phi / c$ to the probability amplitude at points on the screen contributed by the lower slit.

Using a method analogous to the treatment of Young's interference in optics, we see that the interference pattern is shifted by $\Delta S$. Assuming $l \gg d$ and $l \gg \Delta S$, we have

$$
\Delta S \cdot \frac{d}{l} \cdot k=\frac{e}{c} \phi,
$$

$k$ being the wave number of the particles, and so

$$
\Delta S=\frac{e l \phi}{c d k}=\frac{e l \phi}{c d \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} .
$$

Note the treatment is only valid nonrelativistically.

\section{6}

(a) What are the energies and energy eigenfunctions for a nonrelativistic particle of mass $m$ moving on a ring of radius $R$ as shown in the Fig. 4.7.?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-296.jpg?height=259&width=327&top_left_y=1387&top_left_x=499)

Fig. $4.7$

(b) What are the energies and energy eigenfunctions if the ring is doubled (each loop still has radius $R$ ) as shown in Fig. 4.8? 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-297.jpg?height=86&width=157&top_left_y=164&top_left_x=596)

Fig. $4.8$

(c) If the particle has charge $q$, what are the energies and energy eigenfunctions if a very long solenoid containing a magnetic flux passes the rings in (a) as shown in the Fig. 4.9.? and in (b)? Assume the system does not radiate electromagnetically.

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-297.jpg?height=167&width=142&top_left_y=621&top_left_x=607)

Fig. $4.9$

\section{Solution:}

(a) As

we have the Schrödinger equation

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{p}}^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}} \frac{d^{2}}{d \theta^{2}},
$$

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} \frac{d^{2}}{d \theta^{2}} \Psi(\theta)=E \Psi(\theta)
$$

where

$$
I=m R^{2}
$$

or

$$
\frac{d^{2} \Psi(\theta)}{d \theta^{2}}+n^{2} \Psi(\theta)=0
$$

with

$$
n^{2}=\frac{2 I E}{\hbar^{2}}
$$

Thus the solutions are

$$
\Psi_{n}(\theta)=A e^{i n \theta} .
$$

For single-valuedness we require

$$
\Psi(\theta+2 \pi)=\Psi(\theta),
$$

i.e.,

$$
n=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots
$$

Normalization requires

$$
A^{*} A=1, \quad \text { or } \quad A=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} .
$$

Hence the eigenfunctions are

$$
\Psi_{n}(\theta)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{i n \theta}, \quad n=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots
$$

and the energy eigenvalues are

$$
E_{n}(\theta)=\frac{n^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 I} .
$$

(b) The same Hamiltonian applies, and so we still have the same Schrödinger equation

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} \frac{d^{2}}{d \theta^{2}} \Psi(\theta)=E \Psi(\theta)
$$

However, the single valuedness of the solutions now requires

$$
\Psi(\theta+4 \pi)=\Psi(\theta) .
$$

Hence the normalized eigenfunctions and the energy eigenvalues are now

$$
\Psi_{n}(\theta)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi}} e^{i \frac{n}{2} \theta}, \quad n=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots
$$

and

$$
E_{n}(\theta)=\frac{n^{2} \hbar^{2}}{8 I} .
$$

(c) The Hamiltonian in the presence of a magnetic field is

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{1}{2 m}(\mathbf{p}-q \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(\nabla-\frac{i q}{\hbar} \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{x})\right)^{2}
$$

In the region where the particle moves, $\mathbf{B}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=0$ and we can choose $\mathbf{A}=\nabla \varphi$. From the symmetry, we have $\mathbf{A}=A_{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}, A_{\theta}=$ constant. Then

$$
\oint \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{l}=\int_{0}^{2 \pi} A_{\theta} R d \theta=2 \pi R A_{\theta}=\phi, \quad \text { say }
$$

Thus

$$
\mathbf{A}=\frac{\phi \mathbf{e}_{\theta}}{2 \pi R}=\nabla(\phi \theta / 2 \pi),
$$

and we can take $\varphi=\phi \theta / 2 \pi$, neglecting possibly a constant phase factor in the wave functions. The Schrödinger equation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
