R^{\prime}(a+0)-R^{\prime}(a-0)=-C^{\prime} R(a),
$$

where

$$
C^{\prime}=\frac{2 m C}{\hbar^{2}}
$$

Suppose there is at least a bound state. Consider the ground state $l=0$, for which

$$
R(r)= \begin{cases}A j_{0}(i k r)=A \frac{\sin (i k r)}{i k r}, & r<a, \\ B h_{0}^{(1)}(i k r)=B \frac{(-1) e^{-k r}}{k r}, & r>a .\end{cases}
$$

Differentiating $R(r)$ and letting $r \rightarrow a$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&R^{\prime}(a+0)=\frac{B}{k} \cdot \frac{e^{-k a}}{a}\left(k+\frac{1}{a}\right) \\
&R^{\prime}(a-0)=\frac{A}{k}\left[\frac{k \cosh (k a)}{a}-\frac{\sinh (k a)}{a^{2}}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting these in Eq. (2) gives

$$
a C^{\prime}=\frac{2 k a}{1-e^{-2 k a}} .
$$

As for $x \geq 0, x \geq 1-e^{-x}$, we have $a C^{\prime} \geq 1$ and

$$
C_{\min }^{\prime}=1 / a, \quad \text { or } \quad C_{\min }=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m a} .
$$

This is the minimum value of $C$ for which there is a bound state.

(b) We use the method of partial waves. When the particle is incident on the potential with a low velocity, only the $\ell=0$ partial wave is important, for which the radial wave equation

$$
R^{\prime \prime}+\frac{2}{r} R^{\prime}+\left[k^{2}+\frac{2 m C}{\hbar^{2}} \delta(r-a)\right] \quad R=0 .
$$

On setting $R(r)=\chi_{0}(r) / r$ it becomes

$$
\chi_{0}^{\prime \prime}+\left[k^{2}+\frac{2 m C}{\hbar^{2}} \delta(r-a)\right] \chi_{0}=0,
$$

which has solutions finite at $r \rightarrow 0$ and $r \rightarrow \infty$

$$
\chi_{0}(r)= \begin{cases}A \sin k r, & r<a, \\ \sin \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right), & r>a .\end{cases}
$$

As $\chi_{0}(r)$ is continuous at $r=a$, we require

$$
A \sin k a=\sin \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right) \text {. }
$$

Integrating Eq. (3) from $a-\varepsilon$ to $a+\varepsilon$ gives

$$
\chi_{0}^{\prime}(a+\varepsilon)-\chi_{0}^{\prime}(a-\varepsilon)=-\frac{2 m C}{\hbar^{2}} \chi_{0}(a) .
$$

Substituting in the expressions for $\chi_{0}(r)$, it becomes

$$
\frac{k a}{\tan \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right)}-\frac{k a}{\tan k a}=-\frac{2 m C a}{\hbar^{2}} .
$$

For $k \rightarrow 0$, the above becomes

$$
\frac{k a}{\tan \delta_{0}}-1=-\frac{2 m C a}{\hbar^{2}},
$$

or

$$
\tan \delta_{0}=\frac{k a}{1-\frac{2 m a C}{\hbar^{2}}}
$$

i.e.,

$$
\sin \delta_{0}=\frac{k a}{\sqrt{k^{2} a^{2}+\left(1-\frac{2 m a C}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{2}}} \approx \frac{k a}{\left(1-\frac{2 m a C}{\hbar^{2}}\right)}
$$

Hence the total scattering cross section is

$$
\sigma_{t}=\frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{0} \approx \frac{4 \pi a^{2}}{\left(1-\frac{2 m a C}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{2}} .
$$

Note that for low velocities only $s$-waves $(l=0)$ need be considered and the differential cross section is simply

$$
\sigma(\theta)=\frac{1}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{0}=a^{2}\left(1-\frac{2 m a C}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{-2},
$$

which is independent of the angles. Thus the angular distribution is isotropic. 

\section{5}

(a) Find the $s$-wave phase shift, as a function of wave number $k$, for a spherically symmetric potential which is infinitely repulsive inside of a radius $r_{0}$, and vanishes outside of $r_{0}$.

(b) For $k \rightarrow 0$ discuss the behavior of the phase shifts in the higher partial waves.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) This is a typical scattering problem that can be readily solved by the method of partial waves. The potential can be expressed as

$$
V(r)= \begin{cases}\infty, & r<r_{0} \\ 0, & r>r_{0} .\end{cases}
$$

The radial wave function for the $\ell$ partial wave is

$$
R_{\ell}(k r)= \begin{cases}0, & r<r_{0}, \\ j_{\ell}(k r) \cos \delta_{\ell}-n_{\ell}(k r) \sin \delta_{\ell}, & r>r_{0} .\end{cases}
$$

Here $j_{\ell}$ and $n_{\ell}$ are spherical Bessel function and spherical Neumann function of order $\ell$. These functions have the asymptotic forms

$$
\begin{aligned}
&j_{\ell}(x) \stackrel{x \rightarrow \infty}{\longrightarrow} \frac{1}{x} \sin (x-\ell \pi / 2), \\
&n_{\ell}(x) \stackrel{x \rightarrow \infty}{\longrightarrow}-\frac{1}{x} \cos (x-\ell \pi / 2) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence for $r>r_{0}$ we have

$$
R_{\ell}(k r) \stackrel{k r \rightarrow \infty}{\longrightarrow} \sin \left(k r-\frac{\ell \pi}{2}+\delta_{\ell}\right) .
$$

The phase shift $\delta_{\ell}$ can be determined by the continuity of the wave function at $r=r_{0}$. Writing $k r_{0}=x$, the continuity condition

$$
R_{\ell}(x)=j_{\ell}(x) \cos \delta_{\ell}-n_{\ell}(x) \sin \delta_{\ell}=0
$$

gives

$$
\tan \delta_{\ell}=\frac{j_{\ell}(x)}{n_{\ell}(x)} .
$$

In the low-energy limit $x \rightarrow 0$, the functions have the asymptotic forms

$$
\begin{gathered}
j_{\ell}(x) \stackrel{x \rightarrow 0}{\longrightarrow} \frac{x^{\ell}}{(2 \ell+1) ! !}, \\
n_{\ell}(x) \stackrel{x \rightarrow 0}{\longrightarrow}-\frac{(2 \ell-1) ! !}{x^{\ell+1}},
\end{gathered}
$$

so that

$$
\tan \delta_{\ell}=\frac{j_{\ell}(x)}{n_{\ell}(x)} \stackrel{x \rightarrow 0}{\longrightarrow}-\frac{x^{2 \ell+1}}{[(2 \ell-1) ! !]^{2}(2 \ell+1)} .
$$

Thus the $s$-wave $(\ell=0)$ phase shift is

$$
\tan \delta_{0}=-x=-k r_{0} .
$$

It gives a finite contribution to the scattering and the corresponding total cross section is

$$
\sigma_{t}=\frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{0} \approx \frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \delta_{0}^{2} \approx 4 \pi r_{0}^{2} .
$$

The scattering is spherically symmetric, and the total cross section is four times the classical value $\pi r_{0}^{2}$.

(b) Consider the low-energy limit $k \rightarrow 0$.

As

$$
\tan \delta_{\ell} \approx-\frac{x^{2 \ell+1}}{[(2 \ell-1) ! !]^{2}(2 \ell+1)}
$$

$\delta_{\ell}$ falls off very rapidly as $\ell$ increases. All the phase shifts vanish as $k \rightarrow 0$, except for the $l=0$ partial wave. Hence $s$-waves predominate in low-energy scattering. Physically, particles with higher partial waves are farther away from the force center so the effect of the force on such particles is smaller, causing $\left|\delta_{\ell}\right|$ to be smaller.

\section{6}

A particle of mass $m$ is scattered by the central potential

$$
V(r)=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m a^{2}} \frac{1}{\cosh ^{2}(r / a)}
$$

where $a$ is a constant. Given that the equation

$$
\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}+k^{2} y+\frac{2}{\cosh ^{2} x} y=0
$$

has the solutions $y=e^{\pm i k x}(\tanh x \mp i k)$, calculate the $s$-wave contribution to the total scattering cross section at energy $E$.

\section{Solution:}

Letting $\chi_{0}(r)=r R(r)$ we have for the radial part of the Schrödinger equation for $s$-waves $(\ell=0)$

$$
\frac{d^{2} \chi_{0}(r)}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m a^{2}} \frac{1}{\cosh ^{2}(r / a)}\right] \chi_{0}(r)=0 .
$$

With $x=r / a, y(x)=\chi_{0}(r)$ and $k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}$, the above becomes

$$
\frac{d^{2} y(x)}{d x^{2}}+k^{2} a^{2} y(x)+\frac{2}{\cosh ^{2}(x)} y(x)=0 .
$$

This equation has solutions $y=e^{\pm i a k x}(\tanh x \mp i a k)$. For $R$ finite at $r=0$ we require $y(0)=0$. The solution that satisfies this condition has the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
y(x) &=e^{i a k x}(\tanh x-i a k)+e^{-i a k x}(\tanh x+i a k) \\
&=2 \cos (a k x) \tanh x+2 a k \sin (a k x)
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\chi_{0}(r)=2 \cos (k r) \tanh \left(\frac{r}{a}\right)+2 a k \sin (k r) .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{1}{\chi_{0}} \frac{d \chi_{0}}{d r}=\frac{a k^{2} \cos (k r)-k \sin (k r) \tanh \left(\frac{r}{a}\right)+\frac{1}{a} \cos (k r) \operatorname{sech}^{2}\left(\frac{r}{a}\right)}{a k \sin (k r)+\cos (k r) \tanh \left(\frac{r}{a}\right)} \\
\stackrel{r \rightarrow \infty}{\longrightarrow} \frac{a k^{2} \cos (k r)-k \sin (k r)}{a k \sin (k r)+\cos (k r)}=k \frac{a k \cot (k r)-1}{\cot (k r)+a k} .
\end{gathered}
$$

On the other hand if we write $\chi_{0}$ in the form

$$
\chi_{0}(r)=\sin \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right),
$$

then as

$$
\frac{1}{\chi_{0}} \frac{d \chi_{0}}{d r}=k \cot \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right)=k \frac{\cot (k r) \cot \delta_{0}-1}{\cot (k r)+\cot \delta_{0}},
$$

we have to put

$$
\cot \delta_{0}=a k,
$$

or

$$
\sin ^{2} \delta_{0}=\frac{1}{1+a^{2} k^{2}} .
$$

Hence the $s$-wave contribution to the total scattering cross section is

$$
\sigma_{t}=\frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{0}=\frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \frac{1}{1+a^{2} k^{2}}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar^{2}}{m E} \frac{1}{1+\frac{2 a^{2} m E}{\hbar^{2}}}
$$

\section{7}

A spinless particle of mass $m$, energy $E$ scatters through angle $\theta$ in an attractive square-well potential $V(r)$ :

$$
V(r)= \begin{cases}-V_{0}, & 0<r<a, \quad V_{0}>0, \\ 0, & r>a\end{cases}
$$

(a) Establish a relation among the parameters $V_{0}, a, m$ and universal constants which guarantees that the cross section vanishes at zero energy $E=0$. This will involve a definite but transcendental equation, which you must derive but need not solve numerically. For parameters meeting the above condition, the differential cross section, as $E \rightarrow 0$, will behave like

$$
\frac{\partial \sigma}{\partial \Omega} \underset{E \rightarrow 0}{\longrightarrow} E^{\lambda} F(\cos \theta) .
$$

(b) What is the numerical value of the exponent $\lambda$ ?

(c) The angular distribution function $F(\cos \theta)$ is a polynomial in $\cos \theta$. What is the highest power of $\cos \theta$ in this polynomial? 

\section{Solution:}

(a) When the energy is near zero, only the partial wave with $l=0$ is important. Writing the radial wave function as $R(r)=\chi(r) / r$, then $\chi(r)$ must satisfy the equations

$$
\begin{cases}\chi^{\prime \prime}+\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}} \chi=0, & r>a \\ \chi^{\prime \prime}+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left(E+V_{0}\right) \chi=0, & 0<r<a\end{cases}
$$

with $k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}, K=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(E+V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}$. The above has solutions

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\chi(r)=\sin \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right), & r>a, \\
\chi(r)=A \sin (K r), & 0<r<a .
\end{array}
$$

As both $\chi(r)$ and $\chi^{\prime}(r)$ are continuous at $r=a$, we require

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sin \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right) &=A \sin (K a), \\
k \cos \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right) &=K A \cos (K a),
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
K \tan \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right)=k \tan (K a)
$$

and hence

$$
\delta_{0}=\tan ^{-1}\left[\frac{k}{K} \tan (K a)\right]-k a .
$$

For $E \rightarrow 0$

$$
k \rightarrow 0, K \rightarrow k_{0} \equiv \sqrt{\frac{2 m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2}}},
$$

and so

$$
\delta_{0} \rightarrow k\left[\frac{\tan \left(k_{0} a\right)}{k_{0}}-a\right] .
$$

For the total cross section to be zero at $E=0$, we require

$$
\frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{0} \rightarrow 4 \pi a^{2}\left[\frac{\tan \left(k_{0} a\right)}{k_{0} a}-1\right]^{2}=0,
$$

or

$$
\tan \left(k_{0} a\right)=k_{0} a,
$$

i.e.,

$$
\tan \left(\frac{\sqrt{2 m V_{0}}}{\hbar} a\right)=\frac{\sqrt{2 m V_{0}}}{\hbar} a,
$$

which is the transcendental equation that the parameters $V_{0}, a, m$ and universal constant $\hbar$ must satisfy.

(b) \& (c) When $k \rightarrow 0$, the partial wave with $\ell=0$ is still very important for the differential cross-section, although its contribution also goes to zero. Expanding $\tan (K a)$ as a Taylor series in $k$, we have

$$
\tan (K a)=\tan \left(a \sqrt{k^{2}+k_{0}^{2}}\right)=\tan \left(k_{0} a\right)+\frac{a k^{2}}{2 k_{0} \cos ^{2}\left(k_{0} a\right)}+\cdots .
$$

Neglecting terms of orders higher than $k^{2}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta_{0} &=\tan ^{-1}\left[\frac{k}{K} \tan (K a)\right]-k a \\
& \approx \tan ^{-1}\left\{\frac{k}{k_{0}}\left(1-\frac{k^{2}}{2 k_{0}^{2}}\right)\left[\tan \left(k_{0} a\right)+\frac{k^{2} a}{2 k_{0} \cos ^{2}\left(k_{0} a\right)}\right]\right\}-k a \\
& \approx \tan ^{-1}\left\{\frac{k}{k_{0}} \tan \left(k_{0} a\right)-\frac{k^{3}}{2 k_{0}^{3}} \tan \left(k_{0} a\right)+\frac{k^{3} a}{2 k_{0}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(k_{0} a\right)}\right\}-k a \\
& \approx \tan ^{-1}\left\{k a-\frac{k^{3} a}{2 k_{0}^{2}}+\frac{k^{3} a}{2 k_{0}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(k_{0} a\right)}\right\}-k a \\
& \approx \frac{k^{3} a}{2 k_{0}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(k_{0} a\right)}-\frac{k^{3} a}{2 k_{0}^{2}}-\frac{k^{3} a^{3}}{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega} & \approx \frac{1}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{0} \\
& \approx k^{4} F\left(k_{0}, a\right) \\
&=E^{2}\left(\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{2} F\left(k_{0}, a\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the differential cross section per unit solid angle is approximately isotropic and proportional to $E^{2}$ for $E \rightarrow 0$. To find the contribution of partial wave with $\ell=1$, consider its radial wave equations

$$
\frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d}{d r} R\right)+\left(K^{2}-\frac{2}{r^{2}}\right) R=0 \quad(r<a),
$$



$$
\frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d}{d r} R\right)+\left(k^{2}-\frac{2}{r^{2}}\right) R=0 \quad(r>a) .
$$

The solutions have the form of the first-order spherical Bessel function $j_{1}(p)=\frac{\sin \rho}{\rho^{2}}-\frac{\cos \rho}{\rho}$, or

$$
R_{1}= \begin{cases}\frac{\sin (K r)}{(K r)^{2}}-\frac{\cos (K r)}{K r}, & 0<r<a, \\ A\left[\frac{\sin \left(k r+\delta_{1}\right)}{(k r)^{2}}-\frac{\cos \left(k r+\delta_{1}\right)}{k r}\right], & r>a\end{cases}
$$

The continuity of $R_{1}$ and the first derivative of $r^{2} R$ at $r=a$ gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\sin K a}{(K a)^{2}}-\frac{\cos K a}{K a}=A\left[\frac{\sin \left(k a+\delta_{1}\right)}{(k a)^{2}}-\frac{\cos \left(k a+\delta_{1}\right)}{k a}\right], \\
\sin K a=A \sin \left(k a+\delta_{1}\right) .
\end{gathered}
$$

Taking the ratios we have $k^{2}[1-K a \cot (K a)]=K^{2}\left[1-k a \cot \left(k a+\delta_{1}\right)\right]$, or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tan \left(k a+\delta_{1}\right) &=k a\left[1+\frac{k^{2}}{k_{0}^{2}}-\frac{k^{2} a \cot (K a)}{k_{0}}+O\left(k^{4}\right)\right] \\
&=k a+O\left(k^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as

$$
K=\sqrt{k^{2}+k_{0}^{2}} \simeq k_{0}\left[1+\frac{1}{2} \frac{k^{2}}{k_{0}^{2}}+O\left(k^{4}\right)\right] .
$$

Hence

$$
\delta_{1}=\tan ^{-1}\left[k a+O\left(k^{3}\right)\right]-k a=-\frac{1}{3}(k a)^{3}+O\left(k^{3}\right)=O\left(k^{3}\right) .
$$

Thus its contribution to $\frac{\partial \sigma}{\partial \Omega}$,

$$
\frac{9}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{1} \cos ^{2} \theta,
$$

is also proportional to $k^{4}$. Similarly, for $l=2$,

$$
R_{2}= \begin{cases}{\left[\frac{3}{(K r)^{3}}-\frac{1}{K r}\right] \sin (K r)-\frac{3 \cos (K r)}{(K r)^{2}},} & 0<r<a, \\ {\left[\frac{3}{(k r)^{3}}-\frac{1}{k r}\right] \sin \left(k r+\delta_{2}\right)-\frac{3 \cos \left(k r+\delta_{2}\right)}{(k r)^{2}},} & r>a .\end{cases}
$$

The continuity of $R$ and $\left(r^{3} R_{2}\right)^{\prime}$ at $r=a$ then gives

$$
\frac{k^{2}}{K^{2}} \frac{\left[\tan \left(k a+\delta_{2}\right)-k a\right]}{[\tan (K a)-K a]}=\frac{\left[3-(k a)^{2}\right] \tan \left(k a+\delta_{2}\right)-3 k a}{\left[3-(K a)^{2}\right] \tan (K a)-3 K a}
$$

Let $y=\tan \left(k a+\delta_{2}\right)-k a$. The above becomes

$$
\left[\frac{3}{(k a)^{3}}-\frac{1}{k a}\right] y-1=\frac{y(-1+O(k))}{b K^{2}\left(1+O \cdot\left(k^{2}\right)\right)}
$$

where

$$
b=\frac{a}{2 \cos ^{2}\left(k_{0} a\right)-k_{0}} .
$$

Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
y &=\frac{1}{\frac{3}{(k a)^{3}}-\frac{1}{k a}+\frac{1}{b K^{2}}+O(k)} \\
&=\frac{1}{\frac{3}{(k a)^{3}}\left[1-\frac{(k a)^{2}}{3}+\frac{(k a)^{3}}{3 b K^{2}}+O\left(k^{4}\right)\right]} \\
&=\frac{(k a)^{3}}{3}\left[1+\frac{(k a)^{2}}{3}-\frac{(k a)^{3}}{3 b K^{2}}+O\left(k^{4}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{(k a)^{3}}{3}+\frac{(k a)^{5}}{9}+O\left(k^{6}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta_{2} &=\tan ^{-1}(y+k a)-k a \\
& \approx y=O\left(k^{3}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the contribution of partial waves with $l=2$ to $\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}$ is also proportional to $k^{4}$. This is true for all $\ell$ for $E \rightarrow 0$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial \sigma}{\partial \Omega}=&|f(\theta)|^{2}=\frac{1}{k^{2}}\left|\sum_{l=0}^{\infty}(2 l+1) e^{i \delta_{l}} \sin \delta_{l} P_{l}(\cos \theta)\right|^{2} \\
& \underset{E \rightarrow 0}{\longrightarrow} k^{4} F(\cos \theta) \sim E^{2} F(\cos \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the exponent of $E$ is $\lambda=2$. The highest power of $\cos \theta$ in the angular distribution function is also 2 since the waves consist mainly of $\ell=0$ and $\ell=1$ partial waves.

\section{8}

1. The shell potential for the three-dimensional Schrödinger equation is

$$
V(r)=\alpha \delta\left(r-r_{0}\right)
$$

(a) Find the $s$-state $(l=0)$ wave function for $E>0$. Include an expression that determines the phase shift $\delta$. With $\hbar k=\sqrt{2 m E}$ show that in the limit $k \rightarrow 0, \delta \rightarrow A k$, where $A$ is a constant (called the scattering length). Solve for $A$ in terms of $\alpha$ and $r_{0}$.

(b) How many bound states can exist for $l=0$ and how does their existence depend on $\alpha$ ? (Graphical proof is acceptable)

(c) What is the scattering length $A$ when a bound state appears at $E=0$ ? Describe the behavior of $A$ as $\alpha$ changes from repulsive $(\alpha>0)$ to attractive, and then when $\alpha$ becomes sufficiently negative to bind. Is the range of $A$ distinctive for each range of $\alpha$ ? Sketch $A$ as a function of $\alpha$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The radial part of the Schrödinger equation for $\ell=0$ is

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r} \psi\right)+V(r) \psi=E \psi
$$

With $\psi=\mu / r, V(r)=\alpha \delta\left(r-r_{0}\right)$ it becomes

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \mu^{\prime \prime}+\alpha \delta\left(r-r_{0}\right) \mu=E \mu,
$$

i.e.,

$$
\mu^{\prime \prime}-\beta \delta\left(r-r_{0}\right) \mu=-k^{2} \mu,
$$

where

$$
\beta=\frac{2 m \alpha}{\hbar^{2}}, \quad k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} .
$$

The equation has solution for which $\mu=0$ at $r=0$ and $\mu=$ finite for $r \rightarrow \infty$

$$
\mu= \begin{cases}\sin k r, & r<r_{0}, \\ a \sin (k r+\delta), & r>r_{0} .\end{cases}
$$

Integrating Eq. (1) from $r_{0}-\varepsilon$ to $r_{0}+\varepsilon$ and letting $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$ give

$$
\mu^{\prime}\left(r_{0}+\right)-\mu^{\prime}\left(r_{0}-\right)=\beta \mu\left(r_{0}\right) .
$$

The continuity of $\mu$ at $r=r_{0}$ and this condition give

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sin k r_{0}=a \sin \left(k r_{0}+\delta\right) \\
\frac{\beta}{k} \sin k r_{0}=a \cos \left(k r_{0}+\delta\right)-\cos k r_{0}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{2}\left[\sin ^{2}\left(k r_{0}+\delta\right)+\cos ^{2}\left(k r_{0}+\delta\right)\right] &=a^{2}=1+\frac{\beta}{k} \sin 2 k r_{0}+\frac{\beta^{2}}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} k r_{0} \\
\tan \left(k r_{0}+\delta\right) &=\frac{\tan k r_{0}}{1+\frac{\beta}{k} \tan k r_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which determine $a$ and the phase shift $\delta$. In the limiting case of $k \rightarrow 0$, the above equation becomes

$$
\frac{k r_{0}+\tan \delta}{1-k r_{0} \tan \delta} \approx \frac{k r_{0}}{1+\beta r_{0}},
$$

or

$$
\tan \delta \approx-\frac{\beta r_{0}^{2}}{1+\beta r_{0}} k,
$$

neglecting $O\left(k^{2}\right)$. Then, as $k \rightarrow 0$, we have $\tan \delta \rightarrow 0$ and so

$$
\delta \approx-\frac{r_{0} k}{1+\frac{1}{\beta r_{0}}}=A k
$$

where

$$
A=\frac{-r_{0}}{1+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m \alpha r_{0}}}
$$

is the scattering length. (b) For bound states, $E<0$ and Eq. (1) can be written as

$$
\mu^{\prime \prime}-\beta \delta\left(r-r_{0}\right) \mu=k^{2} \mu
$$

with

$$
\beta=\frac{2 m \alpha}{\hbar^{2}}, \quad k^{2}=-\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}} .
$$

The solution in which $\mu=0$ at $r=0$ and $\mu=$ finite for $r \rightarrow \infty$ is

$$
\mu= \begin{cases}\sinh k r, & r<r_{0}, \\ a e^{-k r}, & r>r_{0} .\end{cases}
$$

The continuity conditions, as in (a), give

$$
\mu=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sinh k r_{0}=a e^{-k r_{0}}, \\
\beta a e^{-k r_{0}}=-a k e^{-k r_{0}}-k \cosh k r_{0} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Eliminating $a$ we have

$$
(\beta+k) \sinh k r_{0}=-k \cosh k r_{0},
$$

or

$$
c^{-2 k r_{0}}=1+\frac{2 k r_{0}}{\beta r_{0}} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-494.jpg?height=402&width=553&top_left_y=1111&top_left_x=382)

Fig. $6.1$

For bound states $E<0$. Between $E=-\infty$ and $E=0$, or between $2 k r_{0}=\infty$ and $2 k r_{0}=0$, there is one intersection between the curves (I) $y=e^{-2 k r_{0}}$ and (II) $y=1+\frac{2 k r_{0}}{\beta r_{0}}$ if $-1<\frac{1}{\beta r_{0}}<0$, as shown in Fig. 6.1. Thus if this condition is satisfied there will be one bound state with $\ell=0$. This condition requires (c) In (a) it is found that

$$
-1<\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{2 m|\alpha| r_{0}}, \quad \text { or } \quad \alpha<\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{2 m r_{0}}=\alpha_{0} .
$$

$$
A=-\frac{r_{0}}{1+\frac{1}{\beta r_{0}}}=-\frac{r_{0}}{1+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r_{0} \alpha}} .
$$

The behavior of $A$ is shown in Fig. 6.2, where it is seen that for $\alpha=0$, $A=0 ;$ for $\alpha=\alpha_{0}=\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{2 m r_{0}}, A=\pm \infty ; \alpha=\pm \infty, A=-r_{0}$. With $E \rightarrow+0$, a bound state appears at $E=0$. At this energy $\alpha=\alpha_{0}, \delta=\pm \pi / 2$ and $A=\infty$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-495.jpg?height=567&width=557&top_left_y=649&top_left_x=392)

Fig. $6.2$

\section{9}

The nucleus ${ }^{8} \mathrm{Be}$ is unstable with respect to dissociation into two $\alpha$ particles, but experiments on nuclear reactions characterize the two lowest unstable levels as $J=0$, even parity, $\sim 95 \mathrm{keV}$ above the dissociation level, and $J=2$, even parity, $\sim 3 \mathrm{MeV}$ above the dissociation level.

Consider how the existence of these levels influences the scattering of $\alpha$ particles from helium gas, specifically:

(a) Write the wave function for elastic scattering, in its partial wave expansion, for $r \rightarrow \infty$ (b) Describe qualitatively how the relevant phase shifts vary as functions of energy in the proximity of each level.

(c) Describe how this variation affects the angular distribution of $\alpha$ particles.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The spin of $\alpha$ particle is zero, so the two- $\alpha$-particle (identical particles) system obeys Bose-Einstein statistics and the quantum number $\ell$ of the relative angular momentum must be an even number. There are two additive phase shifts: $\delta_{\ell}^{C}$ caused by Coulomb interaction and $\delta_{\ell}^{N}$ caused by nuclear force. Thus as $r \rightarrow \infty$, the wave function is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi=& \sum_{l=0,2,4, \ldots}(2 l+1) i^{l} \exp \left[i\left(\delta_{l}^{C}+\delta_{l}^{N}\right)\right](k r)^{-1} \\
& \times \sin \left(k r-\frac{l \pi}{2}+\delta_{l}^{C}+\delta_{l}^{N}-\gamma \ln 2 k r\right) P_{l}(\cos \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $k$ is the wave number in the c.m. frame, $\gamma=(2 e)^{2} / \hbar \nu_{r}$.

(b) As the energy increases to a certain value, $\delta_{\ell}^{N}$ also increases from zero because of the action of the nuclear force. Particularly, when the energy is near an unstable energy level of the compound nucleus with a definite $l$, every $\delta_{l}^{N}$ near $\pi$ changes very rapidly. For ${ }^{8} \mathrm{Be}$, this happens when $l=0$ and the energy is near $95 \mathrm{keV}$, and when $l=2$ and the energy is near $3 \mathrm{MeV}$.

Generally, if the energy is lower than the Coulomb potential, nuclear force can be neglected. In such a situation $\delta_{l}^{N}$ is near 0 or $n \pi$.

(c) To see the effect of nuclear force on the angular distribution, we rewrite the partial wave expansion as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi=& \sum_{l=0,2,4, \ldots}^{\infty}(2 l+1) i^{l} \exp \left(i \delta_{l}^{C}\right)(k r)^{-1}\left\{\operatorname { s i n } \left(k r-\frac{l \pi}{2}\right.\right.\\
&\left.-\gamma \ln 2 k r+\delta_{l}^{C}\right)+\left(\frac{\exp \left(2 i \delta_{l}^{N}\right)-1}{2 i}\right) \exp \left[i \left(k r-\frac{l \pi}{2}\right.\right.\\
&\left.\left.\left.-\gamma \ln 2 k r+\delta_{l}^{C}\right)\right]\right\} P_{l}(\cos \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first term inside the large brackets is the Coulomb scattering wave function, which is not affected by nuclear force. We sum it over $\ell$ to get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\exp & i\left\{k r \cos \theta-\gamma \ln [k r(1-\cos \theta)]+\delta_{o}^{C}\right\}-\gamma(k r)^{-1} \\
& \times \exp i\left\{k r \cos \theta-\gamma \ln (k r)+\delta_{o}^{C}\right\} \\
& \times \sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}\left\{\frac{\exp [-i \gamma \ln (1-\cos \theta)]}{1-\cos \theta}+\frac{\exp [-i \gamma \ln (1+\cos \theta)]}{1+\cos \theta}\right\} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The two terms in the last large brackets above arise from the identity of the two $\mathrm{He}^{++}$. These in general do not occur in Rutherford scattering.

The second term in the large brackets in the expansion of $\psi$ is caused by the nuclear force which interferes with the Coulomb scattering. But this effect is quite trivial when $\delta_{l}^{N}$ is near $n \pi$.

\section{0}

Consider the quantum-mechanical scattering problem in the presence of inelastic scattering. Suppose one can write the partial wave expansion of the scattering amplitude for the elastic channel in the form

$$
f(k, \theta)=\sum_{l=0}^{\infty}(2 l+1) \frac{\eta_{l} e^{2 i \delta_{l}}-1}{2 i k} P_{l}(\cos \theta),
$$

where $\delta_{l}(k)$ and $\eta_{l}(k)$ are real quantities with $0 \leq \eta_{l} \leq 1$, the wave number is denoted by $k$, and $\theta$ is the scattering angle. For a given partial wave, obtain the lower and upper bounds for the elastic cross section $\sigma_{\text {elastic }}^{(l)}$ in terms of $\sigma_{\text {inelastic }}^{(l)}$

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

As

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sigma_{\text {elastic }}^{(l)}=\pi X^{2}(2 l+1)\left|1-\eta_{l} e^{2 i \delta_{l}}\right|^{2}, \\
\sigma_{\text {inelastic }}^{(l)}=\pi X^{2}(2 l+1)\left(1-\left|\eta_{l} e^{2 i \delta_{l}}\right|^{2}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
x^{2}=\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi}=\frac{1}{k},
$$

we have

$$
\sigma_{\text {elastic }}^{(l)}=\frac{\left|1-\eta_{l} e^{2 i \delta_{l}}\right|^{2}}{1-\left|\eta_{l} e^{2 i \delta_{l}}\right|^{2}} \cdot \sigma_{\text {inelastic }}^{(l)} \text {. }
$$

As $\eta_{l}, \delta_{l}$ are real numbers and $0 \leq \eta_{l} \leq 1$, we have

$$
\frac{\left(1-\eta_{l}\right)^{2}}{1-\eta_{l}^{2}} \leq \frac{\left|1-\eta_{l} e^{2 i \delta_{l}}\right|^{2}}{1-\left|\eta_{l} e^{2 i \delta_{l}}\right|^{2}} \leq \frac{\left(1+\eta_{l}\right)^{2}}{1-\eta_{l}^{2}}
$$

or

$$
\frac{\left(1-\eta_{l}\right)^{2}}{1-\eta_{l}^{2}} \sigma_{\text {inelastic }}^{(l)} \leq \sigma_{\text {elastic }}^{(l)} \leq \frac{\left(1+\eta_{l}\right)^{2}}{1-\eta_{l}^{2}} \sigma_{\text {inelastic }}^{(l)}
$$

Therefore the upper and lower bounds of $\sigma_{\text {elastic }}^{(l)}$ are respectively

$$
\frac{\left(1+\eta_{l}\right)^{2}}{1-\eta_{l}^{2}} \sigma_{\text {inelastic }}^{(l)} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{\left(1-\eta_{l}\right)^{2}}{1-\eta_{l}^{2}} \sigma_{\text {inelastic }}^{(l)}
$$

\section{1}

A slow electron of wave number $k$ is scattered by a neutral atom of effective (maximum) radius $R$, such that $k R \ll 1$.

(a) Assuming that the electron-atom potential is known, explain how the relevant phase shift $\delta$ is related to the solution of a Schrödinger equation.

(b) Give a formula for the differential scattering cross section in terms of $\delta$ and $k$. (If you do not remember the formula, try to guess it using dimensional reasoning.)

(c) Explain, with a diagram of the Schrödinger-equation solution, how a non-vanishing purely attractive potential might, at a particular $k$, give no scattering.

(d) Explain, again with a diagram, how a potential that is attractive at short distances but repulsive at large distances might give resonance scattering near a particular $k$.

(e) What is the maximum value of the total cross section at the center of the resonance? 

\section{Solution:}

(a) We need only consider the $s$ partial wave as $k R \ll 1$. The solution of the Schrödinger equation has for $r \rightarrow \infty$ the asymptotic form

$$
\psi(r) \rightarrow \frac{\sin (k r+\delta)}{k r}
$$

The phase shift $\delta$ is thus related to the solution of the Schrödinger equation.

(b) The differential scattering cross section is given by

$$
\sigma(\theta)=\frac{\sin ^{2} \delta}{k^{2}} .
$$

(c) The phase shift $\delta$ in general is a function of the wave number $k$. When $\delta=n \pi, \sigma(\theta)=0, \delta_{t}=0$ and no scattering takes place. The asymptotic solution of the Schrödinger equation with $\ell=0$ is shown in Fig. 6.3(a)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-499.jpg?height=251&width=528&top_left_y=962&top_left_x=408)

Fig. 6.3(a)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-499.jpg?height=293&width=464&top_left_y=1309&top_left_x=442)

Fig. 6.3(b)

(d) Consider a potential well as that given in Fig. 6.3(b). If the energy of the incident particle is near an eigenvalue of the well (a bound state), its wave function inside the well will be strongly coupled with its wave function outside and the wave function in the well will have a large amplitude, resulting in resonance scattering.

(e) The maximum value of the total cross section at the center of the resonance peak is $4 \pi R^{2}$, where $R$ is the range of the force of interaction.

\section{2}

For an attractive square-well potential $\left(V=-V_{0}, r<a ; V=0, r>a\right)$ find the "matching equation" at a positive energy, which determines the energy dependence of the $\ell=0$ phase shift $\delta_{0}$. From this show that at high energies, $\delta(k) \rightarrow \frac{m a V_{0}}{\hbar^{2} k}$, and obtain this result from the Born approximation.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let $\chi=r R$. For the $\ell=0$ partial wave, the Schrödinger equation becomes

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\chi^{\prime \prime}+k^{2} \chi=0, & k^{\prime 2}=k^{2}\left(1+\frac{V_{0}}{E}\right), & r<a, \\
\chi^{\prime \prime}+k^{2} \chi=0, & k^{2}=\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}, & r>a .
\end{array}
$$

The solutions are

$$
\chi= \begin{cases}\sin \left(k^{\prime} r\right) & r<a, \\ A \sin \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right), & r>a\end{cases}
$$

The continuity condition

$$
\left.(\ln \chi)^{\prime}\right|_{r=a^{-}}=\left.(\ln \chi)^{\prime}\right|_{r=a^{+}}
$$

gives an equation for determining $\delta_{0}$ :

$$
k^{\prime} \tan \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right)=k \tan \left(k^{\prime} a\right) .
$$

As

$$
k^{\prime 2}=k^{2}\left(1+\frac{V_{0}}{E}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad k^{2}=\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}},
$$

when $k \rightarrow \infty, k^{\prime} \rightarrow k$. Hence

$$
\delta_{0}=\arctan \left[\frac{k}{k^{\prime}} \tan \left(k^{\prime} a\right)\right]-k a \rightarrow\left(k^{\prime}-k\right) a \quad \text { as } \quad k \rightarrow \infty .
$$

Thus, letting $k \rightarrow \infty$ we obtain

$$
\delta_{0} \rightarrow\left(\frac{k^{2}-k^{2}}{k^{\prime}+k}\right) a \approx \frac{k V_{0}}{2 E} a=\frac{m a V_{0}}{\hbar^{2} k} .
$$

The Born approximation expression for the phase shift for $l=0$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta_{0} & \approx-\frac{2 m k}{\hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} V(r) j_{0}^{2}(k r) r^{2} d r=\frac{2 m k V_{0}}{\hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{a} \frac{\sin ^{2} k r}{k^{2}} d r \\
&=\frac{m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}\left[k a-\frac{1}{2} \sin (2 k a)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

whence

$$
\delta_{0} \rightarrow \frac{m V_{0} a}{\hbar^{2} k}
$$

as $k \rightarrow \infty$, in agreement with the partial-wave calculation.

\section{3}

Calculate the scattering cross section for a low energy particle from a potential given by $V=-V_{0}$ for $r<a, V=0$ for $r>a$. Compare this with the Born approximation result.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

The radial Schrödinger equation can be written in the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\chi_{l}^{\prime \prime}(r)+\left[k^{2}-\frac{l(l+1)}{r^{2}}\right] \chi_{l}(r)=0, \quad r>a, \\
&\chi_{l}^{\prime \prime}(r)+\left[k^{2}-\frac{l(l+1)}{r^{2}}\right] \chi_{l}(r)=0, \quad r<a,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\chi=r R(r)$

$$
k^{2}=\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}, \quad k^{2}=\frac{2 m\left(E+V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}} .
$$

Scattering at low energies is dominated by the $s$ partial wave, for which $\ell=0$, and the above become

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\chi_{l}^{\prime \prime}(r)+k^{2} \chi_{l}(r)=0, & r>a, \\
\chi_{l}^{\prime \prime}(r)+k^{2} \chi_{l}(r)=0, & r<a,
\end{array}
$$

whose solutions are

$$
\chi_{l}(r)= \begin{cases}A \sin \left(k^{\prime} r\right), & r<a, \\ \sin \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right), & r>a .\end{cases}
$$

The continuity condition $\left.\left(\ln \chi_{l}\right)^{\prime}\right|_{r=a^{-}}=\left.\left(\ln \chi_{l}\right)^{\prime}\right|_{r=a^{+}}$gives

$$
k \tan \left(k^{\prime} a\right)=k^{\prime} \tan \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right),
$$

or

$$
\delta_{0}=\arctan \left[\frac{k}{k^{\prime}} \tan \left(k^{\prime} a\right)\right]-k a .
$$

For low energies

$$
k \rightarrow 0, k^{\prime} \rightarrow k_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2}}}
$$

and the above becomes

$$
\delta_{0} \approx k a\left[\frac{\tan \left(k_{0} a\right)}{k_{0} a}-1\right] .
$$

The total scattering cross section is then

$$
\sigma \approx \frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{0} \approx \frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \delta_{0}^{2}=4 \pi a^{2}\left[\frac{\tan \left(k_{0} a\right)}{k_{0} a}-1\right]^{2} .
$$

If $k_{0} a \ll 1$

$$
\sigma \approx 4 \pi a^{2}\left[\frac{k_{0} a}{k_{0} a}+\frac{\left(k_{0} a\right)^{3}}{3 k_{0} a}-1\right]^{2}=\frac{16 \pi a^{6} m^{2} V_{0}^{2}}{9 \hbar^{4}} .
$$

In the Born approximation,

$$
f(\theta)=-\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \int e^{-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}} V(r) e^{i \mathbf{k}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{r}} d^{3} r
$$

where $\mathbf{k}^{\prime}, \mathbf{k}$ are respectively the wave vectors of the incident and scattered waves. Let $\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{k}-\mathbf{k}^{\prime}$, with $\left|\mathbf{k}^{\prime}\right|=|\mathbf{k}|=k$ for elastic scattering. Then $q=2 k \sin \frac{\theta}{2}$, where $\theta$ is the scattering angle. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta) &=-\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} V(r) r^{2} d r \int_{0}^{\pi} e^{-i q r \cos \theta^{\prime}} 2 \pi \sin \theta^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} \\
&=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} V(r) \frac{\sin (q r)}{q r} r^{2} d r=\frac{2 m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{0}^{a} r \sin (q r) d r \\
&=\frac{2 m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2} q^{3}}[\sin (q a)-q a \cos (q a)] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\sigma(\theta)=|f(\theta)|^{2}=\frac{4 m^{2} V_{0}^{2}}{\hbar^{4} q^{6}}[\sin (q a)-q a \cos (q a)]^{2}
$$

For low energies $k \rightarrow 0, q \rightarrow 0$

$$
\sin (q a) \approx q a-\frac{1}{3 !}(q a)^{3}, \quad \cos (q a) \approx 1-\frac{1}{2 !}(q a)^{2}
$$

and hence

$$
\sigma(\theta) \approx \frac{4 m^{2} V_{0}^{2} a^{6}}{9 \hbar^{4}} .
$$

The total cross section for scattering at low energies is then

$$
\sigma=\int \sigma(\theta) d \Omega=\frac{16 \pi m^{2} V_{0}^{2} a^{6}}{9 \hbar^{4}} .
$$

Therefore at low energies for which $k \rightarrow 0, k a \ll 1$, the two methods give the same result.

\section{4}

In scattering from a potential $V(r)$, the wave function may be written as an incident plane wave plus an outgoing scattered wave: $\psi=e^{i k z}+v(r)$. Derive a differential equation for $v(r)$ in the first Born approximation.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Two methods may be used for this problem.

\section{Method 1:}

For a particle of mass $m$ in a central field $V(r)$, the Schrödinger equation can be written as

$$
\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) \psi=U \psi
$$

where

$$
U=\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} V, \quad k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} .
$$

Define Green's function $G\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)$ by

$$
\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) G\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)=-4 \pi \delta\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) .
$$

This is satisfied by the function

$$
G\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{\exp \left(i k\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|}
$$

and the Schrödinger equation is satisfied by

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r})=\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r})-\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int G\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) U\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) \psi\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) d^{3} \mathbf{r}^{\prime}
$$

As the incident wave is a plane wave $e^{i k z^{\prime}}$, we replace $U\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) \psi\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)$ by $U\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) e^{i k z^{\prime}}$ in the first Born approximation:

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r})=e^{i k z}-\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int \frac{\exp \left(i k\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} U\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) e^{i k z^{\prime}} d^{3} \mathbf{r}^{\prime}
$$

Hence the scattered wave is

$$
v(r)=-\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int \frac{\exp \left(i k\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} U\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) e^{i k z^{\prime}} d^{3} \mathbf{r}^{\prime} .
$$

Applying the operator $\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right)$ to the two sides of the equation, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) \mathbf{v}(r) &=-\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) \frac{\exp \left(i k\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} U\left(r^{\prime}\right) e^{i k z^{\prime}} d^{3} r^{\prime} \\
&=\int \delta\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) U\left(r^{\prime}\right) e^{i k z^{\prime}} d^{3} r^{\prime}=U(r) e^{i k z}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the differential equation for $v(r)$ is

$$
\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) v(r)=U(r) e^{i k z}
$$

\section{Method 2:}

Writing the radial Schrödinger equation as

$$
\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) \psi=U \psi
$$

where

$$
k^{2}=\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}, U=\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} V,
$$

and substituting in $\psi=e^{i k z}+v(r)$, we get

$$
\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) e^{i k z}+\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) v(r)=U\left[e^{i k z}+v(r)\right]
$$

or

$$
\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) v(r)=\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} V\left[e^{i k z}+v(r)\right]
$$

as $\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) e^{i k z}=0$. In the first Born approximation, $e^{i k z}+v(r) \approx e^{i k z}$, and so the differential equation for $v(r)$ is

$$
\left(\nabla^{2}+k^{2}\right) v(r) \approx \frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} V e^{i k z} .
$$

\section{5}

In the quantum theory of scattering from a fixed potential, we get the following expression for the asymptotic form of the wave function

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}) \underset{r \rightarrow \infty}{\longrightarrow} e^{i k z}+f(\theta, \varphi) \frac{e^{i k r}}{r}
$$

(a) If the entire Hamiltonian is rotationally invariant, give the argument that the scattering amplitude $f$ should be independent of the angle $\varphi$.

(b) Why cannot this argument be extended (considering rotation about any axis) to conclude that $f$ should be independent of $\theta$ as well?

(c) Reconsider part(b) in the case where the incident energy approaches zero.

(d) What is the formula for the scattering cross section in terms of $f$ ?

(e) What is the formula for the first Born approximation for $f$ ? $(\mathrm{Be}$ sure to define all quantities introduced. You need not worry about simple dimensionless factors like 2 or $\pi)$.

(f) Under what conditions is the Born approximation valid?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The incident wave $e^{i k z}=e^{i k r \cos \theta}$ is the eigenstate of $\hat{l}_{z}$, third component of the angular momentum $\mathbf{L}$, with eigenvalue $m=0$. If the Hamiltonian is rotationally invariant, the angular momentum is conserved and the outgoing wave is still the eigenstate of $\hat{l}_{z}$ with eigenvalue $m=0$, that is,

$$
\hat{l}_{z} f(\theta, \varphi)=m f(\theta, \varphi)=0 .
$$

Since $\hat{l}_{z}=\frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{\partial}{\partial \varphi}$, this means that $\partial f(\theta, \varphi) / \partial \varphi=0$.

(b) As the asymptotic form of the wave function $\psi(\mathbf{r})$ is not an eigenfunction of $\hat{L}^{2}$, we cannot extend the above argument to conclude that $f$ is independent of $\theta$.

(c) When the energy $E \rightarrow 0$, i.e., $k \rightarrow 0$, the incident wave consists mainly only of the $l=0$ partial wave; other partial waves have very small amplitudes and can be neglected. Under such conditions, the rotational invariance of $H$ results in the conservation of $\hat{L}^{2}$. Then the outgoing wave must also be the eigenstate of $\hat{L}^{2}$ with eigenvalue $l=0$ (approximately). As

$$
\hat{L}^{2}=-\hbar^{2}\left[\frac{1}{\sin \theta} \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\left(\sin \theta \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\right)+\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \theta} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \varphi^{2}}\right]
$$

we have

$$
\frac{1}{\sin \theta} \frac{d}{d \theta}\left[\sin \theta \frac{d f(\theta)}{d \theta}\right]=0 .
$$

As $f(\theta)$ must be a wave function with all the appropriate properties, this means

$$
d f(\theta) / d \theta=0 .
$$

(d) The differential scattering cross section is given by

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=|f(\theta, \varphi)|^{2} .
$$

(e) In the first Born approximation, for scattering from a central field $V\left(r^{\prime}\right), f$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta, \varphi) &=-\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \int V\left(r^{\prime}\right) \exp \left(-i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) d^{3} r^{\prime} \\
&=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{0}^{\infty} r^{\prime} V\left(r^{\prime}\right) \sin \left(q r^{\prime}\right) d r^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{k}-\mathbf{k}_{\mathbf{0}}, \mathbf{k}$ and $\mathbf{k}_{0}$ being respectively the momenta of the particle before and after scattering. (f) The validity of Born approximation requires that the interaction potential is small compared with the energy of the incident particle.

\section{6}

Consider a particle of mass $m$ which scatters off a potential $V(x)$ in one dimension.

(a) Show that

$$
G_{E}(x)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d k \frac{e^{i k x}}{E-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}+i \varepsilon}
$$

with $\varepsilon$ positive infinitesimal, is the free-particle Green's function for the time-independent Schrödinger equation with energy $E$ and outgoing-wave boundary conditions.

(b) Write down an integral equation for the energy eigenfunction corresponding to an incident wave traveling in the positive $x$ direction. Using this equation find the reflection probability in the first Born approximation for the potential

$$
V(x)= \begin{cases}V_{0}, & |x|<a / 2 \\ 0, & |x|>a / 2\end{cases}
$$

For what values of $E$ do you expect this to be a good approximation? (Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) To solve the one-dimensional time-independent Schrödinger equation

we define a Green's function $G_{E}(x)$ by

$$
\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+E\right) \psi=V \psi,
$$

$$
\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+E\right) G_{E}(x)=\delta(x) .
$$

Expressing $G_{E}(x)$ and $\delta(x)$ as Fourier integrals

$$
\begin{aligned}
G_{E}(x) &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(k) e^{i k x} d k \\
\delta(x) &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{i k x} d k
\end{aligned}
$$

and substituting these into the equation for $G_{E}(x)$, we obtain

$$
\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}+E\right) f(k)=1,
$$

or

$$
f(k)=\frac{1}{E-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}} .
$$

As the singularity of $f(k)$ is on the path of integration and the Fourier integral can be understood as an integral in the complex $k$-plane, we can add $i \varepsilon$, where $\varepsilon$ is a small positive number, to the denominator of $f(k)$. We can then let $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$ after the integration. Consider

$$
G_{E}(k)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d k \frac{e^{i k x}}{E-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}+i \varepsilon}
$$

The intergral is singular where

$$
(E+i \varepsilon)-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}=0,
$$

i.e., at

$$
k=\pm k_{1},
$$

where

$$
k_{1}=\frac{\sqrt{2 m(E+i \varepsilon)}}{\hbar} .
$$

When $x>0$, the integral becomes a contour integral on the upper half-plane with a singularity at $k_{1}$ with residue

$$
a_{1}=-\frac{m e^{i k_{1} z}}{\pi \hbar^{2} k_{1}} .
$$

Cauchy's integral formula then gives

$$
G_{E}(x)=2 \pi i a_{1}=-i \frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k_{1}} e^{i k_{1} x} \quad(x>0) .
$$

As

$$
\varepsilon \rightarrow 0, \quad k_{1} \rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{2 m E}}{\hbar} .
$$

This is the value of $k_{1}$ to be used in the expression for $G_{E}(x)$. Similarly, when $x<0$, we can carry out the integration along a contour on the lower half-plane and get

$$
G_{E}(x)=-i \frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k_{1}} e^{-i k_{1} x} \quad(x<0) .
$$

Here $k_{1}=\frac{\sqrt{2 m E}}{\hbar}$ also. Thus the free-particle Green's function $G_{E}(x)$ represents the outgoing wave whether $x>0$ or $x<0$.

(b) The solution of the stationary Schrödinger equation satisfies the integral equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{E}(x) &=\psi^{0}(\mathbf{x})+G_{E}(x) *\left[V(x) \psi_{E}(x)\right] \\
&=\psi^{0}(x)+\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} G_{E}(x-\xi) V(\xi) \psi_{E}(\xi) d \xi,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\psi^{0}(x)$ is a solution of the equation

$$
\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+E\right) \psi(x)=0 \text {. }
$$

In the first-order Born approximation we replace $\psi_{0}$ and $\psi_{E}$ on the right side of the integral equation by the incident wave function and get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{E}(x)=& e^{i k x}+\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} G_{E}(x-\xi) V(\xi) e^{i k \xi} d \xi=e^{i k x} \\
&+\int_{-\infty}^{x}(-i) \frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k} e^{i k(x-\xi)} V(\xi) e^{i k \xi} d \xi \\
&+\int_{x}^{\infty}(-i) \frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k} e^{-i k(x-\xi)} V(\xi) e^{i k \xi} d \xi
\end{aligned}
$$

For reflection we require $\psi_{E}(x)$ for $x \rightarrow-\infty$. For $x \rightarrow-\infty$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty}^{x}(-i) \frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k} e^{i k(x-\xi)} V(\xi) e^{i k \xi} d \xi=0 \\
\int_{x}^{\infty}(-i) \frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k} e^{-i k x} e^{2 i k \xi} V(\xi) d \xi &=\int_{-a / 2}^{a / 2}(-i) \frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k} e^{-i k x} V_{0} e^{2 i k \xi} d \xi \\
&=-i \frac{m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2} k^{2}} \sin (k a) e^{-i k x}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the reflection probability is

$$
R=\left|\psi_{E}(-\infty)\right|^{2} /\left|\psi_{0}\right|^{2}=\frac{m^{2} V_{0}^{2}}{\hbar^{4} k^{4}} \sin ^{2} k a
$$

When the energy is high,

$$
\left|\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} G_{E}(x-\xi) V(\xi) e^{i k \xi} d \xi\right| \ll\left|e^{i k x}\right|
$$

and replacing $\psi(x)$ by $e^{i k x}$ is a good approximation.

\section{7}

Calculate the Born approximation to the differential and total cross sections for scattering a particle of mass $m$ off the $\delta$-function potential $V(\mathbf{r})=g \delta^{3}(\mathbf{r})$

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

In Born approximation,

$$
f(\theta)=-\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \int e^{-\mathbf{k}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}} V\left(r^{\prime}\right) e^{i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}} d \mathbf{r}^{\prime}
$$

where $\mathbf{k}$ and $\mathbf{k}^{\prime}$ are respectively the wave vectors of the incident and scattered waves. Let $\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{k}^{\prime}-\mathbf{k}$. Then

$$
f(\theta)=-\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} g \int \exp \left(-i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) \delta\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) d \mathbf{r}^{\prime}=\frac{m g}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \exp (-i 0 q)=\frac{m g}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}}
$$

and the differential cross section is

$$
\sigma(\theta)=|f(\theta)|^{2}=\frac{m^{2} g^{2}}{4 \pi^{2} \hbar^{4}} .
$$

As the distribution is isotropic, the total cross section is

$$
\sigma_{t}=4 \pi \sigma=\frac{m^{2} g^{2}}{\pi \hbar^{4}} .
$$



\section{8}

Consider a particle of mass $m$, energy $E$ scattering from the spherically symmetric potential $B \delta(r-a)$, where $B$ and $a$ are constants.

(a) In the case of very high energy (but nonrelativistic) scattering, use the Born approximation to calculate the differential scattering cross section.

(b) In the case of very low energy scattering $(\lambda>a)$, what is the differential scattering cross section?

Note: In part (b) you may find the algebra somewhat lengthy. In this case, work the problem far enough that the remainder of the solution involves only straightforward algebra.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As shown in Problem 6013,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f &=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} r^{2} \frac{\sin q r}{q r} B \delta(r-a) d r \\
&=-\frac{2 m \sin q a}{\hbar^{2} q} B a
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the differential cross section for scattering is

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=|f|^{2}=\left(\frac{2 m \sin q a}{\hbar^{2} q} B a\right)^{2}
$$

(b) At low energies only the partial wave with $l=0$ is important. If we set the radial wave function $R(x)=\chi(r) / r$, then $\chi(r)$ will satisfy

$$
\chi^{\prime \prime}+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}[E-B \delta(r-a)] \chi=0 .
$$

The solutions are

$$
\begin{cases}\chi=A \sin (k r), & r<a \\ \chi=\sin \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right), & r>a\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}
$$

The continuity of $\chi(r)$ at $r=a$ requires

$$
\chi(a+0)=\chi(a-0) .
$$

Integrating the wave equation for $\chi$ from $a-\varepsilon$ to $a+\varepsilon$, where $\varepsilon$ is a small positive number, and then letting $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$, we get

$$
\chi^{\prime}(a+0)-\chi^{\prime}(a-0)-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} B \chi(a)=0 \text {. }
$$

These two conditions give

$$
\frac{k}{\tan \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right)}=\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} B+\frac{k}{\tan (k a)} .
$$

As $E \rightarrow 0, k \rightarrow 0$ and

$$
\tan (k a) \rightarrow k a, \tan \left(k a+\delta_{0}\right)=\frac{\tan (k a)+\tan \delta_{0}}{1-\tan (k a) \tan \delta_{0}} \rightarrow \frac{k a+\delta_{0}}{1-k a \delta_{0}} .
$$

Substituting the above gives

$$
\delta_{0} \approx \frac{k}{\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} B+\frac{1}{a}}
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=\frac{1}{k^{2}}\left|e^{i \delta_{0}} \sin \delta_{0}\right|^{2} \approx\left(\frac{1}{\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} B+\frac{1}{a}}\right)^{2} .
$$

As there is no angular dependence the scattering is isotropic.

\section{9}

A nucleon is scattered elastically from a heavy nucleus. The effect of the heavy nucleus can be represented by a fixed potential

$$
V(r)= \begin{cases}-V_{0} & r<R, \\ 0, & r>R,\end{cases}
$$

where $V_{0}$ is a positive constant. Calculate the deferential cross section to the lowest order in $V_{0}$. 

\section{Solution:}

Let $\mu$ be the reduced moves of the nucleon and the nucleus, $\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{k}-\mathbf{k}^{\prime}$ where $\mathbf{k}^{\prime}, \mathbf{k}$ are respectively the wave vectors of the nucleon before and after the scattering. In the Born approximation, as in Problem 6013, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma(\theta) &=|f(\theta)|^{2}=\frac{4 \mu^{2}}{\hbar^{4} q^{2}}\left|\int_{0}^{\infty} r^{\prime} V\left(r^{\prime}\right) \sin q r^{\prime} d r^{\prime}\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{4 \mu^{2} V_{0}^{2}}{\hbar^{4} q^{6}}(\sin q R-q R \cos q R)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $q=2 k \sin (\theta / 2), k=|\mathbf{k}|=\left|\mathbf{k}^{\prime}\right|$.

\section{0}

A particle of mass $m$, charge $e$, momentum $p$ scatters in the electrostatic potential produced by a spherically symmetric distribution of charge. You are given the quantity $\int r^{2} \rho d^{3} x=A, \rho(r) d^{3} x$ being the charge in a volume element $d^{3} x$. Supposing that $\rho$ vanishes rapidly as $r \rightarrow \infty$ and that $\int \rho d^{3} x=0$; working in the first Born approximation, compute the differential cross section for forward scattering. (That is $\left.\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}\right|_{\theta=0}$, where $\theta$ is the scattering angle.)

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

In the first Born approximation, we have

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=\frac{m^{2} e^{2}}{4 \pi^{2} \hbar^{4}}\left|\int U(r) \exp (i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}) d^{3} x\right|^{2}
$$

where

$$
\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{k}-\mathbf{k}^{\prime}, q=2 k \sin \frac{\theta}{2}=\frac{2 p}{\hbar} \sin \frac{\theta}{2}, \mathbf{k}^{\prime} \text { and } \mathbf{k}
$$

being the wave vectors of the particle before and after the scattering, $U(r)$ is the electrostatic Coulomb potential and satisfies the Poission equation

$$
\nabla^{2} U=-4 \pi \rho(r) .
$$

Let

$$
F(q)=\int \rho(r) \exp (i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}) d^{3} x
$$

where $F(q)$ is the Fourier transform of $\rho(r)$. Using the Poisson equation we have

Hence

$$
\int U(r) \exp (i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}) d^{3} x=\frac{2 \pi}{q^{2}} F(q)
$$

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=\frac{m^{2} e^{2}}{4 \pi^{2} \hbar^{4}} \cdot \frac{(4 \pi)^{2}}{q^{4}}|F(q)|^{2}=\frac{4 m^{2} e^{2}}{\hbar^{4} q^{4}}|F(q)|^{2} .
$$

For forward scattering, $\theta$ is small and so $q$ is small also. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
F(q) &=\int \rho(r) \exp (i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}) d^{3} x \\
&=\int \rho(r)\left[1+i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}+\frac{1}{2 !}(i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r})^{2}+\cdots\right] d^{3} x \\
&=\int \rho(r) d^{3} \mathbf{x}-\frac{1}{2 !} \int \rho(r)(\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r})^{2} d^{3} x+\cdots \\
& \approx-\frac{1}{6} q^{2} \int \rho(r) r^{2} d^{3} x=-\frac{A q^{2}}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

since as $\int \rho d^{3} x=0, \int_{0}^{\pi} \cos ^{2 n+1} \theta \cdot \sin \theta d \theta=0$, the lowest order term for $\theta \rightarrow 0$ is

$$
\frac{1}{2 !} \int \rho(r)(i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r})^{2} d^{3} x \approx-\frac{q^{2}}{6} \int \rho(r) r^{2} d^{3} x .
$$

Hence

$$
\left.\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}\right|_{\theta=0}=\frac{A^{2} m^{2} e^{2}}{9 \hbar^{4}} .
$$

\section{1}

Use Born approximation to find, up to a multiplicative constant, the differential scattering cross section for a particle of mass $m$ moving in a repulsive potential

$$
V=A e^{-r^{2} / a^{2}} .
$$

\section{Solution:}

In Born approximation we have (Problem 6013)

$$
f(\theta)=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{0}^{\infty} r V(r) \sin (q r) d r
$$

where $q=2 k \sin (\theta / 2), \hbar k$ being the momentum of incident particle. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta)=&-\frac{2 m A}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{0}^{\infty} r e^{-r^{2} / a^{2}} \sin (q r) d r=-\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} r e^{-r^{2} / a^{2}} \sin (q r) d r \\
=& \frac{m A a^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2} q} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(e^{-r^{2} / a^{2}}\right)^{\prime} \sin (q r) d r=-\frac{m A a^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-r^{2} / a^{2}} \cos (q r) d r \\
=&-\frac{m A a^{3}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-(r / a)^{2}} \cos \left(q a \frac{r}{a}\right) d\left(\frac{r}{a}\right) \\
=&-\frac{m A a^{3}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-r^{2}} \cos (q a r) d r \\
=&-\frac{m A a^{3}}{4 \hbar^{2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left\{\exp \left[-\left(r-\frac{i q a}{2}\right)^{2}\right]\right.\\
&\left.+\exp \left[-\left(r+\frac{i q a}{2}\right)^{2}\right]\right\} e^{-q^{2} a^{2} / 4} d r \\
=&-\frac{m A a^{3}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \sqrt{\pi} e^{-q^{2} a^{2} / 4}, \\
\sigma(\theta)=|f(\theta)|^{2}=\frac{m^{2} A^{2} a^{6}}{4 \hbar^{4}} \pi e^{-q^{2} a^{2} / 2} \\
&=
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{2}

A nonrelativistic particle is scattered by a square-well potential

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-515.jpg?height=128&width=548&top_left_y=1313&top_left_x=392)

(a) Assuming the bombarding energy is sufficiently high, calculate the scattering cross section in the first Born approximation (normalization is not essential), and sketch the shape of the angular distribution, indicating angular units.

(b) How can this result be used to measure $R$ ?

(c) Assuming the validity of the Born approximation, if the particle is a proton and $R=5 \times 10^{-13} \mathrm{~cm}$, roughly how high must the energy be in order for the scattering to be sensitive to $R$ ? 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Using Born approximation we have (Problem 6013)

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta) & \propto \frac{-1}{q} \int_{0}^{\infty} r V(r) \sin (q r) d r \\
&=\frac{V_{0}}{q} \int_{0}^{R} r \sin (q r) d r=\frac{V_{0}}{q^{3}}(\sin q R-q R \cos q R) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega} \propto\left(\frac{\sin x-x \cos x}{x^{3}}\right)^{2}
$$

where $x=q R=2 k R \sin \frac{\theta}{2}$.

The angular distribution is shown in Fig. $6.4$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-516.jpg?height=408&width=494&top_left_y=884&top_left_x=412)

Fig. $6.4$

(b) The first zero of $\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}$ occurs at $x$ for which $x=\tan x$, whose solution is $x \approx 1.43 \pi$. This gives

$$
R=\frac{1.43 \pi}{2 k \sin \frac{\theta_{1}}{2}} .
$$
mined.

By measuring the minimum angle $\theta_{1}$ for which $\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=0, R$ can be deter-

(c) In order that $R$ may be determined from the zero points of $\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}$, we require that the maximum value of $x, 2 k R$, is larger than $1.43 \pi$, or 

$$
\begin{aligned}
E \geq \frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m_{p}}\left(\frac{1.43 \pi}{2 R}\right)^{2} &=\frac{(1.43 \pi)^{2}}{8} \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m_{p} c^{2}}\left(\frac{c}{R}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{(1.43 \pi)^{2}}{8} \times \frac{\left(6.58 \times 10^{-22}\right)^{2}}{938} \times\left(\frac{3 \times 10^{10}}{5 \times 10^{-13}}\right)^{2} \\
&=4.2 \mathrm{MeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{3}

Elastic scattering from some central potential $V$ may be adequately calculated using the first Born approximation. Experimental results give the following general behavior of the cross section as a function of momentum transfer $q=\left|\mathbf{k}-\mathbf{k}^{\prime}\right|$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-517.jpg?height=276&width=431&top_left_y=846&top_left_x=459)

Fig. $6.6$

In terms of the parameters shown in Fig. 6.6:

(a) What is the approximate size (extension in space) of the potential $V$ ? (Hint: Expand the Born approximation for the scattering amplitude for small q.)

(b) What is the behavior of the potential $V$ at very small distances?

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Born approximation gives (Problem 6013)

$$
f(\theta)=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2} q} \int r V(r) \sin (q r) d r,
$$

where $q \hbar$ is the magnitude of the momentum transfer and $q=2 k \sin \frac{\theta}{2}$. For $q \rightarrow 0$ 

$$
f(0) \approx-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{R} r^{2} V(r) d r \approx-\frac{2 m}{3 \hbar^{2}} R^{3} \bar{V}
$$

replacing $V$ by $\bar{V}$, some average value of the potential in the effective force range $R$. For a small momentum transfer $q_{0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f\left(q_{0}\right) & \approx-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2} q_{0}} \int r V(r)\left(q_{0} r-\frac{1}{6} q_{0}^{3} r^{3}\right) d r \\
& \approx f(0)+\frac{m q_{0}^{2}}{15 \hbar^{2}} R^{5} \bar{V}=f(0)-\frac{q_{0}^{2}}{10} R^{2} f(0)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus an approximate value of $R$ is given by

$$
R=\sqrt{\frac{10}{q_{0}^{2}|f(0)|}\left(|f(0)|-\left|f\left(q_{0}\right)\right|\right)} .
$$

Note that $\left|f\left(q_{0}\right)\right|^{2}$ is the measured value of $\left.\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}\right|_{q_{0}}$ for some small $q_{0}$, $|f(0)|^{2}$ is the value of $\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}$ for a set of small $q_{0}$ extrapolated to $q=0$. From these values the effective range of the potential can be estimated.

(b) In view of the behavior of the scattering cross section for large $q$, we can say that the Born integral consists mainly of contributions from the region $q r \leq \pi$, outside which, on account of the oscillation between the limits $\pm 1$ of the sine function, the contributions of the integrand are nearly zero. Thus we need only consider the integral from $q r=0$ to $\pi$. Assuming $V(r) \sim r^{n}$ for small $r$, where $n$ is to be determined, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta) &=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} \int r^{2} V(r) \frac{\sin (q r)}{q r} d r \\
& \simeq-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{\pi}(q r)^{2} V(q r) \frac{\sin (q r)}{q r} q^{-(3+n)} d(q r) \\
&=\frac{1}{q^{3+n}}\left(-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{\pi} x^{2} V(\mathbf{x}) \frac{\sin x}{x} d x\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

A comparison with the given data gives $\frac{N}{2}=3+n$. Hence $\bar{V}$ behaves like $r^{\left(\frac{N}{2}-3\right)}$.

\section{4}

A convenient model for the potential energy $V$ of a particle of charge $q$ scattering on an atom of nuclear charge $Q$ is $V=\frac{q Q}{r} e^{-\alpha r}$, where $\alpha^{-1}$ represents the screening length of the atomic electrons. (a) Use the Born approximation

$$
f=-\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int e^{-i \Delta \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}} \frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} V(\mathbf{r}) d^{3} \mathbf{r}
$$

to calculate the scattering cross section $\sigma$.

(b) How should $\alpha$ depend on the nuclear charge $Z$ ?

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

For the elastic scattering, $|\mathbf{k}|=\left|\mathbf{k}_{0}\right|=k$, and $|\Delta \mathbf{k}|=\left|\mathbf{k}-\mathbf{k}_{0}\right|=2 k \sin \frac{\theta}{2}$, $\theta$ being the scattering angle. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
f &=-\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int e^{-i \Delta \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}} \frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} V(r) d^{3} \mathbf{r} \\
&=-\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} r^{2} d r \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \varphi \int_{0}^{\pi} e^{-i \Delta k r \cos \theta^{\prime}} V(r) \sin \theta^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} \\
&=-\frac{2 m q Q}{\Delta k \hbar^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\alpha r} \sin (\Delta k r) d r \\
&=-\frac{2 m q Q}{\hbar^{2}} \frac{1}{\left(\alpha^{2}+\Delta k^{2}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Therefore}

$$
\sigma=|f(\theta)|^{2}=\frac{4 m^{2} q^{2} Q^{2}}{\hbar^{4}\left[\alpha^{2}+4 k^{2} \sin ^{2}(\theta / 2)\right]^{2}} .
$$

(b) In the Thomas-Fermi approximation, when $Z$ is large, the atomic electrons can be regarded as a Fermi gas. As such an electron is in a bound state in the atom; its energy is lower than $E(\infty)=0$. Then its maximum possible momentum $p_{\max }$ at $r$ must satisfy

$$
\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\max }^{2}(r)-e \phi(r)=0,
$$

where $\phi(r)$ is the potential at distance $r$ from the nucleus, since its energy is negative. Thus the Fermi momentum at $r$ is

$$
p_{f}(r)=p_{\max }(r)=[2 m e \phi(r)]^{1 / 2} .
$$

For a Fermi gas,

$$
p_{f}=\hbar\left(3 \pi^{2} n\right)^{1 / 3},
$$

where $n$ is the number density. Comparing the above expressions we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
n(r) &=\frac{1}{3 \pi^{2} \hbar^{3}}[2 m e \phi(r)]^{3 / 2} \\
&=\frac{1}{3 \pi^{2} \hbar^{3}}\left(2 m e \frac{Z e}{r} e^{-\alpha r}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $Z e$ is the nuclear charge. As the atom is neutral,

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z &=\int n d^{3} \mathbf{r}=4 \pi \int_{0}^{\infty} n(r) r^{2} d r \\
&=\frac{4}{3 \pi \hbar^{3}}\left(2 m Z e^{2}\right)^{3 / 2} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\frac{3}{2} \alpha r} r^{1 / 2} d r \\
&=\frac{2}{3 \sqrt{\pi} \hbar^{3}}\left(\frac{4 m Z e^{2}}{3 \alpha}\right)^{3 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Hence}

$$
\alpha=\frac{4 m e^{2}}{3 \hbar^{2}}\left(\frac{4}{9 \pi}\right)^{1 / 3} Z^{1 / 3}=\frac{4}{3}\left(\frac{4}{9 \pi}\right)^{1 / 3} \frac{1}{a_{0}} Z^{1 / 3}
$$

where $a_{0}=\hbar^{2} / m e^{2}$ is the Bohr radius.

\section{5}

A particle of mass $m$ is scattered by a potential $V(\mathbf{r})=V_{0} \exp (-r / a)$.

(a) Find the differential scattering cross section in the first Born approximation. Sketch the angular dependence for small and large $k$, where $k$ is the wave number of the particle being scattered. At what $k$ value does the scattering begin to be significantly non-isotropic? Compare this value with the one given by elementary arguments based on angular momentum.

(b) The criterion for the validity of the Born approximation is

$$
\left|\Delta \psi^{(1)}(0) / \psi^{(0)}(0)\right| \ll 1
$$

where $\Delta \psi^{(1)}$ is the first order correction to the incident plane wave $\psi^{(0)}$. Evaluate this criterion explicitly for the present potential. What is the low$k$ limit of your result? Relate it to the strength of the attractive potential required for the existence of bound states (see the statement of problem). Is the high- $k$ limit of the criterion less or more restrictive on the strength of the potential?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The first Born approximation gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta) &=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{0}^{\infty} r^{\prime} V\left(r^{\prime}\right) \sin \left(q r^{\prime}\right) d r^{\prime} \\
&=-\frac{2 m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{0}^{\infty} r^{\prime} \sin \left(q r^{\prime}\right) \exp \left(-r^{\prime} / a\right) d r^{\prime} \\
&=-\frac{4 m V_{0} a^{3}}{\hbar^{2}\left(1+q^{2} a^{2}\right)^{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $q=2 k \sin (\theta / 2), q \hbar$ being the magnitude of the momentum transfer in the scattering. Hence

$$
\sigma(\theta)=|f(\theta)|^{2}=\frac{16 m^{2} V_{0}^{2} a^{6}}{\hbar^{4}\left(1+4 k^{2} a^{2} \sin ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}\right)^{4}} .
$$

The angular distribution $\sigma(\theta) / \sigma(0)$ is plotted in Fig. $6.5$ for $k a=0$ and $k a=1$.

It can be seen that for $k a \gtrsim 1$, the scattering is significantly nonisotropic. The angular momentum at which only $s$-wave scattering, which is isotropic, is important must satisfy

$$
a \cdot k \hbar \leq \hbar, \quad \text { i.e., } \quad k a \leq 1 .
$$

When $k a \sim 1$, the scattering begins to be significantly non-isotropic. This is in agreement with the result given by the first Born approximation.

(b) The wave function to the first order is

$$
\psi(r)=e^{i k z}-\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int \frac{e^{i k\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|}}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} \frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} V\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) e^{i k z^{\prime}} d V^{\prime}
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-522.jpg?height=632&width=705&top_left_y=161&top_left_x=304)

Fig. $6.5$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\frac{\Delta \psi^{(1)}(0)}{\psi^{(0)}(0)}\right| &=\left|\frac{V_{0}}{4 \pi} \int \frac{e^{i k r^{\prime}}}{r^{\prime}} \frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} e^{-r^{\prime} / a+i k z^{\prime}} d V^{\prime}\right| \\
&=\left|\frac{m V_{0}}{\hbar^{2}} \int r^{\prime} e^{i k r^{\prime}-r^{\prime} / a+i k r^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}} \sin \theta^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} d r^{\prime}\right| \\
&=\frac{2 m\left|V_{0}\right| a^{2} \sqrt{1+4 k^{2} a^{2}}}{\hbar^{2}\left(4 k^{2} a^{2}+1\right)}=\frac{2 m\left|V_{0}\right| a^{2}}{\hbar^{2} \sqrt{1+4 k^{2} a^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The criterion for the validity of the first Born approximation is then

$$
\frac{2 m\left|V_{0}\right| a^{2}}{\hbar^{2} \sqrt{1+4 k^{2} a^{2}}} \ll 1 .
$$

In the low- $k$ limit, $k a \ll 1$, the above becomes

$$
\frac{2 m\left|V_{0}\right| a^{2}}{\hbar^{2}} \ll 1, \quad \text { or } \quad\left|V_{0}\right| \ll \frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m a^{2}} .
$$

In the high- $k$ limit, $k a \gg 1$, the criterion becomes

$$
\frac{m\left|V_{0}\right| a}{\hbar^{2} k} \ll 1, \quad \text { or } \quad\left|V_{0}\right| \ll \frac{\hbar^{2} k}{m a} .
$$


limit.

Since in this case $k \gg \frac{1}{a}$ the restriction on $\left|V_{0}\right|$ is less than for the low- $k$

\section{6}

For an interaction $V(r)=\beta r^{-1} \exp (-\alpha r)$ find the differential scattering cross section in Born approximation. What are the conditions for validity? Suggest one or more physical applications of this model.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

In Born approximation, we first calculate (Problem 6013)

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta) &=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{0}^{\infty} r^{\prime} V\left(r^{\prime}\right) \sin q r^{\prime} d r^{\prime} \\
&=-\frac{2 m \beta}{\hbar^{2} q} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\alpha r} \sin q r d r=\frac{-2 m \beta}{\hbar^{2}\left(q^{2}+\alpha^{2}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $q=2 k \sin \frac{\theta}{2}$ and $m$ is the mass of the particle, and then the differential cross section

$$
\sigma(\theta)=|f(\theta)|^{2}=\frac{4 m^{2} \beta^{2}}{\hbar^{4}\left(q^{2}+\alpha^{2}\right)^{2}}
$$

The derivation is based on the assumption that the interaction potential can be treated as a perturbation, so that the wave function of the scattered particle can be written as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\psi(\mathbf{r})=\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r})+\psi_{1}(\mathbf{r}), \quad \text { where } \quad\left|\psi_{1}\right| \ll\left|\psi_{0}\right| \\
\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r})=e^{i k z} \\
\psi_{1}(\mathbf{r}) \approx-\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \int \frac{e^{i k\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|}}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} V\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) \psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) d^{3} r^{\prime}
\end{gathered}
$$

Specifically, we shall consider two cases, taking $a$ as the extent of space where the potential is appreciable. (i) The potential is sufficiently weak or the potential is sufficiently localized. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\psi_{1}\right| & \leq \frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \int \frac{\left|V\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)\right|}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|}\left|\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)\right| d^{3} r^{\prime} \\
& \approx \frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}}|V|\left|\psi_{0}\right| \int_{0}^{a} \frac{4 \pi \bar{r}^{2} d \bar{r}}{\bar{r}} \\
& \approx m|V| a^{2}\left|\psi_{0}\right| / \hbar^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\left|\psi_{1}\right| \ll\left|\psi_{0}\right|$ we require

$$
\frac{m|V| a^{2}}{\hbar^{2}} \ll 1
$$

i.e.,

$$
|V| \ll \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m a^{2}} \quad \text { or } \quad a \ll \frac{\hbar}{\sqrt{m|V|}} .
$$

This means that where the potential is weak enough or where the field is sufficiently localized, the Born approximation is valid. Note that the condition does not involve the velocity of the incident particle, so that as long as the interaction potential satisfies this condition the Born approximation is valid for an incident particle of any energy.

(ii) High energy scattering with $k a \gg 1$. The Born approximation assumes $\psi_{0}=e^{i k z}$ and a $\psi_{1}$ that satisfies

$$
\nabla^{2} \psi_{1}+k^{2} \psi_{1}=\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} V e^{i k z} .
$$

Let $\psi_{1}=e^{i k z} f(\theta, \varphi)$. The above becomes

$$
\frac{\partial f}{\partial z}=-\frac{i m}{\hbar^{2} k} V,
$$

and so

$$
\psi_{1}=e^{i k z} f=-\frac{i m}{\hbar^{2} k} e^{i k z} \int V d z
$$

Then as

$$
\left|\psi_{1}\right| \sim \frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k}|V| a\left|\psi_{0}\right|
$$

for $\left|\psi_{1}\right| \ll\left|\psi_{0}\right|=1$ we require

$$
|V| \ll \frac{\hbar^{2} k}{m a}=\frac{\hbar v}{a},
$$

where $v$ is the speed of the incident particle, $v=\frac{p}{m}=\frac{\hbar k}{m}$. Thus as long as the energy of the incident particle is large enough, the Born approximation is valid.

From the above results we see that if a potential field can be treated as a small perturbation for incident particles of low energy, it can always be so treated for incident particles of high energy. The reverse, however, is not true. In the present problem, the range of interaction can be taken to be $a \approx \frac{1}{\alpha}$, so that $V(a) \sim \frac{\beta}{a}$. The conditions then become

(i) $|\beta| \ll \frac{\alpha \hbar^{2}}{m}$

(ii) $|\beta| \ll \hbar v=\frac{\hbar^{2} k}{m}$, where $k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}$.

The given potential was used by Yukawa to represent the interaction between two nuclei and explain the short range of the strong nuclear force.

\section{7}

Consider the scattering of a $1 \mathrm{keV}$ proton by a hydrogen atom.

(a) What do you expect the angular distribution to look like? (Sketch a graph and comment on its shape).

(b) Estimate the total cross section. Give a numerical answer in $\mathrm{cm}^{2}$, $\mathrm{m}^{2}$ or barns $=10^{-24} \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$, and a reason for you answer.

$($ Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The problem is equivalent to the scattering of a particle of reduced mass $\mu \approx \frac{1}{2} m_{p}=470 \mathrm{MeV}$, energy $E_{r}=0.5 \mathrm{keV}$ by a potential which, on account of electron shielding, can be roughly represented by $\frac{e^{2}}{r} e^{-r / a}$, where $a$ is the range of interaction given by the Bohr radius $0.53 \AA$. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
k a &=\frac{a}{\hbar c} \sqrt{2 \mu c^{2} E_{r}} \\
&=\frac{0.53 \times 10^{-8} \times \sqrt{2 \times 470 \times 10^{6} \times 0.5 \times 10^{3}}}{6.58 \times 10^{-16} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}=1.84 \times 10^{2} \gg 1,
\end{aligned}
$$

for Born approximation to be valid we require (Problem 6026)

$$
|V| \sim \frac{e^{2}}{a} \ll \frac{\hbar v}{a}, \quad \text { i.e., } \frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c} \ll \frac{v}{c} .
$$

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathrm{LHS}=\frac{1}{137}=7.3 \times 10^{-3}, \\
&\mathrm{RHS}=\sqrt{\frac{2 E_{r}}{\mu c^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 0.5 \times 10^{3}}{470 \times 10^{6}}}=1.5 \times 10^{-3},
\end{aligned}
$$

the condition is not strictly satisfied. But in view of the roughness of the estimates, we still make use of the Born approximation.

(a) When the proton collides with the hydrogen atom, it experiences a repulsive Coulomb interaction with the nucleus, as well as an attractive one with the orbital electron having the appearance of a cloud of charge density $e \rho(r)$. The potential energy is then

$$
V(r)=\frac{e^{2}}{r}-e^{2} \int \frac{\rho\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} d \mathbf{r}^{\prime} .
$$

Using Born approximation and the formula

$$
\int \frac{e^{i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}}}{r} d \mathbf{r}=\frac{4 \pi}{q^{2}},
$$

we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta) &=-\frac{\mu e^{2}}{2 \pi \hbar^{2}} \int e^{i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}}\left[\frac{1}{r}-\int \frac{\rho\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} d \mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right] d \mathbf{r} \\
&=-\frac{2 \mu e^{2}}{\hbar^{2} q^{2}}[1-F(\theta)]
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu &=\frac{m_{p}}{2}, \quad q=2 k \sin \frac{\theta}{2}, \\
F(\theta) &=\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi} \iint \frac{e^{i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}} \rho\left(r^{\prime}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} d \mathbf{r}^{\prime} d \mathbf{r} \\
&=\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi} \int e^{i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}} \rho\left(r^{\prime}\right) d \mathbf{r}^{\prime} \int \frac{e^{i \mathbf{q} \cdot \overline{\mathbf{r}}}}{\bar{r}} d \overline{\mathbf{r}} \\
&=\int e^{i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}} \rho(r) d \mathbf{r} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the ground state of the hydrogen atom, we have

$$
\rho(r)=\left|\psi_{100}\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{\pi a^{3}} e^{-2 r / a},
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
F(\theta) &=\frac{1}{\pi a^{3}} \int e^{i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}-\frac{2 r}{a}} d \mathbf{r} \\
&=\left(1+\frac{a^{2} q^{2}}{4}\right)^{-2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
f(\theta)=-\frac{\mu e^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2} k^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sin ^{2}(\theta / 2)}\left[1-\frac{1}{\left(1+a^{2} k^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta / 2\right)^{2}}\right]
$$

Taking into account the identical nature of the two colliding particles (two protons), we have for the singlet state: $\sigma_{s}=|f(\theta)+f(\pi-\theta)|^{2}$, the triplet state: $\sigma_{A}=|f(\theta)-f(\pi-\theta)|^{2}$.

Hence the scattering cross section (not considering polarization) is

$$
\sigma=\frac{1}{4} \sigma_{s}+\frac{3}{4} \sigma_{A} .
$$

Some special cases are considered below.

(i) $\theta \approx 0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{s} &=\frac{\mu^{2} e^{4}}{4 \hbar^{4} k^{4}}\left[\frac{1-F(\theta)}{\sin ^{2} \theta / 2}+\frac{1-F(\pi-\theta)}{\cos ^{2} \theta / 2}\right]^{2} \\
& \approx \frac{\mu^{2} e^{4}}{4 \hbar^{4} k^{4}}\left(2 a^{2} k^{2}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \theta / 2}\right)^{2} \\
& \approx \frac{\mu^{2} e^{4}}{\hbar^{4}} a^{4}=\left(\frac{m_{p}}{2 m_{e}}\right)^{2} a^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

use having been made of the approximation for $x \approx 0$

$$
1 /(1+x)^{2} \approx 1-2 x,
$$

as well as the expression

$$
a=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m_{e} e^{2}}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{\mu e^{2}}\left(\frac{m_{p}}{2 m e}\right) .
$$

Similarly we obtain

$$
\sigma_{A}=\left(\frac{m_{p}}{2 m_{e}}\right)^{2} a^{2} \text {. }
$$

(ii) $\theta \approx \pi:$ A similar calculation gives

$$
\sigma_{s}=\sigma_{A}=\left(\frac{m_{p}}{2 m_{e}}\right)^{2} a^{2} .
$$

(iii) $a^{2} k^{2} \sin ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}=10$ or $\theta \approx 0.07 \pi$ : For $0.07 \pi \leq \theta \leq 0.93 \pi$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma(\theta)=& \frac{1}{4} \frac{\mu^{2} e^{4}}{4 \hbar^{4} k^{4}}\left(\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \theta / 2}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \theta / 2}\right)^{2} \\
&+\frac{3}{4} \frac{\mu^{2} e^{4}}{4 \hbar^{4} k^{4}}\left(\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \theta / 2}-\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \theta / 2}\right)^{2} \\
=& \frac{\mu^{2} e^{4}}{\hbar^{4} k^{4}}\left(\frac{3 \cos ^{2} \theta+1}{\sin ^{4} \theta}\right) \\
=& \sigma_{0}\left(\frac{3 \cos ^{2} \theta+1}{\sin ^{4} \theta}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\sigma_{0}=\frac{\mu^{2} e^{4}}{\hbar^{4} k^{4}}$. The angular distribution is shown in Fig. 6.7.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-528.jpg?height=366&width=404&top_left_y=1234&top_left_x=453)

Fig. $6.7$

(b) As $f(\theta) \rightarrow \infty$ for $\theta \rightarrow 0, \theta \rightarrow \pi$, to estimate the total scattering cross section, consider the total cross section for large scattering angles $(0.07 \pi \leq \theta \leq 0.93 \pi)$ and for small scattering angles: 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{t \text { large }} &=2 \pi \sigma_{0} \int_{0.07 \pi}^{0.93 \pi}\left(\frac{3 \cos ^{2} \theta+1}{\sin ^{4} \theta}\right) \sin \theta d \theta \\
&=2 \pi \sigma_{0} \int_{0.07 \pi}^{0.93 \pi} \frac{4-3 \sin ^{2} \theta}{\sin ^{3} \theta} d \theta \\
=&\left.2 \pi \sigma_{0}\left[-\ln \left(\tan \frac{\theta}{2}\right)-2 \frac{\cot \theta}{\sin \theta}\right]\right|_{0.07 \pi} ^{0.93 \pi} \\
=& 155 \pi \sigma_{0}, \\
\sigma_{t \text { small }}>2 \pi \int_{0}^{0.07 \pi} \sigma(0.07 \pi) \sin \theta d \theta \times 2 \\
&=2 \pi \times 1703 \sigma_{0}[1-\cos (0.07 \pi)] \times 2 \\
&=164 \pi \sigma_{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{8}

The study of the scattering of high-energy electrons from nuclei has yielded much interesting information about the charge distributions in nuclei and nucleons. We shall here consider a simple version of the theory, in which the "electron" is assumed to have zero spin. We also assume that the nucleus, of charge $Z e$, remains fixed in space (i.e., its mass is assumed infinite). Let $\rho(\mathbf{x})$ denote the charge density in the nucleus. The charge distribution is assumed to be spherically symmetric, but otherwise arbitrary.

Let $f_{e}\left(\mathbf{p}_{i}, \mathbf{p}_{f}\right)$, where $\mathbf{p}_{i}$ is the initial, and $\mathbf{p}_{f}$ is the final momentum, be the scattering amplitude in the first Born approximation for the scattering of an electron from a point nucleus of charge $Z e$. Let $f\left(\mathbf{p}_{i}, \mathbf{p}_{f}\right)$ be the scattering amplitude, also in the first Born approximation, for the scattering of an electron from a real nucleus of the same charge. Let $\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{p}_{i}-\mathbf{p}_{f}$ denote the momentum transfer. The quantity $F$ defined by $f\left(\mathbf{p}_{i}, \mathbf{p}_{f}\right)=$ $F\left(\mathbf{q}^{2}\right) f_{e}\left(\mathbf{p}_{i}, \mathbf{p}_{f}\right)$ is called the form factor: it is easily seen that $F$ in fact depends on $\mathbf{p}_{i}$ and $\mathbf{p}_{f}$ only through the quantity $\mathbf{q}^{2}$.

(a) The form factor $F\left(q^{2}\right)$ and the Fourier transform of the charge density $\rho(\mathbf{x})$ are related in a very simple manner: state and derive this relationship within the framework of the nonrelativistic Schrödinger theory. The assumption that the electrons are "nonrelativistic" is here made so that the problem will appear as simple as possible, but if you think about the matter it will probably be clear that the assumption is irrelevant: the same result applies in the "relativistic" case of the actual experiments. It is also the case that the neglect of the electron spin does not affect the essence of what we are here concerned with.

(b) The graph in Fig. $6.8$ shows some experimental results pertaining to the form factor for the proton, and we shall regard our theory as applicable to these data. On the basis of the data shown, compute the root-meansquare (charge) radius of the proton. Hint: Note that there is a simple relationship between the root-mean-square radius and derivative of $F\left(\mathbf{q}^{2}\right)$ with respect to $q^{2}$ at $q^{2}=0$.
