and similarly

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d x_{2}^{2}}=\left(\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right)^{2} \frac{d^{2}}{d R^{2}}-2 \frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} \frac{d^{2}}{d R d r}+\frac{d^{2}}{d r^{2}}
$$

We also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}^{2}=R^{2}+2 \frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} R r+\frac{m_{2}^{2}}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}} r^{2}, \\
&x_{2}^{2}=R^{2}-2 \frac{m_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} R r+\frac{m_{1}^{2}}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}} r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=&-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)} \frac{d^{2}}{d R^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2} \frac{m_{1}+m_{2}}{m_{1} m_{2}} \frac{d^{2}}{d r^{2}} \\
&+\frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \omega^{2} R^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} \omega^{2} r^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K r^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let

$$
M=m_{1}+m_{2}, \quad \mu=\frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} .
$$

The equation of motion becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{\left[\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \frac{d^{2}}{d R^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} M \omega^{2} R^{2}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{d^{2}}{d r^{2}}+\frac{\mu}{2}\left(1+\frac{K}{\mu \omega^{2}}\right) \omega^{2} r^{2}\right] \psi(R, r)} \\
&\quad=E \psi(R, r)
\end{aligned}
$$

It can be reduced to two independent oscillator equations with energy states and wave functions

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=E_{l m}=E_{l} &+E_{m}=\left(l+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega+\left(m+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega \sqrt{1+\frac{K}{\mu \omega^{2}}} \\
\psi_{l m}(R, r)=& \psi_{l}(R) \psi_{m}(r)=N_{l} N_{m} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \alpha_{1}^{2} R^{2}\right] H_{l}\left(\alpha_{1} R\right) \\
& \times \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \alpha_{2}^{2} r^{2}\right] H_{m}\left(\alpha_{2} r\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{l} &=\left(\frac{\alpha_{1}}{\sqrt{\pi} 2^{l} l !}\right)^{1 / 2}, \quad \alpha_{1}=\left(\frac{M \omega}{\hbar}\right)^{1 / 2}, \\
N_{m} &=\left(\frac{\alpha_{2}}{\sqrt{\pi} 2^{m} m !}\right)^{1 / 2}, \quad \alpha_{2}=\left(\frac{\mu \omega}{\hbar}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(1+\frac{K}{\mu \omega^{2}}\right)^{1 / 4},
\end{aligned}
$$

and $H_{m}$ are Hermite polynomials. (b) For $K \ll \mu \omega^{2}$, if we can take

$$
\left(1+\frac{K}{\mu \omega^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2} \approx 1
$$

we have

$$
E_{l m} \approx(l+m+1) \hbar \omega=(N+1) \hbar \omega, \quad N \equiv l+m=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

This means that the degeneracy of the $N$ th energy level is $N+1$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& N \ldots \\
& N=3 \quad l=3, m=0 ; \quad l=2, m=1 ; \quad l=1, m=2 ; \quad l=0, m=3 . \\
& N=2 \quad \underline{l=2, m=0} ; \quad l=1, m=1 ; \quad l=0, m=2 \text {. } \\
& N=1 \quad l=1, m=0 ; \quad l=0, m=1 \text {. } \\
& N=0 \quad \underline{l=m=0} \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

If $K$ is not so small and we have to take

$$
\sqrt{1+\frac{K}{\mu \omega^{2}}}=1+\frac{K}{2 \mu \omega^{2}}+\cdots
$$

then the energy levels with the same $m$ will move upward by

$$
\left(m+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega\left(\frac{K}{2 \mu \omega^{2}}+\cdots\right)
$$

and so the degeneracy is destroyed.

\section{5}

A potential has the form shown in Fig. 7.1, where $V$ is very large but finite.

(i) If a particle is originally in one of the wells, give a formula for the order of magnitude of the rate at which it tunnels into the other. Do not attempt to calculate numerical factors of order unity.

(ii) Sketch the wave functions for the lowest two states. (iii) If two identical bosons with a small repulsive force between them are placed in the wells, write down approximate wave functions for the lowest two states for each of the two cases where the effect of the inter-particle force is much less and much greater than the effect of the fact that $V$ is not infinite.

(Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-619.jpg?height=373&width=483&top_left_y=476&top_left_x=425)

Fig. $7.1$

\section{Solution:}

(i) Denote the ground state by $\psi_{1}$ and the first excited state by $\psi_{2} . \psi_{1}$ is symmetric about the axis of symmetry of the potential well, $\psi_{2}$ is antisymmetric. Assume the particle is initially in the left semi-well and write the initial wave function as

$$
\Psi(x, 0)=\left(\psi_{1}+\psi_{2}\right) / \sqrt{2}
$$

(We can see that this is a good approximation from the diagram given in (ii)) Then

$$
\Psi(x, t)=\left[\psi_{1} e^{-i E_{1} t / \hbar}+\psi_{2} e^{-i E_{2} t / \hbar}\right] / \sqrt{2} .
$$

At time $t_{0}$ for which $e^{-i E_{1} t_{0} / \hbar} / e^{-i E_{2} t_{0} / \hbar}=-1$, we have

$$
\Psi\left(x, t_{0}\right)=C\left(\psi_{1}-\psi_{2}\right) / \sqrt{2}, \quad|C|^{2}=1 .
$$

At this moment the particle is in the other semi-well (i.e., with a large probability). As $-1=e^{i \pi}$, this happens at time

$$
t_{0}=\frac{\pi \hbar}{E_{2}-E_{1}}=\frac{\pi \hbar}{\Delta E} .
$$

For $V$ very large, it can be taken as infinite and

$$
E \approx \frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} n^{2}}{2 m L^{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
\Delta E \approx E_{2}-E_{1}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 m L^{2}}\left(2^{2}-1\right)=\frac{3 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 m L^{2}} .
$$

Hence the rate of tunneling per unit time is of the order

$$
\beta \sim \frac{1}{t_{0}}=\frac{3 \pi \hbar}{2 m L^{2}} .
$$

(ii) The wave functions of the two lowest states are sketched in Fig. 7.2.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-620.jpg?height=295&width=450&top_left_y=766&top_left_x=438)

Fig. $7.2$

(iii) If the repulsive potential between the bosons is much smaller than $V$, the wave functions of the two lowest states are approximately

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Psi_{\mathrm{I}} &=\psi_{1}(1) \psi_{1}(2) \\
\Psi_{\mathrm{II}} &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{1}(1) \psi_{2}(2)+\psi_{2}(1) \psi_{1}(2)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

If the repulsive potential is much larger than $V$, transmission through the central potential barrier is very small, and the wave functions are approximately

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Psi_{\mathrm{I}^{\prime}} &=\psi_{1}(1) \psi_{1}(2) \\
\Psi_{\mathrm{II}^{\prime}} &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{1}(1) \psi_{2}(2)-\psi_{2}(1) \psi_{1}(2)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{6}

Consider a system defined by the Schrödinger eigenvalue equation

$$
\left\{-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(\nabla_{1}^{2}+\nabla_{2}^{2}\right)+\frac{k}{2}\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|^{2}\right\} \psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=E \psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) .
$$

(a) List all symmetries of this Schrödinger equation.

(b) Indicate all constants of motion.

(c) Indicate the form of the ground-state wave function.

You may assume that the ground-state wave function of one-dimensional harmonic oscillator is a Gaussian.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Schrödinger equation has symmetries with respect to time translation, space inversion, translation of the whole system, and the exchange of $\mathbf{r}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{r}_{2}$, as well as symmetry with respect to the Galilean transformation.

(b) Let $\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}, \mathbf{R}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}+\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)$. The Schrödinger equation can then be written as

$$
\left\{-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m} \nabla_{R}^{2}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m} \nabla_{r}^{2}+\frac{k}{2} r^{2}\right\} \psi(\mathbf{R}, \mathbf{r})=E \psi(\mathbf{R}, \mathbf{r}) .
$$

This equation can be separated into two, one for the motion of a particle of mass $2 m$ at the center of mass and one for the motion of a harmonic oscillator of mass $m / 2$ relative to the second particle. The motion of the center of mass is a free motion, so that $P_{R}^{2}, P_{x}, P_{y}, P_{z}, E_{R}, L_{R}^{2}, L_{x}, L_{y}, L_{z}$ are all constants of the motion. Of the relative motion, $E_{r}, L_{r}^{2}, L_{z}$, as well as the parity of the wave function, are constants of the motion.

(c) The ground-state wave function has the form $\psi(\mathbf{R}, \mathbf{r})=\phi(\mathbf{R}) \varphi(\mathbf{r})$. $\phi(\mathbf{r})$ is the wave function of a harmonic oscillator of mass $\frac{m}{2}$ :

$$
\varphi(\mathbf{r}) \sim \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \alpha^{2} r^{2}\right)
$$

with

$$
\alpha^{2}=\sqrt{\frac{m k}{2 \hbar^{2}}} \text {. }
$$

$\phi(\mathbf{R})$ is the wave function of a free particle of mass $2 m$ :

$$
\phi(\mathbf{R}) \sim \exp (-i \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{R} / \hbar)
$$

with

$$
|\mathbf{p}|=\sqrt{4 m E_{R}}, \quad E_{R}=E-\frac{1}{2} \hbar \sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}
$$

\section{7}

Two identical bosons, each of mass $m$, move in the one-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential $V=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}$. They also interact with each other via the potential

$$
V_{\text {int }}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\alpha e^{-\beta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}},
$$

where $\beta$ is a positive parameter. Compute the ground state energy of the system to first order in the interaction strength parameter $\alpha$.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Being bosons the two particles can simultaneously stay in the ground state. Taking $V_{\text {int }}$ as perturbation, the unperturbed wave function of the ground state for the system is

$$
\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\phi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \phi_{0}\left(x_{2}\right)=\frac{\alpha_{0}}{\sqrt{\pi}} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \alpha_{0}^{2}\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\right)\right], \quad \alpha_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{m \omega}{\hbar}} .
$$

The perturbation energy to first order in $\alpha$ is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=\iint_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi_{0}^{*}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) V_{\text {int }}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \psi_{0}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) d x_{1} d x_{2} \\
&=\frac{\alpha_{0}^{2} \alpha}{\pi} \iint_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\alpha_{0}^{2}\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\right)-\beta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}\right] d x_{1} d x_{2} \\
&=\frac{\alpha_{0} \alpha}{\left(\alpha_{0}^{2}+2 \beta\right)^{1 / 2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where the integration has been facilitated by the transformation

$$
\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}=y_{1}, \quad \frac{x_{1}-x_{2}}{2}=y_{2} .
$$

The ground state energy of the system is therefore

$$
E=\hbar \omega+\frac{\alpha_{0} \alpha}{\left(\alpha_{0}^{2}+2 \beta\right)^{1 / 2}} \quad \text { with } \quad \alpha_{0}=\left(\frac{m \omega}{\hbar}\right)^{1 / 2} .
$$



\section{8}

A one-dimensional square well of infinite depth and $1 \AA$ width contains 3 electrons. The potential well is described by $V=0$ for $0 \leq x \leq 1 \AA$ and $V=+\infty$ for $x<0$ and $x>1 \AA$. For a temperature of $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$, the average energy of the 3 electrons is $E=12.4 \mathrm{eV}$ in the approximation that one neglects the Coulomb interaction between electrons. In the same approximation and for $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$, what is the average energy for 4 electrons in this potential well?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

For a one-dimensional potential well the energy levels are given by

$$
E_{n}=E_{1} n^{2},
$$

where $E_{1}$ is the ground state energy and $n=1,2, \ldots$. Pauli's exclusion principle and the lowest energy principle require that two of the three electrons are in the energy level $E_{1}$ and the third one is in the energy level $E_{2}$. Thus $12 \cdot 4 \times 3=2 E_{1}+4 E_{1}$, giving $E_{1}=6 \cdot 2 \mathrm{eV}$. For the case of four electrons, two are in $E_{1}$ and the other two in $E_{2}$, and so the average energy is

(Note: the correct value of $E_{1}$ is

$$
E=\frac{1}{4}\left(2 E_{1}+2 E_{2}\right)=\frac{5}{2} E_{1}=15.5 \mathrm{eV} .
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 m a^{2}} &=\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left(\frac{\pi \hbar c}{a}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{1.02 \times 10^{6}}\left(\frac{\pi \times 6.58 \times 10^{-16} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}{10^{-8}}\right)^{2} \\
&=37.7 \mathrm{eV} .)
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{9}

Consider two electrons moving in a central potential well in which there are only three single-particle states $\psi_{1}, \psi_{2}$ and $\psi_{3}$.

(a) Write down all of the wave functions $\psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)$ for the two-electron system.

(b) If now the electrons interact with a Hamiltonian $\delta H=V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=$ $V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}, \mathbf{r}_{1}\right)$, show that the following expression for the matrix element is correct: 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\psi_{13}|\delta H| \psi_{12}\right\rangle=&\left\langle\psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\left|V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right| \psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
&-\left\langle\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\left|V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right| \psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

(Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The wave functions for a fermion system are antisymmetric for interchange of particles, so the possible wave functions for the system are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi_{12}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)-\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right) \\
&\psi_{13}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)-\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right) \\
&\psi_{23}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)-\psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) We can write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\psi_{13}|\delta H| \psi_{12}\right\rangle=& \frac{1}{2}\left\langle\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\left|V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right| \psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
&-\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\left|V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right| \psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
&-\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\left|V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right| \psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
&+\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{3}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\left|V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right| \psi_{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{1}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the particles are identical, $\mathbf{r}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{r}_{2}$ may be interchanged in each term. Do this and as $V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=V^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}, \mathbf{r}_{1}\right)$, we again obtain the same expression, showing its correctness.

\section{0}

Two identical nonrelativistic fermions of mass $m$, spin $1 / 2$ are in a onedimensional square well of length $L$, with $V$ infinitely large and repulsive outside the well. The fermions are subject to a repulsive inter-particle potential $V\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)$, which may be treated as a perturbation. Classify the three lowest-energy states in terms of the states of the individual particles and state the spin of each. Calculate (in first-order perturbation theory) the energies of second- and third-lowest states; leave your result in the form of an integral. Neglect spin-dependent forces throughout.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

For the unperturbed potential

$$
V(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x \in[0, L] \\ \infty, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

the single-particle spatial wave functions are

$$
\psi_{n}(x)= \begin{cases}\sqrt{\frac{2}{L}} \sin \frac{n \pi x}{L}, & x \in[0, L] \\ 0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

where $n$ is an integer.

The spin wave function of a single particle has the form $\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\ b\end{array}\right)$.

As we do not consider spin-dependent forces, the wave function of the two particles can be written as the product of a space part and a spin part. The spin part $\chi_{J}(M) \equiv \chi_{J M}$ is chosen as the eigenstate of $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}$ and $S_{z}=s_{1 z}+s_{2 z}$, i.e.,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{S}^{2} \chi_{J M}=J(J+1) \chi_{J M}, \\
&S_{J} \chi_{J M}=M \chi_{J M} .
\end{aligned}
$$

$J=0$ gives the spin singlet state, which is antisymmetric for interchange of the two particles. $J=1$ gives the spin triplet state, which is symmetric for interchange of the two particles. Symmetrizing and antisymmetrizing the space wave functions of the two-particle system we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\psi_{n m}^{A}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{n}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{m}\left(x_{2}\right)-\psi_{n}\left(x_{2}\right) \psi_{m}\left(x_{1}\right)\right], \\
\psi_{n m}^{s}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{n}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{m}\left(x_{2}\right)+\psi_{n}\left(x_{2}\right) \psi_{m}\left(x_{1}\right)\right], & n \neq m, \\
\psi_{n}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{n}\left(x_{2}\right), & n=m .\end{cases}
\end{gathered}
$$

The corresponding energies are

$$
E=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 m L^{2}}\left(n^{2}+m^{2}\right), \quad n, m=1,2, \cdots .
$$

The total wave functions, which are antisymmetric, can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi_{n m}^{A}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \chi_{J M}^{s}, \\
&\psi_{n m}^{s}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \chi_{J M}^{A}
\end{aligned}
$$

The three lowest energy states are the following.

(i) Ground state, $n=m=1$. The space wave function is symmetric, so the spin state must be singlet. Thus

$$
\psi_{0}=\psi_{11}^{s}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \chi_{00} .
$$

(ii) First excited states, $n=1, m=2$.

$$
\psi_{1}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{12}^{A}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \chi_{1 M}, \quad M=0, \pm 1 \\
\psi_{12}^{s}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \chi_{00}
\end{array}\right.
$$

The degeneracy is 4 .

(iii) Second excited state, $n=2, m=2$. The space wave function is symmetric, the spin state is singlet:

$$
\psi_{2}=\psi_{22}^{s}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \chi_{00}
$$

which is nondegenerate. Because the perturbation Hamiltonian is independent of spin, the calculation of perturbation of the first excited state can be treated as a nondegenerate case. The perturbation energies of second and third lowest energy states are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\Delta E_{1}^{A}=\int d x_{1} d x_{2}\left|\psi_{12}^{A}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)\right|^{2} V\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) \\
&\Delta E_{1}^{s}=\int d x_{1} d x_{2}\left|\psi_{12}^{s}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)\right|^{2} V\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) \\
&\Delta E_{2}=\int d x_{1} d x_{2}\left|\psi_{22}^{s}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)\right|^{2} V\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{1}

A one-dimensional box of width $L$ contains two spinless particles each of mass $m$. The interaction between the particles is described by a potential energy $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)$. Calculate the ground state energy to first order in $a$.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

Neglecting the $\delta$-potential, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)= \begin{cases}0, & 0 \leq x_{1}, x_{2} \leq L \\
\infty, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases} \\
&H_{0}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x_{1}^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x_{2}^{2}}+V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the results for an infinitely deep potential well, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi_{n l}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\psi_{n}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{l}\left(x_{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{2}{L} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi}{L} x_{1}\right) \sin \left(\frac{l \pi}{L} x_{2}\right), \\
&E_{n l}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{2 m L^{2}}\left(n^{2}+l^{2}\right), \quad n, l=1,2, \cdots .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the ground state, $n=l=1$,

$$
E_{11}=\hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / m L^{2} .
$$

Now consider the $\delta$-potential as a perturbation

$$
\hat{H}^{\prime}=a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) .
$$

The correction to the ground state energy due to the perturbation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H}^{\prime} &=\langle 11|\hat{H}| 11\rangle \\
&=\int_{0}^{L} \int_{0}^{L} a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{1}\right) \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{2}\right)\left(\frac{2}{L}\right)^{2} d x_{1} d x_{2} \\
&=a\left(\frac{2}{L}\right)^{2} \int_{0}^{L} \sin ^{4}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{1}\right) d x_{1}=\frac{3 a}{2 L},
\end{aligned}
$$

and the ground state energy is

$$
E_{11}^{\prime}=E_{11}+\bar{H}^{\prime}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m L^{2}}+\frac{3 a}{2 L} .
$$

\section{2}

Two electrons at fixed positions on the $z$-axis have a magnetic dipoledipole interaction (energy) $E=A\left(\mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2}-3 s_{1 z} s_{2 z}\right.$ ), where $\mathbf{s}_{i}=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{i}, \sigma_{i}$ being Pauli's spin matrix, $A=$ constant.

\section{(a) Express E/A in terms of the total spin operator $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}$. \\ (b) State the eigenvalues of $\mathrm{E} / \mathrm{A}$ and their degeneracy (statistical weights).}

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As

$$
\mathbf{s}^{2}=\frac{1}{4} \sigma^{2}=\frac{1}{4}\left(\sigma_{x}^{2}+\sigma_{y}^{2}+\sigma_{z}^{2}\right)=\frac{3}{4}, \quad s_{z}^{2}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{4}
$$

we have

and hence

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{S}^{2}=\left(\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{3}{2}+2 \mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2} \\
S_{z}^{2}=\left(s_{1 z}+s_{2 z}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2}+2 s_{1 z} s_{2 z}
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
E / A=\left(s_{1} \cdot s_{2}-3 s_{1 z} s_{2 z}\right)=\left(\mathbf{S}^{2}-3 S_{z}^{2}\right) / 2 .
$$

(b) For the common eigenstate $|S, M\rangle$ of $\mathbf{S}$ and $S_{z}$, we have

$$
\frac{E}{A}|S, M\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\left[S(S+1)-3 M^{2}\right]|S, M\rangle .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
|S, M\rangle & E / A & D(E / A) \\
|0,0\rangle & 0 & 1 \\
|1, \pm 1\rangle & -\frac{1}{2} & 2 \\
|1,0\rangle & 1 & 1
\end{array}
$$

Note that for states with $M \neq 0$, the energy levels are two-fold degenerate, i.e., $D=2$. 

\section{3}

(a) A 2-fermion system has a wave function $\psi(1,2)$. What condition must it satisfy if the particles are identical?

(b) How does this imply the elementary statement of the Pauli exclusion principle that no two electrons in an atom can have identical quantum numbers?

(c) The first excited state of $\mathrm{Mg}$ has the configuration $(3 s, 3 p)$ for the valence electrons. In the LS-coupling limit, which values of $L$ and $S$ are possible? What is the form of the spatial part of their wave functions using the single-particle functions $\psi_{s}(\mathbf{r})$ and $\phi_{p}(\mathbf{r})$ ? Which will have the lowest energy, and Why?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) $\psi(1,2)$ must satisfy the condition of antisymmetry for interchange of the two particles:

$$
\hat{P}_{12} \psi(1,2)=\psi(2,1)=-\psi(1,2) .
$$

(b) In an atom, if there are two electrons having identical quantum numbers then $\psi(1,2)=\psi(2,1)$. The antisymmetry condition above then gives $\psi(1,2)=0$, implying that such a state does not exist.

(c) The electron configuration $(3 s, 3 p)$ correspond to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&l_{1}=0, \quad l_{2}=1 \\
&s_{1}=s_{2}=1 / 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{gathered}
L=1, \quad S=0,1 \\
\psi_{S}^{L}(1,2)=\phi_{S}^{L}(1,2) \chi_{S}(1,2)
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\phi_{0}^{1}(1,2) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)+\phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(1+\hat{P}_{12}\right) \phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \\
\phi_{1}^{1}(1,2) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(1-\hat{P}_{12}\right) \phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

The lowest energy state is $\Psi_{1}^{1}(1,2)$, i.e. the state of $S=1$. Because the spatial part of the state $S=1$ is antisymmetric for the interchange $1 \leftrightarrow 2$, the probability that the two electrons get close together is small, and so the Coulomb repulsive energy is small, resulting in a lower total energy.

\section{4}

Two particles, each of mass $M$, are bound in a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential $V=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}$ and interact with each other through an attractive harmonic force $F_{12}=-K\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)$. You may take $K$ to be small.

(a) What are the energies of the three lowest states of this system?

(b) If the particles are identical and spinless, which of the states of (a) are allowed?

(c) If the particles are identical and have spin $1 / 2$, what is the total spin of each of the states of (a)?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{1}^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{2}^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\right)+\frac{K}{2}\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Let $\xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right), \eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)$ and write $\hat{H}$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H} &=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \xi^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \eta^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k\left(\xi^{2}+\eta^{2}\right)+K \eta^{2} \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \xi^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \eta^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k \xi^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(k+2 K) \eta^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The system can be considered as consisting of two independent harmonic oscillators of angular frequencies $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ given by

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k+2 K}{M}} .
$$

The total energy is therefore

$$
E_{n m}=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{1}+\left(m+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{2}
$$

and the corresponding eigenstate is

$$
|n m\rangle=\psi_{n m}=\varphi_{n}^{(k)}(\xi) \varphi_{m}^{(k+2 K)}(\eta)
$$

where $n, m=0,1,2, \cdots$, and $\varphi_{n}^{(k)}$ is the $n$th eigenstate of a harmonic oscillator of spring constant $k$.

(a) The energies of the three lowest states of the system are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{00}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}\right), \\
&E_{10}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}\right)+\hbar \omega_{1}, \\
&E_{01}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}\right)+\hbar \omega_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) If the particles are identical and spinless, the wave function must be symmetric with respect to the interchange of the two particles. Thus the states $|00\rangle,|10\rangle$ are allowed, while the state $|01\rangle$ is not allowed.

(c) If the particles are identical with spin $1 / 2$, the total wave function, including both spatial and spin, must be antisymmetric with respect to an interchange of the two particles. As the spin function for total spin $S=0$ is antisymmetric and that for $S=1$ is symmetric, we have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
S=0 & \text { for }|00\rangle, \\
S=0 & \text { for }|10\rangle, \\
S=1 & \text { for }|01\rangle .
\end{array}
$$

\section{5}

A particular one-dimensional potential well has the following boundstate single-particle energy eigenfunctions:

$$
\psi_{a}(x), \psi_{b}(x), \psi_{c}(x) \cdots, \text { where } E_{a}<E_{b}<E_{c} \cdots
$$

Two non-interacting particles are placed in the well. For each of the cases (a), (b), (c) listed below write down:

the two lowest total energies available to the two-particle system, the degeneracy of each of the two energy levels, the possible two-particle wave functions associated with each of the levels.

(Use $\psi$ to express the spatial part and a ket $\left|S, m_{s}\right\rangle$ to express the spin part. $S$ is the total spin.)
(a) Two distinguishable spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles.
(b) Two identical spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles.
(c) Two identical spin-0 particles.

\section{Solution:}

As the two particles, each of mass $M$, have no mutual interaction, their spatial wave functions separately satisfy the Schrödinger equation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{1}^{2}}+V\left(x_{1}\right)\right] \psi_{i}\left(x_{1}\right)=E_{i} \psi_{i}\left(x_{1}\right)} \\
&{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{2}^{2}}+V\left(x_{2}\right)\right] \psi_{j}\left(x_{2}\right)=E_{j} \psi_{j}\left(x_{2}\right) .} \\
&(i, j=a, b, c \ldots)
\end{aligned}
$$

The equations may also be combined to give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{1}^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{2}^{2}}+V\left(x_{1}\right)+V\left(x_{2}\right)\right] \psi_{i}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{j}\left(x_{2}\right)} \\
&\quad=\left(E_{i}+E_{j}\right) \psi_{i}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{j}\left(x_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider the two lowest energy levels (i) and (ii).

(a) Two distinguishable spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles.

(i) Total energy $=E_{a}+E_{a}$, degeneracy $=4$. The wave functions are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{a}\left(x_{2}\right)|0,0\rangle \\
\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{a}\left(x_{2}\right)|1, m\rangle . \quad(m=0, \pm 1)
\end{array}\right.
$$

(ii) Total energy $=E_{a}+E_{b}$, degeneracy $=8$. The wave functions are

$$
\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ \psi _ { a } ( x _ { 1 } ) \psi _ { a } ( x _ { 2 } ) | 0 , 0 \rangle , } \\
{ \psi _ { a } ( x _ { 1 } ) \psi _ { a } ( x _ { 2 } ) | 1 , m \rangle , }
\end{array} \left\{\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{b}\left(x_{2}\right)|0,0\rangle, \\
\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{b}\left(x_{2}\right)|1, m\rangle . \quad(m=0, \pm 1)
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

(b) Two identical spin-1/2 particles.

(i) total energy $=E_{a}+E_{a}$, degeneracy $=1$. The wave function is $\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{a}\left(x_{2}\right)|0,0\rangle$

(ii) total energy $=E_{a}+E_{b}$, degeneracy $=4$. The wave functions are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{b}\left(x_{2}\right)+\psi_{b}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{a}\left(x_{2}\right)\right]|0,0\rangle \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{b}\left(x_{2}\right)-\psi_{b}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{a}\left(x_{2}\right)\right]|1, m\rangle . \quad(m=0, \pm 1)
\end{array}\right.
$$

(c) Two identical spin- 0 particles.

(i) Total energy $=E_{a}+E_{a}$, degeneracy $=1$. The wave function is $\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{a}\left(x_{2}\right)|0,0\rangle$

(ii) Total energy $=E_{a}+E_{a}$, degeneracy $=1$. The wave function is

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{a}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{b}\left(x_{2}\right)+\psi_{b}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{a}\left(x_{2}\right)|0,0\rangle .\right.
$$

\section{6}

Two electrons move in a central field. Consider the electrostatic interaction $e^{2} /\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|$ between the electrons as a perturbation.

(a) Find the first order energy shifts for the states (terms) of the $(1 s)(2 s)$ configuration. (Express your answers in terms of unperturbed quantities and matrix elements of the interaction $\left.e^{2} /\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|\right)$

(b) Discuss the symmetry of the two-particle wave function for the states in part (a).
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-633.jpg?height=318&width=542&top_left_y=1464&top_left_x=394)

Fig. 7.3 (c) Suppose that, at time $t=0$, one electron is found to be in the $1 \mathrm{~s}$ unperturbed state with spin up and the other electron in the $2 s$ unperturbed state with spin down as shown in Fig. 7.3. At what time $t$ will the occupation of the states be reversed?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The zero order wave function of the two electrons has the forms

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\phi_{+}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \chi_{00}\left(s_{1 z}, s_{2 z}\right) \\
&\phi_{-}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \chi_{1 M_{s}}\left(s_{1 z}, s_{2 z}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\phi_{\varepsilon}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[u_{1 s}(1) v_{2 s}(2)+\varepsilon u_{1 s}(2) v_{2 s}(1)\right], \quad \varepsilon=\pm 1
$$

being the normalized symmetric $(+)$ and antisymmetric (-) wave functions, $\chi_{0}$ and $\chi_{1}$ denote the singlet and triplet spin states respectively. Denoting $u_{1 s}(1) v_{2 s}(2)$ by $|1,2\rangle$ and $u_{1 s}(2) v_{2 s}(1)$ by $|2,1\rangle$, we can write the above as

$$
\left|\phi_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle=(|1,2\rangle+\varepsilon|2,1\rangle) / \sqrt{2} .
$$

Because the perturbation Hamiltonian is independent of spin, we need not consider $\chi$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_{\varepsilon}=& \int d^{3} r_{1} d^{3} r_{2} \phi_{\varepsilon}^{*} \frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|} \phi_{\varepsilon} \\
=& \frac{1}{2}\left(\left\langle1,2|+\varepsilon\langle 2,1|) \frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|}(|1,2\rangle+\varepsilon|2,1\rangle)\right.\right.\\
=& \frac{1}{2}[\langle 1,2|A| 1,2\rangle+\langle 2,1|A| 2,1\rangle\\
&+\varepsilon\langle 1,2|A| 2,1\rangle+\varepsilon\langle 2,1|A| 1,2\rangle]=K+\varepsilon J
\end{aligned}
$$

where $A=e^{2} /\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|, K=\langle 1,2|A| 1,2\rangle=\langle 2,1|A| 2,1\rangle$ is the direct integral, $J=\langle 1,2|A| 2,1\rangle=\langle 2,1|A| 1,2\rangle$ is the exchange integral.

(b) The singlet state $\chi_{0}$ is antisymmetric for interchange of spins. The triplet state $\chi_{1}$ is symmetric for interchange of spins. Similarly, $\phi_{+}$is symmetric for the interchange of $\mathbf{r}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{r}_{2}$, and $\phi_{-}$is antisymmetric for the interchange. Hence the total wave function is always antisymmetric for interchange of the electrons.

(c) The initial state of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(t=0)=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[|1 s 2 s\rangle|\uparrow \downarrow\rangle-|2 s 1 s\rangle|\downarrow \uparrow\rangle] \\
=& \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}[(|1,2\rangle+|2,1\rangle)(|\uparrow \downarrow\rangle-|\downarrow \uparrow\rangle)\\
&+(|1,2\rangle-|2,1\rangle)(|\uparrow \downarrow\rangle+|\downarrow \uparrow\rangle)] \\
=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\psi_{+} \chi_{00}+\psi_{-} \chi_{10}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and so the wave function at $t$ is

$$
\psi(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\psi_{+} \chi_{00} e^{-i E_{+} t / \hbar}+\psi_{-} \chi_{10} e^{-i E_{-} t / \hbar}\right) .
$$

When $e^{-i E_{-} t / \hbar} / e^{-i E_{+} t / \hbar}=-1$, the wave function becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi\left(t_{n}\right) &=e^{-i E_{+} t_{n} / \hbar} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\psi_{+} \chi_{00}-\psi_{-} \chi_{10}\right) \\
&=e^{-E_{+} t_{n} / \hbar} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[|2,1\rangle|\uparrow \downarrow\rangle-|1,2\rangle|\downarrow \uparrow\rangle]
\end{aligned}
$$

which shows that at this time the $1 s$ electron has spin down and the $2 s$ electron has spin up i.e., the spins are reversed. As $-1=e^{i(2 n+1) \pi}, n=$ $0,1,2 \cdots$, this happens at times

$$
t=(2 n+1) \pi \cdot \frac{\hbar}{E_{+}-E_{-}}=\frac{(2 n+1) \pi \hbar}{2 J} .
$$

\section{7}

(a) Show that the parity operator commutes with the orbital angular momentum operator. What is the parity quantum number of the spherical harmonic $Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)$ ?

(b) Show for a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator in state $E_{n}=(n+$ $\left.\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega$ that $\left\langle\Delta x^{2}\right\rangle_{n}\left\langle\Delta p^{2}\right\rangle_{n}=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2} \hbar^{2}$. (c) Consider the rotation of a hydrogen molecule $H_{2}$. What are its rotational energy levels? How does the identity of the two nuclei affect this spectrum? What type of radiative transition occurs between these levels? Remember that the proton is a fermion.

(d) Show that $(\mathbf{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma})^{2}=1$, where $\mathbf{n}$ is a unit vector in an arbitrary direction and $\sigma$ are the Pauli spin matrices.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Applying the parity operator $\hat{P}$ and the orbital angular momentum operator

$$
\mathbf{L}=\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{p}
$$

to an arbitrary wave function $f(\mathbf{r})$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{P} \mathbf{L} f(\mathbf{r}) &=\hat{P}(\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{p}) f(\mathbf{r})=(-\mathbf{r}) \times(-\mathbf{p}) f(-\mathbf{r}) \\
&=\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{p} f(-\mathbf{r})=\mathbf{L} \hat{P} f(\mathbf{r})
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $\hat{P}$ and $\mathbf{L}$ commute, i.e.,

$$
[\hat{P}, \mathrm{~L}]=0 \text {. }
$$

As

$$
\hat{P} Y_{l m}(\theta, \phi)=Y_{l m}(\pi-\theta, \pi+\phi)=(-1)^{l} Y_{l m}(\theta, \phi),
$$

the parity quantum number of $Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)$ is $(-1)^{l}$.

(b) For a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator, we can use the Fock representation

$$
x=\sqrt{\frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}}\left(a+a^{+}\right), \quad p=i \sqrt{\frac{m \hbar \omega}{2}}\left(a^{+}-a\right),
$$

where $a, a^{+}$are annihilation and creation operators having the properties

$$
\begin{aligned}
a|n\rangle &=\sqrt{n}|n-1\rangle, \\
a^{+}|n\rangle &=\sqrt{n+1}|n+1\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

Using these operators we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle n|x| n\rangle &=\sqrt{\frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}}\left\langle n\left|a+a^{+}\right| n\right\rangle \\
&=\sqrt{\frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}}(\sqrt{n}\langle n \mid n-1\rangle+\sqrt{n+1}\langle n \mid n+1\rangle=0,
\end{aligned}
$$



$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle n\left|x^{2}\right| n\right\rangle=& \frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}\left\langle n\left|\left(a+a^{+}\right)\left(a+a^{+}\right)\right| n\right\rangle \\
=& \frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}\left(\sqrt{n}\left\langle n\left|a+a^{+}\right| n-1\right\rangle+\sqrt{n+1}\left\langle n\left|a+a^{+}\right| n+1\right\rangle\right.\\
=& \frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}[\sqrt{n(n-1)}\langle n \mid n-2\rangle+n\langle n \mid n\rangle\\
&+(n+1)\langle n \mid n\rangle+\sqrt{(n+1)(n+2)}\langle n \mid n+2\rangle] \\
=& \frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}(2 n+1),
\end{aligned}
$$

and similarly

$$
\begin{gathered}
\langle n|p| n\rangle=0 \\
\left\langle n\left|p^{2}\right| n\right\rangle=\frac{m \hbar \omega}{2}(2 n+1) .
\end{gathered}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left\langle\Delta x^{2}\right\rangle_{n}=\left\langle(x-\langle x\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle_{n}=\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle_{n}-\langle x\rangle_{n}^{2}=\frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}(2 n+1) \\
&\left\langle\Delta p^{2}\right\rangle_{n}=\left\langle p^{2}\right\rangle_{n}-\langle p\rangle_{n}^{2}=\frac{m \hbar \omega}{2}(2 n+1)
\end{aligned}
$$

we find

$$
\left\langle\Delta x^{2}\right\rangle_{n} \cdot\left\langle\Delta p^{2}\right\rangle_{n}=\hbar^{2}\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}
$$

(c) The rotational energy levels of a hydrogen molecule are given by

$$
E_{r}=\hbar^{2} K(K+1) / 2 I_{0},
$$

where $I_{0}=M R_{0}^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the molecule about the rotating axis, which is perpendicular to the line connecting the two nuclei, $K$ is the angular momentum quantum number, $K=0,1,2, \cdots$. Since the spin of a proton is $\hbar / 2$, the total wave function of the molecule is antisymmetric for interchange of the two protons. When the two protons are interchanged, the wave function for the motion of the center of mass and the wave function for the atomic vibration are not changed; only the wave function for rotation is altered:

$$
Y_{K M_{K}}(\theta, \varphi) \rightarrow Y_{K M_{K}}(\pi-\theta, \pi+\varphi)=(-1)^{K} Y_{K M_{K}}(\theta, \varphi)
$$

If $K$ is even, $(-1)^{K} Y_{K M_{K}}(\theta, \varphi)=Y_{K M_{K}}(\theta, \varphi)$ and the spin wave function $\chi_{0}$ must be antisymmetric, i.e., $\chi_{0}$ is a spin singlet state; If $K$ is odd, $(-1)^{K} Y_{K M_{K}}(\theta, \varphi)=-Y_{K M_{K}}(\theta, \varphi)$ and the spin wave function $\chi_{1}$ must be symmetric, i.e., $\chi_{1}$ is a spin triplet state. The hydrogen molecule in the former case is called a para-hydrogen, and in the latter case is called an ortho-hydrogen. There is no inter-conversion between para-hydrogen and ortho-hydrogen. Transitions can take place between rotational energy levels with $\Delta K=2,4,6, \cdots$ within each type. Electric quadruple transitions may also occur between these levels.

(d)

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\mathbf{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma})^{2} &=\left(\sum_{i} n_{i} \sigma_{i}\right)^{2}=\sum_{i j} n_{i} n_{j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, i} n_{i} n_{j}\left\{\sigma_{i}, \sigma_{j}\right\}=\sum_{i, j} n_{i} n_{j} \delta_{i j}=\sum_{i} n_{i} n_{i}=1 .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the above $i, j$ refer to $x, y, z$, and $\left\{\sigma_{i}, \sigma_{j}\right\} \equiv \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}+\sigma_{j} \sigma_{i}=2 \delta_{i j}$.

\section{8}

Two particles of mass $m$ are placed in a rectangular box of sides $a>b$ $>c$ in the lowest energy state of the system compatible with the conditions below. The particles interact with each other according to the potential $V=A \delta\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)$. Using first order perturbation theory to calculate the energy of the system under the following conditions:
(a) Particles not identical.
(b) Identical particles of spin zero.
(c) Identical particles of spin one-half with spins parallel.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The unperturbed system can be treated as consisting of two separate single-particle systems and the wave function as a product of two singleparticle wave functions:

$$
\psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=\psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) .
$$

The lowest energy state wave function is thus 

$$
\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{8}{a b c} \sin \frac{\pi x_{1}}{a} \sin \frac{\pi x_{2}}{a} \sin \frac{\pi y_{1}}{b} \sin \frac{\pi y_{2}}{b} \sin \frac{\pi z_{1}}{c} \sin \frac{\pi z_{2}}{c}, \\
\quad \text { for } 0<x_{i}<a, \quad 0<y_{i}<b, \quad 0<z_{i}<c, \quad(i=1,2) \\
0, \quad \text { otherwise },
\end{array}\right.
$$

corresponding to an energy

$$
E_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{m}\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}\right) .
$$

First order perturbation theory gives an energy correction

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E=& \int \psi_{0}^{*}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) A \delta\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) d^{3} r_{1} d^{3} r_{2} \\
=& \int A\left|\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right|^{2} d^{3} r_{1}=\int_{0}^{c} \int_{0}^{b} \int_{0}^{a} A\left(\frac{8}{a b c}\right)^{2} \\
& \times\left(\sin \frac{\pi x_{1}}{a} \sin \frac{\pi y_{1}}{b} \sin \frac{\pi z_{1}}{c}\right)^{4} d x_{1} d y_{1} d z_{1}=\frac{27 A}{8 a b c}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
E^{\prime}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{m}\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}\right)+\frac{27 A}{8 a b c} .
$$

(b) For a system of spin- 0 particles, the total wave function must be symmetric for interchange of a pair of particles. Hence the lowest energy state is

$$
\psi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right),
$$

which is the same as that in (a). The energy to first order perturbation is also

$$
E_{s}^{\prime}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{m}\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}\right)+\frac{27 A}{8 a b c} .
$$

(c) For a system of spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles the total wave function must be antisymmetric. As the spins are parallel, the spin wave function is symmetric and so the spatial wave function must be antisymmetric. As $\frac{1}{a^{2}}<\frac{1}{b^{2}}<\frac{1}{c^{2}}$, the lowest energy state is

$$
\psi_{A}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{211}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{111}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)-\psi_{211}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{111}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right]
$$

where $\psi_{111}(\mathbf{r})$ and $\psi_{211}(\mathbf{r})$ are the ground and first excited single-particle states respectively. The unperturbed energy is

First order perturbation theory gives

$$
E_{A 0}=\frac{\hbar \pi^{2}}{m}\left(\frac{5}{2 a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}\right) .
$$

Therefore

$$
\Delta E=\int \psi_{A}^{*}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) A \delta\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{A}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) d^{3} r_{1} d^{3} r_{2}=0 .
$$

$$
E_{A}^{\prime}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{m}\left(\frac{5}{2 a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}\right) .
$$

\section{9}

A porphyrin ring is a molecule which is present in chlorophyll, hemoglobin, and other important compounds. Some aspects of the physics of its molecular properties can be described by representing it as a onedimensional circular path of radius $r=4 \AA$, along which 18 electrons are constrained to move.

(a) Write down the normalized one-particle energy eigenfunctions of the system, assuming that the electrons do not interact with each other.

(b) How many electrons are there in each level in the ground state of the molecule?

(c) What is the lowest electronic excitation energy of the molecule? What is the corresponding wavelength (give a numerical value) at which the molecule can absorb radiation?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Denote the angular coordinate of an electron by $\theta$. The Schrödinger equation of an electron

has solution

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \theta^{2}} \psi(\theta)=E \psi(\theta)
$$

$$
\psi(\theta)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{i k \theta} .
$$

The single-valuedness of $\psi(\theta), \psi(\theta)=\psi(\theta+2 \pi)$, requires $k=0, \pm 1, \pm 2 \cdots$. The energy levels are given by 

$$
E=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}} k^{2} .
$$

(b) Let $0,1,2, \ldots$ denote the energy levels $E_{0}, E_{1}, E_{2}, \ldots$ respectively. In accordance with Pauli's exclusion principle, $E_{0}$ can accommodate two electrons of opposite spins, while $E_{k}, k \neq 0$, which is 2-fold degenerate with respect to $\pm|k|$, can accommodate four electrons. Thus the electron configuration of the ground state of the system is

$$
0^{2} 1^{4} 2^{4} 3^{4} 4^{4}
$$

(c) The electron configuration of the first excited state is

$$
0^{2} 1^{4} 2^{4} 3^{4} 4^{3} 5^{1}
$$

The energy difference between $E_{4}$ and $E_{5}$ is

$$
\Delta E=E_{5}-E_{4}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}\left(5^{2}-4^{2}\right)=\frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}
$$

and the corresponding absorption wavelength is

$$
\lambda=\frac{c h}{\Delta E}=\frac{8 \pi^{2}}{9}\left(\frac{m c}{h}\right) r^{2}=\frac{8 \pi^{2}}{9} \times \frac{4^{2}}{0.0242}=5800 \AA
$$

where $\frac{h}{m c}=0.0242 \AA$ is the Compton wavelength of electron.

\section{0}

A large number $N$ of spinless fermions of mass $m$ are placed in a onedimensional oscillator well, with a repulsive $\delta$-function potential between each pair:

$$
V=\frac{k}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{i}^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{2} \sum_{i \neq j} \delta\left(x_{i}-x_{j}\right), \quad k, \lambda>0 .
$$

(a) In terms of normalized single-particle harmonic oscillator functions $\psi_{n}(x)$, obtain the normalized wave functions and energies for the three lowest energies. What are the degeneracies of these levels?

(b) Compute the expectation value of $\sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{i}^{2}$ for each of these states. For partial credit, you may do parts (a) and (b) with $\lambda=0$. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Treat the $\delta$-function potential as perturbation. As for a system of fermions, the total wave function is antisymmetric, the zero-order wave function for the system can be written as the determinant

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{n_{1} \cdots n_{N}}\left(x_{1} \cdots x_{N}\right) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N !}}\left|\begin{array}{cccc}
\psi_{n_{1}}\left(x_{1}\right) & \psi_{n_{1}}\left(x_{2}\right) & \cdots & \psi_{n_{1}}\left(x_{N}\right) \\
\psi_{n_{2}}\left(x_{1}\right) & \psi_{n_{2}}\left(x_{2}\right) & \cdots & \psi_{n_{2}}\left(x_{N}\right) \\
\vdots & \vdots & & \vdots \\
\psi_{n_{N}}\left(x_{1}\right) & \psi_{n_{N}}\left(x_{2}\right) & \cdots & \psi_{n_{N}}\left(x_{N}\right)
\end{array}\right| \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N !}} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{n_{1}}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \psi_{n_{N}}\left(x_{N}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $n_{i}$ label the states from ground state up, $P$ denotes permutation of $x_{i}$ and $\delta_{P}=+1,-1$ for even and odd permutations respectively. On account of the $\delta$-function, the matrix elements of the perturbation Hamiltonian are all zero. Thus the energy levels are

$$
E_{\left(n_{1}, n_{2}, \cdots, n_{N}\right)}=\left\langle n_{1} \cdots n_{N}|H| n_{1} \cdots n_{N}\right\rangle=\hbar \omega\left(\frac{N}{2}+\sum_{i=1}^{N} n_{i}\right)
$$

where $\omega=\sqrt{k / m}$

(i) For the ground state: $n_{1} \cdots n_{N}$ are respectively $0,1, \ldots, N-1$, the energy is

$$
E_{(0, \ldots, N-1)}=\hbar \omega\left[\frac{N}{2}+\frac{N(N-1)}{2}\right]=\frac{\hbar \omega}{2} N^{2},
$$

and the wave function is

$$
\psi_{0,1, \ldots, N-1}\left(x_{1} \cdots x_{N}\right)=\frac{1}{N !} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \psi_{N-1}\left(x_{N}\right)\right] .
$$

(ii) For the first excited state: $n_{1} \cdots n_{N}$ are respectively $0,1, \ldots, N-$ $2, N$, the energy is

$$
E_{(0, \ldots, N-2, N)}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega\left(N^{2}+2\right),
$$

and the wave function is

$$
\psi_{0,1 \cdots N-2, N}\left(x_{1} \cdots x_{N}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N !}} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \psi_{N-2}\left(x_{N-1}\right) \psi_{N}\left(x_{N}\right)\right]
$$

(iii) For the second excited state: $n_{1} \cdots n_{N}$ are respectively either 0,1 , $\ldots N-2, N+1$, or $0,1, \ldots N-3, N-1, N$. The energy is

$$
E_{(0, \ldots N-2, N+1)}=E_{(0,1, \ldots N-3, N-1, N)}=\frac{\hbar \omega}{2}\left(N^{2}+4\right)
$$

and the corresponding wave functions are

$$
\begin{gathered}
\psi_{0, \ldots N-2, N+1}\left(x_{1} \cdots x_{N}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N !}} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots\right. \\
\left.\psi_{N-2}\left(x_{N-1}\right) \psi_{N+1}\left(x_{N}\right)\right] \\
\psi_{0, \ldots N-3, N-1, N}\left(x_{1} \cdots x_{N}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N !}} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots\right. \\
\left.\psi_{N-3}\left(x_{N-2}\right) \psi_{N-1}\left(x_{N-1}\right) \psi_{N}\left(x_{N}\right)\right]
\end{gathered}
$$

It can be seen that the ground and first excited states are nondegenerate, where the second excited state is two-fold degenerate.

(b) For stationary states,

$$
2\langle T\rangle=\left\langle\sum_{i} x_{i} \partial_{i} V\left(x_{1} \cdots x_{N}\right)\right\rangle
$$

As

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\langle\sum_{k} x_{k} \partial_{k} \sum_{i \neq j} \frac{\lambda}{2} \delta\left(x_{i}-x_{j}\right)\right\rangle=0 \\
\left\langle\sum_{i} x_{i} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i}}\left(\frac{k}{2} \sum_{j} x_{j}^{2}\right)\right\rangle=k\left\langle\sum_{i} x_{i}^{2}\right\rangle
\end{gathered}
$$

we have

$$
2\langle T\rangle=k\left\langle\sum_{i}^{N} x_{i}^{2}\right\rangle .
$$

The virial theorem

$$
\langle T\rangle=\left\langle V\left(x_{1} \cdots x_{N}\right)\right\rangle,
$$

or

$$
E=2\langle T\rangle
$$

then gives 

$$
\left\langle\sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{i}^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{m \omega^{2}} E .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left\langle 0\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{i}^{2}\right| 0\right\rangle=\frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega} N^{2} \\
&\left\langle 1\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{i}^{2}\right| 1\right\rangle=\frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}\left(N^{2}+2\right) \\
&\left\langle 2\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{i}^{2}\right| 2\right\rangle=\left\langle 2^{\prime}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{i}^{2}\right| 2^{\prime}\right\rangle=\frac{\hbar}{2 m \omega}\left(N^{2}+4\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $|0\rangle,|1\rangle,|2\rangle$, and $\left|2^{\prime}\right\rangle$ are the ground state, the first excited state and the two second excited states respectively.

\section{1}

What is the energy difference in $\mathrm{eV}$ between the two lowest rotational levels of the HD molecule? The $\mathrm{HD}$ (D is a deuteron) distance is $0.75 \AA$.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

The rotational energy levels are given by

$$
E_{J}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} J(J+1) .
$$

Thus for the two lowest levels,

$$
\Delta E_{10}=\left.\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} J(J+1)\right|_{J=1}-\left.\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} J(J+1)\right|_{J=0}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{I} .
$$

As the mass $m_{D}$ of the deuteron is approximately twice that of the hydrogen nucleus $m_{p}$, we have

$$
I=\mu r^{2}=\frac{2 m_{p} \cdot m_{p}}{2 m_{p}+m_{p}} r^{2}=\frac{2}{3} m_{p} r^{2}
$$

and hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_{10}=& \frac{\hbar^{2}}{\frac{2}{3} m_{P} r^{2}}=\frac{3}{2} \frac{(\hbar c)^{2}}{m_{p} c^{2}} \frac{1}{r^{2}}=\frac{1.5}{938 \times 10^{6}} \\
& \times\left(\frac{6.582 \times 10^{-16} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}{0.75 \times 10^{-8}}\right)^{2}=1.11 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{eV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{2}

Consider the (homonuclear) molecule $N_{2}^{14}$. Use the fact that a nitrogen nucleus has spin $I=1$ in order to derive the result that the ratio of intensities of adjacent rotational lines in the molecule's spectrum is $2: 1$.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

In the adiabatic approximation, the wave function of $N_{2}$ molecule whose center of mass is at rest can be expressed as the product of the electron wave function $\psi_{e}$, the total nuclear spin wave function $\psi_{s}$, the vibrational wave function $\psi_{0}$, and the rotational wave function $\psi_{I}$; that is, $\psi=\psi_{e} \psi_{s} \psi_{0} \psi_{I}$. For the molecular rotational spectrum, the wave functions of the energy states involved in the transition have the same $\psi_{e}, \psi_{0}$, but different $\psi_{s}, \psi_{I}$. For interchange of the nitrogen nuclei, we have $\psi_{e} \psi_{0} \rightarrow \psi_{e} \psi_{0}$ or $-\psi_{e} \psi_{0}$.

The $N$ nucleus is a boson as its spin is 1 , so the total nuclear spin of the $N_{2}$ molecule can only be 0,1 or 2 , making it a boson also. For the exchange operator $\hat{P}$ between the $N$ nuclei, we have

$$
\hat{P} \psi_{s}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
+\psi_{s} & \text { for } S=0,2, \\
-\psi_{s} & \text { for } S=1,
\end{array} \quad \hat{P} \psi_{I}= \begin{cases}\psi_{I} & \text { for } I=\text { even integer } \\
-\psi_{I} & \text { for } I=\text { odd integer }\end{cases}\right.
$$

As $N_{2}$ obeys the Bose-Einstein statistics, the total wave function does not change on interchange of the two nitrogen nuclei. So for adjacent rotational energy levels with $\Delta I=1$, one must have $S=0$ or 2 , the other $S=1$, and the ratio of their degeneracies is $[2 \times 2+1+2 \times 0+1]:(2 \times 1+1)=2: 1$.

For the molecular rotational spectrum, the transition rule is $\Delta J=2$. As $S$ usually remains unchanged in optical transitions, two adjacent lines are formed by transitions from $I=$ even to even and $I=$ odd to odd. Since the energy difference between two adjacent rotational energy levels is very small compared with $\mathrm{kT}$ at room temperature, we can neglect the effect of any heat distribution. Therefore, the ratio of intensities of adjacent spectral lines is equal to the ratio of the degeneracy of $I=$ even rotational energy level to that of the adjacent $I=$ odd rotational energy level, which has been given above as $2: 1$.

\section{3}

(a) Assuming that two protons of $H_{2}^{+}$molecule are fixed at their normal separation of $1.06 \AA$, sketch the potential energy of the electron along an axis passing through the protons.

(b) Sketch the electron wave functions for the two lowest states in $\mathrm{H}_{2}^{+}$, indicating roughly how they are related to hydrogenic wave functions. Which wave function corresponds to the ground state, and why?

(c) What happens to the two lowest energy levels of $H_{2}^{+}$in the limit that the protons are moved far apart?

$($ Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the protons are fixed, the potential energy of the system is that of the electron, apart from the potential energy due to the Coulomb interaction between the nuclei $\frac{e^{2}}{R}$. Thus

$$
V=-\frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}\right|}-\frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|},
$$

where $\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}$ are as shown in Fig. 7.4. When the electron is on the line connecting the two protons, the potential energy is

$$
V=-\frac{e^{2}}{|x|}-\frac{e^{2}}{|R-x|}
$$

where $x$ is the distance from the proton on the left. $V$ is shown in Fig. $7.5$ as a function of $x$. The wave function must be symmetrical or antisymmetrical with respect to the interchange of the protons. Thus the wave functions of the two lowest states are

$$
\psi_{\pm}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \pm \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right],
$$

where $\phi(\mathbf{r})$ has the form of the wave function of the ground state hydrogen atom: 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-647.jpg?height=258&width=481&top_left_y=160&top_left_x=422)

Fig. 7.4

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-647.jpg?height=310&width=435&top_left_y=546&top_left_x=441)

Fig. $7.5$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-647.jpg?height=232&width=479&top_left_y=985&top_left_x=427)

Fig. $7.6$

$$
\phi(r)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}}\left(\frac{\lambda}{a}\right)^{3 / 2} e^{-\lambda r / a}
$$

where $a$ is the Bohr radius and $\lambda$ is a constant. The shape of the two wave functions along the $x$-axis are sketched in Fig. 7.6. It can be seen that the probability that the electron is near the two nuclei is larger for $\psi_{+}$. Hence $\psi_{+}$corresponds to a lower $V$ and is therefore the ground state wave function. The fact that $E_{+}<E_{-}$can also be seen from

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\pm} &=\left\langle\psi_{\pm}|H| \psi_{\pm}\right\rangle \\
&=\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)|H| \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right\rangle \pm\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)|H| \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

since

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)|H| \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right\rangle=\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)|H| \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
&\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)|H| \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle=\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)|H| \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

and all the integrals are negative.

(c) As the protons are being moved apart, the overlap of the two bound states $\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)$ and $\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)$ becomes less and less, and so $\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)|H| \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right\rangle$ and $\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)|H| \phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right\rangle \rightarrow 0$. In other words, the two lowest energy levels will become the same, same as the ground state energy of a hydrogen atom.

\section{4}

Write the Schrödinger equation for atomic helium, treating the nucleus as an infinitely heavy point charge.

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Treating the nucleus as an infinitely heavy point charge, we can neglect its motion, as well as the interaction between the nucleons inside the nucleus and the distribution of the nuclear charge.

The Schrödinger equation is then

$$
\left(\frac{\mathbf{p}_{1}^{2}}{2 m_{e}}+\frac{\mathbf{p}_{2}^{2}}{2 m_{e}}-\frac{2 e^{2}}{R_{1}}-\frac{2 e^{2}}{R_{2}}+\frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{R}_{1}-\mathbf{R}_{2}\right|}\right) \psi\left(\mathbf{R}_{1}, \mathbf{R}_{2}\right)=E \psi\left(\mathbf{R}_{1}, \mathbf{R}_{2}\right)
$$

where $\mathbf{R}_{1}, \mathbf{R}_{2}$ are as shown in Fig. 7.7.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-648.jpg?height=213&width=266&top_left_y=1341&top_left_x=530)

Fig. $7.7$

On the left side of the equation, the first and second terms are the kinetic energies of the electrons, the third and fourth terms correspond to the attractive potentials between the nucleus and the electrons, and the last term is the repulsive potential between the two electrons. 

\section{5}

The excited electronic configuration $(1 s)^{1}(2 s)^{1}$ of the helium atom can exist as either a singlet or a triplet state. Tell which state has the lower energy and explain why. Give an expression which represents the energy separation between the singlet and triplet states in terms of the one-electron orbitals $\psi_{1 s}(\mathbf{r})$ and $\psi_{2 s}(\mathbf{r})$

\section{Solution:}

Electrons being fermions, the total wave function of a system of electrons must be antisymmetric for the interchange of any two electrons. As the spin triplet state of helium atom is symmetric, its spatial wave function must be antisymmetric. In this state the electrons have parallel spins so the probability for them to get close is small (Pauli's principle), and consequently the repulsive energy, which is positive, is small. Whereas for the spin singlet state the reverse is true, i.e., the probability for the two electrons to get close is larger, so is the repulsive energy. Hence the triplet state has the lower energy.

Consider the interaction between the electrons as perturbation. The perturbation Hamiltonian is

$$
H^{\prime}=\frac{e^{2}}{r_{12}},
$$

where $r_{12}=\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|$. For the singlet state, using the one-electron wave functions $\psi_{1 s}, \psi_{2 s}$, we have

$$
{ }^{1} \psi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{1 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{2 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)+\psi_{1 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{2 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right] \chi_{00}
$$

and for the triplet state

$$
{ }^{3} \psi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\psi_{1 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{2 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)-\psi_{1 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{2 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right] \chi_{1 m}
$$

with $m=1,0,-1$. The energy separation between the states is

$$
\Delta E=\left\langle{ }^{1} \psi\left|H^{\prime}\right|^{1} \psi\right\rangle-\left\langle{ }^{3} \psi\left|H^{\prime}\right|^{3} \psi\right\rangle .
$$

With $\psi_{n s}^{*}=\psi_{n s}$, we have

$$
\Delta E=2 \int \frac{e^{2}}{r_{12}}\left[\psi_{1 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{2 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{1 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{2 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)\right] d \mathbf{r}_{1} d \mathbf{r}_{2} .
$$



\section{6}

(a) Suppose you have solved the Schrödinger equation for the singlyionized helium atom and found a set of eigenfunctions $\psi_{N}(\mathbf{r})$.

(1) How do the $\phi_{N}(\mathbf{r})$ compare with the hydrogen atom wave functions?

(2) If we include a spin part $\sigma^{+}$(or $\sigma^{-}$) for spin up (or spin down), how do you combine the $\phi$ 's and $\sigma$ 's to form an eigenfunction of definite spin?

(b) Now consider the helium atom to have two electrons, but ignore the electromagnetic interactions between them.

(1) Write down a typical two-electron wave function, in terms of the $\phi$ 's and $\sigma$ 's, of definite spin. Do not choose the ground state.

(2) What is the total spin in your example?

(3) Demonstrate that your example is consistent with the Pauli exclusion principle.

(4) Demonstrate that your example is antisymmetric with respect to electron interchange.

\section{Solution:}

(a) (1) The Schrödinger equation for singly-charged He atom is the same as that for $\mathrm{H}$ atom with $e^{2} \rightarrow Z e^{2}$, where $Z$ is the charge of the He nucleus. Hence the wave functions for hydrogen-like ion are the same as those for $\mathrm{H}$ atom with the Bohr radius replaced:

$$
r_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{\mu e^{2}} \rightarrow a=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{\mu Z e^{2}},
$$

$\mu$ being the reduced mass of the system. For helium $Z=2$.

(2) As $\phi_{N}$ and $\sigma^{\pm}$belong to different spaces we can simply multiply them to form an eigenfunction of a definite spin.

(b) (1), (2) A He atom, which has two electrons, may be represented by a wave function

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \phi_{N}(1) \phi_{N}(2)\left[\sigma^{+}(1) \sigma^{-}(2)-\sigma^{-}(1) \sigma^{+}(2)\right]
$$

if the total spin is zero, and by

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\phi_{N 1}(1) \phi_{N 2}(2)-\phi_{N 2}(1) \phi_{N 1}(2)\right] \sigma^{+}(1) \sigma^{+}(2)
$$

if the total spin is 1 . (3) If $\sigma^{+}=\sigma^{-}, \phi_{N 1}=\phi_{N 2}$, the wave functions vanish, in agreement with the Pauli exclusion principle. (4) Denote the wave functions by $\psi(1,2)$. Interchanging particles 1 and 2 we have

$$
\psi(2,1)=-\psi(1,2)
$$

\section{7}

Ignoring electron spin, the Hamiltonian for the two electrons of helium atom, whose positions relative to the nucleus are $\mathbf{r}_{i}(i=1,2)$, can be written as

$$
H=\sum_{i=1}^{2}\left(\frac{\mathbf{p}_{i}^{2}}{2 m}-\frac{2 e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{i}\right|}\right)+V, \quad V=\frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|} .
$$

(a) Show that there are 8 orbital wave functions that are eigenfunctions of $\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{V}$ with one electron in the hydrogenic ground state and the others in the first excited state.

(b) Using symmetry arguments show that all the matrix elements of $V$ among these 8 states can be expressed in terms of four of them. [Hint: It may be helpful to use linear combinations of $l=1$ spherical harmonics proportional to

$$
\left.\frac{x}{|\mathbf{r}|}, \frac{y}{|\mathbf{r}|} \text { and } \frac{z}{|\mathbf{r}|} .\right]
$$

(c) Show that the variational principle leads to a determinantal equation for the energies of the 8 excited states if a linear combination of the 8 eigenfunctions of $\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{V}$ is used as a trial function. Express the energy splitting in terms of the four independent matrix elements of $V$.

(d) Discuss the degeneracies of the levels due to the Pauli principle.

$(B u f f a l o)$

\section{Solution:}

Treating $V$ as perturbation, the zero-order wave function is a product of two eigenfunctions $|n, l, m\rangle$ of a hydrogen-like atom. Thus the 8 eigenfunctions for $H_{0}=\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{V}$ with one electron in the hydrogen ground state can be written as

$$
|l m \pm\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\left|(100)_{1}(2 l m)_{2}\right\rangle \pm\left|(2 l m)_{1}(100)_{2}\right\rangle\right]
$$

with $l=0,1, m=-l, \ldots l$, where the subscripts 1 and 2 refer to the two electrons. The corresponding energies are 

$$
E_{b}=E_{1}+E_{2}=-\frac{\mu\left(2 e^{2}\right)^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2}}\left(1+\frac{1}{2^{2}}\right)=-\frac{5 \mu e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} .
$$

To take account of the perturbation we have to calculate the matrix elements

$$
\left\langle l^{\prime} m^{\prime} \pm|V| l m \pm\right\rangle .
$$

As $V$ is rotation-invariant and symmetric in the two electrons and $|l m \pm\rangle$ are spatial rotation eigenstates, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left\langle(100)_{1}\left(2 l^{\prime} m^{\prime}\right)_{2}|V|(100)_{1}(2 l m)_{2}\right\rangle \\
&=\left\langle\left(2 l^{\prime} m^{\prime}\right)_{1}(100)_{2}|V|(2 l m)_{1}(100)_{2}\right\rangle \\
&=\delta_{l l^{\prime}} \delta_{m m^{\prime}} A_{l}, \\
&\left\langle(100)_{1}\left(2 l^{\prime} m^{\prime}\right)_{2}|V|(2 l m)_{1}(100)_{2}\right\rangle \\
&=\left\langle\left(2 l^{\prime} m^{\prime}\right)_{1}(100)_{2}|V|(100)_{1}(2 l m)_{2}\right\rangle \\
&=\delta_{l l^{\prime}} \delta_{m m^{\prime}} B_{l},
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left\langle l^{\prime} m^{\prime}+|V| l m+\right\rangle=\delta_{l l^{\prime}} \delta_{m m^{\prime}}\left(A_{l}+B_{l}\right), \\
&\left\langle l^{\prime} m^{\prime}+|V| l m-\right\rangle=0, \\
&\left\langle l^{\prime} m^{\prime}-|V| l m+\right\rangle=0, \\
&\left\langle l^{\prime} m^{\prime}-|V| l m-\right\rangle=\delta_{l l^{\prime}} \delta_{m m^{\prime}}\left(A_{l}-B_{l}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Because the wave functions were formed taking into account the symmetry with respect to the interchange of the two electrons, the perturbation matrix is diagonal, whence the four discrete energy levels follow:

The first levels $|1 m+\rangle$ have energy $E_{b}+A_{1}+B_{1}$, second levels $|1 m-\rangle$ have energy $E_{b}+A_{1}-B_{1}$, the third level $|00+\rangle$ has energy $E_{b}+A_{0}+B_{0}$, the fourth level $|00-\rangle$ has energy $E_{b}+A_{0}-B_{0}$. Note that the levels $|1 m+\rangle$ and $|1 m-\rangle$ are each three-fold degenerate $(m=\pm 1,0)$.

According to Pauli's principle, we must also consider the spin wave functions. Neglecting spin-orbit coupling, the total spin wave functions are $\chi_{0}$, antisymmetric, a singlet state; $\chi_{1 s_{z}}$, symmetric, a triplet state. Since the total electron wave function must be antisymmetric for interchange of the electrons, we must take combinations as follows, 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&|l m+\rangle \chi_{0} \\
&|l m-\rangle \chi_{1 s_{z}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the degeneracies of the energy levels are

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
E_{b}+A_{0}-B_{0}: & 1 \times 3=3 \\
E_{b}+A_{0}+B_{0}: & 1 \times 1=1 \\
E_{b}+A_{1}-B_{1}: & 3 \times 3=9 \\
E_{b}+A_{1}+B_{1}: & 3 \times 1=3 .
\end{array}
$$

\section{8}

Describe approximate wave functions and energy levels of the lowest set of $P$-states $(L=1)$ of the neutral helium atom, using as a starting basis the known wave functions for the hydrogen atom of nuclear charge $Z$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{1 s} &=\pi^{-1 / 2} a^{-3 / 2} e^{-r / a}, a=a_{0} / Z \\
\psi_{2 p, m_{l}=0} &=(32 \pi)^{-1 / 2} a^{-5 / 2} r e^{-r / 2 a} \cos \theta, \text { etc. }
\end{aligned}
$$

(a) There are a total of 12 states ( 2 spin components $\times 2$ spin components $\times 3$ orbital components) which you should classify according to the Russell-Saunders coupling scheme, giving all the appropriate quantum numbers. Be sure that the states are properly antisymmetrized.

(b) Give an estimate (to the nearest integer) for the values of " $Z$ " to use for each of the two orbital wave functions. What energy above the ground state results? What mathematical process could be used to calculate the optimum $Z$ values?

(c) Write down an integral which gives the separation between two subsets of these 12 states due to the Coulomb repulsion between the two electrons. Which states are lower in energy?

(d) Which of these $P$-states, if any, can decay to the atomic ground state by the emission of a single photon. (Electric dipole only)

(e) Do there exist any other excited states with $L=1$ which can decay to any one of the $P$-states discussed above by emission of a single photon by electric dipole interaction? If so, give an example of such a state in the usual scheme of spectroscopic notation. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Since $\mathbf{L}=\mathrm{l}_{1}+\mathrm{l}_{2}, L_{z}=l_{1 z}+l_{2 z}, L=1$ means that $l_{1}, l_{2}=0,1$ or 1,0 , i.e. one electron is in $1 s$ state, the other in $2 p$ state. For convenience, Dirac's bra-ket notation is used to represent the states. The symmetrized and antisymmetrized spatial wave functions are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\psi_{1}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=1\right\rangle+\left|2 p, m_{l}=1\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=1\right\rangle-\left|2 p, m_{l}=1\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{3}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=0\right\rangle+\left|2 p, m_{l}=0\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=0\right\rangle-\left|2 p, m_{l}=0\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{5}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=-1\right\rangle+\left|2 p, m_{l}=-1\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=-1\right\rangle-\left|2 p, m_{l}=-1\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the total wave functions to be antisymmetric, we must choose the products of the spin singlet state $\chi_{00}$ and the symmetric space wave functions $\left|\psi_{1}\right\rangle,\left|\psi_{3}\right\rangle,\left|\psi_{5}\right\rangle$, forming three singlet states $\left|\psi_{i}\right\rangle \chi_{00}(i=1,3,5)$; and the products of the spin triplet states $\chi_{11}$ and the antisymmetric space wave functions $\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle,\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle,\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle$, forming nine triplet states $\left|\psi_{i}\right\rangle \chi_{11}(i=2,4,6$, $m=0, \pm 1)$. To denote the twelve states in the coupling representation, we must combine the above antisymmetrized wave functions: The wave functions of the three singlet states are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{ }^{1} P_{1}: \quad\left|m_{J}=1\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{1}\right\rangle \chi_{00} \\
&\left|m_{J}=0\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{3}\right\rangle \chi_{00} \\
&\left|m_{J}=-1\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{5}\right\rangle \chi_{00} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The wave functions of the nine triplet states are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{ }^{3} P_{2}: \quad\left|m_{J}=2\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{11}, \\
&\left|m_{J}=1\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{10}+\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{11}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$



$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|m_{J}=0\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{6}}\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}+\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{10}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{6}}\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{11} \\
\left|m_{J}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}+\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{10}\right) \\
\left|m_{J}=-2\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1} \\
{ }^{3} P_{1}: \quad\left|m_{J}=1\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{10}-\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{11}\right) \\
\left|m_{J}=0\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}-\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{11}\right) \\
\left.\left|m_{J}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}-\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{10}\right) \\
{ }^{3} P_{0}:\left|m_{J}=0\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}-\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{10}+\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{11}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

(b) As the electron cloud of the $2 p$ orbits is mainly outside the electron cloud of the $1 s$ orbit, the value of $Z$ of the $|1 s\rangle$ wave function is 2 and that of the $|2 p\rangle$ wave function is 1 . The energy levels of a hydrogen-like atom is given by

$$
E=-\frac{m Z^{2} e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2} n^{2}} .
$$

Hence the energy of the $2 p$ states above the ground state is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=-\frac{m c^{2}}{2}\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{1}{2^{2}}-\frac{2^{2}}{1}\right) \\
&=\frac{0.51 \times 10^{6}}{2} \times\left(\frac{1}{137}\right)^{2} \times \frac{15}{4} \\
&=51 \mathrm{eV}
\end{aligned}
$$

The optimum $Z$ can be obtained from shielding effect calculations using the given wave functions.

(c) Denote the two subsets of symmetric and antisymmetric spatial wave functions with a parameter $\varepsilon=\pm 1$ and write

$$
\left|\psi_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|1 s\rangle|2 p\rangle+\varepsilon|2 p\rangle|1 s\rangle) .
$$

The repulsive interaction between the electrons,

$$
H^{\prime}=\frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|},
$$

results in a splitting of the energy levels of the two sets of wave functions. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\psi_{\varepsilon}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \psi_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\langle1 s \left|\left\langle2 p \left|+\varepsilon\left\langle 2 p|\langle 1 s|) H^{\prime}(|1 s\rangle|2 p\rangle+\varepsilon|2 p\rangle|1 s\rangle)\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\\
&=\left\langle 1 s 2 p\left|H^{\prime}\right| 1 s 2 p\right\rangle+\varepsilon\left\langle 1 s 2 p\left|H^{\prime}\right| 2 p 1 s\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

the splitting is equal to twice the exchange integral in the second term of the right-hand side, i.e.,

$$
K=\int \psi_{1 s}^{*}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi_{1 s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{2 p}^{*}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{2 p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|} d \mathbf{r}_{1} d \mathbf{r}_{2}
$$

As $K>0$, the energy of the triplet state $(\varepsilon=-1)$ is lower than that of the singlet state. (This is to be expected since when the space wave function is antisymmetric, the two electrons having parallel spins tend to avoid each other.)

(d) The selection rules for electric dipole radiation transition are $\Delta L=$ $0, \pm 1 ; \Delta S=0 ; \Delta J=0, \pm 1$ and a change of parity. Hence the state that can transit to the ground state ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ is the ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state.

(e) Such excited states do exist. For example, the ${ }^{3} P_{1}$ state of the electronic configuration $2 p 3 p$ can transit to any of the above ${ }^{3} P_{2,1,0}$ states through electric dipole interaction.

\section{9}

Justify, as well as you can, the following statement: "In the system of two ground state $\mathrm{H}$ atoms, there are three repulsive states and one attractive (bound) state."

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

In the adiabatic approximation, when discussing the motion of the two electrons in the two $\mathrm{H}$ atoms we can treat the distance between the nuclei as fixed and consider only the wave functions of the motion of the two electrons. For total spin $S=1$, the total spin wave function is symmetric for interchange of the two electrons and so the total space wave function is antisymmetric. Pauli's principle requires the electrons, which in this case have parallel spins, to get away from each other as far as possible. This means that the probability for the two electrons to come near each other is small and the states are repulsive states. As $S=1$ there are three such states. For total spin $S=0$, the space wave function is symmetric. The probability of the electrons being close together is rather large and so the state is an attractive one. As $S=0$, there is only one such state.

\section{0}

In a simplified model for a deuteron the potential energy part of the Hamiltonian is $V=V_{a}(r)+V_{b}(r) \mathbf{s}_{n} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{p}$. The spin operators for the two spin-1/2 particles are $\mathbf{s}_{n}$ and $\mathbf{s}_{p}$; the masses are $m_{n}$ and $m_{p} ; V_{a}$ and $V_{b}$ are functions of the particle separation $r$.

(a) The energy eigenvalue problem can be reduced to a one-dimensional problem in the one variable $r$. Write out this one-dimensional equation.

(b) Given that $V_{a}$ and $V_{b}$ both are negative or zero, state (and explain) whether the ground state is singlet or triplet.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) In units where $\hbar=1$, we have for the singlet state $(S=0)$ of the deuteron,

$$
\mathbf{s}_{n} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{p}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbf{s}_{n}+\mathbf{s}_{p}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{s}_{n}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{s}_{p}^{2}=-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{3}{2} \times 2\right)=-\frac{3}{4}
$$

and the potential energy

$$
V_{\text {singlet }}=V_{a}(r)-\frac{3}{4} V_{b}(r) .
$$

The Hamiltonian is then

$$
H=-\frac{1}{2 m_{n}} \nabla_{n}^{2}-\frac{1}{2 m_{p}} \nabla_{p}^{2}+V_{a}(r)-\frac{3}{4} V_{b}(r),
$$

whence the Hamiltonian describing the relative motion 

$$
H_{r}=-\frac{1}{2 m} \nabla_{r}^{2}+V_{a}(r)-\frac{3}{4} V_{b}(r)
$$

where $\nabla_{r}^{2}$ is the Laplacian with respect to the relative position coordinate $r=\left|\mathbf{r}_{p}-\mathbf{r}_{n}\right|, m=\frac{m_{n} m_{p}}{m_{n}+m_{p}}$ is the reduced mass of the two particles.
