\left[\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}(E-g|x|)\right] \psi(x)=0 .
$$

As

$$
\left[\frac{m E}{\hbar^{2}}\right]=L^{-2},\left[\frac{m g}{\hbar^{2}}\right]=L^{-3}
$$

we have

$$
\left[\left(\frac{m E}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{3}\right]=\left[\left(\frac{m g}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

or

$$
[E]=\left[\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m} g^{2}\right)^{1 / 3}\right]
$$

Hence the eigenvalue has the form

$$
E_{n}=\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m} g^{2}\right)^{1 / 3} f(n)
$$

where $f(n)$ is a function of a positive integer $n$.

(b) First normalize the trial wave function. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
1 &=\int \psi^{*}(x) \psi(x) d x=|c|^{2} \int\left[\theta(x+a) \theta(a-x)\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right)\right]^{2} d x \\
&=|c|^{2} \int_{-a}^{a}\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right)^{2} d x=\frac{2 a}{3}|c|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
|c|^{2}=\frac{3}{2 a} .
$$

Then calculate the average value of the Hamiltonian:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H} &=\int \psi^{*} H \psi d x \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x) \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi(x) d x+g \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x)|x| \psi(x) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x)|x| \psi(x) d x=&|c|^{2}\left\{-\int_{-a}^{0} x\left(1+\frac{x}{a}\right)^{2} d x+\int_{0}^{a} x\left(1-\frac{x}{a}\right)^{2} d x\right\} \\
=& a^{2}|c|^{2} / 6=a / 4 \\
\frac{d}{d x} \psi(x)=& c \delta(x+a) \theta(a-x)\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right) \\
&-c \theta(x+a) \delta(x-a)\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right) \\
&+c \theta(x+a) \theta(x-a)\left(-\frac{|x|}{x} \frac{1}{a}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{\prime}(x) \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi(x) d x &=\left.\psi(x) \frac{d}{d x} \psi(x)\right|_{-\infty} ^{\infty}-\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{d \psi}{d x}\right)^{2} d x \\
&=-\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{d \psi}{d x}\right)^{2} d x \\
&=-|c|^{2} \int_{-a}^{a}\left(-\frac{|x|}{x a}\right)^{2} d x \\
&=-2|c|^{2} / a=-3 / a^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{2 m a^{2}}+\frac{a}{4} g .
$$

For its minimum value, let

$$
\frac{\delta \bar{H}}{\delta a}=-\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{m a^{3}}+\frac{g}{4}=0
$$

which gives

$$
a=\left(\frac{12 \hbar^{2}}{g m}\right)^{1 / 3} \text {. }
$$

Hence an estimate of the ground state energy is

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(\frac{g m}{12 \hbar^{2}}\right)^{2 / 3}+\frac{g}{4}\left(\frac{12 \hbar^{2}}{g m}\right)^{1 / 3}=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{3 \hbar^{2} g^{2}}{2 m}\right)^{1 / 3} .
$$

(c) If we had used a trial function $\psi=c \theta(x+a) \theta(a-x)$ and repeat the above calculation, we would have obtained

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(\mathbf{x})|x| \psi d x &=a^{2} c^{2} \\
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi d x &=0 \\
1 &=\int_{-a}^{a} \psi^{2} d x=2 a c^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{g a^{2} c^{2}}{2 a c^{2}}=\frac{g a}{2} .
$$

As

$$
\frac{\partial \bar{H}}{\partial a}=\frac{g}{2} \neq 0,
$$

$\bar{H}$ obviously has no extreme point. Therefore this trial function is not a good one.

(d) We first choose a trial wave function for the first excited state. It must be orthogonal to that of the ground state. Then use the above method to find a variational estimate of the first excited state energy.

\section{9}

(Use nonrelativistic methods to solve this problem.) Most mesons can be described as bound quark-antiquark states $(q \bar{q})$. Consider the case of a meson made of a $(q \bar{q})$ pair in an $s$-state. Let $m_{q}$ be the quark mass.

Assume the potential binding the $q$ to the $\bar{q}$ can be written as $V=$ $\frac{A}{r}+B r$ with $A<0$ and $B>0$. You are asked to find a reasonable approximation to the ground state energy of this system in terms of $A, B, m_{q}$ and $\hbar$. Unfortunately, for a class of trial functions appropriate to this problem, a cubic equation has to be solved. If this happens to you, and you do not want to spend your limited time trying to solve such a cubic equation, you may complete your solution for the case $A=0$ (without loss of credit). Please express your final answer in terms of a numerical constant, which you should explicitly evaluate, multiplying a function of $B, m_{q}$ and $\hbar$. (Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

\section{Method I}

Use for the trial function the wave function of a ground state hydrogen atom.

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r})=e^{-r / a}
$$

and calculate

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H}=&\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle /\langle\psi \mid \psi\rangle \\
=& \int_{0}^{\infty} d r r^{2} e^{-r / a}\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)\right.\\
&\left.+A r^{-1}+B r\right] e^{-r / a} / \int_{0}^{\infty} d r r^{2} e^{-2 r / a} \\
=& \frac{3 B a}{2}+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{A}{a},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mu=\frac{m_{q}}{2}$ is the reduced mass of the $q \bar{q}$ system. Vary a to minimize $\bar{H}$ by letting $\frac{\delta \vec{H}}{\delta a}=0$, which gives

$$
\frac{3}{2} B a^{3}-A a-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{\mu}=0 .
$$

When $A=0$, the solution is $a=\left(\frac{2 \hbar^{2}}{3 B \mu}\right)^{1 / 3}$. Hence the estimated ground state energy is 

$$
E_{g}=\vec{H}=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{36 B^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m_{q}}\right)^{1 / 3}=2.48\left(\frac{B^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m_{q}}\right)^{1 / 3} .
$$

\section{Method II}

Another estimate of the energy of the ground state can be obtained from the uncertainty principle. Consider

$$
H=\frac{p^{2}}{2 \mu}+\frac{A}{r}+B r .
$$

As the principle requires

$$
p_{x} x \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}, p_{y} y \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}, p_{z} z \geq \frac{\hbar}{2},
$$

we take the equal sign for the ground state and obtain

$$
H=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 \mu x^{2}}+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 \mu y^{2}}+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 \mu z^{2}}+\frac{A}{r}+B r .
$$

To minimize $H$, let

$$
\frac{\partial H}{\partial x}=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{4 \mu x^{2}}-\frac{A x}{r^{3}}+\frac{B x}{r}=0 .
$$

As $H$ is symmetric with respect to $x, y, z$, when it reaches the optimal value, we have $x=y=z$, or $r=\sqrt{3} x$, and the above equation becomes

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 \mu x^{3}}-\frac{A}{3 \sqrt{3} x^{2}}+\frac{B}{\sqrt{3}}=0 .
$$

Letting $A=0$ we get

$$
x=3^{\frac{1}{6}}\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 \mu B}\right)^{1 / 3}, \quad \text { or } \quad r=\left(\frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{4 \mu B}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

Hence

$$
\vec{H}=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{8 \mu x^{2}}+B r=2\left(\frac{9}{2} \frac{\hbar^{2} B^{2}}{m_{q}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}=3.30\left(\frac{\hbar^{2} B^{2}}{m_{q}}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$



\section{0}

An attractive potential well in one dimension satisfies

$$
V(x)<0, \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} V(x) d x \text { finite, } \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} x^{2} V(x) d x \text { finite }
$$

(a) Using trial wave functions of the form $e^{-\beta x^{2} / 2}$, prove that the potential has at least one bound state.

(b) Assuming further that the potential is quite weak $\left(\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} V(x) d x\right.$, $\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} x^{2} V(x) d x$ are both "small"), find the best upper bound (for the energy) for this class of trial functions.

(c) In a dimensionless statement, state precisely what is meant by "small" in part (b).

\section{Solution:}

(a) The given trial function is the ground state wave function of a onedimensional harmonic oscillator. We shall use the normalized function

$$
\psi(x)=\left(\frac{\beta}{\pi}\right)^{1 / 4} e^{-\beta x^{2} / 2}
$$

where $\beta=\frac{m \omega}{\hbar}$. The Hamiltonian can be written as

$$
H=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}+V(x)-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}=H_{0}+V(x)-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2} .
$$

As

$$
\left\langle\psi\left|H_{0}\right| \psi\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega,
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H} &=\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega+\left\langle\psi\left|V(x)-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}\right| \psi\right\rangle \\
&=\frac{1}{4} \hbar \omega+\langle\psi|V(x)| \psi\rangle=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m} \beta+\langle\psi|V(x)| \psi\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\frac{\delta \bar{H}}{\delta \beta}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}+\frac{1}{2 \beta}\langle\psi|V(x)| \psi\rangle-\left\langle\psi\left|x^{2} V(x)\right| \psi\right\rangle .
$$

Since when $\beta \rightarrow 0$

$$
\frac{1}{2 \beta}\langle\psi|V| \psi\rangle=\frac{1}{2 \beta} \sqrt{\frac{\beta}{\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} V d x \rightarrow-\infty
$$

as $V$ is negative,

$$
\left\langle\psi\left|x^{2} V\right| \psi\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{\beta}{\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{2} V d x \rightarrow 0
$$

we have $\frac{\delta \bar{H}}{\delta \beta} \rightarrow-\infty$ as $\beta \rightarrow 0$. When $\beta \rightarrow \infty, \frac{\delta \bar{H}}{\delta \beta} \rightarrow \frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}>0$. Therefore $\frac{\delta \bar{H}}{\delta \beta}=0$ at least for a certain positive $\beta$, say $\beta_{0}$. Thus the trial function is suitable and the energy for the corresponding state is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{E}=\bar{H}\left(\beta_{0}\right) &=\frac{\hbar^{2} \beta_{0}}{4 m}+2 \beta_{0}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}+\left\langle\psi\left|x^{2} V(x)\right| \psi\right\rangle\right) \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2} \beta_{0}}{4 m}+2 \beta_{0}\left\langle\psi\left|x^{2} V(x)\right| \psi\right\rangle<0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore the system has at least one bound state. Note that we have used the fact $\left(\frac{\delta \bar{H}}{\delta \beta}\right)_{\beta_{0}}=0$, which gives, for $\beta=\beta_{0}$,

$$
\langle\psi|V(x)| \psi\rangle=2 \beta_{0}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}+\left\langle\psi\left|x^{2} V(x)\right| \psi\right\rangle\right) .
$$

(b) (c) Let $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} V(x) d x=A, \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{2} V(x) d x=B$. The requirement that $A$ and $B$ are small means that the potential $V(x)$ can have large values only in the region of small $|x|$. Furthermore, for large $|x|, V(x)$ must attenuate rapidly. This means that we can expand the integrals

$$
\begin{aligned}
&A_{1}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\beta x^{2}} V(x) d x \simeq \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(1-\beta x^{2}\right) V(x) d x=A-\beta B, \\
&B_{1}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{2} e^{-\beta x^{2}} V(x) d x \simeq \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{2} V(x) d x=B,
\end{aligned}
$$

Then the minimization condition $\frac{\delta \bar{H}}{\delta \beta}=0$ gives

$$
\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}+\frac{A_{1}}{2 \sqrt{\pi \beta}}-\sqrt{\frac{\beta}{\pi}} B_{1}=0,
$$

or

$$
\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}+\frac{A}{2 \sqrt{\pi \beta}}-\frac{3}{2} \sqrt{\frac{\beta}{\pi}} B=0
$$

i.e.

$$
\sqrt{\beta}=\frac{\sqrt{\pi} \hbar^{2}}{12 m B}+\sqrt{\frac{\pi \hbar^{4}}{144 m^{2} B^{2}}+\frac{A}{3 B}} .
$$

Hence the bound state energy is estimated to be

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{E} &=-\frac{\hbar^{2} \beta}{4 m}+2 \beta \sqrt{\frac{\beta}{\pi}} B \\
&=\left(\frac{\sqrt{\pi} \hbar^{2}}{12 m B}+\sqrt{\frac{\pi \hbar^{4}}{144 m^{2} B^{2}}+\frac{A}{3 B}}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{12 m}-\sqrt{\frac{\hbar^{4}}{36 m^{2}}+\frac{4 A B}{3 \pi}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\mathrm{A}$ and $\mathrm{B}$ are both negative, $\bar{E}<0$. Hence

$$
\bar{E}<\left(\frac{\sqrt{\pi} \hbar^{2}}{12 m B}+\sqrt{\frac{\pi \hbar^{4}}{144 m^{2} B^{2}}+\frac{A}{3 B}}\right)^{2}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}\right)
$$

Since for two arbitrary real numbers $a$ and $b,(a+b)^{2} \geq 4 a b$, the upper bound of $\bar{E}$ is given by

$$
\bar{E}<4\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m}\right) \frac{\sqrt{\pi} \hbar^{2}}{12 m B} \sqrt{\frac{\pi \hbar^{4}}{144 m^{2} B^{2}}+\frac{A}{3 B}}=\frac{-\pi \hbar^{6}}{144 m^{3} B^{2}} \sqrt{1+\frac{48 m^{2} A B}{\pi \hbar^{4}}} .
$$

\section{1}

A particle moves in an attractive central potential $V(r)=-g^{2} / r^{3 / 2}$. Use the variational principle to find an upper bound to the lowest $s$-state energy. Use a hydrogenic wave function as your trial function.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

As the trial function we use the normalized ground state wave function of the hydrogen atom,

$$
\psi=\left(\frac{k^{3}}{8 \pi}\right)^{1 / 2} e^{-k r / 2}
$$

to calculate the energy. For an $s$-state, $l=0$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\vec{H}(k) &=\int \psi^{*} H \psi d \tau \\
&=\int \psi^{*}\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)+V(r)\right] \psi d \tau \\
&=\frac{k^{3}}{8 \pi} \cdot 4 \pi \int_{0}^{+\infty} r^{2} e^{-k r / 2}\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)-\frac{g^{2}}{r^{3 / 2}}\right] e^{-k r / 2} d r \\
&=\frac{k^{3}}{2} \int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-k r}\left[-g^{2} r^{1 / 2}+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} k r-\frac{k^{2} \hbar^{2}}{8 m} r^{2}\right] d r \\
&=\frac{k^{3}}{2}\left[\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m k}-\frac{\sqrt{\pi} g^{2}}{2 k^{3 / 2}}\right] \\
&=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 m} k^{2}-\frac{\sqrt{\pi} g^{2}}{4} k^{3 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\bar{H}$ to be a minimum, $\frac{\partial \bar{H}}{\partial k}=0$, i.e. $\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m} k-\frac{3 \sqrt{\pi}}{8} g^{2} k^{1 / 2}=0$, giving two solutions $k_{1}=0$,

$$
k_{2}^{1 / 2}=\frac{3 \sqrt{\pi} g^{2} m}{2 \hbar^{2}} .
$$

The first solution implies $\psi=0$ and is to be discarded. On the other hand, if $k_{2}^{1 / 2}=\frac{3 \sqrt{\pi} g^{2} m}{2 \hbar^{2}}, \bar{H}$ reaches a minium $-\frac{27 \pi^{2} g^{8} m^{3}}{128 \hbar^{6}}$. This is the upper bound to the lowest $s$-state energy.

\section{2}

A system of spin-1 particles consists of an incoherent mixture of the following 3 pure spin states, each state being equally probable, i.e. one third of the particles are in state $\psi^{(1)}$, etc.

$$
\psi^{(1)}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(2)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(3)}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

(a) Find the polarization vector for each of these 3 pure states.

(b) Find the polarization vector per particle $\mathbf{P}$ for the above mixed state. (c) Calculate the density matrix $\rho$ for the system and verify that $\operatorname{Tr} \rho=1$

(d) Using $\rho$, find the polarization vector $\mathbf{P}$ and check against (b).

Reminder: for $J=1$,

$$
J_{x}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 1 & 0 \\
1 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{array}\right), J_{y}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -i & 0 \\
i & 0 & -i \\
0 & i & 0
\end{array}\right), J_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The polarization vector for a state $i$ is given by

$$
\mathbf{P}^{(i)}=\left\langle\psi^{(i)}|\mathbf{J}| \psi^{(i)}\right\rangle .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P_{x}^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1 & 0 \\1 & 0 & 1 \\0 & 1 & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=0 \text {, } \\
& P_{y}^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & -i & 0 \\i & 0 & -i \\0 & i & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=0 \text {, } \\
& P_{z}^{(1)}=(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & -1\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=1 \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

and so $\mathbf{P}^{(1)}=(0,0,1)$.

Similarly we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{P}^{(2)}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, 0,-\frac{1}{2}\right), \\
&\mathbf{P}^{(3)}=(0,0,-1) .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) For the incoherent mixture, $\mathbf{P}$ is the sum of the polarization vectors:

$$
\mathbf{P}=\frac{1}{3}\left[\mathbf{P}^{(1)}+\mathbf{P}^{(2)}+\mathbf{P}^{(3)}\right]=\frac{1}{6}(\sqrt{2}, 0,-1) .
$$

(c) In terms of the orthonormal vectors

$$
|1\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right),|2\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right),|3\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\psi^{(1)}\right\rangle &=|1\rangle,\left|\psi^{(2)}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|2\rangle+|3\rangle), \\
\left|\psi^{(3)}\right\rangle &=|3\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Generally a state can be expressed as

$$
\left|\psi^{(i)}\right\rangle=\sum_{n=1}^{3} C_{n}^{i}|n\rangle,
$$

where $i=1,2,3$. The density matrix is defined as

$$
\rho=\sum_{i} \omega^{(i)}\left|\psi^{(i)}\right\rangle\left\langle\psi^{(i)}\right|
$$

where $\omega^{(i)}$ is the probability that the system is in the pure state $\left|\psi^{(i)}\right\rangle$, or

$$
\rho_{m n}=\sum_{i} \omega^{i} C_{n}^{i *} C_{m}^{i}=\frac{1}{3} \sum_{i} C_{n}^{i *} C_{m}^{i}
$$

as $\omega^{(i)}=\frac{1}{3}$ for all $i$ in the present case. The matrix of the coefficients is

$$
C=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

and so

$$
\rho=\frac{1}{3} C^{+} C=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{1}{3} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{6} \\
0 & \frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and

$$
\operatorname{Tr} \rho=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{2}=1 .
$$

(d) As $\mathbf{P}=\langle J\rangle=\operatorname{Tr}(\rho J)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P_{x}=\operatorname{Tr}\left(\rho J_{x}\right)=\operatorname{Tr}\left\{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & \frac{1}{3} & 0 \\\frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{6} \\\frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{2} & \frac{1}{6}\end{array}\right)\right\}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{6}\right)=\sqrt{2} / 6, \\
& P_{y}=\operatorname{Tr}\left(\rho J_{y}\right)=\operatorname{Tr}\left\{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & \frac{-i}{3} & 0 \\\frac{i}{6} & \frac{i}{6} & \frac{-i}{6} \\\frac{i}{6} & \frac{i}{2} & \frac{-i}{6}\end{array}\right)\right\}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\frac{i}{6}-\frac{i}{6}\right)=0 \\
& P_{z}=\operatorname{Tr}\left(\rho J_{z}\right)=\operatorname{Tr}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1}{3} & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & -\frac{1}{6} \\0 & 0 & -\frac{1}{2}\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{2}=-\frac{1}{6},
\end{aligned}
$$

same as in (b)

\section{3}

The deuteron is a bound state of a neutron and a proton in which the two spins are coupled with a resultant total angular momentum $S=1$. By absorbing a gamma ray of more than $2.2 \mathrm{MeV}$ the deuteron may disintegrate into a free neutron and a free proton.

(a) Write a wave function for the final state in the reaction $\gamma+D \rightarrow n+p$ using plane waves and being sure to include properly the spin coordinates for the two particles. Assume that the interaction with the gamma ray is via electric dipole coupling.

(b) Suppose the neutron and the proton are to be detected far apart from each other after the disintegration of the deuteron. Looking at this in the center-of-mass system, what correlations will be found in time and space, and in spin? Assume that the target consists of unpolarized deuterons. (You may use the following definition of spin correlation: If a proton is detected with spin "up", what is the probability that the corresponding deuteron will also be detected with spin "up"?)

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The ground state deuteron ${ }^{3} S_{1}$ has positive parity. The electric dipole transition requires a change of parity between the initial and final states. Hence the parity of the free $(n, p)$ system must have parity -1. Assume that the wave function of $(n, p)$ can be written as $\Psi(n, p) \sim$ $\psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{n}, \mathbf{r}_{p}\right) \chi(n, p)$. For $\chi=\chi_{1}^{3}$, after the nucleons are interchanged the wave function becomes $\Psi(p, n)=(-1)^{l} \Psi(n, p)$. For $\chi=\chi_{0}^{1}$, after the nucleons are interchanged, the wave function becomes $\Psi(p, n)=(-1)^{l+1} \Psi(n, p)$. A fermion system must be antisymmetric with respect to interchange of any two particles, which means that for the former case, $l=1,3, \ldots$, and for the latter case, $l=0,2,4, \ldots$, and so the parities are $-1(l=$ odd $)$ and $+1(l=$ even $)$ respectively. Considering the requirement we see that only states with $\chi=\chi_{1}^{3}$, i.e. spin triplet states, are possible. Further, $S=1, L=1,3, \ldots$, and so $J=0,1,2, \ldots$. As the deuterons are unpolarized, its spin wave function has the same probability of being $\chi_{11}, \chi_{10}$ or $\chi_{1-1}$. Therefore, after the transition $(n, p)$ can be represented by the product of a plane wave and the average spin wave function:

$$
\Psi(n, p) \sim e^{i\left(\mathbf{k}_{n} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{n}+\mathbf{k}_{p} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{p}\right)} \cdot e^{-i\left(\omega_{n} t+\omega_{p} t\right)}(1 / \sqrt{3})\left(\chi_{11}+\chi_{10}+\chi_{1-1}\right) .
$$

(b) The correlation of time and space is manifested in conservation of energy and conservation of momentum. In the center-of-mass coordinates, if the energy of the proton is measured to be $E_{p}$, the energy of the neutron is $E_{n}=E_{\mathrm{cm}}-E_{p}$; if the momentum of the proton is $\mathbf{p}$, the momentum of the neutron is $-\mathbf{p}$. Let $\alpha$ be the spin function for "up" spin, and $\beta$ be that for "down" spin. Then $\chi_{11}=\alpha(n) \alpha(p), \chi_{1-1}=\beta(n) \beta(p), \chi_{10}=$ $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[\alpha(n) \beta(p)+\alpha(p) \beta(n)]$, and the spin wave function is

$$
\chi(n, p)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[\alpha(n)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \beta(n)\right] \alpha(p)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \alpha(n)+\beta(n)\right] \beta(p) .
$$

Thus, if the spin of $p$ is detected to be up, we have

$$
\chi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \alpha(n) \alpha(p)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} \beta(n) \alpha(p)
$$

Hence the probability that the spin state of $n$ is also up is

$$
\frac{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}}{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}\right)^{2}}=\frac{2}{3}
$$

\section{4}

(a) You are given a system of two identical particles which may occupy any of three energy levels $\varepsilon_{n}=n \varepsilon, n=0,1,2$. The lowest energy state, $\varepsilon_{0}=0$, is doubly degenerate. The system is in thermal equilibrium at temperature $T$. For each of the following cases, determine the partition function and the energy and carefully enumerate the configurations.

(1) The particles obey Fermi statistics.

(2) The particles obey Bose statistics.

(3) The (now distinguishable) particles obey Boltzmann statistics.

(b) Discuss the conditions under which fermions or bosons might be treated as Boltzmann particles.

$(B u f f a l o)$

\section{Solution:}

Denote the two states with $\varepsilon_{0}=0$ by $A$ and $B$ and the states with $\varepsilon$ and $2 \varepsilon$ by 1 and 2 respectively.

(1) The system can have the following configurations if the particles obey fermi statistics:

Configuration: $(\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B})(\mathrm{A}, 1)(\mathrm{B}, 1)(\mathrm{A}, 2)(\mathrm{B}, 2)(1,2)$

Energy: $0 \varepsilon \varepsilon 2 \varepsilon 2 \varepsilon 3 \varepsilon$

Thus the partition function is $Z=1+2 e^{-\varepsilon}+2 e^{-2 \varepsilon}+e^{-3 \varepsilon}$, and the mean energy is $\bar{\varepsilon}=\left(2 \varepsilon e^{-\varepsilon}+4 \varepsilon e^{-2 \varepsilon}+3 \varepsilon e^{-3 \varepsilon}\right) / Z$

(2) If the particles obey Bose statistics, in addition to the above states, the following configurations are also possible:

Configuration: (A, A) $(\mathrm{B}, \mathrm{B})(1,1)(2,2)$

Energy: $002 \varepsilon 4 \varepsilon$

Hence the partition function and average energy are

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z &=3+2 e^{-\varepsilon}+3 e^{-2 \varepsilon}+e^{-3 \varepsilon}+e^{-4 \varepsilon}, \\
\bar{\varepsilon} &=\left(2 \varepsilon e^{-\varepsilon}+6 \varepsilon e^{-2 \varepsilon}+3 \varepsilon e^{-3 \varepsilon}+4 \varepsilon e^{-4 \varepsilon}\right) / Z .
\end{aligned}
$$

(3) for destinguisable particles obeying Boltzmann statistics, more configurations are possible. These are $(\mathrm{B}, \mathrm{A}),(1, \mathrm{~A}),(1, \mathrm{~B}),(2, \mathrm{~A}),(2, \mathrm{~B})$ and $(2,1)$. Thus we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z &=4+4 e^{-\varepsilon}+5 e^{-2 \varepsilon}+2 e^{-3 \varepsilon}+e^{-4 \varepsilon} \\
\bar{\varepsilon} &=\left(4 \varepsilon e^{-\varepsilon}+10 \varepsilon e^{-2 \varepsilon}+6 \varepsilon e^{-3 \varepsilon}+4 \varepsilon e^{-4 \varepsilon}\right) / Z
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Fermions and bosons can be treated as Boltzmann particles when the number of particles is much less than the number of energy levels, for then the exchange effect can be neglected.

\section{5}

Consider a free electron near a boundary surface.

(a) If $\phi_{k}(x)$ 's are the electron eigenfunctions, show that the function

$$
u(x, t)=\sum_{k} \phi_{k}^{*}(x) \phi_{k}(0) \exp \left(\frac{-\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

satisfies a diffusion-type equation. Identify the corresponding diffusion coefficient.

(b) From the theory of diffusion how would you expect $u(0, t)$ to be influenced by the presence of a boundary at a distance $l$ from the origin? Would the boundary be felt immediately or only after an elapse of time?

(c) Examine the expression for $u(0, t)$ as a sum over $k$ as given in (a). What is the range of $\varepsilon_{k}$ which contribute significantly to $u(0, t)$ at the time when the influence of the boundary is felt by the electron?

\section{Solution:}

(a) The wave function $\phi_{k}(x)$ satisfies the Schrödinger equation of a free particle

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2} \phi_{k}(\mathbf{x})=\varepsilon_{k} \phi_{k}(\mathbf{x}) .
$$

Thus

$$
\nabla^{2} u(\mathbf{x}, t)=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} \sum_{k} \varepsilon_{k} \phi_{k}^{*}(\mathbf{x}) \phi_{k}(0) \exp \left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

Since

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} u(\mathbf{x}, t)=-\frac{1}{\hbar} \sum_{k} \varepsilon_{k} \phi_{k}^{*}(\mathbf{x}) \phi_{k}(0) \exp \left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

$u(x, t)$ satisfies the following diffusion-type equation:

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} u(\mathbf{x}, t)=\frac{\hbar}{2 m} \nabla^{2} u(\mathbf{x}, t) .
$$

The corresponding diffusion coefficient is $\hbar / 2 m$.

(b) Initially $u(x, 0)=\delta(x)$. When $t>0$, the function $u$ starts diffusing to both sides. The boundary will not be felt by the electron before a lapse of time.

(c) Suppose the boundary is at $x=l$. The solution of the diffusion equation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
u(\mathbf{x}, t)=& c \exp \left[-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\right] \\
& \times\left\{\exp \left[-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t} x^{2}\right]-\exp \left[-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}(x-2 l)^{2}\right]\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

When there is no boundary (i.e., $l \rightarrow \infty$ ), the solution is

$$
u(\mathbf{x}, t)=c \exp \left[-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\right] \exp \left(-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t} x^{2}\right) .
$$

From the above two expressions, we see that only when $\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}(0-2 l)^{2} \sim 1$, i.e., at $t \sim 2 m l^{2} / \hbar$, will the electron start to feel the existence of the boundary.

Consider

$$
u(0, t)=\sum_{k}\left|\phi_{k}(0)\right|^{2} \exp \left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

Only states $\phi_{k}$ for which the energy $\varepsilon_{k}$ is such that $\frac{\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar} \lesssim 1$ will contribute significantly to $u(0, t)$. At the time $t \sim \frac{2 m l^{2}}{\hbar}$, we require $\varepsilon_{k} \leq \frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m l^{2}}$ for $\phi_{k}$ to make a significant contribution.

\section{6}

Symmetrizing Maxwell's equations by postulating a magnetic monopole charge of strength $g$, Dirac derived a quantization condition

$$
\frac{e g}{\hbar c}=n,
$$

where $n=$ an integer, $e$ is the electronic charge, and $g$ is the magnetic charge.

In the spirit of the Bohr-Sommerfeld quantization procedure, derive semi-classically a similar quantization condition by quantizing the angular momentum of the field in the "mixed dipole" system shown in Fig. 8.6. Hint: How is the angular momentum of the field related to the Poynting vector?

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-721.jpg?height=456&width=423&top_left_y=567&top_left_x=455)

Fig. $8.6$

\section{Solution:}

The electromagnetic field consists of two components

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=\frac{e\left(\mathbf{x}-\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{x}-\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right|^{3}} \\
\mathbf{B} &=\frac{g\left(\mathbf{x}+\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{x}+\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right|^{3}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In cylindrical coordinates $(\rho, \theta, z)$, we can write $\mathbf{r}=2 a \mathbf{e}_{3}$, where $a=$ $|\mathbf{r}| / 2$, and

$$
\mathbf{x}=\rho \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{1}+\rho \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{2}+z \mathbf{e}_{3},
$$

The angular momentum of the electromagnetic field is

$$
\mathbf{L}_{e m}=\frac{1}{4 \pi c} \int \mathbf{x} \times(\mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B}) d^{3} x .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B} &=e g \frac{\left(\mathbf{x}-\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right) \times\left(\mathbf{x}+\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{x}-\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right|^{3} \cdot\left|\mathbf{x}+\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right|^{3}} \\
&=\frac{e g \mathbf{x} \times \mathbf{r}}{\left[\left(\mathbf{x}-\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right)^{2}\left(\mathbf{x}+\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right)^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}}, \\
\mathbf{x} \times(\mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B}) &=\frac{e g\left[(\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{r}) \mathbf{x}-x^{2} \mathbf{r}\right]}{\left[\left(\rho^{2}+z^{2}+a^{2}-2 a z\right)\left(\rho^{2}+z^{2}+a^{2}+2 a z\right)\right]^{3 / 2}} \\
&=\frac{2 a e g\left(z \rho \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{1}+z \rho \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{2}-\rho^{2} \mathbf{e}_{3}\right)}{\left[\left(\rho^{2}+z^{2}+a^{2}\right)-4 a^{2} z^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}}, \\
\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \cos \theta d \theta &=\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \sin \theta d \theta=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{L}_{e m} &=-\frac{a e g}{2 \pi c} \mathbf{e}_{3} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} d z \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\rho^{3} d \rho}{\left[\left(\rho^{2}+z^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{2}-4 a^{2} z^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}} \\
&=-\mathbf{e}_{3}\left(\frac{e g}{c}\right) \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} d t \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{s^{3} d s}{\left[\left(s^{2}+t^{2}+1\right)^{2}-4 t^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $s=\rho / a, t=z / a$. It can be shown that

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} d t \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{s^{3} d s}{\left[\left(s^{2}+t^{2}+1\right)^{2}-4 t^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}}=1
$$

Hence

$$
\mathbf{L}_{e m}=-\frac{e g}{c} \mathbf{e}_{3} .
$$

The quantization condition is therefore

$$
\left|\mathbf{L}_{e m z}\right|=\frac{e g}{c}=n \hbar,
$$

or

$$
\frac{e g}{\hbar c}=n, \quad n=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots
$$



\section{7}

In a crude picture, a metal is viewed as a system of free electrons enclosed in a well of potential difference $V_{0}$. Due to thermal agitations, electrons with sufficiently high energies will escape from the well. Find and discuss the emission current density for this model.

(Buffalo)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-723.jpg?height=251&width=511&top_left_y=491&top_left_x=411)

Fig. $8.7$

\section{Solution:}

The system of free electrons can be considered as an electron gas of volume $V$ which obeys the Fermi statistics. At absolute temperature $T$ the number density of electrons with momenta between $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{P}+d \mathbf{P}$, where $\mathbf{P}=\left(P_{x}, P_{y}, P_{z}\right)$, is

$$
\frac{d N}{V}=\frac{1}{V} \cdot \frac{d P_{x} d P_{y} d P_{z}}{e^{(\varepsilon-\mu) / k T}+1} \cdot \frac{2 V}{h^{3}}
$$

where the factor 2 is the degeneracy due to the electrons having two spin directions.

Consider the number of electrons, $j_{n}$, leaving $V$ in the $z$ direction per unit cross sectional area per unit time. Such electrons must have a speed

$$
v_{z}=\frac{P_{z}}{m} \geq \frac{1}{m} \sqrt{2 m V_{0}} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
j_{n}=& \int v_{z} \frac{d N}{V}=\frac{2}{m h^{3}} \int_{\sqrt{2 m V_{0}}}^{\infty} P_{z} d P_{z} \\
& \times \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{d P_{x} d P_{y}}{\exp \left\{\left[\frac{1}{2 m}\left(P_{x}^{2}+P_{y}^{2}+P_{z}^{2}\right)-\mu\right] / k T\right\}+1},
\end{aligned}
$$

or, by setting $P_{x}^{2}+P_{y}^{2}=P_{r}^{2}, d P_{x} d P_{y}=2 \pi P_{r} d P_{r}$, and neglecting the number 1 in the denominator,

$$
\begin{aligned}
j_{n} & \approx \frac{4 \pi}{m h^{3}} \int_{\sqrt{2 m V_{0}}}^{\infty} P_{z} d P_{z} \int_{0}^{\infty} \exp \left\{-\frac{1}{k T}\left[\frac{1}{2 m}\left(P_{z}^{2}+P_{r}^{2}\right)-\mu\right]\right\} P_{r} d P_{r} \\
&=\frac{4 \pi k T}{h^{3}} \int_{\sqrt{2 m V_{0}}}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{k T}\left(\frac{P_{z}}{2 m}-\mu\right)\right] P_{z} d P_{z} \\
&=\frac{4 \pi m k^{2} T^{2}}{h^{3}} e^{-\left(V_{0}-\mu\right) / k T} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The electric current density is then

$$
j_{e}=-e j_{n}=-\frac{4 \pi m e k^{2} T^{2}}{h^{3}} e^{-\left(V_{0}-\mu\right) / k T} .
$$

Note that in the above, to simplify the integration, we have assumed

$$
k T \ll \frac{1}{2 m} \cdot 2 m V_{0}-\mu=V_{0}-\mu .
$$

At $T=0$ the electron number density is

$$
n=\frac{2}{h^{3}} \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{3} P_{0}^{3}=\frac{1}{3 \pi^{2} \hbar^{3}}\left(2 m \mu_{0}\right)^{3 / 2}
$$

where $P_{0}, \mu_{0}$, are the limiting momentum and energy. At ordinary temperatures we have

$$
\mu \approx \mu_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(3 \pi^{2} n\right)^{2 / 3} .
$$

The quantity $V_{0}-\mu$ is the work function of the metal and the emission of electrons from incandescent cathodes is known as Richardson's effect.

\section{8}

It is generally recognized that there are at least three different kinds of neutrinos. They can be distinguished by the reactions in which the neutrinos are created or absorbed. Let us call these three types of neutrino $\nu_{e}, \nu_{\mu}$ and $\nu_{\tau}$. It has been speculated that each of the neutrinos has a small but finite rest mass, possibly different for each type. Let us suppose, for this exam question, that there is a small perturbing interaction between these neutrino types, in the absence of which all three types have the same nonzero rest mass $M_{0}$. Let the matrix element of this perturbation have the same real value $\hbar \omega_{1}$ between each pair of neutino types. Let it have zero expectation value in each of the states $\nu_{e}, \nu_{\mu}$ and $\nu_{\tau}$.

(a) A neutrino of type $\nu_{e}$ is produced at rest at time zero. What is the probability, as a function of time, that the neutrino will be in each of the other two states?

(b) [Can be answered independently of (a)] An experiment to detect these "neutrino oscillations" is being performed. The flight path of the neutrinos is 2000 meters. Their energy is $100 \mathrm{GeV}$. The sensitivity is such that the presence of $1 \%$ of neutrinos of one type different from that produced at the start of the flight path can be measured with confidence. Take $M_{0}$ to be 20 electron volts. What is the smallest value of $\hbar \omega_{1}$ that can be detected? How does this depend on $M_{0}$ ?

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) In the representation of $\left|\nu_{e}\right\rangle,\left|\nu_{\mu}\right\rangle$ and $\left|\nu_{\tau}\right|$, the matrix of the Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{lll}
M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0}
\end{array}\right)
$$

The Schrödinger equation

$$
\frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{\partial \Psi}{\partial t}+H \Psi=0
$$

where $\Psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}a_{1} \\ a_{2} \\ a_{3}\end{array}\right), a_{i}$ being the wave function for state $\nu_{i}$, has the matrix form

$$
i \hbar\left(\begin{array}{c}
\dot{a}_{1} \\
\dot{a}_{2} \\
\dot{a}_{3}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2} \\
a_{3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

with the initial condition

$$
a_{1}(0)=1, a_{2}(0)=a_{3}(0)=0 .
$$

The solution is

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}(t)=e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(\frac{2}{3} e^{i \omega_{1} t}+\frac{1}{3} e^{-i 2 \omega_{1} t}\right) \\
a_{2}(t)=\frac{1}{3} e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(e^{-2 \omega_{1} t}-e^{i \omega_{1} t}\right) \\
a_{3}(t)=\frac{1}{3} e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(e^{-2 \omega_{1} t}-e^{i \omega_{1} t}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence the probabilities of the neutrino being in states $\nu_{\mu}$ and $\nu_{\tau}$ are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
P\left(\nu_{\mu}\right)=\left|a_{2}(t)\right|^{2}=\frac{2}{9}\left(1-\cos 3 \omega_{1} t\right), \\
P\left(\nu_{\tau}\right)=\left|a_{3}(t)\right|^{2}=\frac{2}{9}\left(1-\cos 3 \omega_{1} t\right) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

(b) The time of flight of $\nu_{e}$ is $\Delta t=\frac{l}{v}$ in the laboratory time, or $\Delta \tau=$ $\Delta t \sqrt{1-\left(\frac{v}{c}\right)^{2}} \approx \frac{l}{c} \frac{M_{0}}{E}$, where $E$ is the total energy, in the rest frame of $\nu_{e}$. For $P\left(\nu_{\mu}\right) \geq 1 \%$, i.e.,

$$
\frac{2}{9}\left[1-\cos \left(3 \omega_{1} \Delta \tau\right)\right] \gtrsim 0.01
$$

we require

$$
\omega_{1} \geq \frac{\cos ^{-1} 0.955}{3 \Delta \tau}=\frac{0.301}{3 \Delta \tau}=\frac{0.1 c E}{l M_{0}},
$$

or

$$
\hbar \omega_{1} \geq \frac{0.1 \times 3 \times 10^{8} \times 100 \times 10^{9} \times 6.58 \times 10^{-16}}{2000 \times 20}=0.05 \mathrm{eV}
$$

\section{9}

To a good approximation, an electron in a crystal lattice experiences a periodic potential as shown in Fig. 8.8.:

It is a theorem (Floquet's), and a physical fact, that the spectrum of any such periodic potential sparates into continuous "bands" with forbidden "gaps". To construct a very crude model of (the lowest band of) this effect, imagine that the barriers are high, so that the set of "ground states" $|n\rangle$ $\left(-\infty<n<+\infty\right.$ ) (one for each well) are approximate eigenstates. Call $E_{0}$ the energy of each $|n\rangle$. Now suppose $\varepsilon=|\varepsilon| e^{i \alpha}$ is the (small) amplitude for tunneling between any two nearest-neighbor wells (probability for $|n-1\rangle \leftarrow$ $|n\rangle \rightarrow \mid n+1>$ is $|\varepsilon|^{2}$ ). Set up a Hermitian Hamiltonian that describes this. Compute the energy $E(\theta)$ of the state(s)

$$
|\theta\rangle=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{+\infty} e^{i n \theta}|n\rangle
$$

What is the width of your band?

(Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-727.jpg?height=130&width=635&top_left_y=812&top_left_x=349)

Fig. $8.8$

\section{Solution:}

We write the Hamiltonian as a matrix, choosing $|n\rangle$ as basis vectors. Supposing

$$
H|n\rangle=E_{0}\left(1-\varepsilon-\varepsilon^{*}\right)|n\rangle+E_{0} \varepsilon|n+1\rangle+E_{0} \varepsilon^{*}|n-1\rangle
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle m|H| n\rangle &=\int \psi^{*}(x-m a) H \psi(x-n a) d x \\
&=E_{0} \int \psi^{*}(x-m a) \psi(x-n a) d x \\
&=\delta_{m n} E_{0}\left(1-\varepsilon-\varepsilon^{*}\right)+\delta_{m, n+1} \varepsilon E_{0}+\delta_{m, n-1} \varepsilon^{*} E_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used the assumption that tunneling occurs only between adjacent potential wells and the amplitude for tunneling to the right is $\varepsilon=|\varepsilon| e^{i \alpha}$, that to the left is $\varepsilon^{*}=|\varepsilon| e^{-i \alpha}$. Thus the matrix of $H$ is 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-728.jpg?height=407&width=1126&top_left_y=168&top_left_x=90)

$|1\rangle$

$|2\rangle$

$|3\rangle \ldots \ldots \ldots$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
H|\theta\rangle=& E_{0} \sum_{n=-\infty}^{+\infty} e^{i n \theta}|n\rangle\left(1-\varepsilon-\varepsilon^{*}\right)+E_{0} \sum_{n=-\infty}^{+\infty} e^{i n \theta}\left(\varepsilon|n+1\rangle+\varepsilon^{*}|n-1\rangle\right) \\
&=E_{0}(1-2|\varepsilon| \cos \alpha)|\theta\rangle+E_{0} \sum_{n=-\infty}^{+\infty}\left[e^{i(n-1) \theta} \varepsilon+e^{i(n+1) \theta} \varepsilon^{*}\right]|n\rangle \\
&=E_{0}[1-2|\varepsilon| \cos \alpha+2|\varepsilon| \cos (\theta-\alpha)]|\theta\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the energy eigenvalue of $|\theta\rangle$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\theta} &=E_{0}[1-2|\varepsilon|(\cos \alpha-\cos (\theta-\alpha))] \\
&=E_{0}\left[1-4|\varepsilon| \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \sin \left(\frac{\theta}{2}-\alpha\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

From these results it can be concluded as follows:

(i) Since a continuous variation of $\theta$ results in a continuous variation of the energy, the energy levels become an energy band. Furthermore, when $\theta=\alpha, E_{\theta}=E_{\max }=E_{0}\{1+2|\varepsilon|(1-\cos \alpha)\}$, and when $\theta=\pi+\alpha, E_{0}=$ $E_{\min }=E_{0}\{1-2|\varepsilon|(1+\cos \alpha)\}$. So the width of the band is $E_{\max }-E_{\min }=$ $4|\varepsilon| E_{0}$

(ii) When $\alpha$, which depends on the shape of the periodic potential well, is sufficintly small, tunneling between neighboring wells always results in a lowering of the ground state energy.

\section{0}

Consider an idealized (point charge) $\mathrm{Al}$ atom $(Z=13, A=27)$. If a negative lepton or meson is captured by this atom it rapidly cascades down to the lower $n$ states which are inside the electron shells. In the case of $\mu$-capture:

(a) Compute the energy $E_{1}$ for the $\mu$ in the $n=1$ orbit; estimate also a mean radius. Neglect relativistic effects and nuclear motion.

(b) Now compute a correction to $E_{1}$ to take into account the nuclear motion.

(c) Find a perturbation term to the Hamiltonian due to relativistic kinematics, ignoring spin. Estimate the resulting correction to $E_{1}$.

(d) Define a nuclear radius. How does this radius for $\mathrm{Al}$ compare to the mean radius for the $n=1$ orbit from (a)? Discuss qualitatively what happens to the $\mu^{-}$when the $\mu^{-}$atomic wave function overlaps the nucleus substantially. What happens to a $\pi^{-}$under the circumstances? Information that may be relevant:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
M_{\mu}=105 \mathrm{MeV} / c^{2}, & \operatorname{SPIN}(\mu)=1 / 2 \\
M_{\pi}=140 \mathrm{MeV} / c^{2}, & \operatorname{SPIN}(\pi)=0
\end{array}
$$

(Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) We shall neglect the effects of the electrons outside the nucleus and consider only the motion of the $\mu$ in the Coulomb field of the $\mathrm{Al}$ nucleus. The energy levels of $\mu$ in a hydrogen-like atom of nuclear charge $Z$ (in the nonrelativistic approximation) are given by

$$
E_{n}=-\frac{m e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \frac{Z^{2}}{n^{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1} &=-\frac{m}{m_{e}} \frac{m_{e} e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} Z^{2}=-\frac{105}{0.51} \times 13.6 \times 13^{2} \mathrm{eV} \\
&=-0.4732 \mathrm{MeV}, \\
a &=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{Z m e^{2}}=\frac{m_{e}}{Z m} \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m_{e} e^{2}}=\frac{0.5}{13 \times 105} \times 0.53 \AA \\
&=1.9 \times 10^{-4} \AA .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) To take into account the motion of the nucleus, we simply have to replace the mass $m$ of the meson with its reduced mass $\mu=\frac{M m}{M+m}, M$ being the nuclear mass. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1}^{\prime} &=\frac{\mu}{m} E_{1}=\frac{1}{1+\frac{m}{M}} E_{1}=\frac{-0.4732}{1+\frac{105}{27 \times 938}} \\
&=-0.471 \mathrm{MeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Taking into account the relativistic effects the muon kinetic energy is

$$
T=\sqrt{p^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}}-m c^{2}=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}-\frac{p^{4}}{8 m^{3} c^{2}}+\cdots .
$$

The relativistic correction introduces a perturbation Hamiltonian

$$
H=-\frac{p^{4}}{8 m^{3} c^{2}} .
$$

The energy correction $\Delta E$ for $E_{1}$ is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=\left\langle 100\left|-\frac{p^{4}}{8 m^{3} c^{2}}\right| 100\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left\langle 100\left|\frac{p^{2}}{2 m} \cdot \frac{p^{2}}{2 m}\right| 100\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left\langle 100\left|\left(H+\frac{Z e^{2}}{r}\right)\left(H+\frac{Z e^{2}}{r}\right)\right| 100\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left\langle 100\left|\left(E_{1}+\frac{Z e^{2}}{r}\right)^{2}\right| 100\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

For a rough estimate, take $r \approx a$. Then

$$
\Delta E \approx-\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left(E_{1}+\frac{Z e^{2}}{a}\right)^{2}=-\frac{\left|E_{1}\right|^{2}}{2 m c^{2}}=\frac{-0.47^{2}}{2 \times 105}=1.06 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{MeV}
$$

(d) In the scattering of neutrons by a nucleus, an attractive strong nuclear force sets in when the distance becomes smaller than $r \sim r_{0} A^{\frac{1}{3}}$, where $r_{0} \sim 1.2 \times 10^{-13} \mathrm{~cm}$ and $\mathrm{A}$ is the atomic mass number of the nucleus. $r$ is generally taken to be the radius of the nuclues, which for $\mathrm{Al}$ is

$$
r=1.2 \times 10^{-5} \times 27^{\frac{1}{3}}=3.6 \times 10^{-5} \AA .
$$

The difference between the radius of the nucleus of $\mathrm{Al}$ and that of the first orbit of the $\mu$-mesic atom is not very large, so that there is a considerable overlap of the wave functions of the nucleus and the muon. This effect, due to the finite volume of the nucleus, will give rise to a positive energy correction. At the same time there is also a large interaction between the muon and the magnetic moment of the nucleus.

Under similar circumstances, for the $\pi$-mesic atom there is also the volume effect, but no interaction with the magnetic moment of the nucleus as pions have zero spin.

\section{1}

Low energy neutrons from a nuclear reactor have been used to test gravitationally induced quantum interference. In Fig. 8.9, neutrons incident from $\mathrm{A}$ can follow two paths of equal lengths, $\mathrm{ABCEF}$ and $\mathrm{ABDEF}$, and interfere after they recombine at $E$. The three parallel slabs which diffract the neutrons are cut from one single crystal. To change the effects of the gravitational potential energy, the system can be rotated about the line ABD. Suppose $\phi$ is the angle of this rotation $(\phi=0$ for the path ABCEF horizontal).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-731.jpg?height=274&width=631&top_left_y=1173&top_left_x=349)

Fig. $8.9$

(a) Show that the phase difference at point $E$ due to the effect of gravity can be expressed as $\beta=q \sin \phi$, where $q=K \lambda S^{2} \sin 2 \theta, \lambda$ being the neutron wavelength and $K$ an appropriate constant which depends on neutron mass $m$, gravitational acceleration $g$, Planck's constant $\hbar$, and numerical factors. Determine the constant $K$. Assume here that the gravitational potential energy differencs are very small compared to the neutron kinetic energies. (b) The neutron wavelength used in the experiment is $1.45 \AA$. What is the corresponding kinetic energy in electron volts?

(c) If $S=4 \mathrm{~cm}, \theta=22.5^{\circ}$, and $\lambda=1.45 \AA$, how many maxima should be seen by a neutron counter at $F$ as $\phi$ goes from $-90^{\circ}$ to $+90^{\circ}$ ?

Mass of neutron $=939 \mathrm{MeV} / c^{2}, \hbar c=1.97 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{MeV} \cdot \mathrm{cm}$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The wave function of the incident neutrons can be taken as

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=c e^{(i \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{r}-i E t) / \hbar}
$$

where $c$ is a constant. When they move along a certain orbit from $x=0$ to $x=l$ it becomes

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=c \exp \left[\frac{i}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{l} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d x-\frac{i}{\hbar} E t\right]
$$

Thus the phase is

$$
\varphi=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{l} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E t
$$

The neutrons are separated at point $B$ into two beams 1 and 2 , for which $\varphi_{B_{1}}=\varphi_{B_{2}}$.

The situations on lines $\mathrm{BC}$ and $\mathrm{DE}$ are same and so for the two neutron beams, $\Delta \varphi_{C B}=\Delta \varphi_{E D}$. On line $\mathrm{BD}$, we can set the gravitational potential $V=0, E=E_{0}$, and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi_{D B} &=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{S} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} \cdot \frac{S}{v_{0}} \\
&=\frac{1}{\hbar}\left(\sqrt{2 m E_{0}} S-\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} S\right)=\frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $v_{0}$ is the neutron velocity $\frac{1}{m} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}$.

On line CE, the gravitational potential is

$$
V=m g h=m g \cdot \overline{B E} \sin \theta \sin \phi, \quad \text { with } \overline{B E}=2 S \cos \theta
$$

i.e.,

$$
V=m g S \sin 2 \theta \sin \phi
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi_{E C} &=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{S} \sqrt{2 m\left(E_{0}-V\right)} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} t \\
&=\frac{S}{\hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} \frac{S}{\sqrt{\frac{2\left(E_{0}-V\right)}{m}}} \\
&=S \frac{\sqrt{2 m E_{0}}}{2 \hbar}\left(2 \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the phase difference of the two beams of neutrons at point $F$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta &=\Delta \varphi_{D B}-\Delta \varphi_{E C}=\frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}\left(1-2 \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}\left[1-2\left(1-\frac{V}{2 E_{0}}\right)+\left(1+\frac{V}{2 E_{0}}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{3 V S}{4 \hbar E_{0}} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $V \ll E_{0}$. Thus

$$
\beta=q \sin \phi,
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
q & \approx \frac{3}{2} \frac{m^{2} g}{\hbar \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} S^{2} \sin 2 \theta \\
&=K \lambda S^{2} \sin 2 \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda &=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{p}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{\sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} \\
K &=\frac{3}{4} \frac{m^{2} g}{\pi \hbar^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The neutron has momentum

$$
p=\frac{h}{\lambda}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{\lambda}
$$

and hence kinetic energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{k} &=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{2}{m c^{2}}\left(\frac{\pi \hbar c}{\lambda}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{2}{939 \times 10^{6}}\left(\frac{\pi \times 1.97 \times 10^{-5}}{1.45 \times 10^{-8}}\right)^{2} \\
&=0.039 \mathrm{eV}
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) In the range $-1<\sin \phi<1$, the number of maxima seen by a neutron counter at $F$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
n &=\frac{2 q}{2 \pi}=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{S m c^{2}}{\pi \hbar c^{2}}\right)^{2} g \lambda \sin 2 \theta \\
&=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{4 \times 939}{\pi \times 1.97 \times 10^{-11} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}\right)^{2} \times 980 \times 1.45 \times 10^{-8} \times \sin 45^{\circ} \\
&=30 .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{2}

Consider the Dirac equation in one dimension

$$
H \psi=i \hbar \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t},
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
&H=c \alpha p_{z}+\beta m c^{2}+V(z)=c \alpha\left(-i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\right)+\beta m c^{2}+V(z) \\
&\alpha=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & \sigma_{3} \\
\sigma_{3} & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{3}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right), \quad \beta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
I & 0 \\
0 & -I
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$I$ being the $2 \times 2$ unit matrix.

(a) Show that $\sigma=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\sigma_{3} & 0 \\ 0 & \sigma_{3}\end{array}\right)$ commutes with $H$ (b) Use the results of (a) to show that the one-dimensional Dirac equation can be written as two coupled first order differential equations.

(Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{[\sigma, \alpha]=\left[\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sigma_{3} & 0 \\
0 & \sigma_{3}
\end{array}\right),\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & \sigma_{3} \\
\sigma_{3} & 0
\end{array}\right)\right]=0} \\
&{[\sigma, \beta]=\left[\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sigma_{3} & 0 \\
0 & \sigma_{3}
\end{array}\right),\left(\begin{array}{cc}
I & 0 \\
0 & -I
\end{array}\right)\right]=0}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
[\sigma, H]=\left[\sigma, c \alpha p_{z}+\beta m c^{2}+V\right]=c[\sigma, \alpha] p_{z}+[\sigma, \beta] m c^{2}=0
$$

(b) As $[\sigma, H]=0, \sigma$ and $H$ have common eigenfunctions. $\sigma$ is a diagonal matrix. Let its eigenfunction be $\left(\begin{array}{c}\psi_{1} \\ \psi_{2} \\ \psi_{3} \\ \psi_{4}\end{array}\right)$. As

$$
\sigma\left(\begin{array}{c}
\psi_{1} \\
\psi_{2} \\
\psi_{3} \\
\psi_{4}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\psi_{1} \\
-\psi_{2} \\
\psi_{3} \\
-\psi_{4}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\psi_{1} \\
0 \\
\psi_{3} \\
0
\end{array}\right)-\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\psi_{2} \\
0 \\
\psi_{4}
\end{array}\right),
$$

$\sigma$ has eigenfunctions $\left(\begin{array}{c}\psi_{1} \\ 0 \\ \psi_{3} \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\begin{array}{c}0 \\ \psi_{2} \\ 0 \\ \psi_{4}\end{array}\right)$ with eigenvalues $+1$ and $-1$ respectively.

Substituting these in the Dirac equation, we obtain

$$
\left(-i \hbar c \frac{\partial}{\partial z}+V\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\psi_{3} \\
0 \\
\psi_{1} \\
0
\end{array}\right)+m c^{2}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\psi_{1} \\
0 \\
-\psi_{3} \\
0
\end{array}\right)=i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\psi_{1} \\
0 \\
\psi_{3} \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$



$$
\left(-i \hbar c \frac{\partial}{\partial z}+V\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
-\psi_{4} \\
0 \\
-\psi_{2}
\end{array}\right)+m c^{2}\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\psi_{2} \\
0 \\
-\psi_{4}
\end{array}\right)=i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\psi_{2} \\
0 \\
\psi_{4}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Each of these represents two coupled differential equations. However, the two sets of equations become identical if we let $\psi_{3} \rightarrow-\psi_{4}, \psi_{1} \rightarrow \psi_{2}$. Thus the one-dimensional Dirac equation can be written as two coupled first order differential equations.

\section{3}

(a) Write down the Dirac equation in Hamiltonian form for a free particle, and give explicit forms for the Dirac matrices.

(b) Show that the Hamiltonian $H$ commutes with the operator $\sigma \cdot \mathbf{P}$ where $\mathbf{P}$ is the momentum operator and $\sigma$ is the Pauli spin operator in the space of four component spinors.

(c) Find plane wave solutions of the Dirac equation in the representation in which $\sigma \cdot \mathbf{P}$ is diagonal. Here $\mathbf{P}$ is the eigenvalue of the momentum operator.

(Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a)

$$
\bar{H}=c \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \mathbf{P}+\beta m c^{2}=c \alpha \cdot(-i \hbar \nabla)+\beta m c^{2},
$$

where

$$
\alpha=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & \sigma \\
\sigma & 0
\end{array}\right), \beta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)
$$

are the Dirac matrices.

(b) Write

$$
\boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \mathbf{P}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & \sigma \\
\sigma & 0
\end{array}\right) \cdot \mathbf{P}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & \sigma \cdot \mathbf{P} \\
\sigma \cdot \mathbf{P} & 0
\end{array}\right)
$$

As

$$
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{P}=\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{P} 1=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{P} & 0 \\
0 & \sigma \cdot \mathbf{P}
\end{array}\right)
$$



$$
\begin{aligned}
{[\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{P}, H]=} & {\left[\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sigma \cdot \mathbf{P} & 0 \\
0 & \sigma \cdot \mathbf{P}
\end{array}\right), c\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & \sigma \cdot \mathbf{P} \\
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{P} & 0
\end{array}\right)+m c^{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\mathbf{1} & 0 \\
0 & -\mathbf{1}
\end{array}\right)\right] } \\
=& c\left[\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sigma \cdot \mathbf{P} & 0 \\
0 & \sigma \cdot \mathbf{P}
\end{array}\right),\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & \sigma \cdot \mathbf{P} \\
\sigma \cdot \mathbf{P} & 0
\end{array}\right)\right] \\
&+m c^{2}\left[\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sigma \cdot \mathbf{P} & 0 \\
0 & \sigma \cdot \mathbf{P}
\end{array}\right),\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\right]=0+0=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Let $\mathbf{P}$ be along the $z$ direction. Then as $\sigma_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1\end{array}\right)$, we have

$$
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{P}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sigma_{z} & 0 \\
0 & \sigma_{z}
\end{array}\right) P_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
1 & & & \\
& -1 & & \\
& & 1 & \\
& & & -1
\end{array}\right) P_{z}
$$

where the unspecfied elements are all zeros, which is diagonal. Then as shown in Problem 8032 the plane wave solutions of the Dirac equation in this representation are $\left(\begin{array}{c}\alpha \\ 0 \\ \gamma \\ 0\end{array}\right) e^{i P_{z} z / \hbar}$ and $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ \beta \\ 0 \\ \delta\end{array}\right) e^{i P_{z} z / \hbar}$, where $\alpha$ and $\gamma, \beta$ and $\delta$ take two sets of different values. Substituting the eigenfunctions in the Schrödinger equation

$$
\hat{H} \psi=i \hbar \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t}=E \psi
$$

we have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
c P_{z} \gamma+m c^{2} \alpha=E \alpha \\
c P_{z} \alpha-m c^{2} \gamma=E \gamma
\end{array}\right.
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\pm} &=\pm \sqrt{m^{2} c^{4}+P_{z}^{2} c^{2}}, \\
\psi &=\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
0 \\
\frac{E_{\pm}-m c^{2}}{c P_{z}} \\
0
\end{array}\right) e^{i\left(P_{z} z-E_{\pm} t\right) / \hbar} ;
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
-c P_{z} \delta+m c^{2} \beta=E \beta \\
-c P_{z} \beta-m c^{2} \delta=E \delta
\end{array}\right.
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\pm} &=\pm \sqrt{m^{2} c^{4}+P_{z}^{2} c^{2}} \\
\psi &=\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
1 \\
0 \\
\frac{m c^{2}-E_{\pm}}{c P_{z}}
\end{array}\right) e^{i\left(P_{z} z-E_{\pm} t\right) / \hbar}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{4}

Consider a free real scalar field $\phi\left(x_{\mu}\right)$, where $x_{\mu}=x, y, z$ for $\mu=1,2,3$ and $x_{4}=i c t$, satisfying the Klein-Gordon equation.

(a) Write down the Lagrangian density for the system.

(b) Using Euler's equations of motion, verify that $\phi$ does satisfy the Klein-Gordon equation.

(c) Derive the Hamiltonian density for the system. Write down Hamilton's equations and show that they are consistent with the equation derived in (b)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The Lagrangian density is

$$
\mathcal{L}(x)=-\frac{1}{2} \partial_{\mu} \phi(\mathbf{x}) \partial_{\mu} \phi(\mathbf{x})-\frac{m^{2}}{2} \phi(\mathbf{x}) \phi(\mathbf{x})
$$

(b) Using the above expression for $\mathcal{L}$ in Euler's equations of motion

$$
\partial_{\mu}\left[\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}(x)}{\partial\left(\partial_{\mu} \phi\right)}\right]-\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{x})}{\partial \phi(\mathbf{x})}=0
$$

we obtain

$$
\partial_{\mu} \partial_{\mu} \phi(\mathbf{x})-m^{2} \phi(\mathbf{x})=0,
$$

which is just the Klein-Gordon equation. (c) The Hamiltonian density of the system is

$$
\mathcal{H}(x)=\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial\left(\partial_{\mu} \phi\right)} \partial_{\mu} \phi-\mathcal{L}=-\frac{1}{2} \partial_{\mu} \phi \partial_{\mu} \phi+\frac{m^{2}}{2} \phi^{2}
$$

Hamilton's canonical equations

$$
\frac{\partial \mathcal{H}}{\partial \phi}=-\partial_{\mu} P_{\mu}, \quad \frac{\partial \mathcal{H}}{\partial P_{\mu}}=-\partial_{\mu} \phi
$$

where

$$
P_{\mu}=\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial\left(\partial_{\mu} \phi\right)}=-\partial_{\mu} \phi
$$

then give

$$
-\partial_{\mu} P_{\mu}=m^{2} \phi
$$

i.e.,

$$
\partial_{\mu} \partial_{\mu} \phi-m^{2} \phi=0
$$

same as obtained in (b).

\section{5}

It can be shown that the probability for an on-shell charged particle with initial momentum $P$ to emit a virtual photon with momentum $q$ is proportional to the covariant tensor

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=A g_{\mu \nu}+B P_{\mu} P_{\nu}+C q_{\mu} q_{\nu}+D\left(q_{\mu} P_{\nu}+P_{\mu} q_{\nu}\right)
$$

where $A, B, C$ and $D$ are real Lorentz-invariant scalar functions of $q^{2}, q \cdot P$ and $P^{2}=m^{2}$.

(a) Use current conservation to show that $W_{\mu \nu}$ has the form

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=W_{1}\left(g_{\mu \nu}-\frac{q_{\mu} q_{\nu}}{q^{2}}\right)+W_{2}\left(P_{\mu}-q_{\mu} \frac{q \cdot P}{q^{2}}\right) \cdot\left(P_{\nu}-q_{\nu} \frac{q \cdot P}{q^{2}}\right)
$$

i.e., only two of $A, B, C$ and $D$ are independent. (b) Compute $W_{1}$ and $W_{2}$ for a Dirac particle of mass $m$ for which

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=\operatorname{Tr}\left[(P-\not q+m) \gamma_{\mu}(\mathbb{P}+m) \gamma_{\nu}\right] .
$$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Current conservation requires $q^{\mu} W_{\mu \nu}=0$, i.e.,

$$
A q_{\nu}+B(q \cdot P) P_{\nu}+C q^{2} q_{\nu}+D\left[q^{2} P_{\nu}+(q \cdot P) q_{\nu}\right]=0
$$

where $q \cdot P=q^{\mu} P_{\mu}, q_{\nu}=q^{\mu} g_{\mu \nu}$, etc. As $P_{\nu}, q_{\nu}$ are independent and $q^{2} \neq 0$, this gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
A+C q^{2}+D(q \cdot P) &=0 \\
B(q \cdot P)+D q^{2} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving for $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{D}$ and writing $A=W_{1}, B=W_{2}$, we have

$$
D=-W_{2} \frac{(q \cdot P)}{q^{2}}, \quad C=-\frac{W_{1}}{q^{2}}+\frac{W_{2}(q \cdot P)^{2}}{q^{4}} .
$$

\section{Hence}

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=W_{1}\left(g_{\mu \nu}-\frac{q_{\mu} q_{\nu}}{q^{2}}\right)+W_{2}\left(P_{\mu}-q_{\mu} \frac{q \cdot P}{q^{2}}\right) \cdot\left(P_{\nu}-q_{\nu} \frac{q \cdot P}{q^{2}}\right) .
$$

(b) We are given

$$
\begin{aligned}
W_{\mu \nu}=& \operatorname{Tr}\left[(\mathbb{P}-\not q+m) \gamma_{\mu}(\mathbb{P}+m) \gamma_{\nu}\right] \\
=& \operatorname{Tr}\left[\boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}+\boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}-\not q \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}\right.\\
&\left.-\not q \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}+m \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}+m \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $P=P_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha}, \not q=q_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha}$. The Dirac matrices satisfy the anticommutation relation

$$
\left\{\gamma^{\mu}, \gamma^{\nu}\right\} \equiv \gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu}+\gamma^{\nu} \gamma^{\mu}=2 g^{\mu \nu}
$$

and so

$$
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu}\right)=4 g^{\mu \nu}
$$



$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu_{1}} \gamma^{\mu_{2}} \cdots \gamma^{\mu_{n}}\right)=0 \text { for } n=\text { odd } \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu} \gamma^{\lambda} \gamma^{\sigma}\right)=4\left(g^{\mu \nu} g^{\lambda \sigma}-g^{\mu \lambda} g^{\nu \sigma}+g^{\mu \sigma} g^{\nu \lambda}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence in $W_{\mu \nu}$ the terms involving an odd number of $\gamma$ vanish. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\mathbb{P} \gamma_{\mu} P \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=\operatorname{Tr}\left(P_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} \gamma^{\lambda} P_{\beta} \gamma^{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma} \gamma^{\sigma}\right) \\
&=P_{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} P_{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\alpha} \gamma^{\lambda} \gamma^{\beta} \gamma^{\sigma}\right) \\
&=4 P_{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} P_{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma}\left(g^{\alpha \lambda} g^{\beta \sigma}-g^{\alpha \beta} g^{\lambda \sigma}+g^{\alpha \sigma} g^{\lambda \beta}\right) \\
&=4\left(P_{\alpha} \delta_{\mu}^{\alpha} P_{\beta} \delta_{\nu}^{\beta}-P^{\beta} P_{\beta} \delta_{\mu}^{\sigma} g_{\nu \sigma}+P_{\alpha} g_{\nu}^{\alpha} P_{\beta} \delta_{\mu}^{\beta}\right) \\
&=4\left(P_{\mu} P_{\nu}-P^{2} g_{\mu \nu}+P_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right) \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(q \gamma_{\mu} P \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=4\left(h_{\mu} P_{\nu}-\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P} g_{\mu \nu}+g_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right) \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(m^{2} \gamma_{\mu} \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} g_{\nu \beta} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\alpha} \gamma^{\beta}\right) \\
&=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} g_{\nu \beta} g^{\alpha \beta}=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} \delta_{\nu}^{\alpha}=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \nu}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, as for an on-shell particle $P^{2} \approx m^{2}$, we have

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=4 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P} g_{\mu \nu}+8 P_{\mu} P_{\nu}-4\left(q_{\mu} P_{\nu}+q_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right)
$$

A comparison with the given expression for $W \mu \nu$ we find

$$
W_{1}=4 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P}, \quad W_{2}=8 .
$$

Note that for an on-shell charge emitting a virtual photon, initially $P^{2}=$ $m^{2}$, and finally $(\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{q})^{2}=P^{2}-2 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P}+q^{2}=m^{2}$, and so the two expressions for $W_{\mu \nu}$ are consistent.

\section{6}

In order to account for the anomalous magnetic moments of particles, the Dirac equation given below can be used:

$$
\left(i \nabla-e A+K \frac{e}{4 m} \sigma_{\mu \nu} F^{\mu \nu}-m\right) \psi(x)=0 .
$$

Here $e$ and $m$ are the charge and mass of the particle, $K$ is a dimensionless parameter, $A^{\mu}(x)$ is the four-dimensional potential and $F^{\mu \nu}$ is the electromagnetic field tensor, i.e.

$$
F^{\mu \nu}=\frac{\partial A^{\mu}}{\partial x_{\nu}}-\frac{\partial A^{\nu}}{\partial x_{\mu}}, \quad \sigma_{\mu \nu}=\frac{i}{2}\left[\gamma_{\mu}, \gamma_{\nu}\right]
$$

where $\gamma_{\mu}$ is a Dirac matrix, $\gamma_{0}=\gamma^{0}=\beta, \gamma^{i}=-\gamma_{i}=\beta \alpha^{i}, i=1,2,3$. have

(a) It is well known that the above equation is covariant if $K=0$. We

$$
\psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}\right)=S \psi(x),
$$

where $x^{\prime \mu}=a_{\nu}^{\mu} x^{\nu}$ and $a_{\nu}^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu}=S^{-1} \gamma^{\mu} S$. Show that if $K \neq 0$, the equation is still covariant.

(b) Write the equation in the Hamiltonian form and show that the additional interaction does not destroy the Hermiticity of the original Hamiltonian.

(Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As

$$
S^{-1} \gamma_{\mu} S=a_{\mu}^{\nu} \gamma_{\nu}
$$

and $a_{\mu}^{\nu}$ commutes with $S$ and $\gamma$, we have

$$
S^{-1} \gamma_{\mu} S a_{\alpha}^{\mu}=a_{\mu}^{\nu} a_{\alpha}^{\mu} \gamma_{\nu}=\delta_{\alpha}^{\nu} \gamma_{\nu}=\gamma_{\alpha}
$$

Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{\alpha \beta}^{\prime} F^{\prime \alpha \beta} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}\right) &=\frac{i}{2}\left(\gamma_{\alpha} \gamma_{\beta}-\gamma_{\beta} \gamma_{\alpha}\right) a_{\mu}^{\alpha} a_{\nu}^{\beta} F^{\mu \nu} S \psi^{\prime}(x) \\
&=\frac{i}{2}\left(S S^{-1} \gamma_{\alpha} S S^{-1} \gamma_{\beta}-S S^{-1} \gamma_{\beta} S S^{-1} \gamma_{\alpha}\right) a_{\mu}^{\alpha} a_{\nu}^{\beta} F^{\mu \nu} S \psi \\
&=S \frac{i}{2}\left(S^{-1} \gamma_{\alpha} S a_{\mu}^{\alpha} S^{-1} \gamma_{\beta} S a_{\nu}^{\beta}-S^{-1} \gamma_{\beta} S a_{\nu}^{\beta} S^{-1} \gamma_{\alpha} S a_{\mu}^{\alpha}\right) F^{\mu \nu} \psi \\
&=S \frac{i}{2}\left(\gamma_{\mu} \gamma_{\nu}-\gamma_{\nu} \gamma_{\mu}\right) F^{\mu \nu} \psi \\
&=S \sigma_{\mu \nu} F^{\mu \nu} \psi .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
S^{-1} \sigma_{\alpha \beta}^{\prime} F^{\alpha \beta} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}\right)=\sigma_{\mu \nu} F^{\mu \nu} \psi(x) .
$$

Then as $\psi(x)=S^{-1} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ and $\nabla$ and $A$ are invariant, under transformation the Dirac equation becomes

$$
S^{-1}\left(i \not-e A+\frac{K e}{4 m} \sigma_{\alpha \beta}^{\prime} F^{\prime \alpha \beta}+m\right) \psi^{\prime}(x)=0
$$

i.e. the equation is covariant.

(b) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla &=\gamma_{\alpha} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{\alpha}}=\beta \frac{\partial}{\partial t}+\gamma \cdot \nabla \\
A &=\gamma_{\alpha} A^{\alpha}=\beta A^{\circ}+\gamma_{j} A^{j}=\beta A^{\circ}+\gamma_{j} g_{j i} A^{i} \\
&=\beta A^{\circ}-\gamma \cdot \mathbf{A},
\end{aligned}
$$

the Dirac equation can be written as

$$
i \beta \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi=\left(-i \boldsymbol{\gamma} \cdot \nabla+e \beta A^{\circ}-e \boldsymbol{\gamma} \cdot \mathbf{A}-K \frac{e}{4 m} \sigma_{\mu \nu} F^{\mu \nu}+m\right) \psi
$$

Note that we have used units such that $\hbar=c=1$.

Mutiplying both sides by $\beta$ from the left, as $\beta^{2}=1, \beta \gamma_{i}=\beta^{2} \alpha_{i}=\alpha_{i}$, we have the equation in the Hamiltonian form:

$$
i \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t}=H \psi
$$

where

$$
H=-i \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \nabla+e A^{0}-e \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \mathbf{A}-K \frac{e}{4 m} \beta \sigma_{\mu \nu} F^{\mu \nu}+m \beta
$$

with

$$
\alpha=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & \sigma \\
\sigma & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \beta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
I & 0 \\
0 & -I
\end{array}\right)
$$

$\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}, \sigma_{3}$ being Pauli's matrices and $I$ the unit matrix. By definition

$$
\left\{\sigma_{i}, \sigma_{j}\right\}=\sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}+\sigma_{j} \sigma_{i}=2 I \delta_{i j}
$$



$$
(i, j=1,2,3)
$$

It follows that

$$
\left\{\alpha_{i}, \alpha_{j}\right\}=2 I \delta_{i j},\left\{\beta, \alpha_{i}\right\}=0,
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\{\gamma_{i}, \gamma_{j}\right\} &=2 g_{i j} \\
\left\{\beta, \gamma_{i}\right\} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\beta, \sigma_{i j}\right] } &=\left[\beta, \frac{i}{2}\left(\gamma_{i} \gamma_{j}-\gamma_{j} \gamma_{i}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{i}{2}\left(\beta \gamma_{i} \gamma_{j}-\beta \gamma_{j} \gamma_{i}-\gamma_{i} \gamma_{j} \beta+\gamma_{j} \gamma_{i} \beta\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\gamma_{i} \gamma_{j} \beta=-\gamma_{i} \beta \gamma_{j}=\beta \gamma_{i} \gamma_{j}$, etc, and similarly,

$$
\left\{\beta, \sigma_{0 i}\right\}=\frac{i}{2}\left(\beta\left[\beta, \gamma_{i}\right]+\left[\beta, \gamma_{i}\right] \beta\right)=0 \text {. }
$$

Since by definition $\sigma_{i}$ and $\beta$ are Hermitian, $\gamma_{0}=\beta$ is Hermitian and $\gamma_{i}=$ $\beta \alpha_{i}$ is anti-Hermitian. It follows that $\sigma_{i j}$ is Hermitian and $\sigma_{0 i}, \sigma_{i 0}$ are anti-Hermitian. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{\mu \nu}^{+} \beta^{+} &=\sigma_{i j}^{+} \beta^{+}+\sigma_{i 0}^{+} \beta^{+}+\sigma_{0 i}^{+} \beta^{+}=\sigma_{i j} \beta-\sigma_{i 0} \beta-\sigma_{0 i} \beta \\
&=\beta \sigma_{i j}+\beta \sigma_{i 0}+\beta \sigma_{0 i}=\beta \sigma_{\mu \nu}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the Hermitian conjugate of the additional interaction term is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(-K \frac{e}{4 m} \beta \sigma_{\mu \nu} F^{\mu \nu}\right)^{+} &=-K^{*} \frac{e^{*}}{4 m^{*}} \sigma_{\mu \nu}^{+} \beta^{+} F^{\mu \nu^{*}} \\
&=-K \frac{e}{4 m} \beta \sigma_{\mu \nu} F^{\mu \nu}
\end{aligned}
$$

noting that $K, e, m$ and $F^{\mu \nu}$ are real numbers. Therefore the additional interaction is Hermitian, and it does not destroy the Hermiticity of the original Hamiltonian.

\section{7}

Proton and neutron may be regarded as two "isospin" states of a single particle, the nucleon. Denote proton by $|+\rangle$ and neutron by $|-\rangle$ and define the following operators: 

$$
t_{3}|\pm\rangle=\pm \frac{1}{2}|\pm\rangle, t_{\pm}|\mp\rangle=|\pm\rangle, t_{\mp}|\mp\rangle=0 .
$$

The operators $t_{1}=\frac{1}{2}\left(t_{+}+t_{-}\right), t_{2}=-\frac{i}{2}\left(t_{+}-t_{-}\right)$, and $t_{3}$ can be represented by one-half times the $2 \times 2$ Pauli matrices. Together they form a vector $t$ in isospin space.

In a simple model the Hamiltonian for a system of $N$ nucleons all in the same spatial state is the sum of three terms:

$$
H=N E_{0}+C_{1} \sum_{i>j} \mathrm{t}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{t}_{j}+C_{2} Q^{2}
$$

where $E_{0}, C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ are positive constants with $C_{1}>C_{2}, \mathbf{t}_{j}$ is the isospin of the $i$-th nucleon, and $Q$ is the total electric charge in units of $e$. The sum is over all pairs of nucleons.

(a) Show that $\sum_{i>j} \mathbf{t}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{t}_{j}=\frac{1}{2}\left[T(T+1)-\frac{3}{4} N\right]$, where $T$ is the "total isospin" quantum number of the system.

In the rest of this problem it is essential to remember that neutrons and protons are spin-1/2 particles obeying Fermi statistics.

(b) What are the energy eigenstates and eigenvalues of a 2-nucleon system? What is the total spin of each state?

(c) What are the energy eigenstates and eigenvalues of a 4-nucleon system?

(d) What are the energy eigenvalues of a 3-nucleon system?

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $\mathbf{T}^{2}=\left(\sum_{i} \mathbf{t}_{i}\right)^{2}$ has eigenvalue $T(T+1)$ and $\mathbf{t}_{i}^{2}$ has eigenvalue $\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{2}+1\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i>j} \mathbf{t}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{t}_{j} &=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N} \mathbf{t}_{i}\right)^{2}-\sum_{i=1}^{N} \mathbf{t}_{i}^{2}\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2}\left[T(T+1)-\frac{3}{4} N\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) A system of identical spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles must have an antisymmetric total wave function. Hence a system of two nucleons has the following possible structures: Configuration

\section{Isospin State}

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
(p p) & |+\rangle|+\rangle & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|\alpha\rangle|\beta\rangle-|\beta\rangle|\alpha\rangle \\
(n n) & |-\rangle|-\rangle & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|\alpha\rangle|\beta\rangle-|\beta\rangle|\alpha\rangle \\
(p n) & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|+\rangle|-\rangle+|-\rangle|+\rangle) & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|\alpha\rangle|\beta\rangle-|\beta\rangle|\alpha\rangle) \\
(p n) & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|+\rangle|-\rangle-|-\rangle|+\rangle) & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|\alpha\rangle|\beta\rangle+|\beta\rangle|\alpha\rangle) \\
& & |\alpha\rangle|\alpha\rangle, \text { or }|\beta\rangle|\beta\rangle
\end{array}
$$

The corresponding eigenvalues are as follows.

\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
\hline Configuration & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{S}$ & $\mathrm{Q}$ & $\mathrm{E}$ \\
\hline$(p p)$ & 1 & 0 & 2 & $C_{1}+4 C_{2}$ \\
$(n n)$ & 1 & 0 & 0 & $C_{1}$ \\
$(p n)$ & 1 & 0 & 1 & $C_{1}+C_{2}$ \\
$(p n)$ & 0 & 1 & 1 & $C_{2}$ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

In the above, $|\alpha\rangle,|\beta\rangle$ represent single-particle states with spin $+$ and spin - respectively, and $E$ is the energy above $\left(2 E_{0}-\frac{3}{4} C_{1}\right)$.

(c) On account of Paul's principle, there can at most be 2 protons and 2 neutrons, each pair of opposite spins, in a given energy state. For the ordered combination (pnpn) the spin states have four forms $(\alpha \alpha \beta \beta),(\beta \beta \alpha \alpha)$, $(\alpha \beta \beta \alpha),(\beta \alpha \alpha \beta)$. For other ordered combinations similar spin states apply. However, in this case the total wave function cannot be expressed as a simple product of the spin wave function and the isospin wave function. For the possible isospin values $T=2,1,0$, the corresponding energy values are

$$
\begin{gathered}
E=4 E_{0}+4 C_{2}+\frac{3}{2} C_{1}, \quad 4 E_{0}+4 C_{2}-\frac{1}{2} C_{1}, \\
4 E_{0}+4 C_{2}-\frac{3}{2} C_{1} .
\end{gathered}
$$

But as the spatial wave functions of the four nucleons are the same and there are only two spin states for a nucleon, Pauli's principle requires the system's total isospin to be 0 and its energy state can only be the eigenstate 

$$
\psi(1,2,3,4)=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
|+\rangle_{1} \alpha_{1} & |+\rangle_{1} \beta_{1} & |-\rangle_{1} \alpha_{1} & |-\rangle_{1} \beta_{1} \\
|+\rangle_{2} \alpha_{2} & |+\rangle_{2} \beta_{2} & |-\rangle_{2} \alpha_{2} & |-\rangle_{2} \beta_{2} \\
|+\rangle_{3} \alpha_{3} & |+\rangle_{3} \beta_{3} & |-\rangle_{3} \alpha_{3} & |-\rangle_{3} \beta_{3} \\
|+\rangle_{4} \alpha_{4} & |+\rangle_{4} \beta_{4} & |-\rangle_{4} \alpha_{4} & |-\rangle_{4} \beta_{4}
\end{array}\right) .
$$

(d) The configurations for a three-nucleon system are (ppn) or (nnp), and the isospin can be $\frac{3}{2}$ or $\frac{1}{2}$

For (ppn):

$$
E=3 E_{0}+4 C_{2} \pm \frac{3}{4} C_{1},
$$

for $(n n p)$ :

$$
E=3 E_{0}+C_{2} \pm \frac{3}{4} C_{1}
$$

\section{8}

A molecule in the form of an equilateral triangle can capture an extra electron. To a good approximation, this electron can go into one of three orthogonal states $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ localized near the corners of the triangle. To a better approximation, the energy eigenstates of the electron are linear combinations of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ determined by an effective Hamiltonian which has equal expectation values for $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ and equal matrix elements $V_{0}$ between each pair of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$.

(a) What does the symmetry under a rotation through $2 \pi / 3$ imply about the coefficients of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ in the eigenstates of the effective Hamiltonian? There is also symmetry under interchange of $B$ and $C$; what additional information does this give about the eigenvalues of the effective Hamiltonian?

(b) At time $t=0$ an electron is captured into the state $\psi_{A}$. Find the probability that it is in $\psi_{A}$ at time $t$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Under the rotation through $2 \pi / 3$, we have

$$
R \psi_{A}=a \psi_{B}, R \psi_{B}=a \psi_{C}, R \psi_{C}=a \psi_{A} .
$$

Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&R^{2} \psi_{A}=a R \psi_{B}=a^{2} \psi_{C}, \\
&R^{3} \psi_{A}=a^{2} R \psi_{C}=a^{3} \psi_{A},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $a^{3}=1$ and hence

$$
a=1, e^{\frac{i 2 \pi}{3}} \text { and } e^{\frac{i 4 \pi}{3}} .
$$

Suppose the eigenstate of the effective Hamiltonian is

$$
\psi=a_{1} \psi_{A}+a_{2} \psi_{B}+a_{3} \psi_{C} .
$$

Symmetry under the rotation through $\frac{2 \pi}{3}$ means that $R \psi=\psi$, i.e.

$$
a_{1} a \psi_{B}+a_{2} a \psi_{C}+a_{3} a \psi_{A}=a_{1} \psi_{A}+a_{2} \psi_{B}+a_{3} \psi_{C} .
$$

Then the orthogonality of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ requires

$$
a_{1} a=a_{2}, a_{2} a=a_{3}, a_{3} a=a_{1} .
$$

For $a=1$ letting $a_{1}=1$, for $a=\exp \left(i \frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)$ letting $a_{1}=1$, and for $a=$ $\exp \left(i \frac{4 \pi}{3}\right)$ letting $a_{2}=1$, we have the three combinations

$$
\psi^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(2)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
e^{i 2 \pi / 3} \\
e^{i 4 \pi / 3}
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(3)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i 4 \pi / 3} \\
1 \\
e^{i 4 \pi / 3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Let the equal expectation values of $H$ for the eigenstates $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ be zero, then the effective Hamiltonian can be represented by the matrix

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & V & V \\
V & 0 & V \\
V & V & 0
\end{array}\right) .
$$

As $H \psi^{(1)}=2 V \psi^{(1)}, H \psi^{(2)}=-V \psi^{(2)}, H \psi^{(3)}=-V \psi^{(3)}$, the energies corresponding to $\psi^{(1)}, \psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$ are $2 V,-V,-V$ repectively.

There is symmetry in the interchange of $B$ and $C$. Denote by $P$ the operator for the interchange of the two atoms. As $P$ does not commute with $R$, it cannot be represented by a diagonal matrix on the basis of $\psi^{(1)}, \psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$. However, $\psi^{(1)}$ is an eigenstate of $P$ and $\psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$ are degenerate states, though not eigenstates, of $P$. So $P$ imposes no condition on the eigenvalues of $H$.

(b) At $t=0$, we can expand the wave function $\psi_{A}$ as

$$
\psi_{A}(0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[\psi^{(1)}+\psi^{(2)}+e^{-i 2 \pi / 3} \psi^{(3)}\right]
$$

At a later time $t$ we have

$$
\psi_{A}(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[e^{-i 2 V t / \hbar} \psi^{(1)}+e^{+i V t / \hbar} \psi^{(2)}+e^{-i 2 \pi / 3} e^{+i V t / \hbar} \psi^{(3)}\right] .
$$

Hence the probability of an electron, initially in state $\psi_{A}$, being in state $\psi_{A}$ at time $t$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\left\langle\psi_{A}(t) \mid \psi_{A}(0)\right\rangle\right|^{2} &=\left|\frac{1}{3}\left(e^{i 2 V t / \hbar}+e^{-i V t / \hbar}+e^{i 2 \pi / 3} e^{-i V t / \hbar} e^{-i 2 \pi / 3}\right)\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{9}\left|e^{i 3 V t / \hbar}+2\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{9}\left(5+4 \cos \frac{3 V t}{\hbar}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{9}

The energy of a molecule is the sum of the kinetic energies of the electrons and of the nuclei and of the various Coulomb energies. Suppose that for a particular many-particle normalized wave function $\psi\left(\mathbf{x}_{1}, \ldots, \mathbf{x}_{N}\right)$, the expectation value of the kinetic energy is $T$ and of the potential energy is $-U(U>0)$

(a) Find a variational estimate of the ground state energy using a wave function $\lambda^{3 N / 2} \psi\left(\lambda \mathbf{x}_{1}, \ldots, \lambda \mathbf{x}_{N}\right)$ where $\lambda$ is a parameter.

(b) Suppose $\psi$ is the true ground state wave function and that the true ground state energy is $-B(B>0)$. What are the true values of $T$ and $U$ ?

\section{Solution:}

(a) The mean kinetic energy $T$ of the system is given by the sum of terms like

$$
